Growing his banking operations in Asia, targeting Vietnam and China. Bought 2% stake in Italian insurance giant Generali, which purchased majority stake in his CZIH insurance company in 2008. Stake in Russian silver miner Polymetal up 80% since last year. Got his start selling office supplies, then borrowed $1 million against that business and started an investment fund; used it to buy a controlling stake in Czech insurer during its privatization. Built media holdings that he later sold to U.S. billionaire Ronald Lauder for $580 million net profit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leonid Mikhelson, the head of Russia's largest independent gas producer Novatek, negotiated a deal to buy a 25% stake in Sibur Holding petrochemical company from Gazprombank. He and Novatek shareholder, and co-founder of energy trader Gunvor International, Gennady Timchenko, also agreed to take a two-year option to buy 9.4% of Novatek from Gazprombank. Together the pair already own more than 50% in the natural gas producer. In 1987, Mikhelson inherited management of expansive Soviet enterprise that built pipelines, roads and industrial facilities. Four years later he reorganized the company and began gathering up oil and gas production licenses, even accepting them as payment for construction work in order to build Novatek. In 2006 Gazprom bought nearly 20% of Novatek from Mikhelson and his partners, a deal widely seen as a way for the firm to ensure its survival. At that time, Mikhelson got $1 billion for part of his stake and was able to remain chairman. He is also a prolific art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Petroleum magnate's fortune has increased by more than $2 billion in last six months; shares of his Continental Resources up 50%. Youngest of 13 children grew up in one-bedroom Oklahoma house; parents were sharecroppers. First job: pumping gas. Bought truck in 1965; founded Harold Hamm Tank Truck Service the next year. Became one of top Oklahoman oilfield fluid transporters. Founded Continental Resources, oil and gas exploration, production company, in 1967; public 2007. Took gas processing firms Hiland Partners and Hiland Holdings private in 2009. Committed to curing diabetes through Harold Hamm Oklahoma Diabetes Center.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Continental Resources', 'uri': 'companies/continental-resources', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheng is the founder of New World Development, one of Hong Kong's largest conglomerates, with interests in real estate, infrastructure and hotels. One of the businesses behind the rise in his wealth this year: retail. Unlisted jewelry retailer Chow Tai Fook has thrived on a spending boom by mainland shoppers at home and in Hong Kong. Cheng purchased stakes in shipbuilder China Rongsheng Heavy and Xinjiang Goldwind Science last year in connection with Hong Kong listings. Sons Henry and Peter, along with grandson Adrian, sit on New World's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Zyuzin stepped down as chief executive of coal company Mechel last summer but remains chairman. Its shares are up more than a third in the past year. Zyuzin started out with partner Vladimir Iorich in 1995, forming Uglemetkooperatsiya, a coal-trading company, which was among the first to buy up shares in coal mines and coal pits in the Kuzbass region. In 2001 the partners bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Metals Factory, which formed the basis of the Mechel group, now consisting of more than 20 plants and coals mines around the world. Three years later, its shares began trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Firm bought US coal miner, Bluestone Coal, for $425 million plus shares in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2005 jet-setting beer magnate swapped control of his Bavaria brewery for 15% of SABMiller, now worth $8 billion. Other holdings include stakes in Colombia's biggest TV broadcaster Caracol, packaging maker Biofilm and forestry outfit Refocosta. Born into a rich family with interests in breweries, took over management of its holdings in 1972 after his father retired. No longer involved in daily operations. Has homes in New York City, Paris. Also owns a private island, Baru,  off the Caribbean coast of Colombia. Close friend of Colombian author and Nobel laureate Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Son, Andres, appears in U.S. gossip columns with socialite wife, Vogue magazine editor Lauren Davis. His oldest son, Julio Mario, died in 2009 in New York, reportedly from cancer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anil Ambani continues to grab headlines nearly daily. He  was one of several telecom tycoons to be deposed before the Central Bureau of Investigation in connection with India's corruption  scandal over granting of telecom licences. His group denied any involvement or wrongdoing.  In January, the stockmarket regulator, which was reportedly investigating allegations that the group routed money raised overseas into the stock market, passed consent order that he, four other executives wouldn't invest in listed stocks in the secondary market for a year. In February, when shares of his companies crashed, he alleged foul play by a cartel of brokers, instigated by unnamed rivals.  A consortium of Chinese banks agreed to fund up to $12 billion of Chinese equipment purchases by his Reliance Power.  His entertainment arm recently tied up with Tom Hanks' Playtone for an online animated series. He and brother Mukesh, ranked no. 9 in the world, reportedly vacationed together with their families in a South African wildlife park after their patchup last May.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive construction tycoon rarely seen in public, chairs the 142-year old Shapoorji Pallonji Group which sons Shapoor and Cyrus run out of India. It has built The Imperial, two 60-story residential towers in Mumbai. Biggest asset is his 18.4% stake in Tata Sons, holding company of the $70 billion (revenues) Tata Group which owns Corus Steel in the U.K. and marquee brands such as Jaguar, Land Rover and Tetley tea. Its beverage arm is partnering Starbucks in India. Son-in-law Noel Tata considered as frontrunner to succeed  Tata group chairman Ratan Tata who is his step-brother, when he retires next year.

name: Billionaires
bio: In March the Apple founder made a surprise appearance at the unveiling of his iPad 2, after taking medical leave in January. Insanely creative Apple chief transforms a multibillion-dollar industry every few years. First, personal computers with Apple II, Macintosh; then film with Pixar; music (iTunes), mobile (iPhone). Now iPad is treated as messiah tablet, savior for publishing industry. Apple still sells computers, but twice as much revenue now comes from music distribution and hand-held devices. Shot past long-time rival Microsoft as world's most valuable tech company in May. Shares of Apple surged more than 80% over the last year. Still, the majority of Job's fortune comes from Disney; as largest shareholder he owns about $4.4 billion of stock. Reed College dropout founded Apple 1976.

name: Billionaires
bio: Samsung Group Chairman. Samsung Electronics, with sales of $118 billion and $94 billion in operating profit for 2009, became the world's largest memory chip and flat screen TV maker, beating out Siemens and HP. Samsung's share prices soared and so did Lee's wealth. Samsung Life Insurance, of which Lee owns 20%, is to be listed on the domestic stock market in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Internet and telecom firm SoftBank celebrated 30 year anniversary of the company. Owns one of Japan's three biggest wireless carriers, via 2006 acquisition of Vodafone Japan, and the only one with rights to sell the iPhone. Smartphone business booming; stock up 34% over the past year. Company also owns large stakes in Yahoo Japan, Chinese e-commerce site Alibaba.com as well as a 40% of China's largest social-networking service Renren, which is planning to IPO this year. Focused on succession plan: started a school,"Softbank Academia," to groom 300 executives from inside and outside the company; plans to hand over reigns in his 60s. Stated goal: Create Masayoshi Son 2.0.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2010 he restructured his assets in energy sector and became an owner of about 2% stake in state-owned RusHydro, the country's biggest renewable energy company. Started out with chain of currency-exchange booths; founded MDM Bank in 1993. Met fellow billionaire Sergey Popov and pair began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal producer. In 2006 the pair started splitting their business empire, Melnichenko kept Eurochem and a stake in SUEK. In 2009 increased his share in German fertilizer company K+S to 15%. Owns a $350-million megayacht, which resembles a submarine and which he named "A" after his wife Aleksandra Nikolic, a Serbian model.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cohen's hedge fund,  SAC Capital Advisors, is cooperating with investigators after two former employees were charged with insider trading in February. Launched firm in 1992 with $25 million, now manages $12 billion. Returned 15% net of fees in 2010. Charges some of the steepest fees in the business: 3% of assets and 35% of profits on most funds. Art collector, owns works by Willem de Kooning and Damien Hirst; recently bought 1958 "Flag" painting by Jasper Johns for which he reportedly paid $110 million. North Shore Long-Island Health System renamed its pediatric center after Cohen and his wife last year following a $50 million pledge.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of banker Wilhelm von Finck, founder of insurance giant Allianz and private bank Merck, Finck & Co.  Both entities were sold to Barclay's Bank in 1990.  From his tax-free hideaway in Switzerland oversees an investment portfolio that includes real estate, restaurants, hotels, breweries, a chemical manufacturer, an insurance group and a champagne maker.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hard-charging telecom tycoon, snatched the African unit of Kuwait's Zain for $9 billion. His flagship Bharti Airtel, now world's fifth largest telecom firm with 200 million customers in 19 countries. It paid a hefty $2.6 billion for a 3G mobile licence. His joint venture with WalMart runs cash-and-carry stores in North India. Other interests include food processing and insurance. He will be joining Unilever's board this May.Son Shravin joined Bharti's international unit in September, fuelling speculation about Mittal's succession plans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls the country's second largest broadcaster, TV Azteca.  Largest chunk of fortune lies with home electronics retailer Grupo Elektra, which has a finance arm that makes loans to customers. In mid 2010 took financially troubled Mexican wireless carrier Iusacell private; he owned 75%. His Fundacion Azteca foundation is active in promoting youth orchestras across Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and main shareholder of the Sany Group, founded in Hunan Province in 1989 as a small welding materials factory. Today, Liang ranks as China's second-richest person with wealth of $8 billion. He is one of four board members from the group, one of China's largest construction equipment manufacturers, to make this year's billionaires list. Others include Tang Xiuguo, Mao Zhongwu and Xiang Wenbo. Liang founded the business with Tang, Mao, and Yuan Jinhua in 1989. Liang graduated from Central South University, the same school as Tang. All are still active at Sany Group, which employs 53,000 people around the world and has sales that exceed $7 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers were born in Mumbai and raised in the U.K. Simon started out importing carpets and buying real estate; David in metals trading. Later joined together in Transworld, a metals trader that invested in Russia and Kazakhstan in the 1990s. Took proceeds and invested in UK real estate. Latest development in their London Paddington area rejuvenation: a proposed glass tower to dominate city skyline, nicknamed "The Cucumber." Datacenter business Global Switch has been given 2 investment grade ratings in advance of a debut bond offering in the first quarter of 2011; public offering set to follow. Expanding again in metals trading with Metalloyd Limited; recently acquired large stakes in mines in Africa and Asia. Both take active roles in the Reuben Foundation, which funds health care and educational causes; upcoming project in partnership with the Mayor of London and in association with New York's Mayor Bloomberg for disadvantaged areas of London. David lives in London in same house he has owned for past 20 years; Simon resides in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Murdoch's Fox News generated $700 million in operating profit in 2010, crushed the competition in ratings and may have put the Republicans over the top in the midterms. The Super Bowl, on Fox, kicked off with Bill O'Reilly interviewing the president and wound up as the most-watched TV broadcast ever. The circulation of the Wall Street Journal, already the biggest U.S. newspaper, keeps expanding while almost every other daily shrinks. Thanks to a close relationship with Apple, News Corp. became the first publisher to sell digital subscriptions on the iPad with the $30 million launch of The Daily in February. The $673 million purchase of daughter Elisabeth's production company in February furthered his dream of a Murdoch dynasty. Winning full control of British Sky Broadcasting UK in the face of political opposition would be an even bigger triumph. Australia-born tabloid titan inherited one newspaper at age 23.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'News Corp', 'uri': 'companies/news-corp', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio:
In 2010 he restructured his assets in the energy sector and became an owner of about a 2% stake in state-owned RusHydro, along with business partner and fellow billionaire Andrey Melnichenko.
Merged his MDM Bank with Siberian Ursa Bank in 2008; retains controlling stake. After sale of jointly-owned pipe producer TMK in fall of 2006, began divvying up assets with Melnichenko. Assets remaining in joint ownership: coal miner SUEK, which they plan to take public. Left university to sell pipes and copper cable in 1990s; Melnichenko was his banker. Pair began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Another year, another scandal for Italy's Prime Minister. This spring the media and banking billionaire will go to court on charges having sex with a minor and obstructing justice to secure her release from police custody. The allegations have incited protests against Berlusconi after years of accusations of "Bunga Bunga' sex parties, relationships with showgirls and using his power to promote pretty girls to positions within his government. The politician with 9 lives became Italy's prime minister for a third time in 2008 after his predecessor lost a confidence vote and new elections were held. He started out singing on cruise ships. Eventually built fortune through Fininvest, which now has interests in media, life insurance, movie production and soccer team A.C. Milan. Shares of his publicly-traded media company Mediaset have fallen 11% in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor in distressed companies, sold nearly all his Russian assets, including shares in Gazprom, government-owned Sberbank and a massive housing development in suburban Moscow prior to Russia's 2008 financial meltdown. The money allowed him to settle his debts and also to purchase stakes in a few European banks including Royal Bank of Scotland and Fortis as well as Russia's largest gold mining outfit, Polyus Gold. Has also invested in real estate company PIK. Most recently, in summer 2010, Kerimov together with fellow billionaires Alexander Nesis and Filaret Galchev bought Dmitry Rybolovlev's controlling stake in Uralkali, the biggest producer of potassium fertilizers in Russia. For repayment of his share he gave Rybolovlev a part of his stake in Polyus Gold. In autumn 2006 he was seriously injured in a car accident after losing control of a Ferrari Enzo on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice. Recovery was prolonged and painful. Reportedly owns three planes and two yachts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anschutz got his start in oil and gas, has made a habit of getting in and out of new plays early. In late 2010 sold $3 billion worth of Marcellus shale gas and Bakken shale oil fields. Where to deploy that cash? Anschutz' privately held AEG controls 120 entertainment venues worldwide, including iconic arenas like the Staples Center in L.A. and The O2 arena in London. It fills these arenas with much of its own in-house entertainment: sports teams like the L.A. Lakers and L.A. Kings and a stable of musicians including the Black Eyed Peas, Cher, Jon Bon Jovi and Justin Bieber.  Anschutz last year celebrated the completion of AEG's $2.5 billion L.A. Live complex, which adds a hotel, condos, restaurants and smaller theaters adjacent to Staples Center. The vision: expanding the complex even more by replacing L.A.'s outmoded convention center with a new NFL stadium. Anchutz's film group has also produced 33 films including the "Chronicles of Narnia" series and "Ray."  Entertainment is just the latest chapter for Anschutz. The son of an oil driller, he bought out his dad, went broke, and then struck oil in Utah and Wyoming. He parlayed the proceeds into railroads and then used the rights of way to lay fiberoptic cable, which he spun off into Qwest Communications. Despite selling $1.5 billion of Qwest shares before they nosedived, Anschutz was never implicated in an insider trading scandal that netted Qwest CEO Joe Nacchio. But can't win 'em all. In recent months he lost a big complicated tax case over whether or not he sold $375 million in oil company shares as part of a tax dodge a decade ago. I.R.S. wants at least $144 million. Anschutz will appeal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime chairman and largest stakeholder of Islamic-finance giant, the $45 billion (assets) Al Rajhi bank, which he helped found in 1957 with 3 brothers Saleh, Mohammed and Abdullah. Saleh passed away in February. Has begun transferring wealth to the next generation: sold down his Al Rajhi stake in July from 24.6% to 20% as part of a plan to shift shares to family members. Also holds variety of outside business interests, including stakes in cement, agricultural and logistics companies, a shrimp farm and one of the Kingdom's largest poultry processors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Added to his oil empire last year, picking up a 49% stake in indebted Russneft from the company's founder Mikhail Gutseriev for $100 million. Heads London-listed empire AFK Sistema (the System), sprawling operation with interests in some 200 companies ranging from microchips to toy stores. Former plastics engineer, co-founded Sistema in 1993. Early on, Sistema created a joint venture with Moscow's municipal telephone network (MTS) and later received a controlling stake in the network, along with its main assets, which included MTS (now one of the top-three mobile carriers in Russia, traded on the NYSE). Took Sistema public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: The pipeline prince saw his fortune surge thanks in part to a strong public offering of his Kinder Morgan in February; IPO raised nearly $3 billion. Quit as Enron president 1996; Kinder formed pipeline company with friend William Morgan. Earned bachelor and law degrees from the University of Missouri; served as an Army captain in Vietnam War.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kinder Morgan', 'uri': 'companies/kinder-morgan', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Quest to turn his discount clothing chain Fast Retailing into world's leading apparel retailer has stalled due to the yen's persistent strength and a shrinking domestic market. Stock price down 15% over the past year. Sticking to plan of opening approximately 300 stores a year to gain on larger competitors. Also planning to make English the company-wide language.Upped corporate philanthropy in partnership with microlender Grameen Bank to manufacture clothing in Bangladesh at prices affordable to the local population. Horse racing fan and horse owner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rental-car titan's fortune holding steady as Enterprise Rent-A-Car reduces debt and maintains strong  cash flow; demand for temporary rentals remains steady so long as people's cars break down. Left Washington University to join Navy; served as a fighter pilot on U.S.S. Enterprise during WWII. Became sales manager for St. Louis Cadillac distributor. Took 50% pay cut to start company (named after the aircraft carrier he served on) that provided replacement cars. Business took off 1970s when insurance companies were ordered by courts to pay for replacement rentals. Added Vanguard Automotive (National, Alamo) in 2007. Son Andrew is chief executive; daughter Jo Ann Taylor Kindle runs Enterprise Foundation.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start as head of a research lab before Soviet Union collapsed. In 1992 established a precursor to Evraz Holding; made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia. After 1998 Russian financial crisis, bought up hobbled steel companies and coal mines on the cheap. In 2006, partnered with fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich in Evraz. In 2007, made a number of acquisitions, including U.S. firms Claymont Steel Holdings of Delaware and Oregon Steel Mills. Elected chairman of steel giant Evraz in December 2008 replacing fellow billionaire Alexander Frolov with whom he cofounded the group; at the time the group was struggled with $10 billion debt burden. Net debt is now down to $7.2 billion as of year-end.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited 25% stake in Dutch brewer Heineken 9 years ago from her late father, Freddy Heineken. Company has more than 170 premium brands in more than 65 countries. Mother of 5, studied law at the University of Leiden. Enjoys photography, music and architecture.  She is also a member of St. Moritz's elite Corviglia Ski Club. A delegate member of Heineken's  board of directors; her husband, investment banker Michel de Carvalho, sits on the supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires German Khan and Mikhail Fridman, is the biggest financial and industrial group in Russia. Kuzmichev met his future partners in college. In 1991 they started Alfa Bank, which is now the biggest private bank by capital in Russia. The trio bought Tyumen Oil from the state in the late 1990s and merged it with BP's Russian assets into TNK-BP. The group also has stakes in two Russian cellular companies and owns the biggest retailer, X5. Kuzmichev heads the company called A1, which manages the assets Alfa Bank got from its debtors.

name: Billionaires
bio: With family controls Fidelity Investments, America's largest mutual fund company. Firm also boasts large brokerage business, insurance outfit. Ned joined father's company as analyst 1957, president 15 years later. Daughter Abby ran her first diversified fund 1993. Ned trimmed ownership 1995, Abby inherited 24% stake; rumored to have sold some shares back to family members years later. Ownership a mystery: family owns 49% of Fidelity, but size of individual stakes unknown. Abby runs personal and workplace investing division; believed by some to be father's chosen successor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of 114-year old Godrej Group, a consumer goods conglomerate, started by his granduncle. He bought out Sara Lee's 51% stake in itheir joint venture that makes household care products. . Planning to launch chocolate business with Hershey and its own brand of television sets. Property arm, where son Pirojsha works, went public. Planning new development on part of 3,500 acre Godrej estate in suburban Mumbai which remains family's private asset. Daughters Tanya and Nisa also work in the group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs DLF, India's most valuable real estate company, run by son Rajiv who is vice-chairman. Stock has fallen 20% in past year. Ditched plans to build a mall in Mumbai replacing it with a luxury residential project. Also building luxury holiday villas, branded Sama, at tourist hotspots. Hospitality arm owns Aman Resorts chain. DLF Pramerica, is its life insurance joint venture with Prudential International.  Granddaughters, Savitri and Anushka, both Wharton grads, have joined DLF.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retail tycoon Philip Green brought trendy British fashion to New York with clothing chain Topshop in 2009 with help from supermodel buddy Kate Moss. This year he will come ashore with a bigger splash: his joint venture with Simon Cowell, Greenwell Entertainment, launches its own reality talent show on America's Fox TV this fall. Ads for the U.S. version of Britain's super successful X-Factor have already started airing.  High school drop-out got his first break apprenticing with a London show importer. Bought his first store in London selling discounted designer brands at 27 and climbed up the retail ladder. Bought then-struggling Arcadia Group in 2002 for $1.2 billion. Group sales now total $4.4 billion. Shares fortune with wife Cristina through investment vehicle Taveta Investments. Was named International Retailer of the Year by the U.S. National Retail Federation in Jan. 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of satellite-TV service EchoStar, Ergen got his start as financial analyst at Frito-Lay. Tried his hand playing pro poker. He switched to selling TV satellites from a truck with wife in 1980s. Today Dish Network has more than 14 million subscribers and is the only pay-TV provider to offer local channels to consumers in every market nationwide. Partnered with Google in 2007, launched Google TV in May 2010; platform merges Internet capabilities and traditional TV programming. In July announced addition of 99 cent movies to lineup in effort to compete with Netflix and Redbox movie providers. Paid $104 million to TiVo in 2008 for patent infringement but continues to appeal and last May the case was granted a full-court review. Recently Dish in the news for buying $800 million of debt in bankrupt satellite operators DBSD and Terrestar, in hopes of swapping it for equity stakes.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'DISH Network', 'uri': 'companies/dish-network', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former military man turned financial whiz. While teaching in the Siberian city of Kogalym in the late 1980s, Fedun met Vagit Alekperov, who was the head of the local oil and gas company. In 1990s he helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed out of the best Russian oil properties. He now is Lukoil head Alekperov's right-hand man with a more than 9% stake in the company. Also oversees the investing activities of IFD Capital. Owns famous Moscow soccer club Spartak, on which he reportedly spends $70 million a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief Executive of Google oversaw 18% rise in company's stock over past year as it maintains a firm lock on the search market and digs deeper into the mobile arena by giving away its Android operating software to phone makers. In April will step down as Google CEO and serve as executive chairman; cofounder Larry Page will become CEO. Schmidt's venture fund, Tomorrow Ventures, has invested in social gaming and mobile giving startups. Teaches entrepreneurship at Stanford.  Flies his own Gulfstream 550 jet.  His outspoken comments on need to rethink privacy and trust on the Internet ("maybe you shouldn't be doing it") sometimes tie up Google PR. Electrical engineering degree from Princeton, Ph.D. from UC Berkeley. Began in software at Bell Labs, Xerox PARC, pre-IPO at Sun Microsystems in 1983. Rose to chief technology officer; led development of Java technology. CEO of Novell, then CEO of Google in 2001. On eve of Google's 2004 IPO, Schmidt, along with founders Page and Sergey Brin (both billionaires), made pact to stay 20 years.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded software giant SAS Institute with fellow NC State alum John Sall in 1976.  World's largest private software company saw 5% increase in revenues to $2.43 billion in 2010, as clients look to business intelligence to sort out where to make money. Kept promise of no layoffs in 2009, despite downturn. Firm known for worker-friendly policies; wellness programs, on-site daycare centers and free snacks. With Sall, owns tony Prestonwood Country Club and local private school Cary Academy. Outspoken proponent of education reform, has made education the focus of SAS's philanthropy; developed educational software that helps schools extend use of technology as a learning tool.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls Canadian food and retail empire George Weston Ltd., founded by his grandfather in 1882. Owns Loblaw supermarket chain, bakes cookies for the Girl Scouts. Weston also in rag trade with department stores Holt Renfrew in Canada, Brown Thomas in Ireland. Selfridges in the U.K. named "best department store in the world." In 2008 sold Neilson Dairy to fellow billionaire Emanuele Saputo; in 2009 sold U.S. bakery business, which included Entenmann's, Thomas' and Boboli brands, to Mexico's Grupo Bimbo for $2.5 billion. Reportedly interested in acquiring Barneys New York. Avid collector of avant-garde artist Christo. Plays polo with Prince Charles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Through hospitality group JJW, owns and manages 62 hotels and resorts in the UK, France, Austria, Portugal and Egypt. Size of property portfolio shrank after five British boutique hotels he bought in 2007 fell behind on debt payments last June after reportedly coming under pressure from major creditor, Anglo Irish. Other investments through holding group MBI International include residential real estate in Saudi Arabia, an oilfield services company and Egyptian food-processing firm AJWA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rave reviews from Milan's winter fashion week prove the 76-year-old is still setting trends. The designer to the stars also markets perfume, baby clothes, home decor and 5-figure watches. In 2009 he opened a 43,000-square-foot megastore on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue. The designer has licensed his name for a string of hotels; Dubai's Burj Khalifa hotel opened in April 2010. Spent 2 years in medical school at the University of Piacenza before dropping out in 1957 to take a job as a department store buyer. The Italian designer received France's Legion of Honor in summer 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: The most powerful woman in tech made a fortune manufacturing phones and gadgets sold under other companies' brands; now she is getting even richer by marketing them under her own HTC. Sales at the Taipei company, run by her and her husband Wenchi Chen, nearly doubled last year to $9.6 billion and net profit rose by three-quarters to $1.4 billion. Moving beyond hardware, the firm bought Saffron Digital of London, a mobile content provider, in February and said it would invest in U.S.-based gaming company OnLive. Wang, a daughter of the late Taiwan billionaire Y.C. Wang, was a member of a group that bought 26% of Hong Kong's biggest television production company, TVB, in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diamonds are apparently forever for the Oppenheimer family.  Despite rumors to the contrary, Nicky Oppenheimer is not looking to sell his family's 40% stake in DeBeers, the world's largest diamond producer which the family took private a decade ago The diamond producer has returned to profitability, helping boost his fortune to $7 billion, from $5 billion. Did sell a nearly 8% stake in Anglo American, the mining giant founded in 1917 by his grandfather Ernest; now has 2%. Passionate conservationist, owns Tswalu Kalahari Reserve, largest private game reserve in South Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of founder of Cox Enterprises, James M. Cox (d. 1957), Kennedy is the company's chairman. During his tenure, annual revenues have increased from $1.8 billion in 1988 to nearly $15 billion today. Cox Communications recently announced plans to offer Cox On DEMAND service to TIVO subscribers. Cox Enterprises now includes Cox Communications cable company, Cox Media Group (four metro newspapers, more than a dozen other publications, 15 TV stations, 86 radio stations), Manheim (car auction) and AutoTrader.com. Inherited 25% stake in business after mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007.  Serves on numerous boards, including Ducks Unlimited and the PATH Foundation.  Former competitive cyclist; past Masters National, Pan American and World Champion in the 3,000-meter pursuit
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: eBay founder saw his fortune boosted by $1.2 billion this year thanks to a 15% surge in the auction site's stock. The French-born Iranian moved to the U.S. with his family aged six. Wrote code for his site Auction Web at age 28 and renamed it eBay after first choice, Echo Bay, was already taken. The first item ever sold on eBay was his broken laser pointer for which he got $14.83. Became a billionaire in 1998 when company went public. Ceded executive control to new hire Meg Whitman in 1998; remains chairman. An active and eclectic donor; his Omidyar Network has given $5.5 million to a company designing solar powered lanterns and $500,000 to a political satire show in Kenya. This May, launched Honolulu Civil Beat, a local Hawaii news site that costs $20 per month to subscribers.
title: Founder and Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio:
Granddaughter of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957), Parry-Okeden  
inherited 25% stake in business after mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007. Not active in family business, Parry-Okeden lives in near anonymity in Australia, making her one of that country's richest residents. Brother Jim, who also got a 25% stake, is chairman of the nearly $15 billion (revenues) group whose holdings now include Cox Communications cable company, Cox Media Group (four metro newspapers, more than a dozen other publications,15 TV stations, 86 radio stations), Manheim (car auction) and AutoTrader.com.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues in 1972. Retired in May 2003 after 30 years as Its chief executive; now head of supervisory board. 2009 sales fell 8% to $15.2 billion and profits were down 10% to $2.4 billion. Company has restructured to regain its market lead; stock up 30% in a year. In November 2010, SAP lost a copyright infringement court battle against American software rival  Oracle (headed by billionaire Larry Ellison) worth $1.3 billion; SAP is contesting the outcome. Sports enthusiast sails his Morning Glory yacht competitively; skis, snowboards, plays golf and tennis. Owns luxury golf course and hotel, Fancourt Estate, in South Africa's Western Cape province. His Hasso Plattner Ventures, based in Potsdam, incubates promising technology companies. One of Germany's largest philanthropists. In 1998 donated 2.1 million SAP shares then worth $1.5 billion to establish the Hasso Plattner Foerderstiftung (foundation) which supports the sciences, historical preservation and projects in South Africa focusing on underprivileged children and teenagers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shrewd banker started hoarding cash in 2004 as consumers and companies bathed themselves in debt; waited until economy began to crumble 2007. Set about snapping up loans jettisoned by struggling banks, desperate investors. Bottom-feeding a boon: combined net income at his 2 banks have surged. Son of a mechanical engineer scraped together early kitty fixing used televisions; sold to low-income families. Bought Lansing, Mich. rental home at age 19. Opened first branch of Beal Bank in Texas 1988. Added Nevada bank years later. Buys loans on the secondary market instead of originating them. Gifted poker player took on renowned card sharks Doyle Brunson and Phil Ivey at the Bellagio in Las Vegas in some of the highest-stakes games ever played.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Minoru, also a billionaire, inherited initial real estate fortune from father but went their separate ways, unable to agree on a business strategy. Has continued to build his Mori Trust, owner of office buildings, apartment blocks and hotels in high-rent districts of Tokyo. Company has stake in Mori Trust Sogo REIT; share price of the REIT up 5% over the past year. Last year the REIT acquired a 50% joint ownership in Tokyo Shiodome Building from Mori Trust, its sponsor, for $1.2 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plans outlined last year for a life devoted to charitable causes have been swept under the carpet by Andrew Forrest, previous holder of the title of richest Australian. A punitive new tax on iron ore and coal mining proposed by the Australian Government has seen Forrest emerge as an outspoken champion of the mining industry, challenging the government before Senate hearings and at public meetings from the back of a flatbed truck. Forrest has also returned to full-time involvement with the business he launched in 2003. The onetime stockbroker and keen amateur boxer started his first mining company Anaconda Nickel (now called Minara) in 1994. Then hitched his fortune to an iron ore mine in the rugged Pilbara region of Australia's northwest.  His net worth peaked at $12.7 billion in June 2008 when the mining stock hit its all-time high. Known by his schoolboy nickname "Twiggy," Forrest is a descendant of the first premier of the state of West Australia, Lord Forrest of Bunbury.

name: Billionaires
bio: The grandson of a Russian immigrant, Samuel Irving - known as 'S.I.' or 'Si' - co-owns publishing powerhouse Advance Publications with brother Donald. Si presides over Condé Nast's consumer magazines, including Vogue, Vanity Fair and the New Yorker; group has lost some of its sheen over the past few years, with titles Modern Bride, Elegant Bride, Gourmet, and Cookie folding in 2009 (Gourmet is back as an online title only). Now, 40% of his fortune comes from stake in Discovery Communications, operator of cable and satellite TV networks like Discovery Channel, Animal Planet and TLC. Also has an extensive collection of modern art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads agribusiness conglomerate Charoen Pokphand Group, which father founded as small Bangkok seed importer. Over the past year stock more than doubled at 3 largest shareholdings: 7-Eleven store operator, CP ALL, on higher profits and successful expansion; as well as food producers Charoen Pokphand Foods and PT Charoen Pokphand on demand from China and high-margin food sales. Also owns country's third largest mobile phone company, which just took over Hutchison Telecom's Thailand operations. Philanthropist restores Buddhist temples in Thailand, sponsors schools and orphanages. Wealth of his three brothers, whom we believe to be billionaires, has been added to Dhanin's total worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard M.B.A. ran medical device maker Synthes for 30 years; stepped down as chief exec in 2007. He established bio-engineering institute at Harvard and in 2009 announced a $125 million donation -- largest individual philanthropic gift in school's history. An avid conservationist, he contributed $35 million last year to buy and preserve from development vast tracts of land in western Montana, in one of the largest private conservation purchases in US history. His donations have also helped set up a Wilderness Medicine Institute in Wyoming and modernization of the department of orthopedic surgery at University of South Alabama. Now heads Wyss Foundation, which gives scholarships to students getting master's degrees in conservation. Owns a 900-acre ranch and vineyard in California.

name: Billionaires
bio: For 36 years headed pharmaceutical companies Boehringer Manheim and DePuy. In May 1997 engineered their sale to Roche for $11 billion. Made $4.4 billion on the deal. Engelhorn, whose mother was American, sponsors the Heidelberg Center for American Studies at the University of Heidelberg, funding it with a yearly donation of more than $500,000. Also supports the Reiss-Engelhorn Museum in Mannheim. Great-grandson of Friedrich Engelhorn, founder of German chemical company BASF.  Studied chemical engineering in Texas after World War II.  Retired to Switzerland with fourth wife, Heidemarie.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Fubon Group, which has expanded from its early niche in non-life insurance business in Taiwan into an integrated full-service financial services company that is increasingly looking to China. Fubon in January moved to privatize shares in its Hong Kong-traded subsidiary Fubon Banking, whose listing there in 2005 was a milestone for Taiwan banks entering the industry in the former British colony. Tsai's sons Daniel and Richard now lead Fubon's operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Sweden's richest women. In 1982 succeeded her father as head of the Axel Johnson Group, a diversified trading company founded by her great-grandfather in 1873. The privately held $6.3 billion (sales) group has interests in everything from energy to telecom to real estate. Axfood AB, in which it holds a 46% share, is one of the largest food operations in Scandinavia. Attended Radcliffe College in Cambridge, Mass., as an exchange student in the early 1960s. Avid horsewoman and member of numerous Swedish charities, including the World Childhood Foundation, which was founded by the Swedish queen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Metals magnate founded and runs London-listed Vedanta Resources.  Struck $9.6 billion deal to buy 60% stake in Cairn India which owns country's biggest onshore oil field, for an estimated $9.6 billion. Acquisition in limbo since last August over delay in government approvals and objections from state-owned oil explorer ONGC. Faced setback when India's environment ministry rejected Vedanta's proposal to mine bauxite in Eastern India, following a government report that it would hurt local tribal people. Court recently ruled that the land for his proposed Vedanta University was illegally acquired.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Hong Kong's biggest landlords, through his Chinese Estates, is known for his impressive art, wine collections; said to have at least 10,000 bottles of red wine. Paid $16.7 million for 2 incense burners last year.  Bought home in London's tony Eaton Square last January. Active investor in newly listed companies, he also bought and later sold stake in copper miner CST Mining Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ray Dalio oversees Bridgewater Associates, one of world's largest hedge funds, with $75 billion under management. Fund was reportedly up 10% in 2010; invested in currencies, stocks, bonds, interest rates. Dalio shared his 300 rules for life, called Distributed Principles, with staff this spring. Among his wisdom: "Don't use the anonymous 'we' and 'they' because that masks personal responsibility" and "Use 'double-do' rather than 'double-check' to make sure mission-critical tasks are done correctly." Employees are encouraged to find fault with superiors' opinions. Son of a jazz musician, Dalio bought his first stock at age 12. Became futures trader at brokerage CBWL-Hayden Stone. Left to found Bridgewater at age 25.  Enjoys being in the wilderness, bow-hunting, snowboarding; meditates 5 times a week.
title: Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Bridgewater Associates', 'title': 'Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the trio of Brazilians who share control of Anheuser-Busch Inbev, the world's largest beer company, and now also share control of hamburger chain Burger King, which they bought for $4 billion last year. With his former investment banking partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira, turned around Ambev, a Brazilian beermaker, and merged it with Interbrew of Belgium in 2004 to form Inbev. In November 2008 Inbev acquired Anheuser-Busch for $52 billion. The trio also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. Telles reportedly enjoys spearfishing and spending time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened first apparel store in Barcelona 1984. Today the $2 billion (sales) Mango group, is known for producing reasonably priced, trendy women's apparel.  Has more than 1,200 stores in 92 countries, from the Dutch Antilles to China.  Now also makes a menswear line, Mango He. Has shares in Banco Sabadell, one of Spain's largest banking groups; sits on its board.  Media-shy entrepreneur's family came to Spain from Turkey in 1960s; apparently an enthusiastic sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Estée Lauder (d. 2004) and chairman emeritus of the cosmetics company. His Lipstick Indicator Theory holds that people buy more inexpensive luxuries in tough economic times. Estée Lauder shares up 50% over last year. Whitney Museum of American Art chairman emeritus at the last minute voted in favor of the museum's downtown expansion. Owns one of world's finest private collections of Cubist works, including Picasso's 1909 "Nude Woman in an Armchair."
title: Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Estée Lauder Cos', 'uri': 'companies/estee-lauder-cos', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of CLP Holdings, the largest supplier of electricity in Hong Kong, which lately has been looking beyond the former British colony for growth. The company said in December that it reached an agreement with the New South Wales government in Australia to buy state-owned Energy Australia's retailing business.  Kadoorie's Hongkong & Shanghai Hotels is on target to open its Peninsula Paris in 2012.  Kadoorie is the scion of a family of Iraqi Jews who made an early fortune in Shanghai a century ago and later settled in Hong Kong. Board member of billionaire Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Sun Pharmaceuticals, India's most valuable drug-maker, won his three-year battle to gain control of  Israeli generics maker Taro Pharma. The acquisition would boost Sun's US business which fell after the US Food & Drug Administration shut down its American unit citing manufacturing violations. Last year, he hired a top executive from GlaxoSmithKline as chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Good year for Hyundai Motor chairman and his company. Hyundai Motor became the world's fourth-largest automaker beating out Ford in early 2009. It is faring well in U.S.; model Genesis won North American Car of the Year award in 2009. Its program that lets people who lose jobs return newly purchased cars won plaudits.  US branch offered incentives of up to $1,000 to existing Toyota owners who trade in their vehicles for new cars. Building steelmaking plant to be completed in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Captain of Carnival, the world's largest cruise ship operator, Arison is steering through choppy times. Despite increasing fuel costs, 2010 revenue up 7% from 2009; profits up 11% thanks to cost-cutting measures. Today Carnival, which his father founded, operates 98 ships under 11 brands, including Princess, Holland America, Seabourn. Recently announced plans to move Seabourn headquarters to Seattle, where it will share technology and support services with Holland America. Move anticipated to save $25 million annually. At any given time there are more than 270,000 people aboard the fleet. Arison is also majority owner of the NBA's Miami Heat, which boasts big three: Chris Bosh, LeBron James, Dwyane Wade.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Sankyo, the pachinko gambling-machine maker, now run by his son Hideyuki. Company focusing on strengthening balance sheet in face of decreasing customer demand; repurchased 3% of outstanding shares last year. Looking to new games to lift results such as Fever X Japan, introduced in September, which involves collaboration with a popular rock band.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded JCDecaux outdoor advertising company in 1964; it's now the largest outdoor advertising company in the world. Decaux is chairman; sons Jean-Francois and Jean-Charles are co-chief executives. Started out putting ads on "street furniture" such as public toilets and bus shelters. Now places advertising in airports, malls, subways and billboards in 55 countries. Revenues  took a beating in 2009, dropping 12%  - the most difficult year so far.  Company rebounding: posted $3.1 billion sales i n 2010, up 23% over previous year. Leading provider of eco-friendly transportation in big cities, including bicycles for hire. Places recycling bins for batteries, glass or other waste near its street furniture.  Last November installed  a defibrillator in a street furniture panel in a Paris suburb - a first in France.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Swedish billionaire is the year's biggest loser, down $17 billion to $6 billion. The drop from No. 11 to No. 162 has nothing to do with the value of his thriving retailer. He has fallen because his lawyers produced documents that prove the foundation he created, and heads, in tax haven Lichtenstein owns Ikea, and its bylaws bar him and his family from benefiting from its funds. The foundation, which gets royalty payments from Ikea's franchisees tax free, is valued at $12 billion but has only doled out $60 million to charity. Kamprad, who sold the business to the foundation years ago, gets his fortune from his investment firm, Ikano, run by his three sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blackstone CEO has seen his wealth rebound along with his company's stock. The private equity firm's shares have risen 35% in the past year. Schwarzman is a Yale grad (former President George W. Bush was a classmate) and founded a ballet society to meet girls while at school. He gave $100 million to the New York Public Library in 2008; the main Fifth Avenue branch has since been named after him.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Blackstone Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chair of Geneva-headquartered Steinmetz Diamond Group made headlines in April 2010 when he sold a 51% stake in his Guinean iron ore mining company to Brazil's Vale for $2.5 billion; the mining licenses at Simandou and Zogota are believed to be the world's best underdeveloped deposit of iron ore. His stake in Canadian gold and silver miner Gabriel Resources doubled over the past year. Not so lucky in real estate; mounting debts at his Scorpio and Five Mounts real estate led auditors to reportedly question company's viability as a going concern. With wife, oversees the Beny & Agnes Steinmetz Foundation, which donates to schools, hospitals, army units and the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Los Angeles' most influential arts patron stirred up controversy over the extent of his dominion after drawing up the terms to build his own museum on downtown's Grand Avenue. Broad bought first patch of land at age 20. Cofounded Kaufman & Broad with $25,000 borrowed from in-laws; became one of nation's biggest home builders supplying parents of baby boomers with affordable housing. Bought Sun Life Insurance (later renamed SunAmerica) in 1971; sold to AIG 1998 for $18 billion in cash and stock. Contemporary art collector created the Broad Art Foundation 1984; today his lending library makes extensive contemporary art collection available to institutions around the world. Over the years has used his checkbook and influence to promote better public school educators, extend grants to charter schools and encourage scientific research in the fields of inflammatory bowel disease, human genomics and stem cells. Son of Lithuanian immigrants; born in the Bronx, raised in Detroit.

name: Billionaires
bio: The style icon sold $850 million worth of Polo Ralph Lauren shares, roughly a quarter of his stake, in a secondary offering in spring of 2010. Stated reason: diversification. At first investors drove down the stock, but it has mostly recovered and is up 65% since last year. China is a growing market (27 stores). Overall, a wide-ranging product mix--affordable (Chaps), collegiate (Rugby), high-end (Collections), housewares (paint, bedding, lights)--helps company growth. Bronx native worked first job at Brooks Brothers; left school to design ties for Beau Brummel 1976. Launched Polo with $50,000 later that year. Company sales of $5 billion from clothing, shoes, jewelry, home goods, fragrances. Collector has dozens of exotic cars (Bugatti, Bentley, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari), vintage watches.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ralph Lauren', 'uri': 'companies/ralph-lauren', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Extremely discreet, press-shy brothers control luxury brand Chanel. Company was cofounded by their grandfather Pierre Wertheimer, who eventually bought out his early partner Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, designer of the famous little black dress. U.S. resident Alain is chairman of the company, whose Chanel No. 5 perfume is one of world's top-selling scents. Brother Gerard lives in Switzerland and chairs Chanel's watch division. His wife Valerie is president of Action Innocence, a group that combats child pornography on the Web. Brothers own French vineyards Rauzan-Segla in Margaux and Chateau Canon in Saint-Emilion; also thoroughbreds, including horses that have won such races as the French Derby and the Breeders' Cup Turf in the U.S.  Alain reportedly collects old time pieces.

name: Billionaires
bio: The New York native and brother of Samuel Irving (S.I.) oversees the newspaper portion of Advance Publications, which runs local papers in more than 25 American cities; Si takes care of magazines under the Conde Nast banner. Fortune up $400 million since last year thanks to the stock performance of media and entertainment network Discovery Communications, owner of Discovery Channel, Animal Planet, TLC and others (he and Si own a stake). Although he dropped out of Syracuse University, Donald established the Wellesley Center for the Humanities at his wife Susan's alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: The founder of China's largest beverage producer, Wahaha, sees his wealth drop this year as higher raw materials costs eroded profit margins. Zong has lately expressed an interest in diversifying his revenue from beverages into retail even as main business is growing. "You can say, 20%-plus growth isn't enough to satisfy Wahaha," Zong told Forbes Asia at the end of last year. Wahaha's name comes from the sound of a child's laughter.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Philippines richest man came from China as a child to work in father's convenience store. Starting with small shoe store in Manila, he built one of the country's largest retail groups. SM Prime, ,which he controls and is run by son Hans, is the Philippines largest shopping mall developer with 39 malls; continues China expansion. Banco de Oro Unibank, run by daughter Teresita Sy-Coson, is the country's largest bank.  Expanding into gaming with $350 million Las Vegas-style casino scheduled to open in Manila later this year.  Shares fortune with wife and children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buyout investor's stakes in holding company Valhi and Titanium Metals continued upward, gaining 34% and 33% respectively in a year. Environmental groups have raised concerns with the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) over his company Waste Control Specialists' proposed site for disposing radioactive waste from other states. Started out as a bank examiner; got taste for takeovers after buying Dallas drugstore in 1961 for $5,000 cash plus $95,000 loan; sold chain 12 years later to Eckerd Corp. for $50 million. Began building Valhi through hostile buyouts.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Vancouver magnate started with car dealerships, built into eclectic conglomerate including coal shipping terminals, advertising, supermarkets, forestry. Media company owns Guiness World Records, Ripley's Believe It Or Not. Chronically upbeat, still loves going into the office, driving his vintage cars: "I'm doing great; not a complaint in the world." A jewel in the Pattison crown--Palm Springs retreat once home to Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow and her children control one of Brazil's largest steelmakers, Companhia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN). The Steinbruch and Rabinovitch families, through their Vicunha Textile, paid a reported $800 million in 1993 for control of CSN, a formerly state-owned steel company. In 2005 Steinbruch bought out the Rabinovitch stake for a reported $590 million. Her brother-in-law, Eliezer Steinbruch, who shared control of CSN, died in 2008. She is not involved in running the business; son Benjamin serves as chairman and chief executive of CSN. Company made an unsuccessful bid for Cimpor, Portugal's largest cement manufacturer, last year.  Family also owns Banco Fibra; son Ricardo is chairman of the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chairman of electronics contract manufacturing king Hon Hai Precision was dethroned as Taiwan's richest man after a tough 2010 in which the company attracted international attention following a spate of suicides at its mainland operations. Subsequent wage increases won't help costs. Yet Hon Hai, better known in the industry by its trade name Foxconn, still has a strong customer list that includes Apple and HP. Gou founded the company in 1974 with $7,500.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia's richest newcomer. Chairman of Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical, a producer of heparin used to treat cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases. Goldman Sachs has 11% stake in company, which is a supplier to Sanofi-Aventis. It went public in May 2010; shares have been choppy since. Li and wife Li Tan co-founded the company in the 1980s as Chongqing Tongda Biological Products. They later moved to the southern entrepreneurial mecca of Shenzhen, and eventually changed company name. The Lis both graduated from Sichuan University as chemistry majors in 1987.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of online shopping mall operator Rakuten plans to diversify his management and board with foreign nationals as the company expands overseas; eventual goal is to have English as the company language. In October 2010 launched an online shopping mall in China through joint venture with Chinese search engine Baidu. Petitioning Japan Fair Trade Commission to examine the tie up of Yahoo Japan and Google as a potential monopoly on information.

name: Billionaires
bio: His garage startup is now $5.7 billion (revenues) HCL Group, among India's top five software firms. Flagship HCL Technologies bagged a $500 million outsourcing contract from American drugmaker Merck & Co , its largest order ever. Last  June, he sold 2.5% stake in HCL Technologies for $131 million, donating money to his Shiv Nadar Foundation. Daughter Roshni is chief executive of holding entity HCL Corporation. Wife Kiran, an avid art collector, has an art museum in Delhi

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Orascom founder and billionaire Onsi Sawiris. Took over leadership of empire's flagship construction and fertilizer division in 1998. In 2007, sold cement business in Algeria to French construction giant Lafarge. Owns 13.9% stake in Lafarge, and sits on board . Also largest shareholder in cement producer Texas Industries. Had berated management's poor performance, but recently reached agreement to boost stake to no more than 20%. Shares of Orascom on London exchange plunged by more than one-third after uprising in Egypt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investing over $1 billion to expand his food retailer, Magnit. Started out as wholesaler of perfumes and beauty supplies in 1994. Four years later, the Wal-Mart admirer established Magnit, a chain of grocery stores with the slogan "Always Low Prices."  (Wal-Mart's slogan has long been "Everyday Low Prices.") Took the company public in April 2006. Also has investments in agriculture, development and tourism. As a child dreamed of becoming a professional soccer player; in 2008 established the Krasnodar football team. In partnership with government began construction of a new soccer stadium to host the 2018 World Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Zealand's richest person continues to build his packaging empire. His Rank Group bought America's Pactiv, maker of Hefty garbage bags for around $4.4 billion in 2010. Past acquisitions have included Australasian forest products group Carter Holt Harvey, Swiss packager SIG, Alcoa's former packaging unit, Reynolds Consumer Products and Closure Systems International. Drew up the idea for Rank as an M.B.A. student at University of Otago in New Zealand. Boating enthusiast owns 190-foot yacht Ulysses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built Guangdong Province's Midea Group into one of the world's largest electronic and home appliance makers, churning out washing machines, refrigerators and air conditioners for China's emerging middle class. He is the biggest shareholder of the Group, which includes Shenzhen-listed GD Midea and Hong Kong-listed Welling Holding. Possible hot-selling item this year: solar-powered air conditioners. GD Midea took a step abroad last October by buying 32.5% of Misr Refrigeration of Egypt. Relaxes by golfing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bag boy runs family's privately held HEB grocery chain, with $16 billion in sales from 317 stores throughout Texas, Mexico. Has been slashing prices to lure customers away from competitors Wal-Mart and Kroger. Grandmother founded grocer in 1905 in Kerrville, Tex. after her husband fell ill with tuberculosis. Company donates 5% of pretax profits to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began building his empire in 1990 when, with partner Vitaly Malkin, he set up Rossiysky Kredit Bank. Over the years, sold businesses he accumulated during Russia's privatization era including ore mining and metals interests; invested proceeds in Russian stock market. Also has interests in elite real estate project in Moscow and two 5-star hotels. Owns Russian drugstore chain Doctor Stoletov. Collects the Impressionists; his most expensive painting is Dora Maar with Cat by Pablo Picasso, which he bought at Sotheby's in 2006 for $95 million. Last year he received French citizenship, adding to his Russian and Georgian passports. Lives in the Georgian village of Chorvila, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the trio of Brazilians who share control of Anheuser-Busch Inbev, the world's largest beer company, and now also share control of fast food chain Burger King, which they bought for $4 billion last year. With his former investment banking partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Telles, turned around Ambev, a Brazilian beermaker, and merged it with Interbrew of Belgium in 2004 to form Inbev. In November 2008 Inbev acquired Anheuser-Busch for $52 billion. The trio also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hardware mogul's fortune spared from demolition despite tough economic times as legions of cash-strapped suburbanites shunned pricey contractors and took to do-it-yourself home renovation, benefitting his home improvement chain Menards. Revenues in 2009 dropped under $7 billion. U. of Wisconsin-Eau Claire grad earned handyman credentials constructing post-frame buildings to finance education. Began selling tools from a single store in 1970s; Menard's is now nation's third-largest home improvement (by sales) brand behind Home Depot, Lowe's; it has 286 stores in 13 midwestern states.
title: president and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Menard, Inc.', 'title': 'president and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil baron bought up shares in Russia's second biggest gas producer, Novatek , last year.  He also bought a 25% stake in Geotek, one of the biggest geological exploration companies in Russia.  In the late 1980s ran Kinex, a state-owned oil exporter. Became one of its main shareholders when it was later privatized. Today is one of the co-owners of the Gunvor Group, one of the largest international energy traders (2010 revenues: $65 billion), through which state-controlled Rosneft and Gazpromneft oil firms export their products. Controls the engineering and construction company Stroytransgaz, Gazprom's contractor. Also has Finnish citizenship, lives in Switzerland. He won several cases against Russian and UK media outfits that wrote about his business successes in relation to his alleged close ties with Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought Humvee maker AM General in 1992 and launched luxury SUV Hummer market. Sold majority stake to billionaire Ronald Perelman for $930 million in 2004. Owns one of the biggest homes in the U.S. in Sagaponack. N.Y. The 43,031-square-foot mansion is said to have 29 bedrooms and 39 bathrooms. Gives regularly to Jewish causes, including a mikvah (ritual bath) to New York's Fifth Avenue Synagogue.

name: Billionaires
bio: The richest self-made woman in the world is a former journalist. Shares in Wu's Hong Kong-listed real estate developer Longfor Properties rose by a quarter from a year earlier amid brisk sales growth. Contract sales for 2010 soared 81% from a year earlier to $5 billion. From its roots in Chongqing in central China, Longfor has been expanding in relatively profitable markets in first-tier cites. Longfor listed its shares in Hong Kong Nov. 2009. Wu shares her fortune with her husband.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang's fortune increased sharply this year in connection with the successful Hong Kong listing of his shipbuilding company China Rongsheng Heavy Industries, which raised $1.8 billion in November. The IPO attracted investments by China Life and China International Capital Corp., two of China's largest financial industry businesses, as well as Hong Kong billionaire Cheng Yu-tung. The shipbuilder's listing offset a more than one third drop in the value of Hong Kong-listed Glorious Property Holdings, Zhang's other major source of wealth,  in the past year amid China's efforts to cool down real estate prices and inflation. Before he started developing real estate, Zhang worked in the construction materials trade and construction sub-contracting. His first real estate development project was Sunshine Greenland in Shanghai in 1996. He holds a master's degree in business administration from Asia Macau International Open University.

name: Billionaires
bio: The doctor added $200 million to his fortune over the last year as he sold Abraxis BioScience to Celgene for $2.9 billion in October 2010. He's pledged half of his fortune to charity, joining the Bill Gates-Warren Buffett Giving Pledge initiative: "Growing up in South Africa ... we had direct experience of inequality." His father was a village doctor in China; family immigrated to South Africa during WWII. Finished high school at 16; doctor by 23. Took American Pharmaceutical Partners public 2001. Launched cancer treatment Abraxane 2005; drug more potent, with fewer side effects than treatments then available.

name: Billionaires
bio: Revered voice among Brazilian business chairs family-owned conglomerate Grupo Votorantim, whose activities span steel, finance, farming, chemicals, concentrated orange juice, energy, cement and pulp and paper.  Grupo Votorantim was founded in 1918 by Antonio's father, senator Jose Ermirio de Moraes. Group is divided among three siblings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israel's richest woman inherited two of the country's largest companies: $75 billion (assets) Bank Hapoalim, and infrastructure behemoth Housing & Construction. Stake in Carnival Cruise increased 10% in value over last 12 months. Also owns Miya, a $100 million venture dedicated to reducing leaks in underground water pipes. Eccentric heiress published book outlining philosophy of connecting business with spirituality.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: In December 2010 sold his supermarket chain Kopeyka (Kopek) to X5 Group for $1.1 billion in cash. Chairs financial services firm, Ursalib, which is currently looking for a strategic investor or to IPO. Former air force lieutenant colonel met Leonid Fedun, also a former military officer, who was a privatization consultant for Lukoil. After setting up Nikoil (later renamed Uralsib) in partnership with other top Lukoil managers such as Vagit Alekperov, Tsvetkov helped them gain a controlling stake in the oil company; for his services was rewarded with a sizable Lukoil stake. He left the oil firm's board of directors last year but still has about 1% of its shares. Also owns legendary Lomonosov Porcelain, to which he returned its original name, Imperial Porcelain Manufacture. Passionate about Eastern philosophy and yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood's richest man was inducted into 2010 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Fortune up thanks to jump in value of massive contemporary art collection. Geffen owns stake in DreamWorks Studio, although he is no longer involved in that business; departed in 2008. Founded Asylum Records and Geffen Records, launching careers of classics: Eagles, Aerosmith and Guns N' Roses. Sold out to MCA for $550 million in 1990. Started by sorting mail at William Morris talent agency. With partners Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg launched DreamWorks SKG in 1995. Bought $14 million apartment in Manhattan on Fifth Avenue in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned father's small Taiwan trader I Lan Foods Industrial into a mainland Chinese food and beverage giant that sells snacks, rice crackers, dairy products, and, increasingly, juice. Tsai listed Want Want Holdings in Singapore in 1996, only to delist in 2007 and to transfer its food and beverage business to a new Hong Kong listing, Want Want China, in 2008.  Want Want also listed back at home in Taiwan in 2009.  Brisk growth has made Want Want one of few to graduate from Forbes Asia's "Best Under a Billion" List for small caps to its "Fab 50" for blue-chips.  Also operates hotels and media business and invests in insurance. Son Tsai Shao-Chung is a member of Want Want's board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. Charles became chief exec in 1957, half-brother Rupert Jr. joined 8 years later. Duo expanded into Franklin Resources 1969; added Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Now called Franklin Templeton Investments, managed $ $670.7 billion as of December 2010. Charles is chairman, Rupert Jr. vice chairman; son Gregory is chief executive.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned small cork factory started by his grandfather in 1870 into world's largest producer of cork, $495 million (sales) Corticeira Amorim; group now also has real estate and tourism interests. No longer involved in daily operations, but owns 50% of the group. Most of his fortune now comes from his extensive investments in stocks, particularly in finance and energy industries; holdings include 7% stake in Banco Popular; 25% in investment company Finpro; 25% in bank BIC Angola; 51% in  Banco Unico Mozambique; 18% in Galp, Portugal's former state energy company; and 25% of Tom Ford, a luxury fashion designer.   Also has land in northern Brazil that he hopes to develop into a tourist spot. With his two brothers, has established a separate private equity fund to take advantage of the financial crisis and acquire failing companies. In 2009  was awarded an honorary doctor of commercial science from St. John's University in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers turned Bridas, an oil services company founded by their father, into Argentina's second largest oil and gas company. In March 2010, China's National Overseas Oil Co. (CNOOC) paid $3.1 billion for a 50% stake in privately held Bridas. In December, Bridas purchased from troubled British oil giant BP the 40% of oil and gas producer PanAmerican Energy it didn't already own, for $7.1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Briefly China's richest man in 2009, Hui is the founder of Evergrande Real Estate, a Guangzhou-based real estate developer whose shares trade on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The company has more than 18,000 employees and projects (mostly residential) in 60 Chinese cities. The company pushed into commercial real estate by acquiring Kasia Plaza in August. It also moved into hospitality with the opening of the Chongqing Evergrande Hotel in October. The company tapped into the growing appetite for exposure to China's currency in January by selling 9.25 billion yuan ($1.4 billion) of international debt that will be repaid in equivalent amount of U.S. dollars.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Germany's post war retail pioneers. Began career in 1948 selling clothes.  Opened first Massa Department store in 1965. Sold chain in 1986 but smartly held on to the underlying real estate, which he now rents to retailer Metro. Kipp has divested himself of his real estate in the U.S., notably several high-end properties in Manhattan, including 950 Third Avenue. Also has four Swiss luxury hotels and resorts including the Hotel Eden Roc in Ascona, the 105-room Carlton Hotel in St. Moritz and the Tschuggen Grand Hotel in Arosa, where he lives with wife of some 60 years, Hannelore

name: Billionaires
bio: Woo's wealth has increased from a year ago on rising values for his strong commercial property holdings in Hong Kong, which include Harbour City in Kowloon and Times Square in the Causeway Bay shopping district. Shares in Woo's holding company, Wheelock, have climbed about 30% in the past year. Recently finished building one of Shanghai's tallest office structures, located in the city's pricey Jing'An district. Woo is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. Daughter Jennifer Woo runs privately held mall chain Lane Crawford. Woo reportedly in March bought 8% of Salvatore Ferragamo Italia Spa for an undisclosed amount.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Tepper's Appaloosa Management is keeping its winning streak alive; the $16 billion fund was up 34% gross of fees in 2010. Returned 132% in 2009, thanks to timely purchases of financial stocks. Bought Hamptons beachfront mansion in Sagaponack from Former New Jersey Governor John Corzine's ex-wife.  He was head trader on high yield desk at Goldman Sachs, failed to make partner, left to start Appaloosa in 1993. Gave $55 million to Carnegie Mellon's business school in 2004; it was renamed Tepper School of Business. Tepper is currently a minority owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers. Never got an A in high school.
title: President and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Appaloosa Management', 'title': 'President and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Thai energy drink producer T.C. Pharmaceuticals. Teamed up with Austrian Dietrich Mateschitz two decades ago to create energy drink Red Bull. Chaleo provided beverage formula and his partner contributed the marketing flair. Today Red Bull, which has $5 billion (sales), plans to expand to China this year.  Each partner owns 49% of the company. Chaleo's son, Chalerm, who owns one of Asia's leading wine producers, Siam Winery, holds remaining 2%. Family upped stake in privately held Piyavate Hospital.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Budi, inherited clove cigarette maker Djarum from their father but these days get bulk of their fortune from Bank Central Asia, country's largest private bank, which returned to ranks of Forbes Asia's Fabulous 50 list last year. Siblings also have palm oil interests; picked up 65,000 hectares of land in West Kalimantan in 2008. Together they also own Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex in the center of Jakarta.Their Djarum, banned in the US since 2009 along with other clove cigarettes,  has launched Dos Hermanos, a premium cigar blending Brazilian and Indonesian tobaccos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property baron is still bullish on Brazil: Latin America's largest economy accounts for half the $1.5 billion his private investment firm, Equity International, has in developing markets. Also invested in Mexico, Colombia, Peru, Chile, China and Egypt. Began dabbling in real estate while in college. Made first fortune buying and selling real estate from distressed owners. Sold Equity Office Properties to Blackstone for $39 billion in 2007; still owns stakes in Equity Residential and Equity Lifestyle real estate investment trusts. Bought Tribune Co. in 2007; colossal debt, declines in ad revenue forced it into bankruptcy two years later. Company executives blamed Zell for collapse and said they intended to sue him. But court-appointed examiner found Zell acted in good faith. In February, the creditors' committee quietly withdrew its notice.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Michael, inherited clove cigarette maker Djarum from their father but these days get bulk of their fortune from Bank Central Asia, country's largest private bank, which returned to ranks of Forbes Asia's Fabulous 50 list last year. Siblings also have palm oil interests; picked up 65,000 hectares of land in West Kalimantan in 2008. Together they also own Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex in the center of Jakarta.Their Djarum, banned in the US since 2009 along with other clove cigarettes,  has launched Dos Hermanos, a premium cigar blending Brazilian and Indonesian tobaccos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads IOI Group which he built into one of the world's biggest palm oil producers and one of Malaysia's biggest property developers. Group employs 30,000 worldwide. Grew up on a rubber plantation where his father ran a Chinese food shop. Left school at 11 to help support his family, selling ice cream on a bicycle for 4 years before returning to finish high school. All of his children now work for his companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of financier Henry Crown, who founded sand, stone and gravel company Material Service with 2 brothers1919. Expanded firm into world's largest building materials distributor, merged with General Dynamics 1959; still has large stake in the firm. Lester inherited fortune after father's death in1990. Diversified into hotels, sports, technology. Family co-owns Rockefeller Center with Tishman Speyer. Also owns stakes in Chicago Bulls, New York Yankees. Controls Aspen Skiing Company, which owns Aspen Mountain, Aspen Highlands, Buttermilk and Snowmass.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of Tencent, China's largest Internet company by market capitalization, is part of a triumvirate of Internet giants that dominate the China market and are known at home by the acronym TAB: Tencent, Alibaba and Baidu. Ma Huateng, however, couldn't be more different from the leaders of the other two.
