Whereas Jack Ma courts clients for Alibaba in a high-profile way and youthful looking Li turns up in public, Ma is famous for laying low. So far, it doesn't seem to have hurt the company:  Tencent is one of the world's 10 most popular websites, according to survey company Alexa, and its Hong Kong-listed shares are up by about a third in the past year.  Zhang Zhidong, another co-founder, is also on the billionaires list this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. His half-brother Charles took over the company in 1957; Rupert Jr. joined 8 years later. Duo expanded into Franklin Resources 1969; added Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Now called Franklin Templeton Investments, managed $670 billion as of  December. Charles is chairman, Rupert Jr. vice chairman.
title: Vice Chairman and Director
employment: {'name': 'Franklin Resources', 'uri': 'companies/franklin-resources', 'title': 'Vice Chairman and Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former marketing executive created Red Bull energy drink with Thai business partner Chaleo Yoovidhya. Markets drink to young people using cheeky advertising and extreme-sports sponsorships. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the $5 billion (sales) company, which plans to expand to China in 2011. Now also present in France, Denmark and Norway, where it had been banned because of its contents; still banned in Iceland and Uruguay.Company has stakes in two soccer teams: Red Bull Salzburg and New York Red Bulls; also a Formula I team, Red Bull Racing.  Mateschitz's other interests include Seitenblicke magazine; Servus TV;  luxury resort on Fiji island of Laucala; and Hangar-7, the event center on the grounds of Salzburg airport that houses his historical aircraft collection called the Flying Bulls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Suning Appliances of Nanjing, China's largest electrical appliance retailer. Suning's business has benefitted from growth in spending on home appliances and gadgets by China's expanding middle class. Zhang's chain has also gotten boost from a struggle for board control at rival Gome of Beijing, whose founder Wong Kwong Yu is serving jail time. Another rival, Best Buy of the U.S., in February said it was shuttering its handful of flagship stores in the country. Suning has been looking beyond the mainland; last year it bought Citicall Retail Management in Hong Kong. Zhang, a Chinese language student in college, also has real estate investments. His elder brother Zhang Guiping is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heiress is one of seven relatives on list thanks to vast wealth created by Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. in which the family owns an 88% stake. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops; also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations; one of its hardest hit divisions. Fiscal 2010 sales were down 6% to  $107.9 billion; net earnings down 22% to $2.6 billion. Company plans to divest its majority stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909.  No family member has run company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune of shipping tycoon, Greece's richest man, took hit amid country's economic woes.  Stocks of his EFG International, EFG Eurobank, Lamda Development, and Hellenic Petroleum, all fell. No respite as recent unrest in North Africa fuel worries for shipping industry.  Also owns jet and yacht operators PrivatAir and PrivatSea.  He has a Ph.D. from the London School of Economics; sits on the board of Institute of Advanced Studies in Princeton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir is one of seven relatives on list thanks to the value of Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. in which the family owns an 88% stake. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops; also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations; one of its hardest hit divisions. Fiscal 2010 sales were down 6% to  $107.9 billion; net earnings down 22% to $2.6 billion. Company will be divesting its majority stake in  fertilizer maker Mosaic.  William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909.  No family member has run company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.  Art collector: in 2009  donated a more than 116 piece collection of contemporary art including works by Louise Bourgeois, Jasper Johns and Roy Lichtenstein to the Palm Springs Art  Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of conglomerate Hong Leong Group Malaysia gets biggest part of fortune from stake in its Hong Kong listed investment holding company, Guoco Group. Has other interests in financial services, property development and hotels across Southeast Asia. His Hong Leong Bank still stalking Malaysian bank Eon Capital, which it has been trying to take over for a year. Inherited fortune from his father, one of 3 brothers who started a small banking group in the 1920s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir is one of seven relatives on list thanks to vast wealth created by Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. in which the family owns an 88% stake. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops; also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations; one of its hardest hit divisions. Fiscal 2010 sales were down 6% to  $107.9 billion; net earnings down 22% to $2.6 billion.Company plans to divest its majority stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic.  William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909.  No family member has run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns publicly traded Swiss luxury group Richemont, which owns Cartier, Dunhill, makes Chloe bags and MontBlanc pens. Company has been doing better than analyst expectations on the back of accelerating sales in Asia-Pacific. Big on acquisitions: Richemont bought out online fashion portal Net-a-Porter 350 million pounds in April 2010 while his South African holding company, Remgro, bought out private South African investment outfit, VenFin, earlier. Appointed as Chancellor of the University of Stellenbosch,in South Africa where he has an office. With family relatives, owns two of South Africa's best-known vineyards, Rupert & Rothschild and L'Ormarins; owns one of the country's most exclusive golf clubs. Launched L'Ormarins 1200 car rally;has been pushed back from October 2010 to end-2011. Recently, he vowed to take on oil multinational Shell, opposing shale gas development in SA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandfather owned a brick factory, grandfather worked in cement. Father Max carved up his estate 1984: brother Stephen, also a billionaire, got construction company Eternit, Thomas got Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement and concrete. Ran it for 2 decades; stepped down as chairman in 2003; still holds 18% stake. Wine aficionado owns vineyards in Argentina, Australia, California. Also owns Swiss vineyard in his native town of Balgach. Honorary Consul-General of the Republic of Cyprus in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Hendrik, immigrated from the Netherlands 1900s; became barber. Opened North Side Grocery 1934 with 14-year-old son Frederik. Duo launched Meijer Thrifty Acres in 1962; pioneered 'superstore' one-stop shopping. Frederik took over after father's death 1964; handed over reins to sons Doug and Hank 1990, but remains chairman.  Today there are 190 Meijer stores in 5 states. Company recently launched MeijerDoorstepGrocer.co, an online grocery service.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heiress is one of seven relatives on list thanks to vast wealth created by Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S. in which the family owns an 88% stake. Cargill makes money in all areas of food production from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops; also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations; one of its hardest hit divisions. Fiscal 2010 sales were down 6% to  $108 billion; net earnings down 22% to $2.6 billion. Company plains to dvest its majority stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909.  No family member has run company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Discount brokerage pioneer founded eponymous firm in 2-room office 1971. Deregulation of brokerage commissions, birth of online investing propelled company to enormity. Client assets: $1.6 trillion.  Fended off a drawn-out lawsuit against its mortgage-bond mutual fund YieldPlus, with a $119 million settlement, which Schwab called a 'pimple' on firm's record. Left chief exec post in 2008, still chairman. A dyslexic, he has given to Yale Center for Dyslexia and Creativity, the Hawaii Meth Project and mental health programs for young adults at the U. of California, San Francisco through his Charles and Helen Schwab Foundation.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Charles Schwab', 'uri': 'companies/charles-schwab', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chair of copper miner Kazakhmys and former member of Kazakh President Nazarbayev's political council, sold 11% stake in company to Kazakh government entity in October, raising concerns government will attempt to influence company strategy. President Nazarbayev's brother, Bolat Nazarbayev, also serves on company's supervisory council. Currrently listed on Kazakh and London exchanges; mulling listing in Hong Kong. A descendent of Koreans forced by Stalin to move to Kazakhstan, Kim joined Kazakhmys during Khazakstan's early 1990s privatization wave.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of the founder of Danish toymaker Lego. Ran company for 25 years before stepping down in 2004 after several years of losses; remains its sole owner and vice chairman of the board. Thanks to restructuring and sale of assets such as its four Legoland amusement parks,  world's fourth-largest toymaker by sales ($3billion), has been profitable since 2006;  net earnings were up 69% in 2010, as it gained share in a recovering market. Initiated the Next Generation Foundation, focused on children's development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded retailer Metro AG in 1964, which now has $88 billion in sales, with the Schmidt-Ruthenbeck and Haniel families. Beisheim still owns some 10% of the publicly traded company. Manages Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, which invests in Internet and technology companies. In Berlin, owns Beisheim Center, a high-end complex with apartments, office buildings, two five star hotels, shops and cafes. Widower with no children. Has homes in Switzerland, Paris and Germany's Rottach-Eggern. Sports fan supports several foundations that mainly fund athletic programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Public Bank, now Malaysia's third-largest banking group. Group also owns one of the largest private mutual fund management companies in the country, is reportedly bidding for an Islamic insurance license and has bagged a brokerage license in Cambodia. He is also a big shareholder of LPI Capital, a general insurance company in Malaysia and Singapore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over family's shoe business. Turned it into Europe's largest shoe retailer, Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH, a household name throughout Europe. Also owns U.S. retail chains Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway. Son Heinrich runs daily operations. Committed philanthropist, regularly donates large sums to missionary and humanitarian organizations, including a program to help leprosy victims in India, which he visits annually. Holds the Martin-Luther Foundation's "Luther Rose" award for his social and charitable work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund Caxton Associates has reportedly had only one down year since its inception in 1983. Up 10% in 2010. Assets under management: $10.5 billion. Son of a trade unionist, he abandoned Harvard Ph.D. in economics; drove a New York City taxi, studied harpsichord at Julliard. Started trading soybeans at age 31; turned $3,000 he borrowed on his credit card into $45,000. Didn't hedge, lost half the profits and learned lesson about risk. Chairman of Julliard, he has donated 140 scores and sketches by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms to the school.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Dalian Wanda Group, one of China's largest owners of commercial properties.  In a flurry of openings in the month of December alone, Wanda opened five "Wanda Plazas" in different cities, plus two hotels on picturesque Hainan Island. Wanda also owns one of the country's largest movie theater operations. Wang is active socially through the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and as a vice chairman of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce. Pledged $150 million to reconstruct a Buddhist temple in Nanjing last November. Disagreed with our estimate of his wealth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest individual shareholder of Nintendo, the video game console manufacturer he created from playing card-maker run by his grandfather. Ran the company for 55 years before retiring in 2005. Stock down 5% over the past year as competition from likes of Apple, with its games for iPods and iPhones, chip away at market share; strong yen also hurting sales. Company looking to boost profits with the February launch of its 3D-capable handheld game players in Japan; units scheduled to go on sale in U.S. and Europe in March. Bought baseball team Seattle Mariners in 1992, later transferred ownership to Nintendo's U.S. unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Russia's largest private bank, Alfa Bank, which sits within the Alfa Group conglomerate controlled by fellow billionaires Mikhail Fridman, German Khan and Alexei Kuzmichev. Bank plans to merge with Yekaterinburg-based Severnaya Kazna. Grew up in Moscow, attended a well-regarded high school for the city's elite and prestigious Moscow State University. Later worked at the Institute for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. In 1989 went to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; tapped to be minister of foreign economic relations two years later. In 1994 met Alfa Group's Mikhail Fridman and soon became a shareholder of Alfa-Bank. Owns the largest private collection of Russian art in Russia. Keeps the most valuable pieces of art in the UK.

name: Billionaires
bio: With a recent purchase of 1 million acres of land in Maine and New Hampshire, Malone beats out Ted Turner for the title America's largest private land owner; he has total of just over 2.1 million acres. after Stepped down as interim Chairman of the Board at Live Nation in February and unwound his 17-year partnership at InterActiveCorp with Barry Diller in December 2010.  Cable crusader swooped in with $530 million to save Sirius XM from bankruptcy 2009; beat out rival media maven Charles Ergen's Dish Network. Cash injection gave Liberty Media 40% of satellite radio operator. Partner of TCI cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996) sold nation's largest cable company in 1999 to AT&T for $54 billion. Today his Liberty Media owns stakes in cell phones (Sprint Nextel), Internet (Expedia), pro baseball's Atlanta Braves.

name: Billionaires
bio: Montana magnate gets the majority of his wealth from Montana Rail Link railroad, Montana Resources copper and molybdenum mine -- and cash. Also owns largest tug and barge fleet in British Columbia and a stake in marine shipping firm Seaspan. As a child he  bounced around among relatives after his parents divorced. By age 14, he was making his own money doing odd jobs like boxing groceries and shining shoes. Started his own construction firm at age 29. Built reputation on rehabilitation of Butte copper mine, purchased in 1986, and turnaround of bankrupt Morrison Knudsen in 1996. His Dennis and Phyllis Washington Foundation funds 500 scholarships annually to the University of Montana. It also donated 64,000 acre ranch in Oregon to Young Life, a Christian youth ministry that runs a summer camp for over 1,000 teenagers weekly; a middle school camp featuring a water slide park is scheduled for completion this summer. Spends most of his days refurbishing Attessa IV, a 333-ft. yacht with swimming pool. Scheduled to be completed summer of 2011 after recently leaving dry dock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father's one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; built it into Power Corp., a $33 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant. Company owns Montreal daily, La Presse, as well as 6 other newspapers in Quebec and Ontario. Acquired U.S. money manager Putnam Investments in 2007. Power Financial includes life insurer Great-West Lifeco and Investors Group, Canada's largest mutual fund company. Key shareholder of Chinese conglomerate Citic Pacific, French oil giant Total. Sons Paul Jr. and Andre groomed to take over some day. Collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec. Family is friends with French President Nicolas Sarkozy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns the Tengelmann Group, one of Germany's largest food retailers; also 41% of U.S. loss-making grocery chain A&P. The 152-year-old A&P  continues to focus its operations on eight states in the Northeast, after having pulled out of New Orleans and the Midwest in late 2007.   Haub retired in 2000 and turned over reins to sons Karl-Erivan, Georg and Christian. Big fan of the U.S., owns extensive land in Washington State,  a buffalo ranch in Wyoming and a ski resort in the Cascades called Sun Mountain Lodge. Small town celebrity in Tacoma, Wash., thanks to his contribution to the town's revitalization.

name: Billionaires
bio: With $120 in savings, he and 3 brothers got start raising quail, chickens in 1982. Their Hope Group became one of China's largest makers of animal feed. Siblings split in 1995; Yongxing moved to Shanghai. His privately held East Hope Group is still one of China's biggest feed producers, making 100 types. Though core feed business has done well amid rising demand for meat in China, company has over time increased focus on industrial materials including aluminum and plastics. The company last year announced plans to build a grade A office tower in Chengdu. Only son Shawn, a graduate of the University of Southern California, is heir apparent; his wife is from Texas.Along with billionaire brother Liu Yonghao,

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother William leads sourcing firm Li & Fung. Shares have gained approximately a third in the past year amid business agreements with Wal-Mart and sportswear firm Li Ning. Bought Jimlar, which makes Calvin Klein shoes, and Oxford Apparel. Merged its logistics arm, Integrated Distribution Services, into firm in November 2010. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take helm 1970s. Victor, a U.S. citizen, is chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: A big year for Hunt, as the $3.8 billion liquefied natural gas plant he built in Peru is finally operational. Hunt owns 50% of the project, alongside Repsol and others. Project generated some $350 million in royalties to the government in the first half, but politicians are threatening to hike the royalty rate on exported gas. Such a move would hurt Hunt, who also has big stakes in the gas fields that will supply the plant. Taking such risks are nothing new for him. The youngest son of famed wildcatter H.L. Hunt (d. 1974) who was said to be the inspiration for J.R. Ewing character on TV's Dallas, he took his share of inheritance and went his own way, forming Hunt Oil. (He had no part in family's $4.4 billion sale of Hunt Petroleum to XTO in 2007.) In addition to Peru and U.S., he's been wildcatting in Yemen, where he owns 17% of an LNG plant operated by France's Total. On poor terms with government: Hunt and ExxonMobil recently filed for arbitration against Yemen over rights to develop Ma'rib oil block. Could sell: Russia's Gazprom offered $1 billion for the stake last summer. Still plenty to work on back home: Hunt has massive real estate holdings around Dallas, ranches with 400,000 acres across the west, and a fast-growing electric transmission business in Texas run by son and heir apparent Hunter Hunt. He also owns such underperforming assets as power plants in Massachusetts and New York and an oil refinery in Alabama.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Austrian retail chain Billa, sold out to German REWE group in 1996. Invested proceeds in Austrian real estate and is now one of the country's largest private real estate owners. Assets include 5-star Hotel Radisson in Salzburg, the historic building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange, and four palaces in Vienna. Former jazz pianist whose stage name was Charlie Walker has an authorized biography: Karl Wlaschek: A Success Story.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother Victor leads sourcing firm Li & Fung. Shares have gained a third in the past year amid business agreements with Wal-Mart and sportswear firm Li Ning. Bought Jimlar, which makes Calvin Klein shoes, and Oxford Apparel. Merged its logistics arm, Integrated Distribution Services, into firm in November. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take the helm in the 1970s. William is executive director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate tycoon. Portfolio includes 5,000 apartments in LeFrak City and a $3 billion mini-city in Newport, N.J. with 16 million square feet of commercial, residential, retail space. Grandfather Harry began developing real estate 1901. Father, Sam, expanded in New York City and New Jersey; built LeFrak City in Queens in 1959. Richard joined family business 1970s, became chairman after dad died in 2003. LeFrak Energy, which owns interests in 851 onshore producing oil and gas wells, opened Houston office in August 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Westfield shopping mall chain, one of the world's biggest listed retail property groups. Family owns 8% of stock; Frank Lowy is executive chairman, sons Steven and Peter are joint managing directors and son David runs the family's private global hedge fund. Began 50 years ago with one delicatessen in Sydney, after Czech-born Lowy fled post-war Europe; now owns 119 malls in Australia, New Zealand, the US and Britain. In November announced spin-off of 50% ownership of malls in Australia and New Zealand into a new listed trust, Westfield Retail, in attempt to lift stagnant share price. He's locked in a fierce battle with U.S. tax authorities over his alleged misuse of a Liechtenstein tax haven. Chairman of Football Federation Australia. Sons Steven and Peter are in the business and son David runs the family's private hedge fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of legendary media tycoon Kerry Packer inherited $5 billion empire after dad's death in 2005.  The Packer name had been linked to free-to-air television in Australia for decades, but he appeared to abandon the sector. Quick to put personal stamp on business, had spun off media assets and bet on gaming business Crown, which started trading in December 2007. However, Packer shocked the market in October 2010 by buying a $280 million stake in broadcaster Ten Network, then soon after selling half the stake to Rupert Murdoch's son Lachlan Murdoch  and getting a board seat.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold most of his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. With remaining assets built Banco Alfa, now Brazil's 23rd largest bank. Also owns Agropalma, Latin America's biggest palm oil producer (now moving into biodiesel), and C&C, a chain of home improvement stores. Today is mostly retired, reportedly owns 150 pure-bred horses. Trained as a doctor and practiced medicine for two years. When his father died suddenly, Faria took his place running Banco Real.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Bangkok street vendor, he made his fortune selling inexpensive beer and whiskey. Controls Thai Bev, Thailand's largest brewer and distiller, best known for its Chang Beer.  Took his company public in Singapore in 2006 after Buddhist protesters stopped the listing on Thailand's stock exchange.His privately held TCC Land owns Bangkok's famous tech-mall Pantip Plaza, Hotel Plaza Athenee in Manhattan. Also owns other hotels in Asia, the U.S. and Australia, residential, commercial and retail buildings in Singapore and Thailand. Recently made unsuccessful bid for Carrefour's Thai operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Navy vet teamed with Paul Mitchell to launch the shampoo company with $700 in 1980 while living in car; sales now top $900 million. Started tequila maker Patron Spirits with Martin Crowley 1989; friends like Clint Eastwood and Wolfgang Puck introduced drink to Hollywood crowd. Sells more than 2 million cases annually. Philanthropist supporting Grow Appalachia, helping families create self-sustainable gardens to fight obesity and poverty. Last year his salon schools gathered hair clippings to make oil-absorbing buoys for BP spill.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marcel Merieux, a former laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur. Founded BioMerieux in 1974, which had roots in his father's first laboratory, Institut Merieux. Now chairman of the $1.7 billion (sales) company, which specializes in infectious disease diagnostics that test for diseases such as HIV and tuberculosis. Eldest son Rodolphe was killed in 1996 at age 27 when TWA flight 800 crashed over Long Island. Second son, Christophe, who was expected to take over from his father, died of cardiac failure in 2006 at age 39. Third son Alexandre, 32, is a member of the board. Family supports the Merieux Foundation, which helps developing countries combat infectious diseases.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers own almost 16% of retailer Metro. Also own Travel Charm, a chain of 12 luxury hotels and spas in Germany, Austria and Italy. Together fund the Mercator Foundation, which helps immigrant children in Germany improve their language and professional skills through extracurricular study programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met lifelong pal and Amway cofounder Jay Van Andel (d. 2004) in high school when DeVos offered Jay 25 cents a week for a ride to school. Entrepreneurial duo opened drive-in diner after Richard's 2-year stint in the Air Force. Began selling all-purpose cleaner to friends, family, door-to-door in 1959. Reorganized as Alticor in 2000. Today 3 million salespeople peddle its personal care and home products in over 80 countries. Sales: $8.4 billion. Richard retired 1993; youngest son Doug is president. Heart transplant recipient generously supports hospitals, colleges, arts organizations and Christian causes. Owns NBA's Orlando Magic.

name: Billionaires
bio: The daredevil entrepreneur won't just be taking tourists to space when Virgin Galactic launches next year. Branson announced that he'll make room on his rocket plane for scientists, who will carry out research and experiments. The Virgin boss continues to expand his empire on land as well as in space: in November, he launched a magazine exclusively for the iPad called 'Project'. He and fellow billionaire Vinod Khosla backed biofuels start-up Gevo, which raised $107 million in its February IPO. He also launched a US nonprofit, the Carbon War Room, aiming to cut carbon emissions by getting businesses like shipping giant Maersk to pledge CO2 transparency.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped then husband Amancio Ortega make dressing gowns and lingerie in their home. It became one of world's most successful apparel manufacturers, Inditex, which also owns Zara retail stores. Couple divorced years ago, but Mera still holds 7% stake in now $15.8 billion (sales) business. At time of Inditex's public offering also got $600 million in cash, which she's invested in a Spanish film production outfit, a marine fish farming group, a company that looks for cancer treatments in compounds found in the sea, a hotel chain, and a maker of a fingerprinting identification system for newborns. Has received various awards for her contributions to Spanish society via her Paideia Foundation, which helps people with physical and mental disabilities.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: The Cadogan family fortune is on the rise again as the market for prime central London real estate recovers from its recession slump. The 8th Earl Cadogan heads the 300-year-old real estate trust, which owns 90 acres in London's Chelsea. The posh neighborhood is home to luxury retailers like Jimmy Choo and Fendi as well as high-end restaurants. Began his career at merchant banker Schroder Wagg. Took on the management of family's property portfolio in 1974.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of South America's most prominent businessmen oversees a diversified empire with interests in Venezuelan television stations, telecom, a regional brewery and a baseball team. With U.S. billionaire Jerry Perenchio and Mexican billionaire Emilio Azcarraga, sold U.S. Spanish-language TV network Univision to a private equity consortium led by U.S. billionaire Haim Saban for $700 million in 2007.  After locking horns with Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez, Venevision, his Venezuelan broadcaster, is avoiding politics these days, preferring to concentrate on entertainment content, including hugely popular Latin American soap operas. Cisneros and his wife are familiar figures in high society, hobnobbing with former presidents like George H. W. Bush, designers and fellow billionaires. Boasts an extensive collection of Latin American art: one favorite is an Amazonian landscape by German artist Frank W. Post. His foundation promotes education and protection of indigenous people in the Amazon basin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Rowling joined father Reese's (d. 2001) Tana Oil & Gas in 1980. Company had scored big finds in south Texas, shallow gulf waters. In 1989 he sold some properties to Texaco (now Chevron) for $480 million. Sold more to Unocal (also bought by Chevron) a decade later. In 1996 bought the Omni Hotel chain for $500 million, now the biggest part of fortune, with 45 locations. In 2007 traded a chunk of his Chevron shares back to the company in exchange for some drilling prospects. Also owns Gold's Gym, Mexican retailer Waldo's, and big stake in PG&E. Not everything works out: In 2008 invested millions alongside Carl Icahn in struggling Guaranty Financial Group. Lost it all when company collapsed under bad mortgage securities.

name: Billionaires
bio: China native's family moved to Taiwan after the Communist revolution. After college there, Wang earned an MBA from Southeastern Louisiana University and made his first millions in the U.S. in the insurance and real estate businesses. The big money came from China: He set up Golden Eagle International Group in 1992 and has turned it into one of China's largest upscale department store chains. One-third increase in share prices has helped to bump up his wealth in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned Formula One racing into globally popular sport. Sold his F1 stake in 2005 to CVC Capital Partners, then  reinvested with CVC to make new joint company that now controls 100% of Formula One Group. With his 5.3% remaining stake Ecclestone, 80, still runs the $6 billion empire. American driver Zak Brown reportedly in line to succeed him but Ecclestone may not retire anytime soon. Got divorced in 2009 from former model and his wife of 24 years, Slavica, though it's unlikely split resulted in huge payout: wealth is tied up in offshore Bambino trust for his two socialite daughters, Tamara and Petra. Reportedly spent more than $160 million buying them posh houses in London last year. Increased his stake in premier league soccer club Queens Park Rangers to 62% in December 2010; that month was also mugged with his girlfriend outside his Hyde Park offices. Thieves took a watch engraved with his name and left him with a black eye.

name: Billionaires
bio: Via his Digicel Group, cell phone tycoon operates in dozens of Caribbean islands, Honduras, Haiti, Fiji, Tonga and Papua New Guinea, braving coups, riots and threats of nationalization. Endears his firm to masses by cutting prices, donating to local causes. Recently funded the restoration of Hatiti's century-old Iron Market with $12 million of his own money. In 2010, Digicel bought out sister company Digicel Pacific for $825 million. Companies boast a combined 10.75 million subscribers. O'Brien's other holdings: radio stations, online recruiting sites in China, Portuguese resort. Son of a human rights activist created nonprofit Front Line to fly activists out of harm's way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime head of shipper Orient Overseas International, which has lately benefitted from global economic recovery and higher shipping rates. The company has 280 offices in 55 countries. Chee Chen shares fortune with brother Tung Chee Hwa, former Hong Kong chief executive. Holds an undergraduate degree from the University of Liverpool and a graduate degree from MIT. He is a member of the board at BOC Hong Kong (Holdings) Limited, Cathay Pacific Airways, Wing Hang Bank, Sing Tao News Corp., PetroChina, Zhejiang Expressway and U-Ming Marine Transport.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits, Bass Enterprises Production. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson in 1959. Passed it on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production is planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Robert runs private equity firm Oak Hill Capital Partners, whose third fund raised $3.8 billion in capital commitments in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest individual shareholder of IT software maker CA (formerly Computer Associates). Sold data processing firm to University Computing 1968; that company bought by Computer Associates 1987. Still holds 24% stake. Also owns Automobil-und Motoren AG (AMAG), Switzerland's main importer of Volkswagen, Seat, Skoda and Audi. Transferred ownership of his Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland that boasts of 110 horses, many of them race winners, with names like Simple Exchange, Media Puzzle, Refuse to Bend and Go and Go to his daughter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ambitious brothers have been on buying binge since selling their stake in pharma major Ranbaxy Laboratories to Daiichi Sankyo for $2 billion in 2008.  They bought Singapore hospital chain Parkway Holdings but sold out after counter offer from Khazanah, Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund, pocketing $90 million. They bought a diagnostics unit from fellow billionaire Ajay Piramal for $130 million merging it with their Super Religare Labs which they plan to list.  Other purchases include US private equity firm Landmark Partners and Australian dental clinics chain. Brothers are reportedly mulling starting a regional airline. Malvinder is a keen photographer

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over tiny screw business from his father at age 19. Turned it into $11.5 billion (sales) Wurth Group, maker of fasteners; company also has interests in a bank and solar energy firm. Daughter Bettina heads the supervisory board; son-in-law Markus runs group's specialty building products division. Now retired, Wurth rides a Harley-Davidson and has a  professional pilot's license. Vast art collection includes works by Emil Nolde, Ernst, Leger, Alfred Hrdilicka, Edvard Munch and Pablo Picasso. Holds honorary doctorate in art history from the University of Palermo. Owns a 280-foot yacht, Vibrant Curiosity..

name: Billionaires
bio: Intel cofounder focusing on philanthropy; his Gordon & Betty Moore Foundation awards approximately $200 million annually to support environmental conservation and fundamental science, plus science and technology museums and nursing care in the San Francisco Bay area. Latest project: largest donor to construction of the world's biggest telescope, known as the Thirty Meter Telescope, in his part-time resident state of Hawaii. Has donated $50 million to designs and pledged $200 million for the telescope's construction. Chairman emeritus of Intel studied chemistry at UC Berkeley, earned Ph.D. in chemistry and physics from Caltech. Cofounded Intel in 1968; ignited PC revolution. Chief exec until 1987. Four decades ago came up with Moore's Law: computing power will double every 18 months (later updated to 2 years).
title: Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Intel', 'uri': 'companies/intel', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Yang Huiyan is the main shareholder in Country Garden Holdings of Guangzhou, one of China's largest property developers. The company's chairman is Yang's father, Yeung Kwok Keung, who transferred his holding to her before the company went public in Hong Kong in 2007. Wealth is up this year amid strong sales in 2010, owing to the company's large land bank. Yang graduated from Ohio State University with a degree in marketing and logistics. According to Country Garden, she is primarily responsible for the formulation of development strategies.  Rarely seen in public.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Manuel and Placido, shares a fortune gained from selling their stake in retailer Cifra to Wal-Mart's Mexican arm in 1997. Jeronimo is said to live a quiet life in Los Angeles. Manuel has been involved in real estate development. Placido collects art and has owned a chain of restaurants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of United Overseas Bank, Singapore's largest bank, which his father founded in 1935.  He ran it for 33 years until 2007 when son Wee Ee Chong became chief executive. Also has landholdings in Singapore through privately held Kheng Leong. Reportedly bought property in Beverly Hills with view to building luxury residences there. Singapore listed Haw Par, which family owns nearly one quarter of, makes iconic Chinese ointment Tiger Balm. Shares fortune with five children. Avid tennis player.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turkey's richest man chairs mobile phone company Turkcell, the only Turkish company that trades on the New York Stock Exchange, sporting a recent $12 billion market capitalization. He fell off the billionaires list in 2003, due to the enormous debt load at two of his banks, Pamukbank and Yapi Kredi. In November 2006 he sold his Yapi Kredi Bank to Koc Group, a large Turkish family conglomerate that has spawned several billionaire fortunes. Karamehmet re-joined the billionaires list in 2006 and maintained his billionaire status ever since.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli Hollywood producer announced extension of partnership with fellow mogul Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. until March 2022. Recently released "Love and Other Drugs" with Anne Hathaway and is working on "Now" starring Justin Timberlake. Business student and professional soccer player successfully transformed family's bankrupt fertilizer company into a $125 million business with interests in agriculture, aerospace, animal health products, plastic, fiber optics and pharmaceuticals. Later produced such classic movies as "Pretty Woman," "Fight Club" and "Mr. and Mrs. Smith." Close friend of Shimon Peres has vowed to help bring about peace in Middle East. Has extensive art collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of William Ziff Jr (d. 2006) who built the Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). After selling 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994, father retired to Florida. Daniel and his brothers Dirk and Robert, who inherited the fortune, have reinvested the proceeds via New York City-based Ziff Brothers Investments. Money is invested across hedge funds, real estate, debt, equities, commodities. Brothers provided seed money to fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for 10% stake 1994; Och-Ziff public 2 years ago, shares up 12% over last twelve months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oldest son of William Ziff Jr (d. 2006) who built the Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). After selling 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994, father retired to Florida. Along with his brothers Daniel and Robert, Dirk reinvested the proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments. Money is invested across hedge funds, real estate, debt, equities, commodities. Brothers provided seed money to fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for 10% stake 1994; Och-Ziff public two years ago, shares up 12% in last 12 months. Dirk is married to a former Forbes reporter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his Olav Thon Gruppen, the country's largest private real estate company, owns 425 properties in Norway and 25 abroad. The portfolio includes 61 shopping malls as well as office buildings, retail stores, hotels (7,000 rooms) and several Oslo restaurants and pubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of William Ziff Jr (d. 2006) who built the Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). After selling 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994, father retired to Florida. Along with brothers Dirk and Daniel, Robert reinvested the proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments. Today money is invested across hedge funds, real estate, debt, equities, commodities. Brothers provided seed money to fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for 10% stake 1994; Och-Ziff public 2 years ago, shares up 12% over last 12 months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Legendary buyout pioneer will have a new building at Columbia's business school named after him following a $100 million pledge. Among recent notable deals: invested in Dalmia Cement in May to form largest private cement company in India; leading deal to buy Del Monte Foods. Kravis founded KKR with cousin George Roberts and Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg in 1976. Firm was one of first to use leverage in acquisitions. Two years later, KKR orchestrated $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco; deal became basis of the bestselling book Barbarians at the Gate. Patron of the Metropolitan Museum of Art - has a wing named after him. Apparently sold $50 million in art at auction this fall including a 1913 cubist painting by Juan Gris. His economist wife Marie-Josée is president of the Museum of Modern Art board of trustees.
title: Co-Chair and Co-CEO
employment: {'name': 'KKR and Co', 'title': 'Co-Chair and Co-CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of carbide industrial cutting tool manufacturer Iscar, sold out near top of market in 2006 to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, which paid $4 billion for an 80% stake; retains remaining stake with son Eitan as president. Through his four industrial parks Wertheimer seeds high-tech Israeli startups including Blades Technology, a maker of jet-engine blades. After fleeing Nazi Germany, the high school dropout joined the Palmach, the elite strike force of the Haganah, the pre-state defense organization. Former Israeli parliament member supports joint Israeli-Palestinian businesses. Was honored with Oslo Business for Peace Award.

name: Billionaires
bio: One-time tailor has thrived as an entrepreneur amid consumer spending boom in China.  Zhou's main retail brand Metersbonwe targets the young; his second, Me & City, goes after an older crowd.  Zhou aims to generate 10 billion yuan, or $1.5 billion, in total sales annual within five years, compared with 5.2 billion yuan in 2009.  He'd better run quick: Chinese rival Semir, whose founder Qiu Guanghe debuts on our billionaires list this year, expects to IPO in March and has grand plans of his own.  Metersbonwe launched online store www.ibango.com at China's popular online shopping website Taobao in November.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded temporary employment agency Randstad Holding in 1960. Took company public in 1990. Randstad merged with Dutch group Vedior in 2008 to form world's second-largest temp agency (still called Randstad Holding), with revenues of more than $17 billion. Although retired, Goldschmeding remains vice chairman of the supervisory board and still owns 44%. Enjoys sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Singapore resident since 2008, got his start in 1986, when he and brother Christopher, also a billionaire, sold their parents' retailing business to invest in Hong Kong real estate. They cofounded investment firm Sovereign Global, focusing on emerging economies in Russia, Latin America, Asia and Eastern Europe. After they split in 2006, he started Orient Global in Singapore, which invests in emerging markets. Renamed it R.F. Chandler last year. Has $100 million fund aimed at improving education in the developing world; established Freedom to Create prize in 2008 to foster artistic expression.

name: Billionaires
bio: A Hong Kong court declared Chen Din Hwa, who has Alzheimer's, incapable of "managing and administering his properties.Since then a court-appointed committee tapped daughter Vivien to head his privately-held property developer Nan Fung, passing over her older sister Angela, a U.S. resident. Chen's wife, Yang Foo Oi, 85, is suing Vivien, acusing her daughter of exercising undue influence. She even went so far as to seek a divorce from her ailing husband, a move widely seen as intervening on Angela's behalf. Court hearings are slated to begin later this year. For now, Vivien continues to run the group, with help from her long-time partner Frank Seto, who is vice chairman; it is expanding in China and has a prime office project in the center of Shanghai,

name: Billionaires
bio: Became sole owner of  Helm AG when father Hermann, the company's founder, died in June 2010. The $7 billion  (sales) company is one of the world's leading independent chemicals marketing enterprises with interests in trading, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. Has been chairman of executive board since 1984, when his father retired. Reportedly enjoys golf, kayaking and building models.

name: Billionaires
bio: Russian parliamentary deputy since 1999 whose wealth comes from 30% stake in iron ore and steel company Metalloinvest. A private company, it's mulling an IPO. Like former business partner and fellow billionaire Lev Kvetnoi, was born in a small settlement near Moscow and studied at the same school of athletics, the Institute of Physical Culture. Later worked for Moscow's MontazhSpetsBank. With Kvetnoi joined billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metallurgical business; Kvetnoi was sent to Oskol Metal Works, while Skoch went to Lebedinsky Mining. Later Usmanov joined the two firms with a third to create the Metalloinvest conglomerate. Kvetnoi sold out, but Skoch remains a partner. Sponsors a literary competition for young authors called Debut.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left his medical practice in South Africa to join identical twin brother, Thomas, in founding generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986; turned it into Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In 2005 sold the business as well as their 68% stake of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. Now brothers run Santo Holding, which invests in the German biotech sector, in particular companies involved in cancer research. Brothers have established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Said to love sailing, golf and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With identical twin, Andreas, founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986, eventually building it into  Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In 2005 sold business and their 68% of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. Brothers now manage their Santo Holding, which invests in the German biotech sector, with a focus on cancer research.  Brothers established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Is said to be the more extroverted of the twins. Reportedly collects modern art and Swiss watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Belle International, China's biggest women's footwear retailer that benefitted from increase in China's retail spending last year. Tang's wealth has nearly doubled in the past year, due in part to a 50% increase in the company's share price. In addition, we have indentified new information about his holdings. Belle's own brands now account for 55% of sales, up from 52% last year. Firm hired more than 8,000 people in the 6 months ending June 2010. Shares fortune with daughter Tang Ming Wai, group's executive director; son Tang King Loy is a Belle director. Tang serves as the chairman of the Federation of Hong Kong Footwear.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last summer the tabloids gleefully hounded the media maven after a recording of him trying to coax the identity of a source from a Daily Beast reporter leaked on the Internet. He's had better luck with his investments over the past year, as shares of both Viacom and CBS recovered more than 20%. Refinanced $1.46 billion of debt in May 2009, sold $1 billion or so in Viacom and CBS shares. World War II vet, Harvard Law grad, took over family's Northeast Theater Corp., acquired control of Viacom 1987, spun off CBS in 2006.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father, opened Rimi discount supermarket in the late 1970s, later partnering with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket giant Royal Ahold. In 2004 Hagen exercised an option to sell his remaining 20% stake in the venture, forcing Ahold to pony up $1 billion. Bought into department store chain Steen & Strom, then took the whole thing private in late 2007. Chairman of consumer goods company Orkla also invests in real estate and local companies through his Canica group.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Wolfgang, inherited a fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. All except Joachim, who died, have separate billion-dollar fortunes. Helped push out brother Gunter and sister Daniela in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud. Now holds 35% stake in $4.5 billion (sales)  Maxingvest AG, formerly called Tchibo, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, Tchibo. Group also has 50% stake in Beiersdorf AG, which makes Nivea skin care products.  Michael and Wolfgang are on the management board. Brother Joachim died in 2008 after being  hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake; left his share of the family fortune to a charitable foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Michael (all billionaires except Joachim, who is deceased), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Holds 35% stake in $4.5 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, now Maxingvest AG, makers of Tchibo, a well-known German coffee brand. Group also has 50% stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. Wolfgang and Michael are on the management board. Brother Joachim died in 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a lake; left his share of the fortune to a charitable foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rebound of Macau's gambling industry helped boost Galaxy Entertainment's profits and share price. May get another bump soon from the opening of long anticipated resort on the Cotai peninsula in Macau, fitted with 2,200 rooms, hundreds of feng shui-friendly gaming tables and the world's largest rooftop wave pool. Family owns the InterContinental hotel in Hong Kong; also owns 3 Stanford hotels in Hong Kong, rest in the U.S. Also leads property firm K. Wah International. With only an elementary school education, got start helping his grandmother run a store that sold food staples. By 1950 was buying construction equipment from Japan and reselling it to Southeast Asia. Received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Academy of Hospitality Sciences in 2007. Son Francis Lui is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second wife and now widow of Reinhard Mohn who died at 88 in 2009. She and her family inherited a fortune based on a 23% stake in $22 billion  (sales)  Bertelsmann AG, one of the world's leading media conglomerates. Bertelsmann owns assets included the RTL Group, the largest European broadcaster; Random House, world's largest book-publishing group; and Gruner + Jahr, Europe's biggest magazine publisher with such titles as The Financial Times Deutschland and Der Stern. Liz, as she is known, has been actively involved in the company for years; as a member of the supervisory board represented her husband after he retired; also vice CEO of the Bertelsmann Foundation which owns 77% of the company. President of a foundation that seeks to prevent strokes, which she founded in 1992.  In 2003 she and her husband were awarded the Teddy-Kollek prize, given out by the Jerusalem Foundation for people who have actively promoted German-Jewish understanding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Original partner at legendary private equity firm KKR and still active there. Among recent notable deals was an investment in Dalmia Cement in May 2010 to form largest private cement company in India. Roberts made partner at Bear Stearns at age 29; co-founded KKR with cousin Henry Kravis and Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg in 1976. Firm was one of the first to use leverage in acquisitions. Kohlberg retired in 1987. Two years later, KKR orchestrated $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco; deal became basis of the bestselling book Barbarians at the Gate. He is a founder of REDF, a San Francisco non-profit that uses venture philanthropy to create job opportunities. Recently remarried.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Keyence, leading supplier of sensors and measuring instruments to small-factory owners, midsize companies looking to automate production. Also caters to high-tech hobbyists, producing  radio-controlled model cars. Company reported surge in sales and net profits for the nine months through December 2010; stock is up 16% over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires) built publicly-traded Eurasian Natural Resources Corp., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. Now extending company's global reach: in Africa added assets from Democratic Republic of Congo to South Africa; iron ore in Brazil. Subsidiaries of ENRC were named in a filing that challenged purchase of copper and cobalt operations in Congo; previous owner alleged improper seizure and resale by government. ENRC stated assets were fairly obtained; case has not reached court. Uzbekistan native lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals in Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires) built publicly-traded Eurasian Natural Resources Co., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. It's now extending company's global reach: in Africa added assets from Democratic Republic of Congo to South Africa; iron ore in Brazil. Subsidiaries of ENRC were named in a challenge to the purchase of copper and cobalt operations in Congo; previous owner alleged improper seizure and resale by government. ENRC stated due diligence indicated assets were fairly obtained; case has not reached court.  Native of Kyrgyzstan moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. Devout Muslim with 6 sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Patokh Chodiev and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires) built publicly traded Eurasian Natural Resources Corp., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. Now extending company's global reach: in Africa added assets from Democratic Republic of Congo to South Africa; iron ore in Brazil. Subsidiaries of ENRC were named in filing challenging purchase of copper and cobalt operations in Congo; previous owner alleged improper seizure and resale by government. ENRC stated due diligence indicated assets were fairly obtained; case has not reached court. Native of Kyrgyzstan studied literature; later moved to Moscow to start a trading business with Chodiev and Ibragimov. Early on obtained Israeli citizenship and has been very active in Jewish causes. In September caught on board boat off Turkish coast which Turkish authorities allege was scene of a sex party and under-age prostitution; spokesperson stated Machkevich was not involved in any immoral or criminal activity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Niel joins the list thanks to his stake in Iliad SA, a major player in the French telecom market. In 1984, while still in high school, he established Minitel, France's forerunner to the internet. He launched the country's first internet provider, WorldNet, in 1993 and sold it for $50 million just before the internet bubble burst. Three years later he launched Free/Freebox, bundling internet, phone and TV via ADSL. Iliad went public in 2004; Niel now holds over 62%. He also owns a stake in distinguished but struggling French newspaper Le Monde.

name: Billionaires
bio: On the verge of taking hospital giant HCA public for the third time in a deal that will value the chain at $40 billion if the market cooperates. Former Air Force flight surgeon who started HCA with his father in 1968 took the company private in 2006 in a $33 billion buyout with help from KKR, Bain and Bank of America. Restructured the board, adding his two sons, and when the company issued a $2.2 billion cash dividend earlier this year, pocketed $400 million. Offering was announced soon after HCA ended its oversight agreement with the federal government, which had been in place since the company made a record Medicare fraud settlement in 2003. Invested $120 million to start construction on a hospital in Cixi, China, 100 miles south of Shanghai with the Chinese government as a minority partner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker continues as a nonexecutive director of his family's financial-services company, Schroders. Shares shot up 60% year on year, bolstering the fortune he shares with his sister Charmaine. Brother-in-law George Mallinckrodt is a longtime company director, with nephew Philip Mallinckrodt sitting on the company board. In spare time flies planes and breeds Middle White pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of ESL Investments flush from Sears rally, auto gains. Recently his hedge fund cashed out of Citigroup but added large positions in Gap, Cisco and Seagate Technology -- indicating a push into the technology sector. Lawyer's son who read corporate reports, financial textbooks in high school. Skull & Bones at Yale. Learned along side billionaire investor Daniel Och in risk arbitrage department at Goldman Sachs. Went solo 1988. Acquired Kmart in bankruptcy by buying its bonds. Merged with Sears, Roebuck; has served as chairman of combined company since 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, founder of $3.7 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany's leading publishing groups. Now owns more than 52% of company, which publishes more than 170 newspapers in 33 countries, including leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes foreign language editions of Forbes in Poland and Russia. Active in various philanthropic organizations; has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations. Also holder of the Federal Cross of Merit for her efforts to promote social, cultural and scientific dialogue worldwide.

name: Billionaires
bio: Metals and real estate investor mulled several deals this year, including selling his 20% stake in steel producer Metalloinvest --the majority of his fortune -- to buy assets from Inteko billionaire Yelena Baturina; rumors persist about both. In the 1990s was one of the best-known Russian businessmen, co-owner of aluminum plants and the bank Rossiyskiy Kredit. In 2000 sold all his holdings in Russia; laid low for four years. In 2004 made a comeback as co-owner of Metalloinvest with fellow billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Andrei Skoch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked at Drexel Burnham Lambert 1980s; formed buyout shop Apollo Global Management in 1990. Now moving to have this storied private equity firm conduct its own initial public offering. During the credit boom Apollo invested $8.1 billion of equity in 10 buyouts valued at $67.4 billion between March 2006 and December 2008. During the financial crisis things looked bleak, but Black and Apollo have staged a massive comeback, partly by investing in distressed debt, a longtime specialty. Philanthropic investments primarily focus on educational purposes (donating to universities and grade schools alike) as well as medical (founding the Melanoma Research Alliance with wife Debra and serving as chair). Prodigious art collector owns works by old masters, impressionists; serves on board of Metropolitan Museum of Art -helped fund a biography of Pablo Picasso; his father was chief executive of food company United Brands.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers control 19% of Bouygues Group, diversified industrial conglomerate founded by their father in 1952. Martin is chairman and chief executive; Olivier is deputy chief executive. $44.8 billion  (sales) company has interests in telecom, media, construction. Well known construction projects have included the Hassan II mosque in Casablanca, Morocco; University of Riyadh in Saudi Arabia; English Channel Tunnel; the Kwun Tong viaduct in Hong Kong; motorways in Hungary and  the Sydney CityRail airport link. Martin, who celebrated 20 years as head of Bouygues in September 2009, is close confidant of French President Nicolas Sarkozy and godfather of the president's son. Was awarded the Legion d'honneur in July 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of audio technology specialst Dolby Laboratories announced in December 2010 he would retire from the board and become Founder and Director Emeritus. Oregon-born sound sultan Dolby played clarinet as a child; became fascinated with reed vibrations. Hired by audio and video company Ampex at age 16, he played a key role developing electrical components of company's tape recording system. Marshall Scholar received Ph.D. in physics at England's University of Cambridge. Founded Dolby Laboratories in 1965, relocated to San Francisco in 1975. He eventually made his fortune with audio-processing systems that eliminate background noise. First inception was used on soundtrack of 1971 hit "A Clockwork Orange." Last June, Dolby debuted its latest 7.1 surround sound system with Toy Story 3. Took Dolby public in 2005. He holds over 50 patents. Enjoys skiing, sailing, and flying airplanes and helicopters.
title: Founder and director emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Denmark's best known business figures, he's earned the nickname "Duvet Larsen" because of his start selling bedding. His Danish home furnishing chain JYSK, a competitor to IKEA, made over $3 billion in sales last year. Larsen was brought up on a potato farm and apprenticed in a bedding store. Opened his first bedding warehouse in 1979; now has 1,750 furniture stores in 35 countries. Expanding worldwide:  opened first two stores in China last April.  The canny self-promoter stars in his own TV commercials; in 2004, sent a copy of his autobiography, "Hello, My Name is Lars Larsen,"  to all 2.4 million households in Denmark.

name: Billionaires
bio: The 93-year-old pledged $200 million of his fortune to UCLA this winter. His $8.5 billion gamble, City Center, opened in Las Vegas December 2009; it was the most expensive privately funded real estate deal in U.S. history. Stake in MGM worth $11 billion during 2007 highs; today about $1.5 billion. Eighth-grade dropout trained World War II fighter pilots; launched Trans International Airlines and sold for $104 million profit 1966. Bought and sold MGM Studios three times.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock price of his coal mining outfit Bayan Resources has tripled since its 2008 listing in Indonesia.  Company recently inked $270 million deal to acquire a controlling stake in an Australian miner. Born in Singapore, worked for his father's construction company in his twenties. Moved to Indonesia in 1972 seeking better prospects. Hit jackpot  with move into coal mining, buying his first mine in 1997, five years after becoming an Indonesian citizen. Also has stakes in Singapore-listed Manhattan Resources and Singapore HealthPartners. Animal lover has a zoo in Borneo with dozens of animals including gibbons, sun bears, peacocks and orangutans.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four sons of Fred Koch, who invented method of refining gasoline from heavy oil. Expanded oil industry in U.S.S.R. 1930s; returned home before WWII. Founded Koch Industries, passed to sons after death in 1967. With brother Frederick, sold stake to brothers Charles and David for $1.3 billion in 1983. Sued for more, case settled 2001. Created energy conglomerate Oxbow; produces petroleum coke, coal, steel, natural gas. Sales: $4.5 billion. Art and wine enthusiast suing collectors and auction house for selling him counterfeit vino; paid $500,000 for 4 bottles alleged to have belonged to Thomas Jefferson. Sailor; won the America's Cup in 1992.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Eurocement Group is Russia's cement largest producer. Cement empire includes 6% stake in Swiss cement maker Holcim, owned by Swiss billionaire Thomas Schmidheiny. In 1990s created Russia's largest coal-trading company, Rosuglesbyt. Later invested in cement, purchasing the Stern Cement plants and the cement business of fellow billionaire Elena Baturina's Inteko. Bought out partner Georgy Kransyansky to become the company's sole owner. Now investing in fertilizers; will have 9.4% stake in the combined Uralkaliy-Silvinit companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Following the death of their brother and business partner John at 78 in July 2010, brothers James and Arthur now control the secretive, privately held empire that includes oil refineries, gas stations, sawmills, publishing interests and potato farms. Family business was founded in 1881 by grandfather J.D. Irving; it now dominates the economy of New Brunswick and neighboring provinces. Their liquefied natural gas terminal, a joint venture with Repsol YPF of Spain, went into operation in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of Danaher is $900 million richer than a year ago thanks to surging value of company's stock. With brother Steven left father's real estate firm 1979, started buying small manufacturing companies during junk bond frenzy 1980s. Result: Equity Group Holdings, co-founded with billionaire brother.  Acquired crippled REIT, fused with other industrial companies to form Danaher; named after Montana stream where two brothers once fished for trout. Took industrial pump maker Colfax public 2008; his 21% stake is up 63% over the past year.  A trustee of National Gallery of Art, Mitchell, has amassed a valuable collection of post WWII art which includes works by Jeff  Koons, Alexander Calder, and Jackson Pollock, housed at Glenstone, a private museum in Potomac, Md.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Grupo Bimbo, the world's largest bread maker, which had 2009 revenues of US$8.6 billion. Bimbo makes Entenmann's cakes, Thomas English Muffins, Pan Bimbo and Mrs. Baird's breads. In late 2010 announced it would acquire the bakery business of Sara Lee for $959 million.  In 2009 it acquired the US operations of George Weston Foods. With his family, Servitje Montull owns 37% of Bimbo, founded by his father Lorenzo Servitje (age 92) and three others in 1954. Servitje Montull's uncle, Roberto Servitje Sendra, serves as company chairman. Servitje Montull has an MBA from Stanford University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined father's Hartz Mountain Pet Products at the age of 21; sold company for $350 million in 2000 to private equity firm J.W. Childs. Plowed proceeds into burgeoning real estate empire: today owns 38 million square feet of commercial, residential, retail property in New Jersey and New York. Picked up 700 residential units in Rye, N.Y. and Bergen County, N.J. last spring. In February 2010 art collector bought three 16th century knights of armor suits to decorate firm's Manhattan lobby. Son Emanuel oversees family's real estate empire, including hip Manhattan hotels Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand. Gave $30 million to alma mater NYU 1988; business school now bears his name.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the four pioneering Liu brothers that seized opportunity in the early phase of China's economic reforms in the 1980s by selling feed to farmers newly allowed by the Communist government to raise their own fowl and pigs. Liu founded the New Hope Group after the clan went their own ways in 1996. Today, the group is thriving as one of China's largest non-government agribusiness giants. Sichuan New Hope has a market cap worth $2.7 billion at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. Shares have risen recently on his plan to sell a large unlisted agriculture-related business to the listed company.

name: Billionaires
bio: South Indian media baron, owns regional broadcaster Sun TV Network which has 20 television channels that reach 95 million households. Also has 45 FM radio stations, two daily newspapers, four magazines. Expanded into aviation, acquiring budget domestic airline SpiceJet last June, partly from American billionaire Wilbur Ross. Malaysian billionaire Ananda Krishnan's Astro Group is his partner in Sun Direct, a direct-to-home television service with 6.4 million subscribers. Got boost from box office success of Robot, India's most expensive film, produced by his Sun Pictures. He's married to Kaveri, his college sweetheart. Grand uncle M.Karunanidhi, chief minister of Tamil Nadu, his home state, facing heat in India's telecom scam as former telecom minister who was arrested belongs to his party. Younger brother Dayanidhi is federal minister of textiles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Orascom founder Onsi Sawiris played a role in Egypt's revolution, calling on Hosni Mubarak to step down and new government to be formed. Now seems to be distancing himself from politics. Heads Wind Telecom, which provides mobile services across Middle East, Africa, South Asia, Europe and Canada through Orascom Telecom, Italy's Wind Telecomunicazioni and Greece's Wind Hellas. Russian mobile operator Vimpelcom offered to buy Wind Telecom assets for $6.6 billion; Naguib is reportedly considering a revised offer. Failed earlier to sell his telecom assets to South African operator MTN Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining mogul flourishing. Ivanhoe Mines has a $4 billion partnership with Mongolia and miner Rio Tinto to mine copper and gold at rich Oyu Tolgoi site; construction began in mid 2010 and production is expeced to begin in 2012. Currently gung-ho over copper in Congo and platinum in South Africa. Chicago native attended Reed College in Oregon; studied Sanskrit, Buddhism in India after graduating. Made first fortune stumbling on large nickel deposit at Voisey's Bay in Canada; sold nickel-rich property to Inco for $3.1 billion 1996. Sold Ivanhoe Energy's U.S. oil and gas operations to Seneca Resources Corporation for $40 million in July 2009.
title: Founder and Executive Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ivanhoe Mines', 'uri': 'companies/ivanhoe-mines', 'title': 'Founder and Executive Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited chunk of Wal-Mart stock after father James (Bud) Walton, cofounder of Wal-Mart with brother Sam, died in 1995. Shares up 5% in last 12 months. Married to E. Stanley Kroenke, owner of pro basketball's Denver Nuggets, hockey's Colorado Avalanche, plus stakes in football's St. Louis Rams and English soccer titan Arsenal. He has a separate billion-dollar fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: The brother of deceased Taiwan entrepreneurial legend Y.C. Wang helped to guide the family-led Formosa Plastics Group through expansion into one of Asia's largest businesses for decades. Out of the day-to-day operations at the business, his wealth is still tied to the empire, through holdings in Formosa Plastics, Formosa Chemicals and Nan Ya Plastics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fujian Province native is founder of New Huadu Group, with investments in mining, beverages, retail, and tourism, among other businesses. Made bulk of his fortune through Hong Kong-listed Zijin Mining, one of China's biggest nonstate mining companies, with a focus on gold and base metals.  Through his foundation, created the New Huadu Business School of Minjiang University in Fujian; school formally opened in November. Nobel Prize winner Edmund S. Phelps is the business school dean.

name: Billionaires
bio: Holds the reigns to Brazil's largest retailer by revenue, Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao (CBD). After months of intense stop-and-go negotiating CBD announced in July that the joint venture with retailer Casas Bahia was moving forward. CBD has since also announced the acquisition of its remaining stake in supermarket chain Sendas. Diniz's father, a Portuguese immigrant, started a bakery in São Paulo in 1948. With fierce discipline and ambition Abilio turned the bakery into an empire.  In 1989 he was kidnapped by Canadian terrorists who held him in underground cells for 7 days until the federal police set him free. Keeps a strict regimen complete with multiple workouts a day, balanced meals and prayer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Perot sold his data-processing firm Perot Systems to Dell in 2009 for $3.9 billion and pocketed approximately $380 million. The fortune of the former presidential candidate is now mostly in municipal bonds. He also shares ownership of a massive real estate firm, Hillwood, with son Henry Ross Perot Jr; it gave up its stake in a 72-acre Dallas planned community in April 2009 after financial troubles (the German company that took over claims Hillwood was close to defaulting). Family ran full-page ad in the Wall Street Journal in honor of his 80th birthday in 2010. Cotton broker's son, former IBM salesman, made his fortune selling his first data-processing firm EDS to GM for $2.5 billion in 1984. Owned a copy of the Magna Carta but sold it to Carlyle Group managing director (and billionaire) David Rubenstein in 2007 for $21.7 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: The reclusive Gandel is best known as the half-owner of Australia's biggest shopping mall, in the Melbourne suburb Chadstone. Joined his family's women's clothing chain, Sussan, in the 1950s and later sold it to focus on property development. Donated $7 million to the National Gallery of Australia last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriotic Israeli tycoon with penchant for politicians and Chagall paintings sold off stake in Israeli telecom outfit Bezeq for about $1.7 billion pretax in 2009. Bought back rights to popular Power Rangers, initial source of his fortune, from Walt Disney Co. Saban Brands, which will manage the brand, already has plans for 18th season of Power Rangers airing on Nickelodeon and Nicktoons in 2011. In May 2010 group picked up Paul Frank Industries, known for iconic monkey, Julius. Announced partnership with Lionsgate Entertainment to manage Tiger Gate, operator and distributor of action and horror films across TV channels in Asia. "Friend" of Bill and Hillary, has donated more than $10 million to Clintons' causes. Owns stake in Spanish language TV broadcaster Univision, which got big revenue bump from the World Cup. Paid $250 million in back taxes and penalties in 2007 after his former lawyer allegedly placed $1.5 billion of his funds in an illegal tax shelter. Senate report deemed Saban a victim; the lawyer pled guilty in December 2009. Saban is now suing him for $36 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Statistics wizard met partner James Goodnight at North Carolina State. Cofounded SAS Institute 1976, world's largest privately held software company. Runs dynamic data visualization software division. Company revenues increased 5% to $2.43 billion in 2010 as clients looked to business intelligence to sort out where to make money. Despite downturn kept promise of no layoffs in 2009; company says it reinvested 23% of 2009 revenue in research and development. Cary, North Carolina-based firm known for worker-friendly policies; wellness programs, on-site child care centers and free snacks. With Goodnight, owns tony Prestonwood Country Club and local private school Cary Academy. On board of trustees of N.C. State University.
title: Co-Founder, Executive Vice President
employment: {'name': 'SAS Institute', 'title': 'Co-Founder, Executive Vice President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Empresas Polar, one of Venezuela's largest private companies. Produces Polar beer and staples like flour, condiments, tuna fish and wine. Grandson of company founder. Despite leftist President Hugo Chavez's continued public threats to nationalize Polar if it was caught hoarding food (Polar said it has no role in the country's food shortages), company remains private. In November was a recipient of the American Business Council's  award in recognition of his contributions to creating positive changes in Latin America. Family runs one of Venezuela's biggest charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: After father's death in 2005 became sole owner of candy company Storck GmbH, makers of Werther's Original, Riesen, Toffifee, and others. Fourth generation of his family to run the $2 billion group; sales were up 6% in 2009 despite sluggish world economic conditions. Company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve Germany's endangered stork population.

name: Billionaires
bio: The head of hedge fund Centaurus Advisors suffered his first losing year in 2010, rumored to be down 8%. Started trading oil at Enron in 1995; is said to have earned $750 million for company in 2001. When the energy outfit famously collapsed a year later, he went into business for himself founding Centaurus, a hedge fund focusing mostly on natural gas and energy trading.  Big score: he bought up hedge fund Amaranth Advisors' losing positions in natural gas in 2006.  With his wife Laura recently pledged half of their wealth to the Gates-Buffet Giving Pledge. In their letter to Buffet they say: "We look upon our financial position with a mix of disbelief and humility, never having dreamed that we would be in this situation."
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
