bio: Lotti, as she is known to her friends, is second largest shareholder of trendy apparel retailer Hennes & Mauritz, founded by her father Erling Persson in 1947.   The biggest shareholder is brother Stefan who has run the company since 1982. Nephew Karl-Johan Persson became its chief executive in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Cablevision's stock is up 30% this year, boosting the broadcast billionaire's fortune by $700 million. Spun off Madison Square Garden in a public offering 2010; the new MSG holding includes Radio City Music Hall, pro basketball's New York Knicks and hockey's New York Rangers. Cablevision unit Rainbow Media owns cable station AMC, home of hit series Mad Men. Dolan got start editing sports reels and sending them out to TV stations. He started the network that would become HBO in 1965; traded it to Time Inc in 1973 for Long Island cable company that became Cablevision.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Cablevision Systems Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada's cheese mogul enjoying spurt in profits after acquisition spree; Saputo stock up by 35%. Born in Sicily, started Saputo in Montreal in 1954 with parents. Delivered mozzarella by bicycle in the early days. Snapped up U.S. and Canadian dairies in the 1980s as pizza popularity boosted cheese demand. Still serves as chairman; son Lino Jr. is chief.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in China to Russian parents, Triguboff drove taxis in Sydney before getting into construction in 1960s. Now his privately owned Meriton is one of Australia's largest apartment builders; owns and manages 4,000 apartment. He's also one of the country's biggest owners of tourist accommodations. A good sport, he was shadowed last year by 3 young businesspeople, the winners of a magazine's "Win a Week With a Billionaire" contest.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his first fortune trading cotton on Wall Street. Launched Tudor Investment Corp in 1980. Tripled his capital by anticipating the 1987 market crash. His BVI Global Fund returned 7.5% in 2010. Assets under management:$11.5 billion. Avid pheasant hunter and bass fisherman owns property in Florida Keys and Zimbabwe. Founder of New York's poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation, which raised more than $88 million at an event last year.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Often called the Siberian hermit; rarely leaves remote town of Surgut. Avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth. A professional driller, he was appointed chief executive of Surgutneftegas at age 33. In early 1990s privatized the company with his fellow managers. Russia's fourth-largest oil producer plans to boost oil production 2% this year and increase investment spend by 15%. In 2009 the company bought a 21.2% stake in Hungarian group MOL.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Och-Ziff in 1994, with a reported $100 million in seed money from the Ziff brothers. Took the firm public in 2007. Assets under management are now approximately $27.6 billion. Stock currently trading 50% below its IPO price in November 2007. Spent 11 years at Goldman Sachs  in the Risk Arbitrage Department where he worked with other now well-known investors Thomas Steyer, Richard Perry, Edward Lampert. Donated $15 million through his foundation to Solomon Schechter Day School in West Orange; In December, was renamed after his mother, a former history teacher and administrator at the school.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Och-Ziff Capital Management Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Evraz Group; partner and fellow billionaire Alexander Abramov is chairman. Continuing to manage company's $8 billion total debt burden; hired director of 'lean management' to seek out cost reductions. Also has investments in Highlands Gold Mining, and Russia's electricity infrastructure. Got start working as research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy. Has a Ph.D. in physics and mathematics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hui was a pioneer in the real estate market when China opened the industry in the 1990s, before which the Communist government controlled housing in the world's most populous nation with an iron grip. Successful landmark projects in Shanghai and other cities have propelled Hui into the ranks of world's richest property developers. His Hong Kong-listed flagship Shimao Property Holding's contracted sales in 2010 rose 36% from a year earlier to $4.7 billion, and the company expects that figure to reach $5.5 billion this year. However, central government efforts to slow real estate prices have hit Shimao's shares, which declined 22.5% in the past year amid worries about the medium-term outlook for the residential market. Hui has been diversifying away from residential business for several years through hotel and commercial projects, and just last October signed an agreement with the Hilton under which the chain will manage eight hotels expected to be opened by Shimao in eight different cities starting in 2011. Hui, along with fellow billionaire Lu Guanqiu, met President Obama during a January trip to Washington by Chinese President Hu Jintao.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inspired by drilling pioneer George Mitchell to invest in Barnett shale natural gas field. Sold portion to Devon Energy and Crosstex Energy in 2006 for $2.6 billion cash. Reinvested in Barnett, drilling on Ross Perot's land, and sold another chunk in 2008 to Quicksilver Resources for $1.3 billion (personally pocketed $400 million). Reinvested cash in Pennsylvania's Marcellus shale, assembling 650,000 acres; cashed out a portion for $400 million last fall. Next:has quietly assembled 250,000 acres in Utah, ready to start looking for oil. Dartmouth grad studied law at Southern Methodist U. In 1984 left career as Dallas bankruptcy attorney to pursue oil and gas investments. Formed Chief Oil & Gas a decade later. With wife, Jan, Rees-Jones Foundation awarded $2 million grant to Texas Christian University; gave $10 million to Dartmouth for scholarships to Texan students. Has pledged $25 million to Parkland Foundation in Dallas, which runs hospital for indigent people.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began his career selling residential and later commercial property after graduating from Santa Clara University. Sobrato Development now owns and manages 7.7 million square feet of commercial office space, 7,600 residential units and 350 vacant acres in Silicon Valley; clients include Yahoo and Nvidia. It has donated more than $300 million of office space in the past five years, including a $135 million building in San Jose to Silicon Valley Community Foundation.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining magnate is South Africa's first and only black billionaire. Net worth up this year by $1 billion as a result of rising stock prices. Born in the sprawling black township of Soweto and then trained as a lawyer, became first black partner at Bowman Gilfillan law firm in Johannesburg, before starting a contracting business doing mine scut work. Bought low-producing gold mine shafts in 1994, turned them profitable using lean, mean management style. Since then built $1.5 billion (sales) mining conglomerate, African Rainbow Minerals (ARM), with interests in platinum, nickel, chrome, iron, manganese, coal and gold. Benefited from South Africa's Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) laws, which mandate that companies be at least 26% black-owned in order to get a government mining license. Also holds a stake in Sanlam, a publicly traded financial services company outside Cape Town where he sits on the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: The investor lost a very public proxy battle with bookseller Barnes & Noble this September. He had tried to petition shareholders to elect himself and 2 others to bookseller's board, and to modify its poison pill, which prevented him from owning more than 20% of the shares. "The incumbent board is rife with business and personal conflicts," he said. Barnes & Noble believed Burkle was trying to gain control of the company on the cheap, allegations he denied. Grocer's son made smart bets on Whole Foods during credit crunch. Currently in London hunting European deals.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'The Yucaipa Companies, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Spent $5 million on himself and his wife for a joint birthday party in  Courchevel, France that featured acrobats from Cirque de Soleil and celebrities including Steven Spielberg. A week earlier in Kiev, announced the winner of his $100,000 art prize for young artists; Jeff Koons, Damien Hirst and Miuccia Prada were on hand for the fete. Seventh year hobnobbing at Davos. Meanwhile his pipemaker Interpipe struggling to refinance reported $900 million in debt. Instead using proceeds from 2008 sale of his Ukrsotsbank to Italy's UniCredit Group for $2.2 billion to create investment portfolio. New ventures include insurance and oil explorer Geo-Alliance, which he considered IPOing on the Polish bourse in December. Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma used his Ph.D. in pipe design to found Interpipe in 1990.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low profile member of one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. In 2008 family's Banco Itau merged with Unibanco. Now she is one of the largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank and one of the world's fifteen largest banks. Brother, Alfredo, is bank's vice chairman. She serves as president of Alana Institute, a non-profit organization created in 1994 with the mission of promoting social work, education and culture.
person: {'name': 'Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela', 'uri': 'ana-lucia-de-mattos-barretto-villela', 'imageExists': False, 'squareImage': '//specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/5e7422c310380d0006bdac2a/416x416.jpg?background=000000&cropX1=176&cropX2=2832&cropY1=268&cropY2=2925'}
personName: Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela

name: Billionaires
bio: The identical twins sold their InterContinental Hotel Group shares last year, then bought a 25% stake in the London firm Maybourne, parent company of the luxury Berkeley, Claridge's and  Connaught hotels. Started together in the accounts department at General Electric, flipped houses and purchased first hotel in 1975. Their empire also includes the Telegraph Newspaper Group, and U.K.'s largest online retailer, Shop Direct Group. Own private isle of Breqhou; significant investments on neighboring Sark. David offered the Sark's Seigneur, or head, £2 million last year to buy the island but was turned down.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korea's richest politician saw his fortune increase by $1.6 billion. Assemblyman is the biggest individual shareholder in Hyundai Heavy Industries, which he ran until 1988 before he entered politics. Brother of billionaire Chung Mong-Koo is said to have close ties to the current Korean president, a former Hyundai executive. Vice president of FIFA, world governing body for soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs and runs world's largest palm oil firm, Wilmar International, which bought Sucrogen, the largest raw sugar producer in Australia and maker of fuel ethanol, for $1.5 billion. It is building a biochemical refinery in Indonesia and expanding into property in China. Started out as a flour trader working for his uncle, Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok. Struck out on his own, partnering with Indonesia's Martua Sitorus to buy a small palm oil plantation in Sumatra. Later merged their Wilmar with the senior Kuok's plantation and agribusiness group, converting it into palm oil giant.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Hollywood director and producer is still reaping millions from his Star Wars franchise. The 6 movies have earned a total $4.3 billion in worldwide box office (not adjusting for inflation), while toys and other merchandise have grossed $20 billion since 1977. Now a new generation - reared on The Clone Wars, Lucas' Cartoon Network - keeps the legacy alive. His most valuable asset is Industrial Light  & Magic, the special-effects shop founded in 1975; ILM, which expanded from Skywalker Ranch in Marin County to the Presidio in San Francisco in 2005, contributes high-end effects for films like Avatar and the Harry Potter series. Lucas directed his first short in 1967 while studying film at USC (it later became his futuristic police-state flick, THX-1138, a cult classic), and gained fame directing American Graffiti and producing the Indiana Jones series. Next up: the drama Red Tails, which he's executive producing.
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-key and low profile member of one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. Was chosen to lead the family business after death of great-uncle Olavo Setubal in 2008. That same year family's Banco Itau merged with Unibanco. Is now vice chairman of the board of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank and one of the world's fifteen largest banks. Alfredo is among the largest individual shareholders of the bank. With sister, Ana Lucia, supports Alana Institute, a non-profit organization created in 1994 with the mission of fostering and promoting social work, education and culture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparently met Helmut Horten, founder of eponymous German department store chain, in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was 19. Despite 30-year age difference, they wed 7 years later. He died in 1987 and left her an estimated $1 billion fortune. Austria's merry widow now divides her time between a penthouse in Vienna, a residence in Tessin, Switzerland, and a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. Owns one of world's largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII. Rumored to have sold a 35.5 carat diamond, once part of the crown of Bavaria, for $24 million at Christie's auction in December 2008. Said to enjoy hunting and collecting art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest shareholder in property developer LSR Group. Benefitting from rebound in property market after near collapse in 2008. New housing construction up 250% in St. Petersburg last year. Chairman of CIS affairs in the upper house of the Russian parliament. After receiving his economics PhD from St. Petersburg State University, started a residential construction business with a classmate in 1994. During the privatizations, bought one of the largest city-owned construction firms, Lenstroireconstruktsiya, or LSR. Listed its shares in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune tied up in his pipe maker TMK. Like many native sons of the Urals region, started out as a trader. Graduated from the Urals Polytechnic Institute with a concentration in metallurgy. Throughout the 1990s ran a variety of metals plants in the Urals. In 1998 ran the sales division of the Sinarsky Pipe Factory and soon became its main owner. Two years later Sinarsky became part of pipe conglomerate TMK, assembled by MDM Group founders Sergei Popov and Andrei Melnichenko. Pumpyansky became chief executive and acquired a 35% stake in the company, which controlled 3 major pipe plants and later acquired a fourth despite fierce competition from Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group. In October 2006 bought out Melnichenko and Popov; listed TMK on the London Stock Exchange, raising $1 billion. During the crisis he had to hand over controlling stake in TMK to state-owned banks as security for $1.85 billion  loan; the loan was prolonged to 8 years at end of 2008 and Pumpyansky got his stake back.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Kotak Mahindra Bank as small finance outfit in 1985, with industrialist Anand Mahindra. Now has 8 million customers, 300 branches and businesses ranging from private equity to life insurance. Reportedly, wants to buy another bank to expand footprint. Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp acquired a 4.5% stake for $294 million last June. Kotak Education Foundation, family's private trust, works with schools in Mumbai focusing on underprivileged students.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell left their father's real estate firm in 1979, started buying small manufacturing companies during junk bond frenzy in 1980s. Result: Equity Group Holdings, cofounded with billionaire brother. Acquired crippled REIT, fused with other industrial companies to form Danaher; named after Montana stream where two brothers once fished for trout. Took industrial pump maker Colfax public in 2008; his 21% stake is up 63% over the past year. Now chairman of the board of Danaher. Reportedly a dedicated supporter of the Washington Ballet and DePauw University. Movie producer: founder of California-based Indian Paintbrush Co., producers of movies like "The Darjeeling Limited" and "Fantastic Mr. Fox."
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: EBay's first employee and first president, Skoll charted a business plan that took EBay from a start-up to a corporate giant and later cashed out. He now funnels his money, energy into making films for social change through Participant Media and supporting social entrepreneurs through his philanthropic Skoll Foundation. His company's first few films -- Syriana, Good Night, and Good Luck, North Country and Murderball -- got 11 Oscar nominations in 2006 and others, such as An Inconvenient Truth, the global-warming documentary featuring former Vice President Al Gore, continued to pick up honors. In 2008, he started Takepart.com, an online site catering to social activists and then Skoll Global Threats Fund a year later to confront issues ranging from climate change to pandemics and nuclear proliferation. Financed dubbing of the film Gandhi in Arabic, using Palestinian voice actors, to promote non-violence throughout Palestine. His latest multi-award winning documentary 'Waiting for Superman'  takes a hard, critical look at the "academic sinkholes" in US public education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born above a pub in London's East End, helped his family build a catering business. Sold it and became a currency trader. Some reports claim he made more on collapse of sterling on Black Wednesday in 1992 than George Soros. Still an active trader but also main investor in Tavistock Group, which has interests in more than 100 companies. Has $500 million stake in pub operator Mitchells & Butler; owns British soccer team Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs); invests in such restaurants as Freebirds and Blackhawk Grille. Its real estate arm bought the St. Regis Atlanta in February; also has 8,000-plus acres in Orlando and recently completed a luxury resort called Albany with golfers Tiger Woods and Ernie Els near Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. Has homes in Argentina, France, Albany, Lyford Cay and Isleworth near Orlando, Florida. Spends a couple of months a year working from his yacht. Art collection includes works by Picasso, Matisse, Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State law school dropout founded The Limited with a $5,000 loan from his aunt in 1963, and took it public six years later. Sold off the remaining stake in The Limited clothing chain in 2010, having sold the majority stake in 2007. Announced intention to focus on lingerie and beauty parts of the business, including mall staples Victoria's Secret and Bath and Body Works. Now, company is planning an expansion in Canada and the Middle East. Collects contemporary art, including pieces by Picasso, Matisse, Degas and de Kooning.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Limited Brands', 'uri': 'companies/limited-brands', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of the late Dan Duncan assumed control of part of his $12.4 billion pipeline empire after father's death in March 2010 at age 77. Houston's richest man at the time of his dealth, Dan Duncan grew up poor, starting energy company Enterprise Products with 2 trucks in 1968. Today it owns more than 49,000 miles of pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started medical device company Cook Group in 1963; it specializes in stents and catheters. Has expanded internationally, with units in Europe and Asia. Bright-spot: new catheter for ICUs that's juiced with antibiotics to prevent infections. Runs company with help from son Carl. Spent $500 million to buy and restore French Lick Resort and West Baden Springs Hotel in Indiana, adding a casino and a Pete Dye PGA golf course. Gets favorable reviews, but not enough tourists teeing off, modest casino take. A Bloomington, Indiana celebrity on par with his pals Coach Bobby Knight and rocker John Mellencamp. Donated $15 million for new Indiana basketball facility.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of the late Dan Duncan assumed control of part of his $12.4 billion pipeline empire after father's death in March 2010 at age 77. Houston's richest man at the time of his death, Dan Duncan grew up poor, starting energy company Enterprise Products with 2 trucks in 1968. Today it owns more than 49,000 miles of pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of the late Dan Duncan assumed control of part of his $12.4 billion pipeline empire after father's death in March 2010 at age 77. Houston's richest man at the time of his dealth, Dan Duncan grew up poor, starting energy company Enterprise Products with 2 trucks in 1968. Today it owns more than 49,000 miles of pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish-born Azrieli fled Europe during World War II for what was then Palestine. Studied architecture, then went to Canada, where he got into real estate. Today his conglomerate spans Canada, U.S., Europe and Israel. Controls largest water desalination plant in Israel. Octogenarian shows no signs of slowing down: in June 2010 completed the largest private IPO in Israel's history, selling 25% of shares for $700 million. Proceeds going to investments and acquisitions; bought Houston's Galleria Financial Center for $176 million in January. Through Azrieli Foundation supports architecture, education and the arts. Past president of Canadian Zionist Association. Loans masterpieces to Tel Aviv Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who owns more real estate in Salt Lake City than anyone but the Mormon Church gets slightly more than a third of his fortune from hotels and his 2 swank ski resorts, Sun Valley in Idaho and Snowbasin in Utah. He cobbled land for Snowbasin out of sweetheart land swaps with the federal government. Energy investments account for the rest. He sold Tulsa refinery for $130 million but still owns 2 other refineries and roughly 1,000 miles of pipelines (building another with Holly Corp.). Of 2,600 Sinclair-branded filling stations across the West, Holding wants to sell the last 90. Doesn't give interviews. Motto said to be: "If it's worth doing, it's worth overdoing."

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James, founded specialist firm that became Spear, Leeds & Kellogg. New Jersey native went to work at dad's firm early 1970s; turned outfit into dominant marketmaker. Spear Leeds was first specialist to control more than 10% of stocks trading on Big Board 1992. Engineered sale to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion 2000. Plowed proceeds into reinsurance outfit IAT. Firm owns large stakes in TRC (environmental engineering). Sold stake in consumer products-maker Chattem, famous for Selsun Blue shampoo and Gold Bond powder, to French drugmaker Sanofi-Aventis 2009. Member of the U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association; has been a director at Nam Tai Electronics since 2000; also a member of the board at the Ziegler Companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Estée Lauder (d. 2004); daughter Jane elected to board last July, daughter Aerin is senior vice president. Served as U.S. Ambassador to Austria 1986-87; Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for European & NATO Affairs 1983-86. Reportedly sold a Hamptons house to Aerin. President of World Jewish Congress since June 2007. Like older brother, Leonard, owns vast art collection. Paid $135 million for 1907 Klimt portrait 2006, the largest sum ever spent on a single painting at the time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family's scrap-metal business into a media, utilities and oil empire, Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille. Conglomerate sold its stake in media giant Bertelsmann in 2006. In July 2008, at age 82, he completed what some say is the greatest coup of his career by playing a key role in pushing through the stalled mega merger of CNP's subsidiary Suez with French utility Gaz de France. The new company, European energy giant $120 billion (sales) GDF Suez, is now one of the largest independent electricity suppliers in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former butcher's apprentice owns and runs $10.3 billion (sales) Anton Schlecker drugstore chain; group's 14,000 locations account for 70% of Germany's drugstores. Has 3,000 stores in Austria, Holland, Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Portugal and Eastern Europe. Faced with increased competition at home, company has started its own drug mail order and wholesale businesses.  Wife Christa and children Lars and Meike help run the business. Soccer fan. Enjoys sport cars, apparently owns a Ferrari, Aston Martin, Porsche and Jaguar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tax lawyer turned real estate developer, his Related Cos. is on the prowl for distressed property assets. Sold out three luxe condo buildings in New York,  including a $31.5 million record-breaking penthouse sale. Opening a 1.2 million square foot Manhattan development that includes The Signature Center and the YOTEL hotel.  Has begun work on New York City's Hudson Yards, with plan to create a new neighbourhood.  Has offices in Shanghai and Abu Dhabi; recently announced partnership with Mubadala Development Co to develop Abu Dhabi's Sowwah Square.  Lost bid for 1 World Trade Center to the Durst Organization. Raised $1.1 billion with partners SJB Bank to launch a national commercial bank later this year. Completed $1 billion purchase of pro football's Miami Dolphins 2009; in December, he took team to see Broadway show Lombardi  to boost morale before a big game against the NY Jets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of the late Dan Duncan assumed control of part of his $12.4 billion pipeline empire after  her father's death March 2010  at age 77. Duncan grew up poor, starting energy company Enterprise Products with 2 trucks in 1968. Today it owns more than 49,000 miles of pipelines. Randa sits on company's board.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Wanxiang Group, one of China's largest non-government controlled conglomerates. Traveled with Chinese President Hu Jintao to the U.S. in January and met with President Obama. Controls several listed Chinese companies including auto-part manufacturer Wanxiang Qianqiao, beverage firm Hebei Cheng De Lolo, and property company Shunfa. Investing in a solar panel plant in Illinois; son-in-law Ni Pin oversees Lu's U.S. business interests. Started career fixing farm equipment and bicycles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime lawmaker derives bulk of fortune from golf courses, but Japan's sluggish economy has made it difficult to attract golfers. Holds 9% stake in TV Tokyo. Collector of expensive wines also an avid sailor; Itoyama claims to have circumnavigated the world three times in his 150-foot yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded wind turbine manufacturer Enercon in 1984; reportedly built its first wind turbine in his backyard. Trained engineer probably got his inspiration close to home; grew up in windy northern Germany. In 1992 Enercon began producing non-polluting models without gears or hydraulics. The company is now world's fourth-largest wind turbine producer with 8.5% global market share and $4.3 billion in sales. It has over 16,000 wind turbines installed in 30 countries. Enercon now expanding into water: investing in hydroelectric power plants and seawater desalination projects

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first tire store 50 years ago in Ann Arbor, Mich. Now his Discount Tire is the world's largest independent tire and wheel retailer (sales: $2.5 billion); has 774 stores in 22 states. Son Bruce Jr. is president. Company's "Thank You" commercial is Guinness World Record holder as longest-running TV commercial; same ad has been beamed into homes since 1975. Collects Latin American art, old tire ad posters. His charitable foundation funds a college scholarship program for children of Discount Tire employees. Reportedly bought a Palm Beach, Florida mansion for $22.5 million last year.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Sits on the board of her family's conglomerate, Koc Group, but has no role in management. Spent years battling an illness in hospitals around the world; the experience moved her to build nursing education and research center in Turkey. Married a doctor. Fluent in English and German. Brother Rahmi Koc, sister Suna Kirac and nephws Mustafa, Omer and Ali Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swashbuckling chief executive of Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual got a huge boost in December when he sold 18% of the bank to a consortium of foreign institutional investors for $1.8 billion, valuing the bank at $10 billion. BTG Pactual handled some of the largest transactions in Brazil in the past year, including a $12 billion deal between Royal Dutch Shell and ethanol producer Cosan. Armed with new capital, Esteves vows to expand the bank beyond Brazil across Latin America and take it public in 2012. Working up from the IT department, Esteves made his mark in the 1990s as an ace trader at Brazilian investment bank Pactual, which was later bought by Swiss bank UBS. In 2009 he engineered the repurchase of Pactual from UBS.

name: Billionaires
bio: His RED Digital cameras shot the Oscar winning film, "The Social Network." The digital cinema-quality cameras have also been used on the sets of directors Peter Jackson and Steve Soderbergh. Sold motorcycle grips from car trunk 1975; switched to sunglasses in 1983. Oakley founder persuaded star athletes wear his high-tech lenses; went public in 1995. Started Red Digital 2006; sold Oakley to Leonardo Del Vecchio's (see) optics giant Luxottica for $2.1 billion 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited small baby products store in Bahrain in 1973; built it into $3.8 billion (revenues) Landmark Group, a retailing giant in the Middle East. Headquartered in Dubai, it has 900 stores in 15 countries, including India. Focuses on middle-class shoppers. Recently bought Carluccio's, Italian restaurant chain in the UK, and regional franchise of health club group Fitness First. Owns mid-market hotel chain Citymax. Wife Renuka heads Landmark's international operations. His three children also work with him. Family's charity, Landmark International Foundation for Empowerment, supports education for underprivileged children

name: Billionaires
bio: Former lawyer borrowed $300 from wife to start real estate developer Lerner Enterprises in 1952. Made fortune building massive shopping malls in the suburbs of Washington, D.C.: Tysons Corner, Tysons II, Wheaton Plaza, Landover Mall, Dulles Town Center, White Flint. Today owns 20 million square feet of commercial, retail space and 7,000 apartments. Also owns stake in NYC's Chelsea Piers. Moved headquarters to a new 'green' building in Maryland in late 2009. Owns pro baseball's Washington Nationals and small stake in regional broadcaster Mid-Atlantic Sports Network.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, Fadesa Inmobiliaria. Took company public in 2004; sold his 55% stake to real estate group Martinsa for $3 billion in September 2006, just before collapse of Spanish real estate bubble. Holds 5% stake in Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, one of Spain's largest banks. Collects art from Spanish province of Galicia; enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lam has built Quanta Computer of Taiwan into one of the world's largest manufacturers of notebook computers. In January, Quanta said it would form a strategic alliance with 3M to develop touch technology for computers. The Taiwan electronics industry pioneer also sees a good future for cloud computing, and Quanta last year inked a memorandum of understanding with Chunghwa Telecom of Taiwan to promote that business. Quanta needs to innovate as its notebook business being challenged by the lightweight notepad products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pineapple king saw his fortune rise by half a billion this year with a 15% uptick in Dole Foods stock. Dyslexic, left high school in the 9th grade; worked at a gas station before being drafted into the Army in 1943. Moved to Detroit after WWII.  Made small profit buying and selling a diner. Developed property in Arizona. In 1985, bought out failing Hawaiian real estate outfit Castle & Cooke, which owned fruit company Dole. Spun off real estate holdings; still owns assets including Hawaiian island Lana'i. Took Dole, now world's largest fruit, vegetable producer, public in 2009, same year he received his high school diploma. Health nut, daily hour of exercise includes 50 push-ups; no saturated fats, supplements or pain killers; pescetarian (vegetarian who eats fish).

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Rongsheng Petro Chemical of Hangzhou, one of China's largest fiber industry manufacturers. Its shares have risen by nearly 30% since an IPO at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in November. Li controls a smaller listed company, investment firm Ningbo United Group. Li is a vice chairman of the China Chemical Fibers Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon, whose stock is up 35% in the last 12 months. The green company, which he founded in 1969, has "consultants" sell Natura's cosmetics across Brazil and seven other Latin American countries. Media-shy Seabra is reported to live in London. His former cochair and fellow billionaire, Guilherme Peirao Leal, resigned from the post last year to take a stab at running for vice president in Brazil's 2010 elections. (He did not win.)
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: The fortune of one of Taiwan's most prominent landlords has increased in the past year on a run-up in Taiwan's real estate market. Lin's real estate assets include properties such as Hung Tai Center, and investments in Hung Sheng Construction, Cooperative Construction, and Hung Tai Asset Management. Lin-backed financial industry businesses include En Tie Commercial Bank, Capital Investment Trust, Capital Securities and Hontai Life Insurance. Taiyo Life Insurance of Japan owns a minority stake in Hontai. Brother Lin Rong San, who appears on this year's billionaires' list, has a separate real estate empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Hockey fan giving back to the sport. Thisfall Pegula donated $88 million to alma mater Penn State to build a hockey arena and Division 1 team. This February, the natural gas chief bought the NHL's Buffalo Sabres for $189 million from billionaire Tom Golisano. Pegula scored a big payday when Royal Dutch Shell bought his East Resources for $4.7 billion in May 2010; Pegula owned 65% of the company.  Former sole shareholder sold roughly 35% of company to KKR for $330 million in 2008. He still has more than 350,000 acres of shale land in the Appalachian Basin. Penn State math major switched to petroleum engineering for scholarship; joined Getty Oil after graduation, later Felmont Oi. Started East Resource with $7,500 loan from friends and family 1983; drilled sand wells, bought Pennzoil Assets from Devon Energy for $30.6 million in 2000.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: After wresting his DreamWorks studio from Viacom's Paramount Pictures in 2009, the famed Hollywood director received $325 million from India's Reliance Industries (down from a hoped-for $1.5 billion), pulled another $325 million from a syndicated bank deal and signed a distribution deal with Disney. The studio's first Disney release was "I am number 4" (written by disgraced memoirist James Frey),  which came out in February 2011. Spielberg also gets a portion of all ticket sales at Universal theme parks. The director founded the original DreamWorks with Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen in 1994. A decade later, the animation division was spun-off into a publicly traded company run by Katzenberg. The live action studio was sold to Paramount Pictures in 2005. Geffen left in late 2008. Spielberg has directed 24 movies, which have grossed $4 billion in the U.S. His biggest hit so far: "Jurassic Park," which earned $915 million at the global box office. He won two Oscars for directing "Schindler's List" and "Saving Private Ryan." The movie buff dropped out of Cal State Long Beach; received degree in 2002.
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: Nahmad and his two brothers have become influential megadealers of modern and impressionist art by the most well-known names, from Monet and Matisse to Renoir and Rothko. They own a vast inventory of between 4,000 and 4,500 works in a duty-free warehouse next to the airport in Geneva, Switzerland. Among those holdings: 300 Picassos, worth some $900 million. The family buys and sells most of their works at auction. It also trades millions of dollars in currencies and commodities. A skilled backgammon player who bets hundreds of thousands on the game in Monte Carlo, David holds the 1996 world title.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Fiba and Fina holding companies own finance-related businesses in 12 countries in Western and Eastern Europe. Also owns 100 Marks & Spencer, Gap and Banana Republic stores in Russia, Ukraine and Turkey. His fortune began with banking. Founded Turkish bank Finansbank in 1987. Sold 46% to National Bank of Greece for $2.76 billion in 2006 and remaining 9% stake for $700 million in 2008. Then bought Banco Comercial Portugues SA's Turkish unit, in a return to the country's banking industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth generation leader of engineering giant ($30.8 billion sales) Bechtel Corp., firm that built the Hoover Dam, Chunnel. He and his father Stephen are both believed to have 20% of the firm, which builds roads and rail systems, airport and ports, liquefied natural gas processing plants and copper smelters. Future project: construction of  a 440-megawatt solar thermal power complex in California's Mojave Desert. One of the top service providers to the U.S. government, it treats hazardous liquid waste at a former nuclear production site and eliminates unused chemical weapons. Reportedly member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover. On board of Indian School of Business; member of JPMorgan Chase's International Council along with Henry Kissinger and Georges Shultz.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Bechtel Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to engineering giant ($30.8 billion sales) Bechtel Corp., firm that built the Hoover Dam, Chunnel. Stephen became Bechtel president at age 35, chairman 13 years later. Son Riley now runs the show.  Believed to own 20% of the company. Bechtel builds roads and rail systems, airport and ports, liquefied natural gas processing plants and copper smelters.  Future project: construction of  a 440-megawatt solar thermal power complex in California's Mojave Desert; modular nuclear power plants. One of the top service providers to U.S.  federal and state governments, it treats hazardous liquid waste at a former nuclear production site and eliminates unused chemical weapons.  Reportedly a member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover.
title: Former Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Sodexo as catering and river cruise company in 1966 in a warehouse in Marseilles. Today the $21 billion (2009 sales) company supplies food to the U.S. Marine Corps; operates prisons; organizes major sports events such as the Ryder Cup, the Dakar Road Rally, and the World Scout Jamboree. Also has majority stake in the Lido, the Parisian topless cabaret that features ice dancers and trapeze artists; 90% stake in Yachts de Paris, one of the best-known cruise companies operating on the Seine. Is one of the leading food and facilities management services companies in India with its acquisition last year of  Radhakrishna Hospitality Services Group. Bellon stepped down as chief executive in 2005 but remains chairman. Penned autobiography, "I've Had a Great Time".

name: Billionaires
bio: Pioneering media baron and onetime partner of Rupert Murdoch, he heads $2.5 billion (revenues) Essel Group which owns TV broadcaster Zee Entertainment, run by eldest son Punit.  It bought entertainment channel 9X and partnered with Geodesic to provide TV programs on mobile phones.  Group's Dish TV has 10 million subscribers. Other interests include packaging, cinemas, online lotteries, gold refining and amusement parks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish immigrant married Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson in 1971; inherited 36 million J&J shares when he died in 1983. Stake now worth over $2 billion. Monaco resident collects Renaissance, baroque art; in December 2009 sold a Rembrandt to Steve Wynn for $33 million. Developing Children's Bay Cay, private island residential complex in the Bahamas. Recipient of numerous prizes for her artistic, humanitarian and education projects worldwide. Active supporter of  Art for Autism, whose honorary patron is Prince Albert of Monaco

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father's dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. Decade ago, sold his stake in GEA to MG Technologies for $1 billion in cash and 21% interest in combined group. Cashed out rest In March 2006 selling stake to various institutional investors for approximately $630 million.   Lives in  Switzerland his wife and six children. Enthusiastic sailor, has a yacht named Hetairos. Owner of a luxury resort, Fregate Island, in the Seychelles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Senior statesman of Turkish industrialists, ran Koc Group until 2003. Now serves as honorary Chairman of Koc Holding. Received numerous awards over the years from the German, Italian and Turkish governments; also recipient of five honorary doctorates. Spent two years traveling the world on his yacht after he retired. Avid sailor still spends months calling on ports around the world on his luxury yacht. Member of both the Istanbul Ocean Racing Club and the New York Yacht Club. His sisters Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac and his sons Mustafa Vehbi, Mehmet Omer and Yildirim Ali Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1981, took over L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB, founded by his father Lars in 1944 as a construction company.  Controls 53% of the $2.9 billion (sales) diversified holding company with interests in property management and investments; has about 150 properties in its portfolio. His two daughters have their own stakes in the firm, worth some $670 million, not reflected in dad's net worth.  Enjoys hunting and curling; was once a junior world champion of curling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Antonio founded tour outfit Globus in 1928 with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano. Today Sergio controls family's tour and travel empire. Says he doesn't invest in equity markets; bulk of wealth tied up in low-risk bonds, minimizing damage wrought by global recession. Empire includes several charter airline businesses. Travels via helicopter, private jet, yacht ("Lady Marina"); owns $600,000 Mercedes Maybach.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of supervisory board  of Mercadona, the third largest chain of supermarkets in Spain with 1,270 stores.  Roig holds  55% of the $22 billion (revenues) group established by his parents in 1977. Mercadona's  A.L.P. (always low prices) marketing strategy  has enabled them to fight the sector doldrums and hold onto a. 27% market share.  Daughters Hortensia, Amparo, Juana and Carolina all sit on the supervisory board with him.  Last February was awarded the Prince Felipe prize for entrepreneurs.  Holds the title of Doctor Honoris Causa from the University of Valencia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founding patriarch of Egypt's most famous business dynasty. Onsi's three sons Naguib, Samih and Nassef run separate Orascom telecom, hotels and construction divisions. Studied agriculture in college after father urged him to pursue farming. Found it boring, and instead opened a small contracting firm in Upper Egypt. Was forced to rebuild after Nasser nationalized company in 1960s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband and wife couple's Hong Kong-listed Soho China has thrived in a Beijing property market with commercial sites such as Chaoyangmen Soho by Zaha Hadid Architects. The company is now making a big splash in Shanghai, with four investments since 2009 in key Shanghai areas: One in Jing'an, one along the Bund, one in the new Hongqiao Transportation Hub district and the latest, in October, right next to Xintiandi. Pan is one of China's most popular bloggers. Zhang, formally an executive with Goldman Sachs, speaks English fluently and attended the World Economic Forum meeting at Davos this year.
title: Cofounder, CEO
employment: {'name': 'Soho China Ltd.', 'uri': 'companies/soho-china', 'title': 'Cofounder, CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Industrialist turned philanthropist and environmentalist. In 1978 became president of the board of his father's Eternit, a construction materials manufacturer. Began moving the company away from asbestos long before it was a banned substance. Diversified over the next ten years, investing in forestry firm Grupo Nueva and other multinationals. In 2003 donated all shares of Grupo Nueva, worth $1 billion, to his Viva Trust, whose profits are used to promote causes like sustainability and education. Much of his wealth is now held in a diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and private equity investments and is handled by professional managers. Art collector favors contemporary painters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forbes Asia's 2009 businessman of the year stepped down as executive chairman of commodities trading firm Noble Group in September; he returned two months later as nonexecutive chairman.  Englishman from Brighton started career as a "coolie in a scrap yard" after quitting school at age 15. Since Elman founded Noble in 1986, the company has grown to employ 11,000 people at offices and plants in 38 countries. In December Noble acquired two sugar mills from Brazilian ethanol producer Grupo Cerradinho, adding to its sugar cane milling capacity. In February announced a strategic alliance with Xanadu Mines, a Mongolian exploration company listed in Australia, to explore coking oil, iron ore and ferro alloys opportunities. Prior to setting up Noble, Elman spent 10 years with commodities trading firm Phibro as regional director of its Asia business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and 85% owner of investment firm Melker Schorling AB. Founded MSAB in 1999 and took it public in 2006, attracting such investors as fellow billionaire Stefan Persson,  who sits on the board of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded generic drug maker Apotex in 1974; today sales exceed $1 billion. Company sent seven million pills to treat AIDS patients in Rwanda in 2009. Locked in court fight with relatives who allege they are owed a piece of the fortune; Sherman filed countersuit, rebutting their claims. Son Jonathan Sherman is new owner of Ontario's bankrupt Steelback Brewery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Daito Trust Construction, developer of commercial and residential real estate, is selling his stake back to the company. Share repurchase offer runs through March; Tada expected to net nearly $2 billion if goes through. Tada scrapped previous sale of stake to private investors, including fellow Japanese billionaire Akira Mori, after financial crisis locked up credit markets in 2008. Company has since been on a rebound, stock price up 60% over the past year as demand for housing picks up. Recently established farm to raise Shiitake mushrooms.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a Taiwan farmer, Lin has built up one of the country's largest property fortunes with large holdings in northern Taiwan. Also majority owner of Union Bank and publisher of the Liberty Times, a popular daily newspaper. Three sons are actively involved in the business empire. Brother Lin Yu-Lin also appears on this year's billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Huabao International, one of China's largest producers of flavorings. The company's Hong Kong-trade shares -- and Chu's wealth -- are up from a year ago as investors favor stock in businesses that benefit from growing consumer demand in China. However, that rosy year-on-year picture camouflages some bad news:  Huabao's stock has tanked by 30% since October, a plunge that Chu didn't help by selling off 6.3% at the end of January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James (Bud) Walton, ran handful of small 5-and-10 stores in Arkansas and Missouri with brother Sam. Duo built first Wal-Mart in 1962. With sister Ann Walton Kroenke, inherited chunk of retailer's stock after Bud's death 1995. Shares worth nearly $2.6 billion today. Bought pro hockey's St. Louis Blues in 1999 with husband, Bill; sold six years later. Founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet in New York 2003. Owns Providence Bank, commercial real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Guo Guangchang is the chairman and main founder of Fosun International, one of China's largest privately-owned conglomerates with interests in pharmaceuticals, property, steel, mining, retail, services and strategic investments. The company has become active as a partner for foreign companies looking to expand in China. Fosun bought a 7% stake in Club Mediterranee SA (Club Med) last June and is helping to grow its business in the mainland. In January, it signed a tentative agreement with U.S. insurer Prudential to jointly invest up to $600 million. Holds stake in U.S.-listed Focus Media, the largest outdoor media in China. Fosun Media is a licensing partner of Forbes Media in China. Guo holds a bachelor's degree in philosophy and master's degree in business administration both from Fudan University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Became prime minister-elect of Lebanon in January, but now struggling to form a government. First stint as prime minister came in the wake of Rafic Hariri's assassination in 2005. Founded telecom company Investcom with brother Taha during Lebanon's civil war in 1982. After public offerings in London and Dubai, sold stake to South Africa's MTN Group for $5.5 billion in 2006. With proceeds formed M1 Group which has investments in New York and London real estate, French preppy apparel Façonnable, and oil exploration in Colombia. Still MTN's largest individual shareholder. Founded think-tank Middle East Prospects Forum to promote better governance in the Arab world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother of prime minister-elect Najib Mikati keeps lower profile. Founded together telecom company Investcom during Lebanon's civil war in 1982. Sold stake to South Africa's MTN Group for $5.5 billion in 2006. Family is MTN's largest individual shareholder through holding company M1 Group. Has investments in oil exploration in Colombia, in New York and London real estate, and owns French preppy apparel company Façonnable. Son and Columbia University grad Azmi runs M1.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister in law Wilma Tisch, controls family fortune built by their late husbands, famed investors Preston and Laurence Tisch. Duo started with small New Jersey hotel 1946. Acquired Loews Theatres 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. holding company includes diverse investments: oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk), insurance (CNA). Stock up 17% over the past year. Joan's son, Jonathan, heads Loews Hotels. Wilma's son, James, is CEO of Loews. Other son, Andrew, is Co-Chairman of the Board. Inherited 50% ownership of the New York Giants, which her late husband bought in 1991.

name: Billionaires
bio: Main owner of Brightoil Petroleum, a Shenzhen-based company in the oil storage and transportation business. State-run China Development Bank agreed to provide the firm with $4 billion of financing in December. In 2008, Sit paid $90 million for a 68% stake in First Sign International Holdings, which designed and manufactured garments. He later changed the company's name to Brightoil Petroleum. Group, which trades on Hong Kong stock exchange, now has offices in Singapore and Houston. Sit was apparently born in Anhui Province and holds a doctorate in philosophy from Nanjing University.Company's website and annual report don't have a full biography.

name: Billionaires
bio: Certified jet pilot Udvar-Hazy retired as chariman and chief exec of AIG unit International Lease Finance Corp. in early 2010; media reports suggest his move might have had something to do with the salary caps established by the U.S. government as part of its AIG bailout. In January announced plans to take public his new aircraft leasing company, Air Lease Corp.; offering could raise up to $100 million. Air Lease expects to have a fleet of more than 100 commercial planes. Left Budapest as a child, moved to New York. Entered aircraft business while still an undergraduate at UCLA; put together $1 million airplane deal for Air New Zealand senior year. With fellow Hungarians Louis and Leslie Gonda, used $150,000 savings and $1.7 million bank loan to start International Lease Finance Corp. Sold to AIG for $1.3 billion in stock in 1990; claims to have cashed out of AIG before stock plummeted. Gives to Smithsonian.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of his family's Yildiz Holding. Completed $850 million purchase of Godiva chocolates from Campbell Soup Co. in 2007. Yildiz Holding operates seven production facilities in seven different countries, producing biscuits, chocolate, cakes and crackers in Saudi Arabia, Romania, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, and Pakistan and incorporated two plants in Belgium and the U.S. with the Godiva acquisition. Fluent in English and German, enjoys sailing, hunting and travel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Presides over Mashreq, leading UAE bank. Took a hit for its exposure to real estate and overleveraged companies, and still stuggling with restructuring and bad loans. In a statement to shareholders, Al Ghurair was optimistic, but net earnings in the first nine months of 2010 fell 42%. Al Ghurair heads UAE's national assembly. During Egypt's uprising, he reportedly blasted regional and international powers for interfering in the affairs of Arab countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Hengli Group, one of the world's largest textile fiber manufacturers. Started out in business by selling waste silk; borrowed money to buy a town-owned collective silk plant in the city of Wujiang in Jiangsu Province in 1994.  Hengli Group hnow as total assets of $5.8 billion.  Its 2010 sales of $5 billion generated pre-tax profit of $784 million. Chen's next target: A petrochemical complex in Dalian.

name: Billionaires
bio: Profits at Dyson's eponymous vacuum firm doubled last year, thanks to investment in research and international expansion. Best known for creating the bag-less vacuum, but debuted his latest invention in 2010: a futuristic bladeless fan. Attended art school to study design and engineering. Ran through 5,127 prototypes until he perfected G-Force, an upright vacuum using spinning technology to maintain constant suction. Introduced product in U.K. in 1993; it was an immediate hit. Guards technology zealously. Last year, he called on UK Prime Minister David Cameron to protect intellectual property against Chinese counterfeiters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three decades after taking over his father's oil and gas business in 1977, sold acreage in North Dakota's Bakken Shale oil play to XTO Energy for $1.8 billion in 2008. Now Headington is funding another passion: moviemaking. He's invested roughly $300 million so far (through a production company he owns with Graham King) to bankroll 10 films, including Martin Scorsese's The Departed and The Aviator, both starring Leonardo DiCaprio. Young Victoria won 2009 Oscar for costume design. Last year's The Tourist, starring Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp, didn't do as well as hoped. Coming soon: an adaptation of Hunter S. Thompson's The Rum Diaries, also starring Depp, as well as a potential 3-D blockbuster from Scorsese, Hugo Cabret. In preproduction is a biopic of Queen singer Freddie Mercury starring Sacha Baron Cohen. Headington owns two ultrachic hotels in Dallas - Lumen and Joule - and is restoring historic mosaics from the city's Mercantile building. Meanwhile, Headington Oil still produces 15,000 barrels per day of oil and natural gas equivalents.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire is founder and owner of $3.3 billion (sales) Novomatic AG, one of the largest international gaming groups. A butcher by profession, started gaming career in 1974  importing American pin ball machines to Austria. Branched into casinos and game and slot machines. Now one of the world's largest manufacturers of electronic betting machines such as slots, video poker, video lottery, multiplayer games and electronic table games. Operates over 160,000 gaming machines in some 1,000 traditional and electronic casinos in Germany, Croatia, Switzerland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia; also present in Latin America where it runs one of the region's  argest casinos, Chile's Casino Resort Monticello. Expanding into the Internet with server-based games and downloadable table games.   Eldest son Thomas heads one subsidiary, Austrian Gaming Industries. Car buff owns some 120 vintage Jaguar models. In 2003 was made an honorary professor  by the Austrian Ministry of Science for his support of foundations that research non-substance addictions such as pathological gambling.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Vadim Novinsky owns Ukraine's Smart Holding Group which has a 25% stake in Ukrainian billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's iron ore producer Metinvest. Also has stakes in oil and gas company Regal Petroleum and supermarket chain Amstor. Lives in Russia. President of Sambo Federation of St. Petersburg.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father got start making watering cans in summer and hot water bottles in winter. Eventually founded Loh KG in 1961. Friedhelm, his second-born son, took over 13 years later. Company, now known as the Friedhelm Loh Group, manufactures safes, post boxes, intercom systems and switch boxes that protect electrical and electronic circuits. Has $3 billion in sales, with around 11,500 employees in over 70 plants worldwide. Known for his religious beliefs, has established the Christian Media Foundation, publishers of Christian literature. Avid collector of antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eighth grade math "class captain" worked odd jobs to help support family. First from high school to attend MIT, unbeatable tic-tac-toe algorithm won him full ride. Made associate publisher at first computer magazine, Computers and Automation, while studying neurobiology. Sold car for $5k and used cash to found IDG. Asked friends to invest in start-up, only wife and sister did. Each gave $10. Today $10 worth over $4 million. 460 websites, 200 publications reach 270 million people in 95 countries. Sales: $3.16 billion. Employees: 13,150. Dresses up as national icon at IDG manager meetings; in China- Confucius, Austria- Kaiser Franz Joseph, Boston- Ben Franklin. Founded McGovern Institute for brain research at alma mater.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'International Data Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Spent a decade figuring out how to drill and crack the tricky rock of the Barnett Shale formation in north Texas. His techniques have led oil and gas companies into the "shale gale" -- opening up drilling in the Haynesville, Marcellus, Eagle Ford shales. Has created at least 200,000 jobs in recent years, made millionaires out of poor landowners and given America 100 years worth of clean(er) energy. Son of Greek immigrants started Mitchell Energy & Development in 1946. Sold out to Devon Energy for $3.5 billion in cash and stock in 2001. Created the Woodlands, a master-planned suburb north of Houston. Still comes to the office, guiding work to restore historic hotels he owns on Galveston Island damaged by Hurricane Ike in 2008. Generous donor to alma mater Texas A&M; donated $35 million in 2006. Has 10 kids.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of discount shoe retailer ABC Mart, helped by strong yen, which cut procurement costs. Continues to open new stores and expand dress shoe line. Company stock price up 11% over the past year. Former amateur boxer stepped down as chairman in 2007 but still has large stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: The world's youngest billionaire, Dustin Moskovitz was Mark Zuckerberg's Harvard roommate and Facebook's third employee. He is just 8 days younger than his friend. The two dropped out of Harvard and moved to California to work for the social-networking firm full-time; he was its first chief technology officer and then vice president of engineering. He left in 2008 to start Asana, a software company that allows individuals and small companies to better collaborate. Values of his new company: "pragmatism," "being a mensch," "admitting when you're wrong," and "chill-ness." Reportedly sold around a 1% stake in Facebook last year but held onto an estimated 5% in the company, whose value has soared to $50 billion, based on the recent Goldman Sachs transaction. Moskovitz signed onto the Giving Pledge in December; a photo of him and his live-in girlfriend Cari Tuna, a Wall Street Journal reporter who apparently will help him identify causes, accompanied his pledge letter.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: President Trump? The Donald says he is considering running for US President in 2012. So when will he announce his decision? Probably, he told Forbes, at the season finale of Celebrity Apprentice in June. A man with many dreams: Trump also recently said that he'd consider bailing out the New York Mets to help out his friend, Mets owner Fred Wilpon.  The Donald promotes his golf courses through Golf Channel and is producing MTV's new reality series Ladette to Lady. His name is emblazoned on alcohol, ties, even mattresses. But does the brand have value? Trump says it's worth at least $6 billion.
title: Entrepreneur, Personality

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Andrei Klyamko, owns Ukraine's Smart Holding Group which has a 25% stake in Ukrainian billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's iron ore producer Metinvest. Also has stakes in oil and gas company Regal Petroleum and supermarket chain Amstor. Russian native studied at Leningrad Academy of civil aviation. In mid 90s, cofounded Lukoil-North-West company and worked as its representative in Ukraine. Began to buy shares of Ukrainian metallurgy companies. In 2006 he united those companies into Smart Holding Group; a year later, exchanged them for 25% stake in Metinvest.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of the Dogus Holding conglomerate founded by his father, who died in 2001. The group is active in financial services, automotive, construction, media, tourism, real estate and energy. Dogus Grup and GE Capital (an arm of General Electric) are partners in Garanti Bank, one of Turkey's largest banks. In November 2010,  Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA) of Spain purchased 6.3% of the bank from Dogus Holding for $2 billion and 18.6% from General Electric for $3.8 billion. Married to Diana Sahenk, an American.

name: Billionaires
bio: The queen of daytime TV is now the queen of cable. Winfrey's OWN station launched in the beginning of 2011. Programming so far is thin and heavy on Winfrey proteges like Dr. Phil and Gayle King. Expect more diversity as the station finds its feet. In addition to her cable channel, Winfrey in overseeing the last season of her syndicated show, a magazine and Harpo productions. She also started a school for girls in South Africa. Winfrey has 5.2 million followers on Twitter.
title: Entrepreneur, Personality

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief operating officer of Wilmar International, one of world's largest palm oil producers. Increased export tax and price controls in China caused 2010 net profit to drop 30%. Continued expansion, buying Sucrogen, Australia's largest sugar firm. Former economics student traded shrimp as a teenager, then switched to palm oil. Bought his first plantation in 1994. Later cofounded agribusiness Wilmar International with nephew of Malaysia's richest man, Robert Kuok. Merged Wilmar with the senior Kuok's plantation and agribusiness group in 2007. He still holds 10% of company's  shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded construction company ENKA in late 1950s with his brother-in-law Sadi Gulcelik, who died in an air crash in 1980 in Saudi Arabia. It is now Turkey's largest construction firm; also does business in Russia. Plus Enka is the largest private sector electricity producer in Turkey and owner of ten shopping malls in Russia. Son Mehmet Sinan Tara, also a billionaire, runs the company. Born in Macedonia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang, who was China's richest man in 2009, has been lauded for pioneering the electric car in China, but shares in BYD, the auto and battery maker that he chairs, have plunged by nearly half on execution troubles. One highlight of a tough year: A morale-boosting visit to BYD's headquarters in Shenzhen by Warren Buffett, whose investment outfit Berkshire Hathaway owns approximately 10% stake of BYD.  Buffett brought along pal Bill Gates. Wang joined a high-profile philanthropy dinner in Beijing organized by the two U.S. business icons; dinner was shunned by many of China's low-profile rich.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded conglomerate YTL Corp. in 1955, using the first letters of his name. Children all work in the company; 56-year-old son, Francis, has run it for over two decades. Its secondary listing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in 1996 made it the first non-Japanese company from Asia to start trading there. Communications unit has pumped $2.5 billion into a 4G network and Internet technology in Malaysia. Also owns PowerSeraya, Singapore's second-largest power generator and Starhill Global REIT, which owns retail properties in Malaysia and Singapore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy brothers cofounded international real estate investment company Topland Group in 1980s. In 2004, Topland acquired 33 stores, 2 distribution units from Tesco for $1.2 billion, sold its 50/50 joint-venture interest in 2007 for $1.9 billion. Acquired 78 Marks & Spencer stores in leaseback deal for $505 million in 2001, now worth $1.2 billion. In January, Topland and Barclays agreed to co-invest $660 million in the natural resources sector.  The partnership also allows Topland to co-invest in future deals that Barclays sources and executes over the next five years. Sol resigned as chairman and CEO of Topland after the introduction of a 50% tax rate on high earners. Eddie remains group chairman and managing director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Established Netease as an Internet portal in 1997 and has led the company through transformation into one of the world's largest online game companies.  Wealth is up in the past year amid a 47% increase in revenue, to $847 million, and 21% rise in net profit to $343 million. A partner of Blizzard Entertainment of the U.S., Netease launched World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King in China last August.  Holds an engineering degree from China's University of Electronic Science and Technology. Worked as a technical engineer for China Telecom and US-based database software company Sybase in mainland China prior to founding Netease. Ding also owns a pig farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: The 82-year-old owns the NFL's Tampa Bay Buccaneers, which is valued at $1 billion), excluding debt. Also controls English soccer's Manchester United, worth $1.84 billion --the sport's most valuable team, burdened by a near 50% debt load. Inherited watch business from father at 15; formed real estate company First Allied. Today owns more than 6.7 million square feet of retail space. His Glazer Children's Museum opened in Tampa this fall. Sons now manage family assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Major shareholder of Investments AB Latour, which holds stakes in Assa Abloy, world's largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of largest publicly traded security companies; and Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures. A member of the Swedish nobility (a count), his family is of Scottish origin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hobby Lobby founder David Green is a big contributor to Baptist ministries and evangelical education, like Jerry Falwell's Liberty University and Oral Roberts University. Latest philanthropic venture: acquiring Christian artifacts for the National Bible Museum. The museum will include items purchased by Green including medieval manuscripts, Hebrew scrolls and a rare sixth century Bible called the Codex Climaci Rescriptus (written partly in Palestinian Aramaic). The son of a poor preacher, Green started Hobby Lobby in 1970 in Oklahoma City with $600. Chain now has 435 arts and crafts stores in 35 states. Green has grown the company according to biblical principles, like closing stores on Sunday. Has delivered 420 million copies of Gospel booklet to children in 100 countries.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Low profile member of one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. In 2008 family's Unibanco merged with Banco Itau. Now he is a board member and one of the largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank and one of the world's fifteen largest banks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazilian filmmaker is a member of one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. In 2008 family's Unibanco merged with Banco Itau. Now he is one of largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank and one of the world's fifteen largest banks. He is also president of Instituto Moreira Salles, a non-profit foundation started in 1990 to promote cultural development in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made first fortune developing commercial and retail properties. Later sports: owns pro basketball's Denver Nuggets, hockey's Colorado Avalanche, football's St. Louis Rams,  plus stake in English soccer titan Arsenal; reportedly battling Russian oligarch Alisher Usmanov for control over the soccer club. Took control of Rams in August, but must relinquish majority stakes in Nuggets and Avalanche by the end of 2014 to comply with NFL ownership rules. Married to Ann Walton Kroenke, who inherited chunk of Walmart stock after father James (Bud) Walton died 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Matriarch chairs privately held media outfit Bennett, Coleman & Co, run by sons Samir and Vineet.  Portfolio includes The Times of India, and The Economic Times, newspapers; TV channels Times Now, Zoom and ET Now; FM radio network Radio Mirchi. Times Private Treaties, group's private equity arm, which barters ad space for equity, has stakes in over 135 companies.  Granddaughter Trishla, a Stanford grad, also works in group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low profile member of one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. Responsible for orchestrating merger of family's Unibanco with Banco Itau in 2008, creating global superpower Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank and one of the world's fifteen largest banks. Today serves as the bank's chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Well known and sometimes controversial Polish businessman has shares in brewer SABMiller to thank for big chunk of his fortune. Focusing on energy investments of late. In 2010 he listed Kulczyk Oil Ventures, an upstream oil and gas company with assets with Brunei, Syria and Ukraine. In January 2011 he bought gas power plant Elektrocieplownia Nowa Sarzyna. Owns a yacht, travels in his own plane. In Has homes in Florida, on the coast of France and on one of the islands of the Mediterranean Sea.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazilian filmmaker is a member of one of Brazil's oldest, most distinguished banking families. Named after father, Walther Moreira Salles, who founded Unibanco. In 2008 family's Unibanco merged with Banco Itau. He is one of largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank and one of the world's fifteen largest banks. Directed award-winning 1998 Brazilian film Central do Brasil ("Central Station").

name: Billionaires
bio: Dairy king's Leprino Foods supplies cheese for budget-friendly fare like Dominos, Papa John's, Pizza Hut pizzas, Hot Pockets, string cheese. Father, Mike Sr., came to the U.S. in 1914, settled in Colorado. Whipped up homemade mozzarella and ricotta cheese for local customers in 1950s. Son Jim joined company at 18; turned modest family business into world's largest mozzarella producer. Today Leprino Foods operates 12 plants around U.S. and Europe. By-products whey protein, lactose, sweet whey powder used in infant formula, yogurt. Plans for plant in Colorado expected to boost dairy production, fuel local economy.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Bangalore's GMR Group as it cashes in on India's infrastructure boom. Son-in-law Srinivas Bommidala runs flagship GMR Infrastructure whose New Delhi airport terminal was built in time for the Commonwealth Games. It sold holding in power unit InterGen to China's Huaneng Group for $1.2 billion. Singapore's Temasek has invested $200 million in GMR Energy. Family owns cricket team Delhi Daredevils.

name: Billionaires
bio: His late father cofounded Cadila in 1952 as a maker of vitamins. He took charge after company split in 1995 and built his listed Cadila Healthcare into India's fifth-largest pharma firm. Its VaxiFlu-S is the first swine flu vaccine made by an Indian company. It has recently joined Bayer Healthcare in a new marketing company. Group also makes Sugar Free, country's largest selling sweetener.  His US-educated son Sharvil works with him as deputy managing director

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed private equity colossus Carlyle Group with Daniel D'Aniello, William Conway in 1987; had early success putting ex-politicos to work buying defense-oriented businesses. Turned around operations, flipped for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money. Set to become the biggest private equity company after purchasing Dutch asset manager AlpInvest giving it nearly $150 billion assets under management (up from $98 billion). Deal is expected to close in March 2011. Sits on 30 nonprofit boards, including Lincoln Center and the Kennedy Center. Collector of historical artifacts: purchased first map copyrighted with American flag after American Revolution for $2.1 million from Christie's auction in December 2010. Lent this rare map to the Library of Congress. Also owns last privately-owned copy of the Magna Carta, the Emancipation Proclamation, and the Declaration of Independence lending each to the national archives, the oval office, and the state department respectively. Claims to read 6 books a week. Sign outside his Nantucket home says: "Rather be working."
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former special education teacher is the lone member of her family to serve on the board of directors of the medical device company Stryker founded by her grandfather, Homer H. Stryker, a surgeon who invented mobile hospital beds. She is passionate about education, the empowerment of women and the support of non-traditional college students. She is believed to be among the anonymous donors to the Kalamazoo Promise, a scholarship program that provides college tuition to all Kalamazoo Public School students. She's also an avid downhill skier and accomplished calligraphy artist.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Tu founded memory-chip operation Camintonn in 1982, sold four years later for $6 million. Formed Kingston Technology; sold 80% to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, immediately distributed $100 million in employee bonuses. Bought it back three years later for $450 million. Today Kingston is nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit; products grace cell phones, digital cameras, MP3 players. Beating competitors on price by closely monitoring chip supply to avoid having excess inventory if chip prices fall. Another tactic: using less packaging. Both billionaires continue to work in cubicles at center of sales floor.
title: COO

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner David Sun founded memory-chip operation Camintonn in 1982, sold four years later for $6 million. Formed Kingston Technology; sold 80% to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, immediately distributed $100 million in employee bonuses. Bought back three years later for $450 million. Today Kingston is nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit; products grace cell phones, digital cameras, MP3 players. Counting on demand-hungry Asia to offset weakness elsewhere. Beating competitors on price by closely monitoring chip supply to avoid having excess inventory if chip prices fall. Another tactic: using less packaging. Both billionaires continue to work in cubicles at center of sales floor. Plays drums with his band, JT and California Dreamin'.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Announced in August that newly discovered oil and gas field Leviathan, controlled by subsidiary of Tshuva's Delek Group, is estimated to contain 16 trillion cubic feet of easily recoverable gas and could hold 4.3 billion barrels of oil. Shares of publicly traded Delek Group, which operates 232 gas stations and has interests in insurance, car dealerships and cable television in Israel, just slightly higher than last year. Real estate holdings not so hot: Prized property, The Plaza, recovering but retail has not been immune to New York City's real estate downturn. Plans to build a Plaza-themed mega-casino in Vegas also turned sour.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped found and grow $45 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank wiith brothers Saleh, Sulaiman and Mohammed (Saleh passed away in February). Today, one of the largest Islamic banks in the world. Despite being forced to double provisions in October to safeguard against soured loans, bank stock has climbed slightly in past year, helping boost value of his 6% stake. Also holds various outside investments, including stakes in two cement factories, a diversified manufacturing business and a private bank and wealth advisory based out of Dubai and London.

name: Billionaires
