bio: Former rice trader gets bulk of fortune from Malaysia Mining Corp. (MMC), through which he holds concessions to operate a port and an airport in Johor; owns stake in power producer Malakoff. Through listed Tradewinds, recently took over national rice supplier Padiberas Nasional. Owns Harrods in Malaysia. Sponsors the Islamic Arts Museum Malaysia.

name: Billionaires
bio: The owner of basketball's Dallas Mavericks might jump into baseball this year; has shown interest in buying the New York Mets. In March he reached out to actor Charlie Sheen about a possible reality show on his cable channel HDNet. Last summer Cuban mounted a last-minute bid for baseball's Texas Rangers but lost out to Nolan Ryan's group. "I want to win championships, and in my mind there was hope of winning a World Series with the Rangers." Separately, he's touting startups as the catalyst for job creation and has an incentive plan: "Make all equity investments up to $250,000 and held for at least 3 years tax free when sold." Headline-grabbing entrepreneur voices opinions through tweets and blogmaverick.com. Started audio and video portal Broadcast.com with college pal Todd Wagner (also a billionaire); sold to Yahoo for $5.7 billion 1999. Current entertainment investments include HDNet, 2929 Entertainment.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Merger talks between his private company Palmary Enterprises, which owns Australia's manganese ore miner, Consolidated Minerals, and Australia's OM Holdings, regarded as world's last independent supplier of high-grade manganese, broke down in the fall; still owns 11% stake in OMH. With partner and fellow billionaire Ihor Kolomoyskyy controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in early 1990s. Stake in Ukraine's oil and gas giant Ukrnafta may be threatened as the government attempts to reassert control over the company. His Bogolyubov Foundation focuses on promoting Jewish education and religion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Frustrated by his inability to deliver high returns of late, Druckenmiller told investors in August that he'd be winding down his $12 billion (assets) hedge fund, Duquesne Capital Management, 30 years after he started the firm with $1 million. Hired by George Soros in 1988; duo reported to have made $1 billion in a day with timely short position on British Pound in 1992. Back on his own again in 2000. Reportedly made money in 2008 when most other firms tanked. In December 2009 he announced a $705 million commitment to "medical research, education and the fight against poverty", including $100 million for a new neuroscience institute at NYU Langone Medical Center. Chairs Harlem Children's Zone, which helps 17,000-plus children and adults.

name: Billionaires
bio: Timberland tycoon "Archie" took Sierra Pacific public in 1969, private again four years later. Bought 522,000 acres of Santa Fe Southern Pacific Railroad timberland with a $460 million loan in 1988. Today firm owns nearly 2 million acres in prestigious California and Washington regions. Patiently waiting out recession; biological tree growth allows acreage to uniquely appreciate over time. Son Mark handles finances.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former WWII Navy photographer, Hilton began hotelier career as an elevator operator at father Conrad Hilton's (d. 1972) El Paso Hilton. Initially resisted following in dad's footsteps; founded Carte Blanche Credit Card, Air Finance Corporation and AFL's LA Chargers. Helped negotiate merger with NFL to create Super Bowl. Returned to Hilton Hotels; named president, CEO in 1966. Introduced gambling to hotels; Hilton Hotels was first NYSE-traded company to enter casino gaming industry. In 2007 sold Hilton Hotels to private equity firm Blackstone for $26 billion; personally netted $800 million from the deal. Now focuses on philanthropy, flying, fishing. In 2007, pledged 97% of his wealth to Conrad N. Hilton Foundation, which is run by son Steven. In October, awarded Fédération Aéronautique Internationale's Gold Air Medal, the organization's highest sport aviation award for his lifelong dedication to aviation. His Barron Hilton Cup glider competition attracts international participants, winner receives a week-long camp at his Nevada ranch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Merged his French staffing company Ecco with Klaus Jacobs' Swiss Adia in 1996 to create Adecco. Now one of world's largest employment agencies, with $28.5 billion in sales. Per Swiss law, stepped down as co-chairman of Adecco in 2005 at age 73 and is now honorary president. Keeps busy as chairman of the board of Akila Finance, a holding company in Luxembourg. Lives in London, tazes there are lower than in France; was awarded the French Legion of Honor.  Business partner Klaus Jacobs died in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jewelry business insiders call British diamond merchant Graff the new Harry Winston. Specializing in the highest end of jewelry retailing, Graff has 33 stores worldwide. Clients include the Sultan and Queen of Brunei and Donald Trump. Prices for top-quality diamonds remained strong this year, driving Graff's net worth up. Graff attracted attention in November when he bought the highest-priced gem ever sold at auction, a 24.78-carat pink diamond he bid on over the phone at a Sotheby's sale in Geneva. He named the stone the Graff Pink. Graff broke his own record, the 2008 purchase at auction of a $24 million, 31-carat blue diamond he renamed the Graff-Wittelsbach. A self-made tycoon, Graff spent childhood in London's gritty East End, dropping out of school at age 14 to become a jeweler's apprentice. In 2008 he achieved full vertical integration when he bought a stake in publicly traded diamond miner Gem Diamonds. Other assets include jewelry company Graff Diamonds International, a polished diamond trading venture in Antwerp, a real estate company in Luxembourg that holds properties in London's tony Mayfair district, and a stake in a South African diamond wholesaler. Graff splits his time between homes in Gstaad, London, Cap Ferrat, New York City and his 150-foot Feadship yacht. Also owns Delaire Graff Estate, a vineyard and winery with a boutique hotel and restaurant in Stellenbosch, the Napa Valley of South Africa, and an extensive modern and contemporary art collection. On a personal note, Graff, 72, has acknowledged that he fathered a baby girl out of wedlock two years ago. He and French wife Anne-Marie have been married 48 years, and remain together.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Regained control over his former oil company Russneft last year; now restructuring debt, seeking potential mergers. This comes after he quit Moscow for London following trouble with the government several years ago. At end of 2006, was accused of violating terms of his oil license and failure to pay taxes. Gutseriev denied the charges; sold his oil firm, RussNeft, to billionaire Oleg Deripaska and left the country. Several charges since lifted. Born in Kazakhstan, to which his Ingush family had been deported after World War II. Later became president of state oil company Slavneft. Was dismissed in 2002 before privatization, but was able to return to big oil. Over four year period, Swiss trader Glencore helped him buy a number of small Russian oil firms, which he united into RussNeft.


At  In 2010 the deal with Russneft was turned around and Deripaska returned the company to Gutseriev. The deal was negotiated by the owner of AFK Systema Vladimir Yevtushenkov. Systema got 49% stake in Russneft.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Maruhan, Japan's largest operator of pachinko parlors, also owns Mister Donut, Seattle Coffee and Zoka franchises in Japan. Operates golf driving ranges, bowling alleys, movie theaters as well as hotel casino in Macau. Diversification keeping sales up, profits steady. Korean immigrant to Japan set up a cultural and educational center in his hometown of Sacheon, South Korea last year. Also established Hantetsu Cultural Foundation in Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oldest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri separated from family's business in 2008, and now runs his own real estate and investment vehicle from Monaco. Real estate arm Horizon Development partnered with Jordanian government to build a $5 billion new urban area in downtown Amman. Expanded his main line of business, logistics & transportation, by merging with logistic company Globe Express Services. In 2010 bought logistics company Globe Express Services. Investment arm Farass has stakes in high- tech companies, including Apple. Most investments are now outside of Lebanon. Pledged $15 million for a new computing institute at Boston University, his alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ingram family matriarch took over as chairman of distribution conglomerate $1.9 billion (estimated sales) Ingram Industries in 1995, after husband's death. Group transports commodities on barges, distributes books. In 2009 merged its book, print-on-demand and digital divisions into Ingram Content group, overseen by her son John, who replaced her as chairman in 2008. Provides print on demand services. Also provides publisher content to Apple's iBookstore for iPad. Ingram Entertainment, run by son David, is a distributor of DVDs and video games. Son Orrin runs industrial businesses. Marine division operates nearly 4,000 barges and over 100 towboats, hauling coal, grain, fertilizer on America's inland waterways. Vassar grad is prominent in Nashville society; sits on boards of four cultural institutions that support theater, opera and the symphony in Tennessee.
title: Former Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ingram Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Former Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Ankara-born heiress is youngest sister of magnate Rahmi Koc, head of family conglomerate Koc Group.  Fluent in French and English, is former recipient of Woman of the Year award sponsored by university women's group in Turkey. Honorary Fellow of London Business School also named a library for herself at a university founded by her family. She can only communicate using her eyes; she has ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis), also known as Lou Gherig's disease.

name: Billionaires
bio: He diversified his portfolio in media and oil and gas last year, including increasing his stake to nearly 25% of London-listed JKX Oil and Gas. With partner and fellow billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in early 1990s. Stake in Ukraine's oil and gas giant Ukrnafta may be threatened as the government attempts to reassert control over the company. Was appointed president of the European Council of Jewish Communities in what some called a coup.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the fall of 2009 the Cirque du Soleil founder became the first clown in space when he blasted into orbit after 6 months training in Russia. Back on Earth, his circus continues to expand across the map with 22 shows in spread throughout the U.S., Europe, Africa and Asia. Planning to partner with the Light Group to build a Cirque themed mega-club in Las Vegas next year. The former fire-breather started Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus became a for-profit group in 1985. He bought out majority partner in 2000. Hit jackpot when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas in 1991. Today group has six permanent shows in Sin City. In 2008 he sold 20% of Cirque to two Dubai firms for $600 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: The world's first ethanol billionaire announced a joint venture with Shell that is being hailed as an  important collaboration between a global oil giant and a Brazilian renewable energy company. Ometto controls Cosan S.A., one of the world's largest growers and processors of sugarcane, also one of the largest producers of ethanol and one of Brazil's key fuel distributors. Cosan listed its shares on the Brazilian stock exchange in 2005 and the New York Stock Exchange in 2007. The company's origins date from 1936, when the Ometto's grandparents established a sugarcane mill in Piracicaba, northwest of Sao Paulo. Cosan has grown into an integrated sugar and ethanol producer and distributor through acquisitions and new partnerships. In 2008 Cosan paid a reported $1 billion to buy fuel retailer and distributor Esso's assets from ExxonMobil.

name: Billionaires
bio: A legend in the Calgary oilpatch, Riddell has been working the territory for five decades. The output from his earliest natural gas wells fetched just 15 cents per thousand cubic feet, but he stuck with it, eventually cobbling together a prime position in the burgeoning oil sands region that he sold to Norway's Statoil. Though his primary vehicle remains Paramount Resources, shares of upstart Trilogy Energy have surged in the past year on new discoveries in the Montney oil play. He is part owner of the Calgary Flames hockey team.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Paramount Resources Ltd.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Future Electronics in 1968 and built it into the world's third-largest electronics distributor; products include semiconductors and electromechanical components. Gained momentum in 2010 with sales back up from lagging electronic sales through most of 2009. Investing in Europe and Asia. Supports Alcor Life Extension Foundation, which promotes cryonics, the science of freezing bodies with the intent to restore life when technology becomes available. Currently sitting in the middle of a messy divorce with wife, Margaret Antonier.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year, with billionaires Suleiman Kerimov and Filaret Galchev, bought a 53% stake in fertilizer producer Uralkali from Dmitry Rybolovlev (also a billionaire). The company is merging with Silvinit; Nesis will have an 8.5% stake in the combined entity. Started out in the 1990s by reinvesting profits from Central Asian uranium mining into other metals, shipbuilding. Created miner Polymetal; sold the company to Kerimov in 2005; bought back stake at rock-bottom prices three years later during the financial crisis, now owns 19%. His IST Group also controls Nomos Bank, which is planning to IPO in London and Moscow this year, as well as a railroad-car repair factory, a chemicals factory and land for housing developments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of late Greek shipping magnate Stavros Niarchos inherited father's art collection of such masterpieces as Vincent van Gogh's "Self-Portrait with a Bandaged Ear" and Pablo Picasso's self-portrait "Yo, Picasso." Philip, who is a board member of the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, has added such contemporary works as Jean-Michel Basquiat's "Self-Portrait" and Andy Warhol's "Shot Red Marilyn." Commissioned to do Philip's portrait, Warhol created a series based on CAT-scans of Philip's skull. While Philip is intensely private, multiple art experts pinned his collection as world's most valuable in private hands.

name: Billionaires
bio: Southern California real estate baron owns more than 100 developments, with 10,000 multifamily residences and 6.2 million-plus square feet of office space. Other holdings: golf courses, marina, restaurants, plane, yacht. Suing UBS and others for fraud. Pled guilty to tax felony in 2007 for stashing more than $200 million in Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Road hauler Schneider National recovering from 2009's rough year; 2010 revenue increased 28% to $3.7 billion. Looking to China for growth. Father, Al, founded freight company with one truck in 1935, grew rapidly through acquisitions, expanding into interstate shipping. Donald, who became president in 1976, pioneered use of satellite tracking technology, transportation logistics. Today ranks with companies like J.B. Hunt as one of the largest truckload carriers in North America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sister of fellow billionaire Ferit Sahenk, who runs family's Dogus Holding. Filiz Sahenk handles the group's retail partnerships with luxury brands Tod's (owned by new Italian billionaires Diego and Andrea Della Valle) and Armani (Georgio Armani is also a billionaire). Advocate of women's leadership is also president of Ayhan Sahenk Foundation. Also active in the International Myeloma Foundation. Has a large antique collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Yurun Group of Nanjing has a diversified business empire. Zhu's main listed company is China Yurun Food, a pork processor that trades in Hong Kong and competes in China with Hormel Foods. His main retail business is Nanjing Central Emporium, which is listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Cut his stake in Yurun Food to 25% from 30% in November. Studied at the China Europe International Business School in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retail mogul Schulze received electronics training during his stint with the Minnesota Air National Guard. Worked at father's electronics distribution company before opening his own stereo store in 1966. Renamed it Best Buy in 1983 and took it public in 1985. Began warehouse-model in 1989 to attract more customers, thicken margins. Encouraged customers to play with products. Stepped down as CEO in 2002 but is still chairman of the board. Retailer now has $49.7 billion in sales and 1100 domestic stores. Continuing international expansion; opened first Best Buy branded stores in Turkey in 2009 and the UK April 2010.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns investment bank Stephens, Inc. founded by uncle W.R. (Witt) in 1933 with $15,000 to start underwriting and dealing muni bonds. Father Jackson (d. 2005) joined in 1946. Brothers paid $5.4 million for Arkansas-Oklahoma Gas in 1954. Plowed earnings into private equity. Investment criteria: "Whim and caprice." Famously underwrote Wal-Mart's public offering in 1970. Warren grew up in the business, became chief executive 1986. Witt died 1991. Bought out cousins' stake in 2006. Adding to private equity stakes like Stephens Media, which owns 30 newspapers including Las Vegas Review-Journal. Golf nut built ultra-private Alotian Club on 1,000 acres outside of town. Also a wine aficionado, he sold 5,000 bottles in Sotheby's auction 2007. His favorite quaff: 1959 Chateau Latour.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a barber, Anderson sold popcorn as a kid to earn extra cash. Attended UCLA on a hockey scholarship and earned $14 a week working nights at an aircraft factory; graduated Phi Beta Kappa. Naval officer during WWII, he studied for CPA exam in spare time; graduated first in his law school night class from Loyola. Started his own law firm in 1953. Three years later, founded Ace Beverage with exclusive rights to deliver Budweiser in Los Angeles. Through Topa Equities, expanded into insurance, auto dealerships, agriculture and real estate. Real estate portfolio has 4 million square feet of commercial space in California, Hawaii, US Virgin Islands. Emphasizes saving; has called compound interest the "eighth world wonder."

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Shanghai-listed Xinjiang Guanghui Industry is the richest man in China's Xinjiang Province. Guanghui's biggest source of profit is real estate. However, the company is investing aggressively in energy, too. Guanghui's "Flying Tigers" basketball team ranked no. 2 in the country's basketball league last year. James Singleton, a former NBA player with the Dallas Mavericks and Washington Wizards, plays for the team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime head of Esprit steadily reduced his majority stake in recent years, pocketing close to $2 billion along the way. Sold his remaining stake in the apparel firm this year; gave up board seat in 2009. Got his big break in 1971 when company's American founders hired him as their primary sourcing agent; eventually bought rights to the clothing brand in Europe and Asia. Married to former Taiwanese movie star Brigitte Lin. Said to be an amateur paleontologist and an enthusiastic golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: The deputy chair of Edizione SRL founded the Benetton Group with his siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto in 1965. Today Benetton is a $2.85 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley. Shares are down 20% over the last year as the increasing cost of commodities and small exposure to the red hot Asian markets hurt growth forecasts. The family also owns a big stake in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies; this asset is now worth more than the clothing company.

name: Billionaires
bio: The clothing king chairs his family's holding company, Edizione SR. He also makes investments via personal holding company Regia SRL. Along with siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Carlo, he formed Benetton Group in 1965. The $2.85 billion (sales) clothing company sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley. Shares are down 20% over the last year as the increasing cost of commodities and small exposure to the red hot Asian markets hurt growth forecasts. The family also owns a significant chunk of Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies; this asset is now worth more than the clothing retailer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Giuliana originally knitted sweaters that brother Luciano would peddle by bicycle; sold under a variety of labels before becoming United Colors of Benetton. She founded the Benetton Group with siblings Luciano, Carlo and Gilberto in 1965. Today Benetton is a $2.85 billion (sales) clothing company, with brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley. Shares are down 20% over the last year as the increasing cost of commodities and small exposure to the red hot Asian markets hurt growth forecasts. The family also owns a large chunk of Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies; this asset is now worth more than the clothing business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Gilberto, formed Benetton Group in 1965. After running it for four decades, Luciano is now chairman of the $2.85 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley. Shares are down 20% over the last year as the increasing cost of commodities and small exposure to the red hot Asian markets hurt growth forecasts. The family also owns a large chunk of Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies; this asset is now worth more to the family than the clothing retailer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Record-label tycoon started out playing in a band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father's death. Moved to London in 1975 and founded Zomba Recordings, whose crown jewel is Jive Records. Ventured stateside in 1978, signing acts like Billy Ocean and the Cars, later Britney Spears, Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync. Sold Zomba Recordings to BMG for $2.7 billion in 2002. Now lives in the Cayman Islands, spending part of his time on charitable foundation Elma Philanthropies, which works in twelve African countries on children's education and health issues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Mary Janet Cargill, who died February 2010, now shares his mother's fortune with his two siblings; their net worths are up as a result, despite the fact that Cargill's sales and earnings slipped. He is one of seven relatives on the Forbes billionaires' list to earn fortune from Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S., in which the family owns an 88% stake. Company is planning to divest itself of stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic later in 2011. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. No family member has run company since Whitney MacMillan  stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Mary Janet Cargill, who died February 2010, now shares his mother's fortune with his two siblings; their net worths are up as a result, despite the fact that Cargill's sales and earnings slipped. He is one of seven relatives on the Forbes billionaires' list to earn fortune from Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S., in which the family owns an 88% stake. Company is planning to divest itself of stake in fertilizer maker Mosaic. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909.  No family member has run company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: The private equity chief is among the group of tycoons vying for ownership of the NBA's Detroit Pistons. He paid his way at Michigan State by telemarketing; cofounded software firm. Started buyout business with brother Alec (also a billionaire); later founded Platinum Equity out of his home in 1995; has since made more than 100 acquisitions. Buys underperformers with good assets. "You can't control the market. You can control your company."

name: Billionaires
bio: Namesake of Campbell Soup founder lives quietly in South Dublin after cashing out of family business; sold off much of his 10.5% stake in Campbell Soup for $1.5 billion in mid 1990s. Renounced U.S. citizenship, moved to Ireland before the sale, presumably to avoid capital gains taxes. Said to frequent Bahamas with Finnish wife. Joined movement to legalize game ranching in Wyoming, fox hunting in Great Britain.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, three brothers, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang, and sister Daniela, inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz. Headed the family Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, for almost 35 years. A  nasty family feud led him and his sister Daniela to sell their combined 40% stake in the German consumer goods group to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in 2003. Now he and his sister own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in German shipping company Germanischer Lloyd. Mayfair is reportedly backing Panel Board Holding, a Dutch company which makes building materials out of wheat straw waste. Sold a stake in Puma  to Francois Pinault's PPR group for well over $1 billion in 2007. Brother Joachim died in 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.  Raises horses at his stud farm; races his yacht All Smoke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Honorary chairman of Japanese retailer Seven & I, which operates 7-Eleven convenience stores, supermarkets, and restaurants. Though sales flat for the first nine months of the fiscal year, net profits rose 30% due to cost controls, scale-back in capital investment. Company remains concerned over slow recovery in consumer consumption. Looking to expand in China. Stock is up 12% over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Only son of former Samsung Group chairman Lee Kun Hee. Promoted to president of Samsung Electronics in December 2010. Previously served as vice president and chief operating officer. Began his career at Samsung, Korea's largest conglomerate, in 1991. Has an MBA from Keio University in Japan. Samsung accounts for almost 20% of Korea's gross domestic product, is the world's top liquid-crystal display panel and memory chipmaker. It's the second largest mobile phone manufacturer after Nokia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Lee & Man Paper, one of Asia's largest paper producers. In a year when the paper industry has been battling rising costs for raw materials, Lee & Man managed to eke out a 2% increase in profits for the six months to September. Sales rose by 36% to a six-month record of $885 million as global economic recovery and brisk growth in China boosted orders.  Sons Raymond and Man Bun run the business. Nippon Paper paid $470 million for a stake last June. Lee is the honorary principal of the Qionghai Jiaji Secondary School and Hainan Guoxing Secondary School in the mainland. He is an honorary citizen of Dongguan in Guangdong Province. Enjoys horse racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Mary Janet Cargill, who died February 2010, now shares her mother's fortune with her two siblings; their net worths are up as a result, despite the fact that Cargill's sales and earnings slipped. She is one of several relatives on the billionaires list to earn fortune from Cargill, the largest private company in the U.S., in which the family owns an 88% stake. Company is divesting its stake in fertilizer Mosaic later this year. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. No family member has run company since Whitney MacMillan stepped down as chief executive in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in South Africa, he bought his first stock at age 13. Member of legendary professional investing team at BT Funds Management in 1980s. Left to set up his own Platinum Asset Management, with backing from George Soros, in 1993. Cashed out part of stake in his Platinum Asset Management in a well-timed offering in 2007; still owns 57%. Artist wife, Judith, runs the White Rabbit Gallery in Sydney, showcasing one of the world's largest collections of contemporary Chinese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of visionary oil baron John D. Rockefeller now working to give away his fortune. Key beneficiaries: New York's Museum of Modern Art, Rockefeller University, Harvard, Americas Society, Council on Foreign Relations. Grandfather turned $4,000 in oil refining into Standard Oil, energy giant that fueled American industrial revolution. Company broken up in landmark antitrust case 1911. Father invested in real estate. Has collected modern and contemporary art for more than 70 years; parents helped establish MoMA. Insect enthusiast has one of largest beetle collections in world.

name: Billionaires
bio: The founder of Chile's LAN airlines, Pinera was elected president of Chile in January 2010 and took office in March, just days after a deadly earthquake struck, killing 500 and causing $30 billion in damages. Yet he oversaw an economy that grew 5.2% last year. Pinera, a conservative, plans bold reforms in 2011 including overhauling education and healthcare. His approval ratings dipped below 50% after the trapped Chilean miners were rescued and have stayed below 50%. Since taking office he fulfilled a campaign pledge to divest his holdings, selling his 26% stake in LAN Airlines for $1.5 billion, the TV channel Chilevision to Time Warner for a reported $150 million, and his stake in Blanco y Negro, owners of  Chile's  most popular football team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine's youngest billionaire benefiting from rising iron ore prices; stock in his iron ore producer Ferrexpo doubled over the past year. In the summer rumors swirled of a tie up with Czech billionaire Zdenek Bakala's NWR, which bought a 21% stake in Ferrexpo in 2008. Company recently purchased Danube River waterway transport provider Helogistics. Graduate of Kyiv State Economic University is also a parliamentary deputy; his party is in opposition to President Yanukovich's Party of Regions. Soccer fan owns FC Vorskla football.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older of two living billionaire brothers descended from a Middle Eastern banking family. In 2006 Moise sold to his brother Joseph his holding in Banco Safra, now Brazil's 9th-largest bank, plus stakes in Safra-owned banks in New York, Luxembourg and other locations, for an undisclosed sum estimated at $2 billion. Joseph and Moise's deceased brother Edmond had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife Lily.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and majority shareholder of Polsat, the first private television broadcaster in Poland, which was recently purchase by Cyfrowy Polsat, a digital satellite TV platform listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange that is also controlled by Solorz-Zak. Owns shares in Invest Bank, pension fund PTE Polsat, pharmaceutical company Bioton and TV producer ATM Group. Has stated his interest in taking over from the government one of the largest energy producers in Poland, ZE PAK. Enjoys playing tennis and yachting.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Rajawali Corp. sold stake in cementmaker Semen Gresik for $1.1 billion this year; had previously cashed out stakes in tobacco firm Bentoel International and cellphone firm Excelcomindo Pratama. Used some of the cash to acquire 46 percent of PT Nusantara Infrastructure, toll road operator, in November.  Rumored to be planning backdoor listing of plantation business through newly acquired Eatertainment International. Said to be looking for coal, gold investments. Also has investments in hotels; picked up Surfers Paradise in Queensland last year. His Rajawali Foundation at Harvard University put out major study recommending reforms for Indonesian economy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beanie Babies craze that made him a billionaire faded years ago, but Ty Inc. still sells plush toys in 50,000 retail outlets. New offerings: Beanie Boo's, Li'l Ones and Beanie Bandz; sold 1.7 million rubber bracelets at wholesale in first week. Warner bought Four Seasons New York Hotel in 1999; cost to spend a night in his Ty Warner Penthouse Suite: $35,000 a night, considered most expensive hotel room in America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soaring on solar's fortunes. The chairman of polysilicon maker GCL-Poly Energy is $1 billion richer this year amid a flurry of contracts, improved profit and a doubling in price of its Hong Kong-listed shares.  GCL in October signed a silicon wafer supply contract with Indosolar of India valued at $600 million over four years. In February, GCL and Wells Fargo in the U.S. announced funding for six solar projects in California. The company has a research center in Richland, Washington. Zhu is also vice chairman of the Cogeneration Professional Committee of the Chinese Society for Electrical Engineering.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the largest individual investors in the Saudi stock market. Holdings include major stakes in Savola Group, one the Kingdom's largest food processors, finance institution Banque Saudi Fransi and resort operator Saudi Hotels. Major investor in real estate development company Al Aqeeq, which is planning seven upscale hotels near the Grand Mosque in and around Mecca and Medina.

name: Billionaires
bio: A tiff is brewing between companies run by Azcarraga, the chief executive of powerhouse Mexican TV broadcaster Televisa, and Carlos Slim, Mexico's richest man. Slim-controlled phone companies Telmex and Telcel as well as retailers belonging to Grupo Carso pulled their advertising from Televisa in late February after Televisa increased ad rates by 20%. Televisa said the increase came because the Slim companies did not participate in "upfront" ad buying for the year. Analysts say a truce may still be reached. Meanwhile, Azcarraga is nudging into Slim's hold on telephony in Mexico by offering bundled Internet, phone and cable TV through Televisa's cable TV unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads construction company CD-155, which saw an uptick in building this year. State orders flowing: took part in reconstruction of famed Bolshoi Theater and in building new homes for people who lost theirs in the fires of last summer's heat wave. After graduating from the Moscow Institute of Civil Engineering, started out at one of the divisions of Soviet construction behemoth Glavmosstroi. In 1993 that division became a private company called Construction Department 155; Balakin is its largest shareholder. Later worked in highly-placed jobs in the Moscow city government and in 2005, after four years as a bureaucrat, turned his focus to his business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth generation of family to run $7.9 billion (revenues) Globus & Co., one of Germany's largest food retailers. Also operates 83 hardware stores and nine electrical appliance stores. Great great grandfather Franz Bruch opened first store in 1828. Thomas Bruch took over from his father in 1979.  With his three sons working at firm, continued family stewardship seems assured.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Gap in 1969 with late husband Donald, who died in 2009 of cancer at age 81. Originally a San Francisco jeans and music store, Gap empire has grown to more than 3,000 locations and expanded to include Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986) and Old Navy (1994). Owns large contemporary art collection, featuring pieces by Andy Warhol, Chuck Close, Richard Serra and Alexander Calder. Loaned collection to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 2010 after attempt to open museum in San Francisco's historic Presidio district was nixed following resident complaints. Handed control to three sons John, Robert and William in 2004; John has minority stake in Oakland A's baseball team.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: Former dermatologist sold drug manufacturer Ivax to Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005; elected chairman of Teva last March. Teva, where he holds large chunk of fortune, has seen stock price drop by 15% over last year. Also invested in slew of biotech startups, including Miami-based biopharma company Opko Health, Inc., and medical device company SafeStitch LLC. Took over Key Pharmaceuticals with partner Michael Jaharis 1972; created new delivery systems for old drugs. Sold to Schering-Plough in 1986; founded Ivax the following year to develop generic pharmaceuticals and veterinary products. Vice chair of Teva, trustee of the Scripps Research Institute. With wife, Patricia, gives away millions of dollars a year to the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Griffin's hedge fund Citadel celebrated its twentieth anniversary in 2010 with 10% gains, following a 62% surge in 2009. Assets are $12 billion, well below the $20 billion it managed in 2008 before the economic crisis. Began investing as Harvard undergrad when he read Forbes article about Home Shopping Network. Art enthusiast is board member at the Museum of Contemporary Art and the Art Institute of Chicago. Wife Anne runs Aragon Global hedge fund.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Senator from Murmansk Oblast in northwestern Russia is benefiting from fertilizer boom. Last year his Fosagro, the second-largest producer of phosphorous fertilizer concentrate in the world, signed a record-breaking deal for a $1.5 billion delivery of fertilizers to India. Former Moscow communist committee leader; in early 1990s became avid capitalist working with Mikhail Khodorkovsky's Menatep Group and then ran a department of Rosprom, which managed the industrial assets of Menatep. In 2001 ran the board of directors of Apatit, which was a part of Rosprom. Led a management buyout of Apatit during the prosecution of former billionaire Khodorkovsky and acquired control. Apatit became the main holding of Fosagro.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg and four brothers, Gunter, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang, inherited a fortune from her father, coffee magnate Max Herz. A nasty family feud led her and older brother Gunter to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, to their mother and three other brothers for an estimated $5 billion in 2003. She and Gunter now own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in German shipping company Germanischer Lloyd. Mayfair is reportedly backing Panel Board Holding, a Dutch company that makes building materials out of wheat straw waste. Sold a stake in Puma to Francois Pinault's PPR group for more than $1 billion in 2007. Brother Joachim died in 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of China's most successful real estate developers, Huang controls Shanghai-listed investment company Xinhu Zhongbao through Zhejiang Xinhu Group, his main holding company. Headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou, Xinhu Zhongbao has more than 30 real estate projects under development in 20-plus cities. Company is a shareholder in financial service firms including Shengjing Bank, Chengdu Rural Commercial Bank, Xiangcai Securities and Xinhu Futures. In January 2011, Xinhu Zhongbao said it would form a 70%-owned joint venture movie and television production company, in partnership with well-known Chinese film industry figures Hu Mei and He Yanjiang. Expanding its real estate investments in southern China, Xinhu Zhongbao bought 35% of Guangzhou real estate company Times Group for $200 million in February 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forced out of McCain Foods' day-to-day operations in the 1990s after family feud; remains vice chairman with one-third stake in the company, which is the world's largest producer of frozen french fries. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods, where son Michael is chief, in 1995. This year, disputes erupted among shareholders concerning whether directors are too closely involved on a personal level with McCain family. Donates to philanthropic causes like National Ballet School of Canada and National Gallery of Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: BP paid wildcatter Lewis $200 million in March 2010 to set up a joint venture to drill on 100,000 of his acres in the Eagle Ford Shale in Texas. He still controls another 300,000 acres in the area: "We have a 28-year head start in this area." He also has oilfields in Colombia and is the only American with a contract to drill for Pemex in Mexico, though latter has been called off because of border violence. In 1978 took a job driving 300 miles a day to check gauges on oil and gas wells. His commute improved after he paid $4,200 for a 65hp Aeronca Chief prop plane (he had gotten flying lessons from his father, an Air Force pilot). He soon started his own gauging business. In 1983 bought his first well for $13,000. He had no engineering degree--he trained as a mechanic and got a B.A. in criminal justice--but met a lot of teachers. "You wouldn't believe how much I learned just talking to the service guys who were working on somebody else's project." Then bought wells in gas-rich Dimmit and Webb counties, began drilling his own and building pipelines. Passion: owns 20 World War II fighter planes. Best known is Glacier Girl, a P-38 that crashed in Greenland during the war, only to be steamed out of ice 50 years later. Survived esophageal cancer.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older sister Esther, also a billionaire, inherited construction firm Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. Their husbands ran the company from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The sisters took over and jointly ran the business until 1997, when Alicia sold her share to Esther for $800 million. Over the years, has invested the proceeds in such companies as steelmaker Acerinox,  electric utility Iberdrola and Banco Sabadel; also owns hotels in Spain, Italy and Portugal; real estate in the U.S., Hong Kong and China. Controls two hedge funds, one in Spain and one in England, that manage over $700 million in funds. Through her charitable foundation, sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. at places like Columbia University's Medical Center. In 2009 was named an honorary member of the Spanish Society of Psychiatrists for her efforts in promoting the study and development of child and juvenile psychology. Has been linked romantically with the Duque de Huescar, heir to the Spanish aristocratic house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother, Bennett Dorrance (also a billionaire), sits on the board of Campbell Soup, founded by grandfather John T. Dorrance, who developed method of canning condensed soup in 1897. Now company is world's leading soup maker with $7.7 billion in revenues. Owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth). Breeds horses at her Iron Spring Farm in Pennsylvania. Recently embroiled in alleged extortion scheme by one-time friend who reportedly demanded a $250,000 allowance to keep quiet about the heiress' life. An indictment for three counts of extortion has been filed in federal court.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Kong-born developer has been busy in Shanghai, where he is famous for developing one of the city's modern landmarks, the Xintiandi entertainment district. His Shui On Land paid $477 million in September for land next to newly booming transportation hub in the Hongqiao area on Shanghai's western side. Born into an entrepreneurial family, Lo first started building his business in China in 1985, one of the first in Hong Kong's building sector to do so. Remarried to a former Miss Hong Kong in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained lawyer made his fortune in banking. Gained notoriety during the Bank of New York money-laundering scandal at the end of the 1990s, when the Moscow State University graduate was known as "the Yeltsin family banker." (No charges were filed against him in connection with the case.) Considering sale of part of his 51% stake in mobile phone retail chain Evroset in a potential initial public offering in London this year. In January increased his stake in home entertainment retailer HMV Group to 6%; rumored to be planning an unsolicited bid for the retailer's bookshop chain Waterstone's. One of the founders of Imperial Bank, at one point ran MDM-Bank and was a major investor in Troika-Dialog investment bank and Ingosstrakh insurance company. In recent years has preferred the role of portfolio investor, putting money into real estate, retail, construction and oil fields. In 2007 bought U.S.-based blogging site LiveJournal.com, extremely popular among Russian users. Pet projects: cultural center Art-Strelka and art-house cinema theater Pioneer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of his shoemaker Geox are down nearly 20% over the past year as high material costs hurt net profit. Wine maker cut holes in shoe soles during hot walk in Nevada 1989. Developed membrane that let shoes breathe; blocked dirt and water. Idea turned down by Nike. Founded Geox 1995; took public 2004. Second largest casual shoe maker in world. Makes footwear for men, women, children; branched into golf spikes and clothing. Champions practical research and development, innovation, the importance of patents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Horse breeder who started privately-held Serum Institute of India in a corner of his father's stud farm and built it into big exporter of children's vaccines. Launched nasal vaccine for swine flu last year.  Also has minority stakes in generics maker Orchid Chemicals and rival Panacea Biotec.  Son Adar oversees operations. Collects custom-built cars. He's planning to build a charitable hospital in the name of his late wife Villoo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Well regarded investor bought more BP stock after big spill last year. He's part owner of Pebble Beach golf course in California, which hosted U.S. Open in June 2010. Wholesaler's son helped manage the Bass family's $50 million portfolio in 1970s; eventually made billions. Supports Teach for America, charter school group Knowledge is Power Program (known as KIPP). Rainwater received Stanford Business School's prestigious Arbuckle Award in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Renowned investor founded hedge fund Tiger Management (son suggested name) in 1980. It became one of the world's biggest hedge funds, peaking at $22 billion in assets under management in 1998. Suffered severe losses from the burst of the tech bubble in 2000. Still invests but does not take money from any new investors. Mentors former employees, known as Tiger Cubs, who've done well themselves: Among them are billionaire Steve Mandel and tycoon John Griffin, who dedicated a building at The McIntire School of Commerce at the University of Virginia in Robertson's name. Also advises and invests in the latest generation of potential hedge fund stars known as Tiger Seeds. Fan of New Zealand: in addition to vineyards, has built golf courses and is opening his third resort there. Pledged half his wealth to charity via  the Bill Gates-Warren Buffett Giving Pledge. In his letter to Buffett says: "One very fortunate thing is that I did not get nearly as enthusiastic about philanthropy early on as I am now; if I had there would be very little to give away."

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns the Philippines' largest cigarette maker, Fortune Tobacco; and second largest beer maker Asia Brewery. Biggest chunk of fortune comes from Hong Kong-based Eton Properties which is continuing its expansion in China. Philippine Airlines, which he controls, suffered disruptions over a strike threat by pilots. Expects big blow from country's new "open skies" policy introduced last year. Got his start as a chemical engineer and mopped floors to pay for school. Enjoys flying helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of industrialist Stefan Schorghuber, who died unexpectedly in 2008 at age 47. The mother of three worked for several years alongside her husband in the group's hotel, ski lift and golf segments; since his death she has taken her husband's place as head of the group's supervisory board. She oversees a fortune that includes breweries, real estate, construction and services.  Family is well-known in Munich for its support of modern art and its subsidized holidays for underprivileged children and their families.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the four co-owners of coal company Sibuglemet holding; he serves as president. The asset is cresting with rising coking coal prices. Former Soviet machine building factory designer, started working for state-owned Rosugol where he took part in the reform of the Russian coal industry. With Vladimir Melnichenko and Valentin Bukhtoyarov (both billionaires) founded Sibuglemet in 1995; joined by Alexander Shchukin (also a billionaire) in 1999. Last summer, with State Duma deputy Zelimkhan Mutsoev, bought a 47% stake in potash miner Silvinit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Returns to billionaires' list after 12 year hiatus; was last listed in 1999 with $1.9 billion fortune. Owns some 20% of one of Portugal's largest retailers  $10 billion (revenues) Jeronimo Martins, which traces its beginnings to a tiny store in Lisbon opened in 1792. Shares up nearly 50% over the past year. Company operates super and hypermarkets (Pingo Doce, Feira Nova and Recheio) in Portugal and retail stores (Biedronka) and pharmacies (Bliska Apteka Na Zdrowie) in Poland. Was president from 1996 -2004; president of supervisory board since 2004. Four of his seven children work in the company; son Pedro is CEO, son Jose is a director.
person: {'name': 'Eliseo Alexandre Soares dos Santos & family', 'uri': 'alexandre-soares-dos-santos', 'imageExists': False, 'squareImage': '//specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/58a0752da7ea431f3219551d/416x416.jpg?background=000000&cropX1=0&cropX2=733&cropY1=153&cropY2=886'}
personName: Eliseo Alexandre Soares dos Santos & family

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of his real estate investment trust Taubman Centers surged more than 65% as REITs recover. The mall maven is bringing the film industry to Pontiac, Mich., installing Raleigh Studios Michigan in an old GM truck plant. U. of Michigan dropout founded Taubman Centers in 1950; today firm runs 26 malls; 8 more in the works. Took auction house Sotheby's private in 1983, public again in 1988; family sold controlling interest in 2005. Penned memoir, Threshold Resistance, about career and 9-month prison sentence served in 2004 on art auction price-fixing charges.

name: Billionaires
bio: In late 1980s acquired Knorr-Bremse AG and transformed it into world's leading manufacturer of braking systems for rail and commercial vehicles. Saw sales drop 18% in 2009 to $3.9 billion as a result of the global recession.Group is a big player in China where it has five joint ventures and its own production plant; in 2009 won a $680 million contract to equip a Chinese high-speed train with braking and door systems. Chairman of supervisory  board; said to  enjoy hiking, skiing and animal photography.  Has received various awards for his philanthropic contributions, including his support of children's cancer research and aid to developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech visionary, early backer of Google: his initial $100,000 investment is now worth some $2 billion. Also was cofounder of Sun Microsystems; an inventor of Cisco Systems's switching business. Cofounded and ran Kealia, a computer design system that he sold to Sun in 2004.  Left Sun Microsystems in 1995, returned in 2004 as senior vice president and chief architect. In October 2009 resigned from Sun (now a part of Oracle) to become chairman and chief development officer of Arista networks, a tech outfit that will compete against network equipment maker Cisco Systems. Project reunites him with Canadian billionaire David Cheriton, cofounder and chief scientist of the venture. The pair's previous project, Granite Systems, was sold to Cisco in 1996.  Also has stake in chip-designing software maker Magma Design Automation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last April he opened Wynn Encore, his new $600 million Macau casino. Construction of a new casino in Macau's Cotai area is slated to begin in 2011. Shares of his Wynn Resorts recovered 100% over the last year as the credit crisis eased and investors gambled on casino stocks. Divorce from his (second) divorce from his wife, Elaine, now also a billionaire, became final January 2010. Son of bingo parlor operator; his Vegas resort has an 111,000-sq.-ft. casino.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Resorts', 'uri': 'companies/wynn-resorts', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: In February the footloose billionaire raised about $1.1 billion for a new cash shell called Justice, targeting investments in companies worth $1.4 billion or more. His holdings range from a revitalization project in Newark, N.J. to Hydro Electric Power Plants in Turkey to a Spanish media conglomerate. In September he brought German retailer Karstadt out of bankruptcy for $95 million and recently said he had improved the department store chain's revenues since taking over. Has been a vocal proponent for fixing California's government -- put $20 million into a committee focused on the state's problems. Collector of Picasso, Warhol, Basquiat and Koons, claims he likes to hold on to art more than hoarding cash. Father, Heinz, amassed world-famous collection of works by Picasso. Berggruen grew up in France and Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fast fashion welcomes a new pair of billionaires to the fold. Founder of Forever 21 Do Won and his wife Jin Sook Chang immigrated to America from Korea in 1981. They opened their first store in 1984; sales grew from $35k to $700k that year. Today Forever 21 operates 470 stores worldwide; annual sales are estimated to be $2.2 billion. The couple's daughters are heavily involved - Linda runs marketing, and Esther heads the visual display team.  The firm has been criticized for copying designer clothes and has been sued about 50 times for copyright infringement. Born-again Christians, the two keep bibles in the office, and print John 3:16 on the bottom of each bag.

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed private equity colossus Carlyle Group with Daniel D'Aniello, David Rubenstein in 1987; found early success putting ex-politicos to work buying defense-oriented businesses. Turned around operations, flipped for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's movie Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money. Set to become the biggest private equity company with purchase of Dutch asset manager AlpInvest; Carlyle will have nearly $150 billion assets under management (up from $98 billion). Deal is expected to close in March 2011.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed private equity colossus Carlyle Group with William Conway, David Rubenstein 1987; early success putting ex-politicos to work buying defense-oriented businesses. Turned around operations, flipped for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money. Set to become the biggest private equity company after purchasing Dutch asset manager AlpInvest, giving it nearly $150 billion assets under management (up from $98 billion). Deal is expected to close in March 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has led Canadian Natural Resources to become a leader in Alberta's oil sands mining, with Horizon project on track to grow to 500,000 barrels per day in a decade. Reportedly thinks total oil sands production can grow from 1.5 million bpd to 4 million bpd in 25 years. Sees most of that heading south, doubts approvals to export oil sands crude from Canada's west coast will come any time soon. More than just an oil tycoon, Edwards owns skiing resorts and is a co-owner of the Calgary Flames hockey team, currently serving on National Hockey League executive committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Environmental Systems Research Institute in 1969 with wife, Laura. Today ESRI is the world's largest mapping software company; tracks stimulus money in some states. Son of a gardener grew up in Redlands, Calif., studied environmental science at Cal State Polytechnic Pomona (Cal Poly Pomona), urban planning at U. of Minnesota, landscape architecture at Harvard. Started ESRI with $1,100 of family savings. Goal: use computers to aid environmental planning. Today outfit provides geographic-information software to 350,000 customers, including federal agencies, health departments in all 50 states, Centers for Disease Control & Prevention.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Kenya, spent teens in India. Earned engineering degree from Indian Institute of Technology; moved to U.S. after landing programming job for Tata Consultancy Services in 1976. Founded outsourcing outfit Syntel in 1980 with wife, Neerja Sethi, while earning his M.B.A. from U. of Michigan. Took the company public 1997. Revenues in 2010: $532 million, up 27% from 2009. Company has over 16,200 employees. Stepped down as chief executive two years back but remains chairman. Played for India in 1994 bridge world championship. Established foundation supporting entrepreneurship and education.
title: Chairman and Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: The world's wealthiest venture capitalist, Doerr made millions with early investments in Amazon, Netscape and Sun Microsystems before his bet on Google made him a billionaire. Recently hosted President Obama and a Who's Who of tech titans at his Woodside, Calif. home. After a sharp left turn into green-tech--with notably few exits--his firm is now clamoring to get into hot internet start-ups, no matter the cost. Kleiner Perkins invested in Zynga (the online game company) and Ngmoco (which recently sold to Japan's DeNa for $400 million) early, but had to pay top dollar to get into Facebook at a $52 billion valuation; Groupon at a $4.75 billion valuation; and Twitter at a $3.7 billion valuation. Recently doubled KPCB's "iFund" to $200 million to spur iPad app development and launched a $250 million "sFund" for social apps and services. Not abandoning clean-tech just yet: Bloom Energy (fuel cells) and OPower (energy efficiency) remain promising bets. Doerr got his start selling microprocessors for Intel. Enjoys cycling, hiking, photography, skiing, and trampolining with his kids.
title: Partner
employment: {'name': 'Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers', 'title': 'Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Became a billionaire betting against subprime in 2007; his fund was up 47% in 2009 but lost momentum in 2010 losing 12%. Invested heavily in broadband start-up LightSquared. Assets uinder management: $6.4 billion, down from $25 billion in 2008. The youngest of nine kids, Falcone grew up in a three-bedroom house in Chisholm, Minn. Money was tight: His father was a utility superintendent, and his mother worked for 80 cents an hour at a shirt factory. Falcone played hockey but worked hard to get good grades and landed a financial aid package at Harvard, where he majored in economics. Started at the junk bond desk at Kidder, Peabody & Co in 1985 after an injury ruined his professional ice hockey career (he now invests in NHL's Minnesota Wild). Also spent stints at Wachovia and Barclays. Lost his entire investment in troubled plastics maker, AAB Manufacturing - an event he credits for having "had a profound impact upon my success as a hedge fund manager." Superstitious: If fund loses money one day, wears a different watch the next. His pet potbellied pig has its own room in Manhattan town house. His wife is on the board of the New York City Ballet.

name: Billionaires
bio: London resident is the main shareholder of Hong Kong-listed Chinese real estate company Renhe Commercial Holdings, which specializes in underground shopping malls. It's been a rough ride for investors that purchased the company's IPO in October 2008; shares have tanked by 35%.  Renhe in January said it would pay $292 million for an 80% stake in properties in the eastern Chinese city of Wuxi. Hawken, who has been chairperson since 2002, assists directors in formulating strategies, according to the company's prospectus. Hawken holds an undergraduate degree in Chinese literature from Heilongjiang University. Her brother Dai Yongge is the company's CEO. Dai's wife Zhang Xingmei is also on Renhe's board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over roofing empire ABC Supply after husband and business partner, Kenneth Hendricks, died in 2007 from a fall at their home in Afton, Wis. Today controls nation's largest roofing, window and siding wholesale distributor. After last year's acquisition of a top competitor, building supplies distributor Bradco Supply Co., 2010 sales reached $4.1 billion, up from 2009's $2.7 billion. The high school grad met her late husband at age 21, and together launched ABC in 1982. She now presides over 25 million square feet of commercial property and a growing family (seven children, 17 grandchildren). Hendricks is no typical mother hen, though. She hunts wild birds with a shotgun on her 200-acre estate and likes to ride horses and Harley-Davidsons.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'ABC Supply', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former IBM software engineer cofounded German software firm SAP in1972 with four former IBM colleagues. Successfully built up North American market for SAP, then left the firm in 1997 after a falling out with his partners. Trained mathematician holds an honorary professorship of mathematics from the University of Karlsruhe for his support of talented students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields. His charitable foundation gives money to cancer and AIDS research, art and historic preservation. Divides his time between a home in Hamburg and one in the U.S. Avid golf player.

name: Billionaires
bio: Serial entrepreneur isn't retiring anytime soon: he's back in the garbage business, merging waste management firm Swisher Hygiene with Canadian investment firm CoolBrands; he took the combined company public in 2010. Started out with one trash truck, and built haulage giant Waste Management. After retiring from WMX in 1984, Huizenga switched industries, investing in Blockbuster Video. He sold the movie rental outfit to Viacom for $8.4 billion in 1994. Owned the Miami Dolphins for 15 years before selling the team to real estate billionaire Stephen Ross for $1.1 billion in 2009; still owns a 5% stake in the team and has a Dolphins helmet painted on the tail of his Boeing 737 business jet. Sold his Floridian Yacht & Golf Club in 2010; still owns thousands of acres of real estate across Florida and North Carolina.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharma entrepreneur sold New River Pharmaceutical to Shire in 2007 for $2.6 billion. His take: $1.2 billion. Now investing in medical startups like Intrexon, engaged in "synthetic biology," building  organisms in lab piece by piece. Avid falconer; appointed to the University of Virginia Board of Visitors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Luo leads Cheng Shin Rubber, one of the largest suppliers of tires in the mainland. Made his early money supplying the bicycle industry in Taiwan. Today, Cheng Shin is a frequently mentioned "China play" among investors because of its deep involvement in the mainland, where company is expanding from its main manufacturing base in Fujian inland, to Chongqing. Customers include GM, Ford.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Akira, also a billionaire, inherited initial fortune from father but went their separate ways, unable to agree on a business strategy. Minoru is known for his grandiose projects: he built Tokyo's swank Roppongi Hills as well as China's tallest building, the Shanghai World Financial Center, which happens to house the world's highest hotel, the Park Hyatt, occupying the 79th to 93rd floors. In a recent interview, indicated he was considering stepping down as chairman. Fortune up due to improved shareholding information.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of factory worker, did odd jobs to put himself through college. Saved money he earned as a kitchen appliance salesman to buy a distillery and made his first fortune in brandy. His holding company, Alliance Global, has interests in food and beverage, real estate, gaming. Its stock price doubled in past year, making him a billionaire for the first time. In January, he led a $100 million takeover of property developer Fil-Estate Land, which owns 10% of the land on Boracay Island. Plans to develop resorts there.

name: Billionaires
bio: Using cash from sale of his oil company Rompetrol to Kazakhstan's state-owned energy operator KazMunaiGaz in 2008 to expand in energy, real estate and retail. His Marexin plans to spend up to $1 billion exploring oil and gas in Black Sea. Developing grocery stores across Romania called Mic.ro network; in August bought Minimax hypermarket chain. Also set up Bet-Caffe, a sports betting agency last spring. Owns Adevarul Holding media trust, which publishes Forbes Romania under license from Forbes Media LLC. Via his foundation, founded in 2007, grants scholarships from high school level to Phd students; also sponsors education awards for innovative teaching.

name: Billionaires
bio: Television tycoon "Jerry" made bulk of fortune selling Spanish-language broadcaster Univision for $13.7 billion in 2007 to a group led by fellow billionaire Haim Saban. One of the largest private landowners in Malibu. Onetime talent agent represented Marlon Brando, Elizabeth Taylor. Formed Embassy Communications with All in the Family producer Norman Lear, sold to Coca-Cola for $485 million 1985. Plowed proceeds into TV; with partners, bought Univision from Hallmark for $550 million in 1992. Longtime Republican donor.
title: Founder & Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Columbia University computer science professor launched hedge fund D.E. Shaw in 1980; firm managed around $24 billion last year. Firm has very selective hiring; only one in 500 applicants make the cut. Now chief scientist of computational biochemistry lab; designed supercomputer to simulate ways proteins move. Was appointed to the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology by President Clinton in 1994, and again by President Obama in 2009. Senior research fellow at Columbia since 2005.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'D. E. Shaw & Co., L.P.', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Branched out from family's real estate business to build his Rajan Raheja Group. Its businesses include batteries, petrochemicals, cement, ceramic tiles, retailing and media. Listed cable distribution arm Hathway Cable & Datacom last year. Also owns insurance venture in partnership with Australia's QBE and stake in Trident, part of Oberoi hotel chain. His newsweekly Outlook was among those to report on India's telecom scam that led to telecom minister's resignation and arrest.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Gree, Japan's largest social networking website, which is overtaking rival billionaire Kenji Kasahara's Mixi. May be facing off with Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg soon; setting up shop in California. On global expansion kick: working with Tencent, the largest Internet service portal in China. Stock is up 35% over the past year; 5-for-1 stock split last fall. Started out at Sony, then worked for fellow billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani at online shopping site Rakuten. Left in 2004 to set up Gree at a tech incubator; company name inspired by American social psychologist Stanley Milgram's concept of "six degrees of separation." Eventually transitioned the site into mobile gaming to better compete with rivals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Minnesota state senator's first job: napkin stamper at Carlson Wedding Service. Bought majority interest from owner Bill Carlson 1975, founded Taylor Corp. These days sales eroding as consumers shift to electronic greetings. Invested in agribusiness on Iowa and Minnesota farmland; sells liquefied, pasteurized eggs to food companies and restaurants. Planning to earn millions more while finding a permanent solution to hearing loss. Recently invested in Envoy, a microdevice implanted deep within ear. Majority owner of pro basketball's Minnesota Timberwolves; looking to bring in experienced free agent to lead team's youth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with Cheng-da Tsai and Hong-tu Tsai, one of three Tsai family members who inherited large stakes in Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding when their father Tsai Wan-lin died in 2004. Hong-tu and Cheng-da purchased most of T.Y. Tsai's stake at the end of last year, industry executives say. The purchase came less than two years after Hong-tu had asked T.Y. for help in steering Cathay Financial through the 2008 global financial crisis. Cathay Financial says it "can't comment" on any transfer of shares among the three brothers. T.Y. collects cars and art, including at least one Monet. Developing luxury property in Taipei with fellow tycoon Lin Ming Hsiung.

name: Billionaires
bio: Evangelical tech entrepreneur tirelessly pushing his vision of a more friendly, connected business world, via Salesforce.com's software Chatter. Took out two ads during the Super Bowl broadcast. Investors buy it: stock has doubled in the past year as revenues jumped 27% to $1.6 billion. Believes Salesforce can reach $2 billion in a year. Founded his first company at age 15 to write Atari videogames. He started Salesforce after stints at Apple, Oracle; championed "the end of software" and declared its mission to take traditional software online. The industry has followed. In June 2010 pledged $100 million to University of California San Francisco toward construction of new children's hospital, and plans to give more. Hawaii fan signs emails "Aloha."
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Agaoglu Group, a builder of hotels, resorts and ski lodges in Turkey; also one of Turkey's biggest housing providers, owns a huge landbank. Began selling his largest project in the European side of Istanbul, My World Europe, in September 2010. The project consists of 3.100 homes. Also investing in energy; group's first plant, in Mersin in the south of Turkey was finished in 8 months with an investment of $56 million. Agaoglu bought $156 million worth of new land in 2010. Passionate about luxury cars, has a Lamborghini, two Bentleys and a Ferrari.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gross controls the world's largest mutual fund, Pimco Total Return. He's been urging lawmakers to cut federal deficit gradually. In his latest newsletter to investors, Gross warns that stock prices and bond yields are sitting in an "artificial foundation."  Spent 4 months in Vegas playing blackjack after college and turned $200 into $10,000. Became investment superstar after discovering that the key to profits was to trade bonds, not buy and hold. Managed $10 million portfolio for Pacific Life 1970s; spun off fixed-income division, took it public in 1994. Sold 70% to Allianz AG for $3.3 billion 1999. Active philatelist donated much of his stamp collection to Doctors Without Borders. Gave $23 million to the organization in 2010, as well as $10 million to the Millennium Village Project at Columbia University.
title: Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Pacific Investment Management Company LLC', 'title': 'Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded his first hospital in 1984. Named it Asklepios after Greek God of medicine. Now owns 111 hospitals with combined $2.9 billion in revenues; employs 36,000 worldwide. While 96 are in Germany, also has hospitals in Portugal, Greece, Russia, Romania; has six in California operated by Pacific Health Corp. Also has joint venture with Tongji University in China. Practiced as an accountant and lawyer before founding the hospital chain; has degree from Insead at Fontainbleau, France, and an MBA from Harvard University. Owns the Kempinski Hotel Falkenstein in Koenigstein, a five star luxury spa and hotel in the Taunus mountains near Frankfurt, Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Early Light International, one of the world's largest manufacturers of toys. Yet Hong Kong real estate accounts for the bulk of Choi's wealth. Collector of timepieces (has more than 200), bought 90% of watch retailer Halewinner in November. Also collects cars. Has minority stakes in Hong Kong-listed Regal Hotels, Town Health.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice president of Hyundai Motors and oldest son of Hyundai Motor billionaire chairman Chung Mong-Koo. He was promoted to Hyundai Motor's new vice chairman last year from president at the smaller affiliate Kia Motors Corp. Will manage expansion plans that include building a new plant in Brazil and a third plant in China. Credited with the successful launch of the Kia Cee'd (a small family car) in Europe and other models such as Soul and Forte. President of the Asian Archery Federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Ashmore Group, a London fund manager specializing in emerging-market debt with $35.3 billion under management. Saw recent market turmoil as an opportunity. Profits rose by a third to $348 million in fiscal 2010 as developing world central banks and sovereign funds invested in home markets. Took company public 2006, raising $2 billion. Still has a 43% stake. Cambridge law graduate started career at Australia & New Zealand Banking Group. rose through the ranks of the emerging-market division. Launched what is now Ashmore in 1992 with other ANZ Group alumni; officially became independent in 1999. Has been chief executive since 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controlling shareholder of oilfield services concern Eurasia Drilling Company in January sold 5% stake for $240 million. Geologist predicted pent-up demand in post-Soviet Russia's deteriorating oil sector; set up oil-services firm PetroAlliance in 1995. In 2003 sold PetroAlliance to oil-services giant Schlumberger. A year later, with Russian oil companies consolidating and shedding assets, teamed up with partners including former Halliburton managers to buy Lukoil's well-drilling business. The firm, Eurasia Drilling Co., listed in London in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of steel tycoon John Hillman Jr., owner of Pittsburgh Coke & Chemical. Diversified family fortune via Hillman Co: real estate, venture capital, private equity. Early backer of venture capital monster Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, LBO titans Kohlberg Kravis Roberts; co-owner of downtown Pittsburgh's PPG Place. Philanthropist gives via various family foundations to U. of Pittsburgh, cancer research. Shuns publicity: "A whale is harpooned only when it spouts."

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Lupin which was known as maker of drugs to treat tuberculosis but has expanded into  drugs for chronic diseases. Picked up traction with acquisitions, notably in Japan, Europe and South Africa. Making big push in the U.S. with daughter Vinita leading charge. Aiming to triple sales to $3 billion by 2013. Son Nilesh, a chemical engineer, is in charge of research, manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of construction equipment manufacturer Lonking has thrived amid China's building boom. Rival of the quartet of billionaires to make the list this year from China's Sany Heavy Industry -- Liang Wengen, Tang Xiuguo, Mao Zhongwu and Xiang Wenbo. Active in business groups: Member of the executive committee of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce and vice chairman of the Fujian Province Federation of Industry and Commerce. Holds an  executive MBA from Fudan University in Shanghai. Also a director at Weichai Power Co. Shares fortune with wife Ngai Ngan Ying.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stockbroker's son invested $4,000 in cable company with frat brother 1963. Continental Cablevision grew into largest privately held cable company in country; sold to US West for $11 billion 1996. Later bought company back, renamed MediaOne; sold to AT&T for $58 billion 3 years later. Invests via Pilot House Associates.
title: Chair

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile real estate magnate founded Cyrela Brazil Realty in 1978; built it into largest developer of high-end residential buildings in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. Later expanded by inking development deals with partners in various regions of Brazil. Horn also owns slice of agricultural investor BrasilAgro. Long before the Gates-Buffett Giving Pledge came along, Horn told Brazilian press he plans to give away most of his fortune at his death; reportedly already gives 20% of his earnings to charity every year.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Delaware North won contract to fix-up, operate restaurants at Scotland's Glasgow Airport; also won NASA contract for Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex. Announced it was acquiring the Jumer's Casino & Hotel located in Rock Island, Ill., for $180 million last fall; acquiring new resort property outside Yellowstone. Father, Louis, started selling popcorn and peanuts in 1915; grew into massive sports concession business. Jeremy took over after dad's death; transformed Delaware North into global player in food and hospitality. Owns pro hockey's Boston Bruins, TD Banknorth Garden, stake in lucrative New England Sports Network. Leading search for the State University of New York at Buffalo's next president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leading critic of Russian authorities hit by roadblocks: His National Reserve Bank in Moscow was searched, as was his Crimean hotel. The former KGB agent refuses to leave Russia for fear of forced exile. Last year sold off small stake in Russian national carrier Aeroflot; bulk of fortune lies in bank assets. Owns Novaya Gazeta, Russia's leading opposition newspaper; bought London's Evening Standard and the UK's The Independent for 1 pound each.
