His son Evgeny, a London socialite, is senior executive director of the Evening Standard. Lebedev's political career not as successful: member of Russian parliament til 2007, tried to launch new social democrat party with Mikhael Gorbachev, which fizzled. Runs the Raisa Gorbachev Foundation which has built a free children's cancer hospital in St. Petersburg.

name: Billionaires
bio: Native Indian now Indonesian citizen, is one of three brothers whose fortune spans India, Thailand and Indonesia through numerous public and private companies involved in textiles, plastics .Controls Indorama Synthetics, Indonesia's largest polyester manufacturer. Chairman of Indorama Ventures, which brother Aloke, also a billionaire, runs from his base in Thailand. Brother Om Prakash, who lives in New Delhi, has his own polyester fibers and yarns business in India. Resident of Singapore, also has home in London, where his wife's brother, steel billionaire Lakshmi Mittal, lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of China Oceanwide Group, one of Beijing's largest property owners and investment companies. Top properties include Minsheng Financial Center in Beijing, Oceanwide New World in Shanghai, Glory China Center in Hangzhou, and Oceanwide Elite Plaza in Qingdao. Shares in Lu's Shenzhen-listed real estate flagship Oceanwide Real Estate Group are off by 33% in the past year as China's central bank has tightened monetary policy to cool property prices and inflation; as a result his net worth is $400 million lower than in 2010. Lu holds a minority stake in Chinese computer maker Levono through an investment in its main owner, Legend Holdings, that he made in 2009.  Lu is also an investor in Shenzhen-listed Minsheng Investment Management, which owns commercial real estate in Qingdao. Socially active as a vice chairman of the All-China Federation of Industry & Commerce, among other organizations. China Oceanwide was founded by Lu in 1988.

name: Billionaires
bio:
His Stroygazconsulting has close ties with Russia's state owned gas producer, Gazprom; building compressed air plant, Portovaya, near Baltic Sea for Nord Stream pipeline; once complete it will be the the biggest in Russia. Jordanian-born businessman came to Russia as exchange student; attended
oil and chemistry institute in Azerbaijan. As a student, began trading computers, cars. Later traded yellow phosphorus, timber, oil products. In the mid-90s bought a construction factory in Tyumen and started building living space for Gazprom workers. Each year orders from the gas monopoly grew; Manasir's company Stroygazconsulting went into pipeline construction, road construction, field facilities construction. One seeming gaffe: in 2004 was commissioned by Gazprom to build a $30 million palace to host Gazprom events, but in 2008 Gazprom cancelled the contact; now it stands empty on the shores of a reservoir outside Moscow.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Drexel Burnham Lambert partner made billions in the leveraged buyout heyday of the 1980s. Nicknamed the 'Junk Bond King' after revitalizing the high-yield bond market. Among the clients that got rich thanks to his fast money-raising abilities: fellow billionaires Henry Kravis, Ted Turner and Carl Icahn. Spent 22 months in jail in early 1990s after pleading guilty to securities fraud. Now invests in educational companies LeapFrog, K12 and Nobel Learning Centers, and has given away more than $1 billion of his own money since 1972 to causes including cancer research (he survived prostate cancer and is in remission).

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon, hotel chain Hyatt. Tom selected by father Jay as primary overseer of collective family fortune, but family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways in 2001. Sparked lawsuit by Robert's two youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, living with his ex-wife. Suit settled for $1 billion. Control of Marmon Holdings sold to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway in 2007, Hyatt initial offering in 2009. Tom retains titles of executive chairman at Hyatt, chairman of Marmon Holdings, board seats at Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines and credit-reporting firm TransUnion.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Chair of pachinko game maker Universal Entertainment Corp. (formerly Aruze) nearly doubled his net worth as his company stock rose 120% on strong sales of new gaming titles as well as contribution from Wynn Resorts, run by American billionaire Steve Wynn, in which the group has a 20% stake. Expanding business to the Philippine capital with $2.7 billion investment in Manila casino; plans to list the unit in Hong Kong after 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam vet's Majestic Realty is one of country's largest commercial builders: 70 million square feet in Los Angeles, Denver, Las Vegas, Dallas. Built Staples Center arena in Los Angeles with Philip Anschutz; also owns stakes in pro basketball's L.A. Lakers, hockey's L.A. Kings. May be step closer to building 75,000-seat football stadium outside L.A. in hopes of luring a team back in time for 2011 NFL season. Reportedly got legislative exemption from the City of Industry to build the stadium. USC grad donated $23 million to alma mater's fine arts school 2006.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Majestic Realty, Co.', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Dyslexic fisherman reportedly told by schoolteacher he'd never amount to anything. Main holding, Aker ASA, is s maritime conglomerate that operates shipyards, offshore drilling, seafood and shipping. Has been expanding drilling. Got start selling fish off a single boat in Seattle, Wash.; returned to Norway and built up fleet and reputation as a ruthless corporate raider. Lived large with giant yacht and Boeing jet but nearly drove his shipping empire into the ground by 2003; sold yacht, paid off debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Kyobo Life Insurance, which his father founded. Studied to be an obstetrician; also a professor medicine. He won the 2009 Asia Insurance Industry Award. Kyobo Life Insurance saw net profits of $253 million in the last fiscal year despite the economic crisis. It has also had the highest return on equity among Korea's big three life insurers in the past five years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fred Smith's FedEx recovered from 2009 with increased shipping demand; stock is up nearly 20% in past 12 months. Yale grad explained vision for integrated network of planes and trucks in college paper about logistics in the computer age; launched Federal Express 1971 and pioneered elaborate tracking systems. Owns 10% stake in the Washington Redskins.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio:
Cable news pioneer owns 2.1 million acres of land across 12 states and also 100,000 acres in South America. Long the biggest private land owner in U.S., recently passed by his friend, fellow billionaire John Malone; the two have neighboring trophy ranches in northern New Mexico. 
Worked for father at Turner Advertising until he committed suicide in 1963. Created 24-hour news by starting CNN in 1980. Merged Turner Broadcasting with Time Warner in 1996; became AOL Time Warner's largest individual shareholder after combining the 2 companies in 2000. Shares collapsed; personally lost $7 billion in 2 years. Sold stake, retired from board in 2006. Has donated more than $1.5 billion to charity, including the United Nations Foundation. Especially passionate about, and invests heavily in, renewable energy: formed alliance with Southern Company of Atlanta to start on solar projects. His Cimarron Solar Facility in New Mexico is among largest solar photovoltaic plants. Similarly, Luckie Street Solar Project is in second phase of construction. Skilled sailor won America's Cup in 1977. Enjoys fly fishing, nature, and biking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Austrian citizen settled in Hong Kong some 40 years ago and married daughter of shipping tycoon Yue-Kong Pao. Now chairs BW Group, whose fleet of more than 140 oil tankers and gas carriers is one of world's largest maritime groups; includes publicly traded company BW Offshore and privately held BW Maritime, BW Fleet and BW Gas. Recipient of China's Friendship Ambassador award for his contributions to China-Austria ties. Southern Methodist University law school alumnus, supports a graduate scholarship program for Chinese lawyers studying at SMU's Dedman School of Law. Oxford and Harvard-educated eldest son, Andreas Sohmen-Pao, is chief executive of BW Maritime and BW Gas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard graduate and cofounder of Royal Caribbean, whose stock nearly doubled in value over last year. Pocketed at least $500 million in 2008 when China Oilfield Services acquired all of Awilco Offshore, including his 40% stake, for $2.5 billion. Chairs the family investment company, with stakes in oil tankers, Russian hotels and Baltic shopping centers. Also owns private Norwegian real estate outfit Linstow.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chairman of China Liansu Group debuts on 2011 list after an IPO in Hong Kong in June 2010. Wong's company supplies plastic pipes and pipe fittings in China. It didn't take long before Wong took some money off the table. Wong sold off 150 million shares, or a 5% stake in the company, in January at HK$6.28 (US$0.80) per share, according to a Hong Kong Stock Exchange announcement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Finalized $23 billion sale of family's gum operation to privately held candy giant Mars in 2008; combined company is now the largest confectioner in the world. Wrigley Jr. had stayed on after acquisition by Mars but left in January 2011 to pursue philanthropic interests. Wrigley Co. founded 1891 by great-grandfather (d. 1932), who moved from Philadelphia to Chicago to sell soap, then baking powder. Introduced first spearmint chewables 1893; sent 4 sticks of gum to every person in U.S. with listed phone number 1915. Fourth-generation Wrigley took over 1999. Boasts the highest asking price of any residential property in Chicago's city limits with $14m Gold Coast penthouse.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: His real estate investment trust, Boston Properties, is up 30% this year. Despite weak advertising and tepid circulation, the U.S. News and World Report and New York Daily News owner remains optimistic about media. Son of Montreal tobacco and candy seller cofounded Boston Properties; took public 1997. Has donated hundreds of millions of dollars to cancer research; charitable foundation ripped off by Madoff; issued complaint with N.Y. State Supreme Court against money manager J. Ezra Merkin for investing with Madoff.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Boston Properties', 'uri': 'companies/boston-properties', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicknamed "the Guru" in his native Nigeria, Adenuga debuts on our billionaires' list after making waves with mobile technology. His telecoms carrier Globacom recently launched a 4G network, and he's invested $1 billion in a submarine cable connecting Nigeria to the rest of the world. He made his first million at age 26 selling lace and distributing Coca-Cola, then won a contract to build military barracks in the late 1980s. He owns a stake in the Equitorial Trust Bank and chairs Niger Delta oil exploration firm Conoil. Adenuga is a soccer devotee and sponsors a number of tournaments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Over the past year focused on consolidating Poland's mining market into his New World Resources, regarded as the biggest player on the coal market in Central Europe. Lost bid for Poland's Bogdanka mine in November. Now looking to buy Polish firm JSW, as well as mines in Ukraine. Heads effort to build first presidential library for former Czech president Vaclav Havel. Heavily invested in last Czech election in May 2010, supporting three center-right parties. Bought stake in Belgian professional cycling team Quick Step, which is expected to compete in Tour de France in 2013. Last summer married long-term partner and Miss Czechoslovakia from 1991, Michaela Malacova.

name: Billionaires
bio: Coal industry veteran makes debut, thanks to public offering of his Harum Energy in October. Retains majority stake of firm run by son Lawrence who is president commissioner. Big supporter of increased China-Indonesia trade, visits China often. Also has stake in listed Australian miner Cockatoo Coal. Hobbies are reading, swimming and jogging.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson in 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, in 1968. Bass Enterprises Production planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Lee invests with Sid; billions of dollars in Cayman Islands investment accounts.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits, Bass Enterprises. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson in 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion in 2005. With help from Stanford classmate Richard Rainwater (also a billionaire) turned millions of oil inheritance into billions in the stock market. Big bet on Disney in 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Texas private equity giant TPG, David Bonderman runs one of world's busiest deal shops; with affiliates, manages $48 billion. Firm, known for its good retail touch, having backed Neiman Marcus, Petco and American Tire Distributors, is leading buyout of J. Crew, which it has owned on and off for more than a decade; shareholders approved deal. Bondermann met co-founder James Coulter while working for billionaire Robert Bass. Duo left to pursue first deal together: salvaged Continental Airlines with $66 million investment, stake worth $700 million 5 years later. Started Texas Pacific Group 1992. He once worked for the U.S. Justice Dept. Chairman of Ireland airline Ryanair. He sits on the boards of the Grand Canyon Trust, Wilderness Society, American Himalayan Foundation and other environmental groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother, Edgar Sr., inherited Seagram spirits empire that was built up by their father, Sam, and sold to Vivendi in 2000. Major philanthropist co-wrote book published Nov. 2009 entitled, "The Art of Giving: Where the Soul Meets a Business Plan." His Andrea & Charles Bronfman Philanthropies annually gives $15 million to a host of causes. Helped found Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youths from North America on educational tours of Israel. Started the Andy Prize in memory of his late wife, Andrea, who was killed by a taxi while walking their dog near their Manhattan apartment in January 2006; prize awarded annually to an Israeli decorative artist for excellence in ceramics, jewelry, textile or glass. Recently purchased a 2-bedroom co-op on 5th avenue in Manhattan for more than $20 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of SK Group, Korea's third largest conglomerate by assets with 77 affiliate firms in energy, telecom and chemical among others. His wife is the daughter of South Korea's former president, Roh Tae Woo. Chey is the primary shareholder of SK C&C, the holding company of the SK Group.  He is currently focusing on the China market and is the leading member of the Korea Handball Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, William (d. 2002), discovered opportunity in Asia following stint as General MacArthur's trade attaché in WWII, founded sourcing and logistics company in 1949. William, better known as "Chip," started working for William E. Connor & Associates at age 12. Took reins 1980s. Moved closely held outfit from Tokyo to Hong Kong in 1985; expanded to 35 offices in 20 countries, managing global sourcing for over 60 companies. More than half of business comes from women's apparel, home goods; remainder from textiles, lighting, other apparel. Example:  $1.7 billion (sales) women's retailer, Chico's, announced in 2009 they would be partnering with Connor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Created Poland's largest leasing business in the 1990s. Ten years later sold his shares to French bank Credit Agricole for $280 million. Since then has concentrated on real state, banking and insurance sector. Majority shareholder of Getin Holding, Poland's seventh largest bank; and real estate company LC Corp. In October 2009 beat the world record in cave diving, swimming 10.5 miles (17 kilometers)  in underground corridors over the course of 10 hours.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls Porto Seguro, Brazil's largest auto insurance firm, whose shares are up 30% over last year as Brazilians buy record numbers of cars. Company was founded in 1945 and purchased by the Garfinkel family in 1972. When his father died in 1978, Jayme was groomed to take over. Took the company public in 2004. Through Porto Seguro, Garfinkel has supported the creation and maintenance of schools for young children in favelas, or shantytowns, around Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shoe shiner-turned-doctor-turned-billionaire entrepreneur, today he presides over publicly-traded Amil Participações S.A., the largest managed care organization in Brazil (market cap: $3.8 billion), providing health insurance and medical care to more than 5 million members. New billionaire this year. Decided to become a doctor at age 14, studied for medical degree at Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro while working at a struggling clinic, which he bought before graduating in 1971. Acquired other clinics soon after, and co-founded Amil Assistência Médica in 1978. In August 2010 negotiated the merger of MD1, his diagnostic company, with Dasa, the largest chain of laboratories in Latin America. Shares assets with ex-wife, Dulce Pugliese de Godoy Bueno, but retains voting rights to her shareholdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister and fellow billionaire Mary Alice Dorrance Malone, sits on the board of Campbell Soup, founded by grandfather John T. Dorrance, who developed method of canning condensed soup in 1897.  Now company is world's leading soup maker with $7.7 billion in revenues. Owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth). Two-thirds of his shares are pledged as collateral to banks for loans. Co-founder and managing director of Arizona real estate firm DMB Associates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media baron first struck it rich as a founding investor in production company Endemol, associated with such reality TV hits as Deal or No Deal, Fear Factor and Big Brother. Endemol was sold to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000. Four years ago, bought back into Endemol, picking up a 5% stake. Holds stake in RDF Media, which produces Wife Swap; and  RTL Netherlands. Concentrating his energy these days on developing TV and multimedia shows via Talpa Media. Some of its creations:  Battle of the Choirs; quiz shows Pretty Smart, Dating in the Dark and Know Your Nation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazilian philanthropist and socialite is also a member of one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. In 2008 family's Banco Itau merged with Unibanco. Now Maria de Lourdes ("Milú") is one of the largest individual shareholders of Itau Unibanco Holding SA, Brazil's second biggest bank and one of the world's fifteen largest banks. She is also president of São Paulo's Museum of Modern Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Having netted $1.5 billion in the sale of his Addax Petroleum to Sinopec in 2009, Gandur could have retired to focus on adding to his world-class collections of art and Egyptian antiquities. Last March Gandur donated $20 million to Geneva's art and history museum and pledged to house many of his 800 artefacts there--including 250 works of post-war abstract art. But instead of slowing down, the oil tycoon is looking to get back in the game, launching Oryx Petroleum to vie for Nigerian oil fields being shed by Shell. Gandur's trading group already sells fuels throughout sub-Saharan Africa, and in Sierra Leone has launched a $400 million project to grow sugarcane for ethanol.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of legendary oil baron J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976). Sold Getty Oil to Texaco in 1986 for $10 billion; plowed proceeds into investments, wine. Seeded mutual fund servicing outfit ReFlow Management 2002; stake in investment firm Forward Management. A trained musician, he composes operas; his works were performed in his hometown San Francisco in 2010 by the Russian National Orchestra. Investor in friend and former San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom's PlumpJack Group hospitality business. The name comes from Shakespeare's character Falstaff; Getty has named an opera and his business website (ifalstaff.com) after the portly knight. Big donor to Democrats, including President Obama and Nancy Pelosi.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded and runs Gruma, the world's largest tortilla maker; brand names include Mission and Guerrero. U.S. agricultural commodities powerhouse Archer Daniels Midland is  a 23% shareholder. The majority of Gonzalez Barrera's wealth, however, comes from his stake in Banorte, a successful Mexican bank that earlier in its history was owned by the Mexican government. He returns to the billionaires list after a hiatus of more than a decade, based on the strength of Banorte's stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited a beauty and health care products company from her late husband in 1975. Also has a 7.5% stake in watchmaker Swatch, now worth over $900 million. Biggest part of her fortune comes from her collection of 20th century art, which reportedly includes over 600 pieces by such artists as Pablo Picasso, Paul Cezanne, Salvador Dali, Francis Bacon and Alberto Giacometti. Keeps the works in a converted printing factory where she also lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: The veteran investor has run investment vehicle Portland House Group for decades. Hains hit big time in 1993 when he sold investment in the U.S. steelmaker Wheeling-Pittsburgh for $107 million.While it's previously owned businesses in retail, manufacturing, engineering and property, it now concentrates on funds management, with the bulk of its portfolio invested outside Australia.  Active horse breeder and racer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second son of Lebanon's late Prime Minister Rafik Hariri catapulted into politics after father's assassination in 2005. Was prime minister until January this year, when government collapsed after Hezbollah cabinet ministers walked out on him for refusing to reject findings of a special tribunal set up to investigate father's murder. Hezbollah members could be indicted. Now waging war of words with Hezbollah, calling for its disarmament. Owns 50% of Saudi Oger, a construction, telecom and real estate conglomerate which he and his brothers inherited from their father.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and CEO of $8.8 billion (sales) S.C. Johnson; son of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), who ran the household products firm for 46 years; great-grandson of former salesman who started wax company in 1886. Best known for brands like Windex, Pledge and Ziploc. Going greener; reduced greenhouse gas emissions by 27% since 2005 with efforts like a factory powered by methane gas from nearby dump in hometown of Racine, WI; wind turbine helps run plant in Netherlands. On board of Conservation International. Family known for social responsibility; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic; left indelible stamp on Racine, commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters in late 1930s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Ronesans Construction in 1994 in St Petersburg, Russia. Now builds shopping malls, airports, factories, cement factories, offices, hotels, marine facilities and hydroelectric plants mostly in Eastern Europe and the Middle East. Ronesans Construction is also one of the largest commercial real estate developers and investors in Turkey, Russia and Libya; owns 12 shopping malls in Turkey and two in Russia. Self-described family man spends free time reading books.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), the great-grandson of former salesman who started wax company in 1886. Sam joined company in 1954, expanded to industrial cleaning, banking, camping supplies; passed company on to fifth generation in 2000. Their four children attended Sam's alma mater, Cornell University, before entering family business. Children all work at the company and are billionaires. Imogene is founding director and chairman of the Prairie School, a college preparatory day school; also a director at Cornell University's Laboratory of Ornithology. Family known for social responsibility; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic; left indelible stamp on hometown of Racine, Wisconsin, commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters in late 1930s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of former salesman who started wax company in 1886. Expanded to industrial cleaning, banking, camping supplies. Brother Fisk heads  ($8.8 billion sales) S.C. Johnson; despite recession consumers continue to buy their household staples: Windex, Pledge, Ziploc. Curtis runs industrial cleaning outfit Diversey Inc., formerly JohnsonDiversey; family sold 15% stake last year to private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice; still have 51%. Member of World Wildlife's National Council. Family known for social responsibility; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic; left indelible stamp on hometown of Racine, Wisconsin,  commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), the great-grandson of the salesman who started wax company in 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Runs financial services company Johnson Financial as well as Johnson Outdoors, a publicly traded camping and military supplier. She is the driving force behind the company's crusade for environment, despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump. Founder and chairman of Next Generation Now, a pioneering child development and family resource center in central  Racine, WI.  Family known for social responsibility, big supporters of the Smithsonian and the Mayo Clinic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company in 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Winnie is president of the Johnson Family Foundation. Socially responsible family: staunch backers of the Smithsonian and the Mayo Clinic; left indelible stamp on hometown of Racine, Wisconsin, commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters in late 1930s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jones' new 111,000-seat stadium hosted the Superbowl and helped the Dallas Cowboys rake in $420 million last year to maintain its status as the most valuable NFL team, worth $1.8 billion. Team performed better financially than it did on the field; missed playoffs with a 6-10 record. Thanks to lucrative seat licenses, Jones took on relatively little debt building his $1.2 billion cathedral to Texas football. Former Arkansas Razorback made first fortune in 1970s drilling natural gas wells. Bought the Dallas Cowboys for $150 million in 1989; team has won 3 Super Bowl rings under his ownership. Still owns large oil and gas holdings, shopping centers. Big Salvation Army supporter has used Cowboys to raise more than $1 billion for the charity over past 11 years.
title: President and General Manager
employment: {'name': 'Dallas Cowboys', 'title': 'President and General Manager', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his integrated polyester company Indorama Ventures public last year. Share price has more than quadrupled since. Busy dealmaking since announcing plan to invest $3.8 billion to more than double company's capacity over next three years. Snapped up plants in China, Mexico, Poland and the US so far this year. Resident of Thailand for over two decades, is son of Indian entrepreneur and younger brother of Sri Prakash Lohia, one of Indonesia's richest and also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist, starting in the 1990s Katz started buying up distressed pharmacies with help of drug distributor McKesson. Cobbled together 1,925 pharmacies to create one of the biggest chains in North America. Sold remaining 25 Snyders Drug Stores in Minnesota to Walgreens after unsuccessful attempt to expand in U.S. Bought Edmonton Oilers for $200 million in 2008. Investing a reported $200 million to build new downtown hockey arena.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean billionaire's firm Nexon launched the world's first online game "Baram e Nara" (The Kingdom of the Wind) way back in 1994, and went on to produce hits "Maple Story", "Mabinogi", and "Cart Rider". Now the country's foremost online game producer, Nexon's annual revenues are set to top $900 million.  Its Japanese offshoot Nexon Japan is getting ready to float on the Tokyo Stock Exchange this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: His links-style golf course, Whistling Straits, hosted the PGA Championship in August. Owns the Old Course Hotel at St. Andrews; currently rehabbing nearby Hamilton Hall, purchased for $18 million December 2009. Grandfather bought steel foundry to build farm tools 1873; today businesses include plumbing, faucets, engines, hospitality. Makes 20 different models of toilets in 14 colors. Has served as chairman and chief executive since 1972; son David elected president and chief operating officer in 2009.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kohler Co.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With business partner Dmitry Kamenshchik, owns Moscow's Domodedovo Airport, which was hurt by unforeseen events over the past few months: ice rain last December paralyzed the airport; then 30 people died in a terrorist attack at the airport in January. Served in the Navy. Reportedly bought a $30 million apartment in the Sea One seafront project in Tel Aviv in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Their $1.7 billion (sales) Torrent Group was founded by their father as a pharma outfit in 1959.  Older brother Sudhir led charge into power with the acquisition of two state-owned utilities. Today, energy firm Torrent Power is their most valuable asset. Younger sibling Samir looks after Torrent Pharma. Last year, it signed pact with AstraZeneca to supply 18 generic drugs.  Brothers are keen on sports.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard, a chartered surveyor, and his older brother Ian, a former optometrist, kicked off their buiness career together by opening optical stores and acquiring the David Clulow chain in 1992 (which they recently sold in 2011). Main business these days is real estate, which they first entered in 1980s with founding of property trading company, Strategic Properties. Now Richard serves as Executive Chairman and Ian as International Managing Director of group, which has investments, developments, and business interests in over 10 countries, including the UK, Scandinavia, Germany, Russia, South Africa and Panama. Recent news: sold Victorian Shopping Center in Cape Town, South Africa, in a $1.5 billion deal with Dubai World. Richard is single, Ian married to journalist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mansour and his two brothers debut on the billionaires list, each with their own billion-dollar fortune despite recent revolution in their native Egypt. The Mansours are the biggest sellers of GM vehicles worldwide, and their Mansour Group has other interests including the largest supermarket chain in Egypt and the country's second largest real estate developer. Sustained little damage during the Egypt uprising; any long term impact remains unclear. Mohammed was the country's Minister of Transportation from 2005 until 2009; has a sprawling estate in Cairo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Wuzhou Minovo, a producer of starch, MSG and organic fertilizer. Meng's wealth was largely from Hebei Meihua Monosodium Glutamate Group until the business was folded into Shanghai-listed Wuzhou Minovo in a process that was completed last year after delays in connection with reported violations of environmental protection rules. Wuzhou Minovo's foreign investors include Temasek Holding and Softbank Investment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of  Infosys Technologies is due to retire in August when he turns 65.  Created a stir when he suggested that India's civil service should be abolished, as a measure to improve governance.  His venture capital fund Catamaran's investments include stake in controversial microlender SKS Microfinance, which went public last year. Sits on boards of HSBC, Ford Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Hong Kong-listed property investor and developer Kowloon Development is working on projects in Hong Kong, Macau and the mainland cities of Shenyang, Foshan, Zhongshan and Tianjin. Net worth is up $200 million from a year ago as company shares rise on comeback from 2008 financial crisis. He also controls real estate developer Polytec Asset Holdings, a Hong Kong-traded subsidiary of Kowloon Development. His wife, who shares the fortune, and son are involved in business.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former engineer, who dropped out of the billionaire ranks during the financial crisis as his chemicals company, Ineos, struggled to handle its heavy debts, makes comeback. World's third largest chemicals company with $39 billion in sales, business got lift recently after Petrochina agreed to pay $1 billion for 50% in its European refinery operations earlier this year. Ineos had largely grown through series of acquisitions. The biggest: the $8.7 billion deal to buy BP Group's Innovene business in 2005.  Headquarters shifted to Switzerland from U.K. apparently to save taxes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sportsman recently made headlines after coming to the aid of a floundering English soccer club: "A lot of Brits take the ownership of their clubs very seriously and are rather skeptical when an American gets involved. What I impressed on them is that I'm not buying the team. We're sponsoring a club that was rather impoverished and undercapitalized for the league it's playing in." His stake in Rich Products now 75% after brother David sold his stake and dropped from ranks of the richest. Hollywood turning his book Fish Fights into film Islamorada. Soy-based whipped cream company founded by father Robert Sr. now the basis of $2.9 billion (sales) food empire. Led campaign to raise $1.5 billion for nonprofit medical mecca Cleveland Clinic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Candy maker is credited with inventing more than 200 sweets including Gummi Bears,  Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies. Said he gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. Makes these candies for Haribo, he and his family's $2.5 billion (sales) candy company. He and brother Paul rebuilt the company after World War II and  ran it together for until Paul's death in August 2009. Hans, who is single and has no children, still runs the company and is in charge of marketing; nephew Hans Guido Riegel  heads production and technical questions. Two other newphews, Hans Juergen Riegel and  Hans Arndt Riegel, also sit on the supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: The aviation enthusiast quit his job at a mass-merchandise store after boss asked him to repossess a live monkey; self-employed since. Bought a convenience store in 1959, grew into 65 locations; later bought gas stations, oil wells, manufacturing and casinos. Purchased New Frontier Hotel & Casino for $165 million in 1998; sold to El-Ad Group for $1.24 billion in 2007. In March 2009 paid $755 million for Treasure Island casino from MGM Mirage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief technical officer at Broadcom has been focused on the company he cofounded since a judge exonerated Samueli from accusations that he'd lied to the SEC in 2008. Met business partner Henry Nicholas at aerospace and automotive company TRW. Designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas' spare bedroom. Founded Broadcom in 1991; took it public 7 years later. UCLA grad funded alma mater's School of Engineering & Applied Sciences. Owner of hockey team Anaheim Ducks.
title: Chief Technology Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Broadcom', 'uri': 'companies/broadcom', 'title': 'Chief Technology Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns half of German publishing house Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck; half-brother Stefan von Holtzbrinck owns the rest. Siblings bought out their other brother Dieter in 2006.  In 2009, Dieter acquired Handelsblatt, Germany's biggest financial newspaper, and other assets from his siblings in return for canceling out financial obligations owed to him; has established a new company: Dieter von Holtzbrinck Medien GmbH.  Monika heads book publisher S. Fischer Verlag, which dates back to 1886; group was the original publisher of Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka and Hermann Hesse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of oilman Charles Schusterman (d. 2000) Lynn Schusterman owns what appears to be the biggest privately held energy producer in America. Samson Resources, now run by daughter Stacy, operates roughly 4,000 oil and gas wells and has interests in another 11,000; recovered an estimated 34 million barrels of oil (and natural gas) last year. Firm is a partner with Chevron and Noble on deepwater gulf wells--had to stop drilling after BP spill. Lynn meanwhile spends her time on philanthropy, especially Jewish causes, through the Charles & Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Warren Buffett's lifelong friend was first his rival; vied against the Oracle of Omaha for the hearts of girls in high school. Today sits on Berkshire Hathaway board. Bulk of fortune lies in MidAmerican Energy, electric utility acquired by  Berkshire Hathaway in 2,000. Studied civil engineering at Colorado State; went to work for father's employer, Kiewit Construction (now Peter Kiewit Sons'). Chief executive 1979. Pushed company into telecom, fiber optics, power plants. Retired 1998, still chairman of Level 3 Communications.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Shin Dong-Bin, Vice chairman of Lotte Group since 1997 and the chief executive of Lotte Shopping since 2006, is the second son of group founder Shin Kyuk-ho. Studied business at Aoyama Gakuin University in Japan and received his MBA from Columbia University, and once worked at Nomura Securities. He is now playing a major role in moving the Lotte brand into overseas markets. Lotte Department Store opened a branch in Moscow in 2007 and one in Beijing in 2008. The retail unit is currently planning to open a second branch in Tianjin and other major cities in China. It also plans to open a store in Hanoi in 2013. Lotte Chilsung Beverage, the company's soft drink affiliate, acquired Doosan Corporation's liquor unit for $448 million early last year. Korea Seven, a subsidiary running Seven Eleven stores, took over Buy The Way for $245 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Strong demand for industrial and mining equipment in China and Australia, plus a rise in advertising, made him a billionaire once again. Already the biggest Caterpillar dealer in Australia through his WestTrac, has a franchise to sell and service the Caterpillar earthmoving and construction gear in China as well. Also a media baron, he is cutting debt by arranging for another media outfit to buy his Seven Media Group, operator of Australia's top-rated television network. Self-made billionaire started out installing television aerials on suburban homes as a teenager. He's the top private buyer of Victoria Crosses, acquiring three of these rarely seen Australian military awards at prices up to $1.2 million each and donating them to the Australian War Memorial.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $4 billion (sales) Avantha Group's biggest holding is power equipment maker Crompton Greaves. Was part of consortium that built Belwind, one of Europe's largest offshore wind farms. Plans to list Avantha Power & Infrastructure  and papermaker Ballarpur Industries' Dutch arm.  His realty unit has stake in Lavasa, an upcoming city near Mumbai which got into in trouble over allegedly flouting green norms. Avid golfer, he's  president of the Professional Golf Tour of India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kentucky farm boy Ueltschi fell in love with airplanes listening to a radio broadcast of Charles Lindbergh's 1927 transatlantic flight. Opened "Little Hawk" hamburger stand to raise money for lessons. University of Kentucky dropout flew Pan Am planes for 26 years. Founded corporate pilot training outfit FlightSafety International in 1951 and took it public in 1968. He later sold the business to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway in 1996 for $1.5 billion in stock and cash. Now chairs Orbis International, a non-profit that fights blindness in developing countries and operates flying eye-surgical center.

name: Billionaires
bio: A trained physicist. He and four former IBM colleagues founded German software company SAP in 1972; with 2009  sales and software profits down, SAP is restructuring. Retired from SAP in 1998.  Stepped down from its supervisory board in May 2007. Devotes his time to his Klaus Tschira Foundation, one of Germany's largest philanthropies.  Foundation  supports  scientific research and cultural projects such as a youth software prize given to students who explain math or science matters to their peers with the clever use of software.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Dieter and half-sister Monika Schoeller, inherited publishing house Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck from their father George, who founded it as a book club in 1948.  Has run the $3.3 billion (sales) company, which includes book publishers Farrar Straus, St. Martins Press and Henry Holt, since 2001.  In 2006 he and Monika bought out Dieter's one-third share. In 2009, they sold Handelsblatt, Germany's biggest financial newspaper; 50% of weekly newspaper Die Zeit and other assets back to Dieter, which let them off the hook in terms of paying him cash. No sibling rivalry: he and siblings sit on Die Zeit's supervisory board together. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining the Holtzbrinck company in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: The music lover adds $500 million to his net worth as his pipeline company, Energy Transfer, continues to hum; shares of ETE and ETP both up more than 20% in past year. Warren built up his pipeline network in wake of Enron's collapse; currently the largest in Texas. He is now searching for new acquisitions to expand his empire. Bought 3,500-acre Colorado ranch for $46.5 million in April 2010. Has spent 41 years in the pipeline business; swept warehouses at age 13 for the Sun Oil pipeline where his dad worked. Owns Austin Texas' Music Road Records, supporting and marketing singer-songwriters and folk musicians.

name: Billionaires
bio: First appeared in Forbes' ranks at age 8 but officially inherited fortune in June 2001 on his 18th birthday. Went to high school in Rome; in June 2008 received an M.A. in economics and theology from the University of Edinburgh in Scotland. But this prince hardly needs to earn his keep. Assets include real estate, art and a tech company and 30,000 hectares of woodland in Germany, one of the largest forest holdings in Europe. Despite local opposition is apparently going ahead with plans to build one of the world's largest solar farms in Bavaria, southern Germany, to sell electricity. Lives in family castle,  Schloss Emmeram. Eligible bachelor is also a race car driver; tours with a German auto-racing league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Also known as Tony Zhang. He is cofounder of Tencent, China's largest Internet company by market capitalization, part of a triumvirate of Internet giants that dominate the China market and are known at home by the acronym TAB: Tencent, Alibaba and Baidu. Ma Huateng, another cofounder, is also on the billionaires' list this year. Zhang holds degrees from Shenzhen University and the South China University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother and fellow billionaire Dmitry, started out importing computers to Russia. Brothers then set up a bank and have been active in real estate and media. Alexei heads up their IT business and general strategy. In 2010 brothers sold their telecommunication company Synterra to Megafon, which is owned by billionaire Alisher Usmanov and Alfa Group, for $745 million. Despite their wealth they felt a lack of education and completed executive MBAs at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Alexei uses free time to assist clergymen at Moscow's Church of the Trinity.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With brother and fellow billionaire Alexei, started out importing computers to Russia. Brothers then set up a bank and have been active in real estate and media. In 2010 sold their telecommunication company Synterra to Megafon, which is owned by billionaire Alisher Usmanov and Alfa Group, for $745 million. Despite their wealth they felt a lack of education and completed executive MBAs at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Dmitry is a Federal Council (Senate) representative for the gas-rich polar region of Yamal.


Brought into the business by older brother Alexei, also a billionaire; they are now equal partners. Started out importing mainframes to Russia. Brothers then set up IT-company Technoserv and a bank. Later have been active in real estate and media. Since Dmitry became a senator in 2006 Alexei headed all businesses of the group. In the beginning of the 2010 EBRD bought a minority stake in their Promsvyazbank. Later in June brothers sold their telecommunication company Synterra to Megafon which is owned by billionaire Alisher Usmanov and Alfa Group for $745 mil.  Despite their wealth, the brothers felt a lack of education and completed executive M.B.A.s at the University of Chicago. Dmitry got his degree in 2006.  Dmitry is working in Federation Council as a representative from the gas-rich Arctic region of Yamal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casden Properties' proposal to build new mixed-use, residential-retail project in West Hollywood at Movietown Plaza is projected to include 294 condos, 76 senior rental apartments, 32,300 square feet of retail space and parking garage. Real estate portfolio includes more than 200,000 square feet of office space, 3,100 luxury apartments, including renowned Palazzo Westwood. Collects Jewish antiquities.
title: CEO, Chairman & Founder
employment: {'name': 'Casden Properties LLC', 'title': 'CEO, Chairman & Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairwoman of publicly-traded Amil Participações S.A., the largest managed care organization in Brazil (market cap: $3.8 billion), providing health insurance and delivering health care to 5 million people. New billionaire; shares assets with ex-husband, Amil founder Edson de Godoy Bueno (he retains voting rights over her shareholdings). Met her former husband in medical school and helped him build Amil, starting with the acquisition of a few medical clinics. She was assistant professor in the pediatrics department at Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, where she also served as academic dean of the undergraduate program and founded the Pediatric Rheumatology Service of the Martagão Gesteira Pediatric Institute. Received a PhD in management from McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ultra-reclusive tycoon listed his sporting goods retailer Sports Direct International in February 2007.  Kept a 70% stake in the company and continues to oversee more than 400 stores and brands such as Kangol, Lonsdale and No Fear as deputy executive chairman. Company swung back to a profit in 2010 while share price rose by a quarter. Retailing business faring better than his foray into soccer. Bought Newcastle United in July 2007 but failed to sell twice since then, and remains unpopular with fans. Most recently was criticised for firing manager Chris Hughton in December 2010, despite club returning to the first-tier Premier League last year. Reportedly lost about $1.5 million in one night playing craps at a casino in Newcastle in January, tipping the dealer $1,000 as he left the venue.

name: Billionaires
bio: Quieter co-founder of Texas private equity giant TPG, James Coulter runs one of world's busiest deal shops; with affiliates, manages $48 billion. Firm known for good retail touch, having backed Neiman Marcu, Petco, is leading buyout of J. Crew, which it has owned on and off for more than a decade; deal recently approved by shareholders. Firm reportedly looking to invest in Indonesian coal. Notable losers in the past decade include Washington Mutual, TXU and Harrah's. Coulter met co-founder David Bonderman while working for billionaire Robert Bass. Duo left to pursue first deal together: salvaged Continental Airlines with $66 million investment, stake worth $700 million 5 years later. Started Texas Pacific Group 1992.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Videocon is a homegrown maker of consumer electronics and appliances. Facing heat over telecom unit Datacom; he was among several tycoons to be deposed before the Central Bureau of Investigation over corruption scandal involving granting of telecom licences. He denied any wrongdoing. Oil and gas arm recently struck gas off the Mozambique coast. Older sibling Rajkumar is a member of parliament. He gives public addresses on the Bhagavad Gita, the sacred Hindu text, and plays the flute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Believed in mobile phones back in their brick-sized days and in 1987 started selling them in stores. Eventually sold out to a private equity group for $2.8 billion in 2006. Caudwell set up a charity, Caudwell Children, in 2009 to provide wheelchairs and specially-adapted sports equipment for sick and disabled children in the United Kingdom and now acts as chairman, attending half a dozen events a year. Last year raised nearly $3 million, with help from Elton John, at charity's annual Butterfly Ball. Scrapped with burglars at his Jacobean mansion in Staffordshire in November after a break-in, and was left with a cut forehead and elbow after being hit with an iron crow bar. Thieves took cash and designer jewelry. Avid sportsman scaled Mt. Everest and used to pedal 14 miles to work on his bike. Also has homes in London and France.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lawyer's son reared in Kentucky coal country, Craft became a lawyer himself. Joined MAPCO coal unit as assistant general counsel, 1980; became president, 1987. Craft was rewarded with a big stake for leading firm's LBO and conversion into tax-efficient public master limited partnership in 1996; it was renamed Alliance Resource Partners three years later. Its chief executive since, he's overseen subsequent expansion across Appalachia, Midwest. Not surprisingly, long-time advocate of coal as solution to country's energy issues. Personal fortune has soared as stock jumped over the past year; new billionaire this year. Big fan of basketball team at double alma mater University of Kentucky, to which he is big donor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dad helped pioneer shopping mall concept in late 1940s. DeBartolo Jr. led DeBartolo Realty Corp.'s merger with Simon Property Group in 1996 to create largest public REIT in North America. San Francisco 49ers won NFL-record five Super Bowl championships during his 23-year ownership in the 1980s and 1990s. No longer owns team; he swapped his share with sister Denise for hefty stake in industry giant Simon Property Group following his federal bribery conviction in 2000. Today "Mr. D." owns 14.8 million SPG shares; shares up 48% since last year. Also owns stake in Famous Famiglia pizza joints, DeBartolo Sports & Entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Englander met first business partner John Mulheren on the floor of  the American Stock Exchange. Duo founded Jamie Securities but firm collapsed after Mulheren was convicted of insider trading (the conviction was later overturned). Founded Millennium Partners hedge fund in 1990 with $35 million. Firm manages over $7 billion in assets; charges expenses instead of a management fee. Hates losses: Englander fires traders who lose a predetermined amount of money. Result: returns of 13% for 2010. Wife is sister of famed investor Jack Nash (d. 2008).
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: The co-founder of Blackberry maker Research in Motion oversees a company that, while still growing, is fighting to keep pace with innovations from rivals like Apple's iPhone and other smartphone makers. He's also found himself in the middle of disputes with the governments of India and Saudi Arabia concerning a possible ban of the Blackberry product due to security issues. Research in Motion will soon launch its tablet computer, the PlayBook, with a brand new operating system. Founded Waterloo's Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in 1999; has since donated $150 million to the quantum physics research institute. Chancellor of University of Waterloo.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former Exxon geologist, Hildebrand levers up to buy proven fields, uses advanced technology to boost efficiency. Headline deal of 2010: sold a 40% stake in his Hilcorp Energy's acreage in South Texas' Eagle Ford for $400 million to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts. Founded Hilcorp in 1989; started small, just "3 guys and a telephone." Bought out partner Thomas Hook for $500 million in 2003. Company gives employees bonuses tied to company's growth in lieu of stock options; employees can also buy stakes in Hilcorp's projects. Donates to Houston Zoo and Contemporary Arts Museum Houston.

name: Billionaires
bio: Finland's first dollar billionaire heads $6.8 billion (sales) elevator, escalator maker Kone; company is also involved with the products' installation and maintenance. The firm was founded 101 years ago and purchased by Herlin's great grandfather in 1924. Chief executive of firm from 1996 to 2006; chairman since 2003, the year his father Pekka died. Chairman of Security Trading Oy; also sits on the board of Finnish construction firm YIT.

name: Billionaires
bio: Twelve years after selling his direct-satellite TV outfit to DirecTV for $1.3 billion, Hubbard still holds a large stake. His Hubbard Broadcasting's ReelzChannel airs in 50 million homes. Hubbard has passed reins to son and is now company's "chief cheerleader." In January, Hubbard Broadcasting made one of the largest radio-station deals in years, when it acquired 17 stations for $505 million. Now Hubbard Aviation Technologies, acquired in 2008 for $200,000, occupies his time. The company makes hush kits, which muffle engine noise, allowing older Gulfstream aircraft to meet sound requirements; being phased in at airports around the world. Inherited love of flying from father, a pilot who started one of first commercial airlines in U.S., Kentucky Aviation Flight.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharma investor a big supporter of Columbia U. Medical Center, Weill Cornell Medical College, Tufts U. School of Medicine. Former partner with Philip Frost (also a billionaire). Korean vet launched Kos Pharmaceutical in 1988; created cholesterol-battling drug Niaspan, sold to Abbott Labs in 2006 for $4.2 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger sister Alicia, also a billionaire, inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. Their husbands ran FCC from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The  sisters took over and ran operations jointly until 1997 when Esther bought her sister's stake for $800 million. Now owns 48% of $18 billion (sales) FCC; sits on its supervisory board. Also sits on board of Cementos Portland Valderrivas and Veolia Environment. Holds the Gold Cross for Social Solidarity for her social work; her Esther Koplowitz foundation, which supports and houses the mentally and physically impaired, has spent more than $95 million to date. Donated some $20 million to help fund the Esther Koplowitz Center, a new biomedical center which opened in Barcelona last year;  researches treatments for diseases like cancer, multiple sclerosis and malaria. Spanish nobility, holds the title of Marquesa  de Casa Penalver. She is married to Fernando Falco, Marques de Cubas, scion of an old Spanish family.  Apparently loves ballet and classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Sanan Optoelectronics, headquartered in the southeastern Chinese city of Xiamen. Sanan is the largest manufacturer of full-color light emitting diodes in China, and has thrived amid the growing use of color LEDs in the consumer electronics and lighting industries. His net worth is up $600 million from last year's $1.3 billion. Formed a joint venture with Emcore of New Mexico last year to develop components for land-based solar power energy systems. Sanan's shares are listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: China has become the world's largest auto market in the past few years, but most players are large, state-owned businesses or multinationals. Li Shufu is a scrappy businessman from the country's entrepreneurial mecca of Zhejiang Province, near Shanghai. Li's Geely snapped up Volvo from Ford with a $1.8 billion deal that closed in August 2010, putting 105,000 Volvo workers in the hands of a leader who employs less than one fifth of that figure at home and who, 15 years ago, was making refrigerator parts. In a recent speech he predicted great things for Geely and Volvo down the road. Investors aren't so certain: Shares are up by only 5% from a year ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: The company he founded and chairs, aluminum-products producer China Zhongwang, went public in Hong Kong in 2009. Corporate governance controversies have dogged him and contributed to a 30% fall in the share price this past year. His net worth dropped 40% from $3.2 billion a year ago. Honored in 2004 as a "constructor of socialism with Chinese characteristics" by the Chinese Communist Party's Central Committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Home Depot, now the world's largest home improvement retailer. Helped by improving sales, Home Depot's stock has recovered; up 30% over the past year. Marcus worked as a cabinet-maker at his father's shop; started the DIY chain with Arthur Blank after getting fired from now defunct Handy Dan; took outfit public in 1981. Retired in 2001. Now focuses on philanthropy: donated $250 million to open Georgia Aquarium, the world's largest, in 2005 and opened the Marcus Autism Center in Atlanta in 2008.
title: Co-founder, ex chairman of the board
employment: {'name': 'Home Depot', 'uri': 'companies/home-depot', 'title': 'Co-founder, ex chairman of the board', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairman of auto and battery maker BYD stays out of the spotlight compared with chairman and fellow billionaire Wang Chuan-fu. The net worth of both men has tanked in the past year, amid high-profile problems with the ramp up of BYD's auto-related businesses. Last year Lu was worth $3.1 billion; now he's worth nearly 40% less. Lu is also chairman of investment company Guangzhou Youngy Management & Investment Group. He once worked at the Chaohu Center branch of China's central bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock in worldwide hotel operator and franchisor Marriott International, which hotel heir J.W. Marriott Jr heads, is up more than 36% over the past year. His father opened Washington, D.C. root beer stand Hot Shoppe in 1927 and later expanded into catering, restaurants, hotels; opened first hotel, Twin Bridges, in 1957. Group of hotels became Marriott International. Split company in 1993 with brother, Richard, in effort to boost returns, get control of high debt; Richard chairs real estate investment trust Host Hotels & Resorts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chief executive of Nidec, maker of micromotors used in DVDs, hard drives, robots, game consoles. On acquisition hunt in Europe to expand motor business following purchase of motor subsidiary from U.S. electronics firm Emerson Electric last year. Despite strong sales and profits - from April to December sales rose 23.5% and net profits increased 35.6% - company stock down 11% because of fears PC growth will slow as global economies falter. Favorite color is green; reportedly has 1,300 ties in varying shades of green as well as green shirts, cuff links and handkerchiefs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy aeronautical engineer built world's largest manufacturer of electrical heating appliances (stoves, electrical fireplaces, space heaters, decorative fires, water heaters). Founded Glen Electric in 1973; acquired Dimplex four years later. Became sole owner of Glen Dimplex in 2003. Estimated sales in 2010: $1.87 billion. Trustee emeritus at University of Notre Dame in Indiana.

name: Billionaires
bio: Civil engineer holds 12% of Spain's largest construction company, $22 billion (sales) Actividades de Construccion y Servicios S.A., which he has headed since 1993. Well known in Spain for ties to popular Real Madrid soccer club, once the team of stars like David Beckham and Zinedine Zidane; ran club from 2000 to 2006. Resigned in February 2006 after string of defeats. Club is giving him another chance: re-elected him president in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. Penny oversees the family real estate investments, senior-housing firm Vi and airport-parking outfit Parking Spot. Still holds top spot at credit-reporting firm TransUnion. Was key fundraiser for Barack Obama's presidential run in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile property baron started out in family's real estate business, then went his own way after family division in 1996. His privately held K. Raheja Corp has expanded beyond Mumbai. Portfolio includes six hotels, bookstore chain Crossword, hypermarkets and malls. The group is building a luxury hotel near Mumbai's international airport. Department store chain Shoppers Stop is the only listed entity. Sons Ravi and Neel work with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Jude, lords over Reyes Holdings, $12.5 billion (sales) food and beer distribution conglomerate. Purchased small South Carolina beer distributor for $740,000 in 1976; bought Chicago Beverage Systems three years later. Now the largest beer distributor in the U.S., delivering 80 million cases a year. Also own McDonald's largest U.S. supplier, Martin-Brower, acquired in 1998; today the outfit delivers burgers and fries to all Canadian McDonald's and thousands of locations in the U.S. McDonald's Supplier of the Year in 2009. Chris and Jude are co chairmen; brother David runs beer outfit, James commands real estate. On the board of the Ronald McDonald House Charities, chairman of the board of Children's Memorial Hospital and a trustee of the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother (and fellow billionaire) Christopher, lords over Reyes Holdings, $12.5 billion (sales) food and beer distribution conglomerate. Purchased small South Carolina beer distributor for $740,000 in 1976. Bought Chicago Beverage Systems three years later. Now the largest beer distributor in the U.S., delivering 80 million cases a year. Also own McDonald's largest U.S. supplier, Martin-Brower, acquired in 1998; today the outfit delivers burgers and fries to all Canadian McDonalds and thousands of locations in the U.S. McDonald's Supplier of the Year in 2009. Chris and Jude  are co-chairmen; brother David runs beer outfit, brother James commands real estate. Trustee of Northwestern University; sits on various boards, including NorthShore University HealthSystem, and the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago. Reportedly purchased oceanfront Kiawah Island home for $14 million last summer.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Legendary investor is part of private equity consortium making a deal with Irish government to buy EBS, the country's biggest savings bank. Reportedly willing to put more than $800 million into purchase. On a roll: also considering buying oil and gas company Exco Resources Inc. In April 2010 paid $154 million for 21% stake of Richard Branson's consumer-credit business Virgin Money. In June sold his 30% stake in Indian airline SpiceJet for $127 million. Also announced July deal with former CVS Caremark Chairman Edwin "Mac" Crawford. Joined Rothschild 1976; cleaned up Drexel Burnham junk-bond financings as bankruptcy specialist. Made initial fortune buying, restructuring failed companies in steel, coal, textiles and car parts. Head of the prestigious Japan Society on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pipemaker recovering with help from two massive deals; his OMK (United Metals Company) is supplying an oil pipeline to China and a gas pipeline to Germany. Graduate of Moscow State Institute of Steel & Alloys, which several of Russia's tycoons attended. Worked as an economist in the Central Research Institute for Ferrous Metallurgy. In 1989 started a joint venture in scrap-metal recycling with a $1.5 million loan from Sberbank, Russia's largest bank. Then started buying up shares in pipe producer Vyksunsky Metallurgical Plant (VMP), a factory in the Urals region; by 1999 Sedykh and his partners were controlling shareholders. Later established the United Metallurgical Company, Russia's second-largest pipe producer and its largest maker of railway wheels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shen's wealth has climbed $400 million since last year amid a run-up in Chinese retail stocks and a Chinese government push to stimulate consumer spending. He chairs Hong Kong-listed Intime Department Store, China's 47th biggest retailer in 2009, according to an industry survey. The company last year forged an alliance with Henderson Land, led by fellow billionaire Lee Shau Kee, selling a minority stake to the Hong Kong developer. Shen is also a shareholder in Metroland Corp., which develops property along Beijing's subway system. Metroland also invested in a hotel in Shanghai's trendy Xintiandi area last year. He is also the biggest shareholder in Shenzhen-traded Science City Development, an engineering and construction company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk-Ho is vice president of Lotte in Japan and lives in Tokyo. Sits on boards of Lotte Chilsung Beverage, Lotte Hotel, Lotte Aluminum. Although he owns a lower stake than he did last year, his fortune has increased after Lotte shares soared.

name: Billionaires
bio: Strategic investor in four large companies listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange: ceramic maker Cersanit, developer Echo Investment, flooring company Barlinek and chemical company Synthos. Also has funds that invest in the futures, currency and commodities markets. Lives in Kielce, Poland where in the late 1980s he developed construction company Mitex, which he sold to a French company in 2002. Passionate about racing cars. In 2008 won a European racing championship.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2003 the Stroher family sold their nearly 80% stake in Wella AG, the world's biggest professional hair care group, to Proctor & Gamble for $4 billion. As a granddaughter of Wella's founder, she got $1 billion from the sale. She and her husband, a former nurse, have a well-known collection of contemporary German art that includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Hong Kong-listed United Energy Group, a supplier of oil and natural gas. In December 2010, United Energy agreed to pay struggling oil giant BP a total of $775 million in cash for most of its exploration and production assets in Pakistan. Zhang also chairs Orient Group, listed in Shanghai, which holds a 3% stake in China Minsheng Banking, one of the largest Chinese banks not controlled by the government; Zhang is the bank's vice chairman. His daughter Zhang Meiying is a board member at United Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: His conglomerate RGE (Royal Golden Eagle) has $10 billion in assets; owns papermaker April and palm oil firm Asian Agri. Has operations in China, Brazil. Member of the Asia executive advisory board of Wharton and member of the Insead International Council. One of his subsidiaries, Sateri International, kicked off trading at Hongkong Stock Exchange in December last year. Eldest of 7 boys dropped out of school at age 17 to help support his family. Says he taught himself English by translating Readers' Digest, Life and Newsweek.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Research In Motion with fellow billionaire Mike Lazaridis in 1984. Later created BlackBerry, forever tethering businesspeople to email (thanks?). RIM now launching PlayBook, a tablet device to compete with Apple's iPad. In active ego-match with Steve Jobs over whose is better. Sports nut, has tried three times to buy an NHL team to move to Ontario. Member of Trilateral Commission.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Russian Standard vodka remains optimistic about purchasing Ukrainian vodka maker Nemiroff, though in March the company's shareholders said Nemiroff was off the market. Exploring investments in Vietnam; considering expanding into other products like whiskey. The entrepreneur earned his first rubles in late 1980s helping foreign tourists find rooms in Moscow hotels. Worked as a consultant for Italian confectionary Ferrero Rocher; then started selling Italian vermouth, winning an exclusive contract with Martini & Rossi. In 1998 created the first upscale brand of Russian vodka, Russian Standard. In 1999, with help of McKinsey & Co., set up Russian Standard Bank, pioneering consumer credit market; became market leader three years later. Bank is one of the top 30 in the Russian market; it has ean xclusive partnership with American Express in Russia. Owns a Boeing 737 aircraft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to run Bauer Media Group, mass-media company founded by his grandfather in 1875. The $2.7 billion (sales) group publishes everything from TV guides to special interest publications like Auto Zeitung (cars) and kochen & geniessen (cooking), to magazines like Neue Post. U.S. titles include First for Women, Woman's World and InTouch. Sells in 15 countries including Mexico, Russia and China. Is one of Britain's largest radio producers after acquiring various divisions from British media company Emap in 2007. Daughter Yvonne is now CEO of Bauer Media Group; he is chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns $2.3 billion (revenues) Viessmann Werke GmbH, one of Europe's largest producers of boilers and heating equipment. Grandfather founded group more than 90 years ago. Ran company beginning in 1993; in 2008 moved to supervisory board to concentrate on company strategy. Company supports the  Viessman Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers; also sponsors cold weather sports like skiing and sledding as well as Formula One racing. President of the Kassel Chamber of Commerce, treasurer of Marburg University. Has a professional pilot's license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wilson made a bundle selling luxury workout wear: stocks in his yoga-inspired apparel company Lululemon were up 170% this past year, earning him a spot on the billionaires list. He started his career with outerwear company Westbeach Snowboard  in 1979. He opened the first Lululemon store in 2000 in Vancouver and took the firm public in 2007. Now, Lululemon boasts a cult following and revenues of $700 million from 140 stores and catalog sales. Wilson concocted the company's manifesto, including slogans like "The pursuit of happiness is the source of all unhappiness," and "What we do to the earth we do to ourselves."

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire is one of the four co-owners of Sibuglemet, a coal mining company that is also the among the largest coal suppliers in Russia. He is responsible for the company's economic, financial and accounting matters. The group has benefitted from rising coking coal prices. Graduate of Siberia metallurgy institute started working at one of the coal mines in the Kemerovo region. With Anatoly Skurov and Vladimir Melnichenko (both billionaires) founded Sibuglemet in 1995; joined by Alexander Shchukin (also billionaire) in 1999. Bukhtoyarov is a big fan of horse races, owns several horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime go-between for major oil companies and state-owned oilfields in the Gulf settled in Britain in 1980 after fleeing Saddam Hussein's Iraq. This year, he upped his stake in Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris' Orascom Telecom; its stock is now recovering from a dip in late January, at the start of Egypt's civil unrest. Auchi's General Mediterranean Holdings owns hotel and office properties in France, U.K., the Middle East and Chicago; also invests in construction, pharmaceuticals and finance companies. Owns Team Lebanon of A1 Grand Prix Race series.

name: Billionaires
bio: A key fundraiser in President Obama's charge to the White House, the founder of JMB Realty Neil Bluhm hosted a birthday party for the President when he turned 49 in August (price of admission: a $30,000 contribution to the DNC). Bluhm's other political connections in Illinois enabled him to build a casino near O'Hare airport, which is under development close to Chicago's city limits. He is the lead investor in Philadelphia's first gambling parlor, Sugarhouse, which opened in September and apparently isn't doing as well as expcted. Bluhm's Rivers Casino in Pittsburgh opened in August 2009 and is the number one source of game revenue in the state. Other interests: stakes in distressed banks and Walton Street Capital, a private equity real estate fund. Arts patron and board member of Chicago's Art Institute and New York City's Whitney Art Museum, Bluhm values his collection at $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buck earned a PhD from Columbia, worked as a nuclear physicist before loaning his family friend Fred DeLuca $1,000 in 1965 to open a sandwich shop. It eventually became Subway; now has 34,000 locations in 95 countries, and overtook McDonalds as the chain with the most outlets at the end of 2010. It plans to open 3,000 stores in Asia in the next five years. The sandwich chain has gotten a huge boost from its ad campaign starring formerly obese Jared Fogle and from the introduction of the $5 footlong sandwich. Company estimates that it has sold 20 billion sandwiches in the last 45 years. Buck gives generously to the Smithsonian museums. Among his gifts are a giant 23-carat ruby named after his late wife Carmen Lucia.
title: Co-Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Cathy runs Chick-Fil-A, the second-largest fast food chicken chain in the U.S.; only KFC is bigger. Operates 1,500 stores in 39 states, with annual sales of $3.5 billion in 2010. Among its most popular items: chicken sandwiches and waffle fries. Turnover among Chick-Fil-A operators is a low 5% annually. The company cooks an estimated 76 million chickens a year. A devout Baptist, Cathy keeps his stores closed on Sundays (costing an estimated $500 million in lost revenue a year); has taught Sunday school to young teens for 52 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: His secret to success? "Stubbornness, perseverance and a little bit of fearlessness. You can't be afraid to make decisions. You just make them and things fall as they may. You can't be a leader if you're afraid to decide." Opened first grocery store at 100th St. and Broadway 1969; owned 10 stores by age 24, made $25 million a year in revenue. Plowed $5 million into Manhattan real estate in 1977; property worth $100 million 5 years later. Today his Red Apple Group owns hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of real estate, New York's Gristedes grocery chain. Best asset: United Refining Co. Firm owns 372 gas stations, Pennsylvania refinery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford professor set up students Sergey Brin and Larry Page, now billionaires, with venture capitalists Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Rewarded with a chunk of Google stock. Reunited in late 2008 with past business partner Andreas Bechtolsheim, a German billionaire, in new outfit Arista Networks, a low-cost switchmaker aimed at competing with Cisco Systems. Has donated to University of British Columbia to support university teaching led by Nobel Prize winning physicist Carl Wieman: "I think of this as an investment in the most important asset we have, namely the next generation!"

name: Billionaires
bio: Cooperman grew up in South Bronx and started his career as a Xerox quality control engineer in 1965. Got his MBA from Columbia, where he used to carpool with former billionaire Mario Gabelli. Headed Goldman Sachs Asset Management prior to starting his own hedge fund, Omega Advisors, in 1991. Now manages over $5 billion. Treasurer of Damon Runyon Cancer Research, he oversees the investment of the foundation's $60 million endowment. Told Forbes in November: "I have proved that with an average IQ, lots of drive and ambition coupled with a heavy dose of good luck, a lot can be accomplished."
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Fuyao Glass Industry Group, one of China's largest glass suppliers to the auto industry. Benefiting from a boom that has turned China into the world's largest market for automobiles, Fuyao's  net profit in 2010 increased 57% from 2009's $172 million, according to a company statement. That would make the company the world's second biggest auto glass supplier. Customers include Audi, Ford, Fiat, Nissan. His hobbies include golf and art collecting. Cho donated $158 million to charity in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Middlebury football player Jim Davis bought New Balance on day of Boston Marathon in 1972. The running shoe manufacturer had 6 employees at the time.
