It now has 4,000 globally and revenues topping $1.6 billion. The brand, which adopted an "endorsed by no one" philosophy, focuses on selling comfort and support. It also maintains domestic manufacturing; 25% of its shoes sold in North America are made or assembled in the US. It recently launched True Balance toning shoe which claims to help increase muscle stimulation,burning more calories.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: At age 17, borrowed $1,000 from family friend Peter Buck to open sandwich shop in 1965. Single store spawned Subway, fast-food franchise known for healthy options. Today outfit has overtaken McDonalds in number of outlets; boasts 34,000 locations in 95 countries. Popular "$5 Footlong" sandwiches boosted sales. First created healthy buzz with ubiquitous Jared commercials; claimed formerly obese student lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Oversees day-to-day management of the company; has sold an estimated 20 billion sandwiches in the last 45 years.
title: President and Co-Founder
employment: {'name': "Doctor's Associates (Subway)", 'title': 'President and Co-Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairman of Hikvision Digital Technology, a Hangzhou-based supplier of video surveillance products that employs 3,600. Went public in May 2010 on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange; current market capitalization is $6.2 billion. Gong graduated from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 1986 and became a Hong Kong resident in 1992. Hikvision in December was selected as the general contractor for a city government project in Chongqing to set up more than 500,000 video surveillance points.

name: Billionaires
bio: Greene became a billionaire by buying credit default swaps on subprime mortgage-backed bonds as housing crashed. Fled to cash; currently taking advantage of low rates by refinancing real estate holdings. Invested $75 million in property in the past year, including 270 condos in Flordia's Coconut Creek. Also spent $24 million of his own money on a failed Senate campaign. Put himself through Johns Hopkins U. working as a busboy at the Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, teaching Hebrew School part-time and checking IDs outside a gym. Also traveled the country selling circus tickets in later years; put himself through Harvard business school.  Owns 145-foot yacht Summerwind. Bought Malcolm Glazer's Palm Beach mansion in December 2009 for $24 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst. Family's media empire today includes 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, Albany Times Union), magazines, TV and radio stations, stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. The cable holdings are doing especially well; family's stake in ESPN is worth more than $5 billion. Family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: The grandson of publishing magnate William Randolph Hearst oversees a family media empire that includes TV, newspapers, magazines, and internet holdings. Owns shares in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime and A&E, which are doing especially well; family's stake in ESPN is worth more than $5 billion. In 2010 company bought digital marketing firm iCrossing for an estimated $325 million. Harvard grad is an affiliated partner in Silicon Valley venture firm Kleiner, Perkins Caufield & Byers and was both editor and publisher of the San Francisco Examiner from 1984 to 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Maoye International Holdings, which operated 37 department stores in 16 Chinese cities as of the end of January. Has been building out nationally from his early base in Shenzhen, just north of the Hong Kong border.  In December 2010, the company paid $170 million for land to build a new commercial complex in Taizhou in Jiangsu Province.  A month earlier, Maoye said it would pay $62 million for an 80% stake in Zibo Dongtai Building in central Shandong Province, which owns or operates department stores, supermarkets and a distribution center in the city of Zibo. Investors seeking to benefit from growth in China's consumer spending, especially in second- and third-tier cities, have helped to push up Maoye's Hong Kong-traded shares by 41% in the past year, giving Huang's wealth a boost, too. Maoye went public in Hong Kong May 2008.  Huang is reportedly the brother of Huang Shih Tsai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst. Family's media empire today includes 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, Albany Times Union), magazines, TV and radio stations, stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. The cable holdings are doing especially well; family's stake in ESPN is worth more than $5 billion. Family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst. Family's media empire today includes 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, Albany Times Union), magazines, TV and radio stations, stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. The cable holdings are doing especially well; family's stake in ESPN is worth more than $5 billion. Family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: London-born son of a mechanical engineer studied chemical engineering at Imperial College. Joined European bond desk at Salomon Brothers, rose to managing director. Then headed proprietary trading group at Credit Suisse First Boston. With four other Credit Suisse employees, launched hedge fund Brevan Howard 2002. Returned 18% in 2009; up 1% in 2010. Sold 15% stake to Swiss Re in 2007 for undisclosed sum. Firm now manages $28 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former real estate executive started first self-storage facility 1972; today Public Storage has more than 2,100 facilities in U.S. and Europe with 135 million rentable square feet. Also owns 20 million square feet of commercial, industrial property. Retired as chief executive in 2002; remains chairman. Net worth lower as he's been dsitributing assets to his heirs. Daughter Tamara Gustavson, who sits on Public Storage's board, debuts on billionaires' list this year. He's a donor to Republican-aligned causes; gave $2.55 million to Karl Rove's American Crossroads PAC before November midterm elections. Horse racing enthusiast, he owns 700-acre Spendthrift Farm in Kentucky. Goes by middle name, Wayne.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sudanese-born "Mo" founded Celtel, a mobile phone company that now serves 23 countries in Africa and the Middle East. Sold it in 2005 for $3.4 billion; pocketed $1.4 billion. London resident now spends his time on philanthropy and investing in Africa. Created Mo Ibrahim Foundation to improve governance of African countries. Most prominent element of the foundation is a lifetime award of $5 million over 10 years, and $200,000 annually thereafter, to an African head of state who has retired within the preceding three years and left his country materially better off and more transparent. Awarding committee decided not to award the prize in 2009 or 2010.  The Foundation also publishes a 300-page index of conditions in 53 developing countries, covering 88 variables such as health, press freedom, and infrastructure. Future projects will include information on agricultural development and climate change.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controlling shareholder of supermarket chain Dixi which this February acquired Russian supermarket chain Victoria, becoming the third biggest retailer in Russia. Graduated from prestigious Moscow State Institute of International Relations and founded Mercury company in 1991, which began by importing food and alcohol; now it is the biggest tobacco distributor in Russia. In 2005 Kesayev bought from former billionaire Shalva Chigirinsky a stake in oil company Sibir Energy. Because of the conflict between Chigirinsky and Sibir Energy shareholders, in the summer of 2009 Kesayev sold his stake in Sibir Energy to state-controlled Gazpromneft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest shareholder in Moscow's Vnukovo Airport also sits on board; government stake set to be privatized in second half of 2011, expected to generate bidding war. Also holds shares in a number of airport service companies including an airplane repair factory. In 1995 joined billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metals group, for a time serving as chief executive of an Usmanov company. In 2006 sold out to Usmanov when his patron created a metals conglomerate that included a Kvetnoi company. In 2007 used some of the capital to buy National Standard Bank, which had been affiliated with yet another Usmanov company, and NovorossCement, Russia's third-largest cement producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire is one of the four co-owners of Sibuglemet, a coal mining company that is one of the country's largest coal suppliers. He oversees the company's coal exports. The group has benefitted from rising coking coal prices. Graduate of Kuzbass polytechnic institute started working at one of the coal mines in the Kemerovo region. With Anatoly Skurov and Valentin Bukhtoyarov (both billionaires) founded Sibuglemet in 1995; joined by Alexander Shchukin (also a billionaire) in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairman of Guangzhou R&F Properties with fellow billionaire Zhang Li. R&F has evolved from a regional leader to national heavyweight, with a market capitalization of $4.3 billion. Holds minority stake in Chinese brokerage Haitong Securities. Li chairs the Council of Guangdong Chamber of Real Estate and is a part-time professor at Sun Yat-Sen University and Jinan University. Sister Helen Li is an R&F board member.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deputy chairman of $1.8 billion (sales) Coloplast, a Danish health care company that makes medical devices in the fields of ostomy and urology such as colostomy bags and catheters; also makes dressings for wounds.  Owns a third of the public company. His late father, Aage Louis-Hansen, founded the business in 1957; took it public in 1983.

name: Billionaires
bio: New on the list. Youngest brother of Mohamed Mansour, 49-year-old Yasseen heads Palm Hills Developments, Egypt's second largest real estate developer. Builds luxury housing and resorts. Impact of Egypt's revolution still unclear. Cousin who was Mubarak's housing minister before ouster in cabinet shake-up, is a shareholder in Palm Hills and other Mansour holdings. He now faces allegations of corruption. Youssef is graduate of George Washington University.

name: Billionaires
bio: New to the list. Older brother of Mohamed Mansour, Youssef, 65, was instrumental in building the largest supermarket chain in Egypt, Metro. Stores spared looting during uprising; loyal employees stood guard daily to defend from theft and stay open for business. Now situation unclear. Devotes time to family foundation, with mission to eradicate illiteracy and promote education. With wife, enjoys collecting Louis XIV furniture and Renaissance paintings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock of his publicly traded real estate investment trust, Host Hotels & Resorts, up 41% over the past year. Father, J.W. Marriott Sr., opened Washington, D.C. root beer stand the Hot Shoppe in 1927. Expanded into catering, restaurants, hotels; opened first hotel, Twin Bridges, 1957. Became Marriott lodging empire. Split company with brother J.W. amid bondholder protest in 1993: J.W. serves as CEO of Marriott International.

name: Billionaires
bio: Welsh-born venture capitalist inspires equal parts fear and respect. Early investor in Google, Yahoo, PayPal still swings for the fences: led investment in video camera maker Pure Digital (sold to Cisco for $590 million); turned rubber into gold when he flipped Zappos to Amazon for $1.2 billion in 2009; led firm's investment in battery maker A123 Systems (went public in 2009); helped orchestrate Google's pending $700 million purchase of portfolio company ITA Software last July; took prepaid debit-card company Green Dot public that same month; joined LinkedIn's board shortly before it filed to go public. Maintains board seats at 24/7 Customer, Aricent, Gamefly, Klarna, Kayak.com, and WeatherBug. Former journalist recently rereleased update of his book "Return to the Little Kingdom: How Apple and Steve Jobs Changed the World." Self-proclaimed bookworm owns personal library containing thousands of books.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Broadcom cofounder has been focused on philanthropy and smoothing out his image since charges of drug distribution and options backdating were dropped last year. With partner Henry Samueli launched semiconductor maker Broadcom from spare bedroom of Redondo Beach condo 19 years ago. Broadcom shares up 35% over last 12 months. In 2008 Nicholas mobilized California to pass Marsy's Law, crime victim's bill of rights named for his murdered sister. Nicholas Academic Centers helping send 66 underprivileged graduating seniors to college this year. Divorce settlement with ex-wife Stacey could cost him his billionaire status.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire is one of the four co-owners of privately-held Sibuglemet, the largest coal supplier in Russia. Group has benefitted from rising coking coal prices. Graduate of Moscow mining institute began his career as a drift miner in one of the coal mines in Kemerovo region. Joined founding trio Anatoly Skurov, Vladimir Melnichenko and Valentin Bukhtoyarov (all billionaires) in 1999 after receiving a stake in the Polosukhinskaya coal mine, which became a part of the group. Also invests in dairy plants and agriculture in Kemerovo region.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of software outfit Infosys Technologies and longtime chief executive stepped down two years ago to become chairman of the Unique Identification Authority of India. Its ambitious mandate is to provide a unique identity number to all Indian residents. Target is to issue 600 million of them by 2014; has issued 2 million so far. Wife Rohini, a former journalist, supports several non-profits in the areas of water, education and micro-finance. Donated $5 million to Yale University and over $1 million to the Indian Institute for Human Settlements, a new university focused on sustainable urbanization in Bangalore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Comic book titan sold Marvel Entertainment to Disney in 2009 for $4 billion in cash and stock; remains CEO. His fortune got a $200 million boost since last year thanks to his Disney stock, up 25%. Bought Marvel in 1993, beating out Carl Icahn and Ron Perelman. Now making a killing at the theater; his firm's box office hits include 2010's Iron Man 2. Perlmutter fought in Israel's Six-Day War in 1967 and moved to the U.S. soon after with $250 to his name. Started out presiding over Jewish funerals in Brooklyn. With partner, became principal shareholder in Odd-Lot Trading Co. Also owned Toy Biz. One of few existing photos of him in public domain is from a 1985 Forbes photo shoot.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Marvel Entertainment', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. J.B. has flirted with politics, raising funds for Hillary Clinton's presidential run in 2008. Co-owns venture fund, New World Ventures, and private holding company, Pritzker Group, with brother Tony.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. A former Hyatt employee, John sold his shares in the hotel chain last year. Through his private investment holding company Geolo Capital, bought majority stake of San Francisco boutique hotelier Joie de Vivre in 2010. Is working to expand the chain outside of California. Also bought and renovated Carmel Valley Ranch south of Monterey, Calif. Onetime Grateful Dead fan funded production of well-reviewed documentary film about activist and 60s radical Wavy Gravy. Collects photography, including works by Richard Avedon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father fled Nazi Germany. Jerry studied German literature at Columbia, later joined father-in-law Robert Tishman's realty firm. Divorced the daughter, but Speyer and Tishman continued to work together; created Tishman Speyer 1978. Today owns stakes in New York landmarks Chrysler Building and Rockefeller Center. With BlackRock Inc. lost $5.4 billion bet on Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartment and retail complexes in Manhattan after defaulting on mortgage in 2010. Has been on a real estate shopping spree in the past few months after restructuring debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened $450 million development in Indianapolis in February with kickoff celebration starring Diana Ross. Mega complex has five hotels including 1,005-room JW Marriott, the largest JW Marriott hotel in the world. Took over his father's billboard business in 1946. Plowed profits into building a hotel empire; later sold signage operation for $960 million to Chancellor Media Corp. In 2006 flipped 100 hotels to BET founder Robert Johnson for $1.7 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property tycoon sold Manchester's famous Trafford Centre shopping complex to Capital Shopping Centres in return for a 23% stake in the publicly traded mall firm. Whittaker's Peel Group also sold the majority stake in its airport operations to Canada's Vancouver Airport Services. His company is behind MediaCity UK, a massive development in the northern city of Salford that will serve as the BBC's new headquarters. Maintains a stake in Pinewood Shepperton film studio, where James Bond movies, among others, are filmed. Owns Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Co-founder of Anadolu Group, brewer and distributor of beer and soft drinks including one of country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. Anadolu is expanding in Russia and other former Soviet Union nations, with partner and fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan. Also makes Isuzu vehicles in Turkish plants; imports, sells Lada and Kia cars throughout Turkey, Ukraine and Central Asian countries. Built a hospital affiliated with Johns Hopkins Medical School in Istanbul. As a boy worked in his father's small grocery store in Istanbul.

Came to Istanbul to serve in the military; he stayed to work in business. Co-founder of Anadolu Group, brewer and distributor of beer and soft drinks including one of country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. Owns group, which is expanding in Russia and other former Soviet Union nations, with partner and fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan. Also makes Isuzus in Turkish plants; imports, sells Lada and Kia cars throughout Turkey, Ukraine and Central Asian countries. Built a hospital affiliated with Johns Hopkins Medical School in Istanbul.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Zorlu Textile with brother Zeki Zorlu, turning it into Turkey's largest exporter. Now his Zorlu holding company is active in consumer electronics, energy, finance and real estate. Owns private-label TV maker and distributor Vestel.  Sold Denizbank to Dexia, a French-Belgian financial establishment, in 2006. He is building Zorlu Center on the land he bought for $800 million dollars in 2007; it will include a culture and arts center, a hotel, a business center, a shopping center, and residences.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former owner of steelmaker Arcelor backed billionaire Lakshmi Mittal in his successful 2006 bid to merge steel groups Arcelor and Mittal Steel. Now holds about 2% of ArcelorMittal, world's largest steel company.  Very press shy, reportedly never goes out in public without a bodyguard to safeguard him and his family from kidnapping and assassination attempts by Basque separatists. Owns cattle ranch Ganaderias Aguadulce in south of Spain, where he raises bulls for bullfighting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited fortune from late husband Jerry Zucker, whose $3.2 billion (estimated sales) InterTech Group is a diversified chemical manufacturer that makes products like sealing devices, gaskets, and woven and nonwoven fabrics. Company ranked No. 116 on Forbes' 2010 list of America's biggest private companies. She also owns the Carolina Ice Palace and half of the Carolina Stingrays, a minor league hockey team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Al Ghurair Group, one of Dubai's oldest merchant families, with interests in banking, malls and manufacturing. Son Majid is chief executive. In a rare interview with the Financial Times recently, admitted that his family wasn't immune to the credit crunch. "Banks are putting more pressure on us to repay some debt," he said. Called on the government to help the banking sector. No surprise: Father Saif owns close to 40% of Mashreq, the struggling UAE bank helmed by his nephew Abdul Aziz Al Ghurair.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Sulaiman, Abdullah, and the late Saleh, helped found and grow $45 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank, today one of the largest Islamic banks in the world. Bank's stock price has held steady in past year despite doubling provisions in October to safeguard against soured loans. As a member of the Saudi Council of Chambers of Commerce, helps promote Saudi's agricultural interests abroad. With five sons, owns various industrial assets, including a gypsum company, a mineral water bottler and the nation's third-largest steel manufacturer.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Began career in grocery business, eventually moved to real estate. Privately held Arnel & Affiliates manages 5,500 apartments and 2 million square feet of commercial space in southern California.
Also owns private equity outfit Westar Capital. Investments range from Petmate, a pet product manufacturer, Candle Lamp Company and Lifecare Solutions. Former owner of pro baseball's Seattle Mariners; 1993 recipient of the Horatio Alger Association of distinguished Americans Award. Served as ambassador to Spain under President George W. Bush. Dec. 2009 was appointed to board of directors of Pacific Mercantile Bancorp.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Arnel & Affiliates', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: "Cultural diplomat" of China chairs Fu Wah International Group, one of Beijing's largest commercial property developers. Fu Wah's biggest project, Jinbao Street in the city's Chaoyang district, includes the Regent Hotel, the Hong Kong Jockey Club, Ferrari and Lamborghini as partners. Fu Wah launched its first luxury residential project, Mandarin Court, in Beijing last December. The average asking price: $12,000 per square meter. Chan is also curator and founder of the China Red Sandalwood Museum located in the Jinbao area.
title: Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of hedge fund Moore Capital, with $14 billion assets under management. His main fund finished up 4.5% in 2010. Moved back from London to Long Island; owns several luxury properties including Robin's Island, 145-acres in New York's Peconic Bay. Bought back a piece of his history, picking up his family's Southern plantation last year. Put his Lyford Cay house on market for $35 million after what he says was a three-hour police invasion of his home that was politically motivated. Now fighting with Xcel Energy and Tri-State Generation and Transmission Association over massive 95-mile, high-voltage power line that they plan to build across portions of his Trinchera Colorado ranch, which he bought from Forbes family for $175 million in 2007. Bacon spent summers manning fishing boat for NYSE board member Walter Frank; fellow angler persuaded Bacon to apply to Columbia Business School; now sits on its Board of Overseers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Syria and armed with a Wharton MBA, Asfari joined oil production firm Petrofac in 1991, bought it out in 2001 and took it public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005. Today, the company is part of the FTSE 100 and has a market cap topping $8 billion. London-based Asfari has grown Petrofac from one plant in Tyler, Texas to a multinational with offices in China, Russia and across the Middle East. His latest focus: the abundant oilfields off the UK's continental shelf. Last year spun off Petrofac's North Sea operations to form a new company, EnQuest; its market cap is $1.7 billion. When he isn't tending to his growing oil empire, spends time in the south of France on his yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate raider known for snapping up large stakes in distressed companies. Got start as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. Has targeted advertising companies: built up a stake in French agency Havas, demanded board seats, gutted management and made himself chairman. Also has shares in Aegis Group, the British media and market research concern. Eclectic portfolio includes African shipping, Asian palm-oil plantations, plastics. Group is developing an electric car called the BlueCar. Hosted close friend French President Sarkozy on his yacht for a post-election holiday off Malta in 2007. Has a collection of 1,000 comic books.

name: Billionaires
bio: New to the list this year, Cline is the new king coal. His Foresight Energy owns some 3 billion tons of coal reserves, most of it in Illinois. Coal is in his blood; 100 years ago his grandfather mined coal with a pickaxe in Beckley, W.V. Today Cline has a 150-acre estate there. Growing up his dad paid him a penny for each bag he filled with dirt from under the porch. When it started to collapse he learned a lesson about building roof supports. In 2006 made a deal to sell portion of his reserves to Natural Resource Partners, in which he now has a stake of $750 million. Sold a piece of Foresight to Carlyle Riverstone 2007. Expanding mines quickly; could reach 80 million tons a year by the end of decade. In Florida, owns a 34,000 square foot oceanfront manse; docks his 164-foot yacht Mine Games in Palm Beach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born into poverty in wartime Taiwan 1944, grew up doing farm chores and helping his father fish. One of the junior-high-school graduate's first jobs: mixing cement at a construction company. Arrived in Taipei with a suitcase of rice and little money in his pocket. Eventually started supplying cement to builders, taking on subcontracting jobs, and developing his own real estate projects. Today, his Farglory Land Development is one of Taiwan's largest developers; its stock is up about 20% in the past year, in part due to sales from new projects. Other interests include an insurance company and hotel chain. Also invests in projects on the mainland, where he partners with Hong Kong billionaire Hui Wing Mau. Now looking even farther abroad: last November, Chao announced plans to invest as much as $1 billion in a project that will house the stock exchange in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates. Farglory also says it is planning to invest $100 million in South Korea. Hikes for an hour each day before coming to work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tabloid king Desmond is dipping his toe in network television. In 2010, his media company Northern & Shell bought Channel 5, one of the five terrestrial UK TV networks, for £104 million. Owns celebrity magazine brand OK!, and launched spin-off show OK! TV on his new channel in February. The Guardian called it "colossally vapid". High school dropout started his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974. Built stable of titles including at one time more than 40 adult entertainment publications, which he sold in 2004, but not before earning him the nickname "Dirty Desmond" among media insiders. Bought British newspaper group Express in 2000. For fun and charity, plays drums with his band RD Crusaders, whose other musicians include folks from The Who and Led Zeppelin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with fellow Chinese billionaires Pang Qinghua and Li Guoqiang, Huang is one of the world's richest auto distributors. Huang co-founded Zhongsheng Group in 1998 with Li in Dalian. Zhongsheng distributes luxury and mid-to-high end automobile brands including Mercedes-Benz, Lexus, Audi, Toyota, and Honda. Huang holds a bachelor's degree in economics from Xiamen University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dubin founded Highbridge Capital with billionaire pal Henry Swieca. His fund took over $6 million (assets) Brazilian investment firm Gávea in October. Grew up in Washington Heights, NY, sold  55% of Highbridge in 2004 to JPMorgan Chase for $1.3 billion.  Assets under management: $21 billion, up 5.6% over the last year. Dubin is the founding board member and former chair of Robin Hood Foundation. His wife, a former Miss Sweden, is a physician at the first aid unit at NBC. The couple recently founded a breast cancer center at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Ken Fisher lives above the offices of his money management outfit Fisher Investments, "kind of like an old-school Chinese laundry." The firm, which he founded in 1979, has $43 billion in assets under management. Longtime Californian, is shifting some of his employees to Washington State. Reasons: lower taxes, better schools, safer neighborhoods. Author of 7 finance-related books, 4 of which have been New York Times bestsellers. Has written a column for Forbes for 26 years. Asked what boards he sits on, Fisher responded: "None. For-profits would be conflicts of interest and non-profits are distracting." Passions: redwood trees; finding and digging up 19th-century redwood mill sites; 19th Century bottles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Chongyi Zhangyuan Tungsten, one of China's largest tungsten mining companies. The company listed its shares on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last March; the stock price has more than doubled since. Huang is the chairman of the China Tungsten Industry Association and a director of the China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: On top of his booming transport and logistics business, Linfox, he's now building a portfolio of industrial properties around Australia and also owns one of the country's fastest-growing regional airports. He famously left school at 16 and bought his first truck 3 years later. His business card still reads "Truck Driver."

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of clothing maker Bosideng in China's Jiangsu Province proved himself cool by signing a licensing agreement to open Rocawear stores in China. The store was set up in 1999 in the U.S. by hip-hop singer Jay-Z; Gao is looking to open 300 shops in the world's most populous nation by 2012. The first opened its doors in Shanghai in January. The move is part of an effort by Gao to smooth out Bosideng's core down jacket business, which peaks ahead of the winter season. The company is China's largest down clothing manufacturer with a sales network that covers 65 cities. Gao is getting some help with strategic planning from venture capital fund IDG, which has a seat on his board and holds a minority stake in the company. Gao is member of the executive committee of the China Federation of Industry and Commerce and the president of the Textile & Garment Chamber of Commerce of the All-China Federation of Industry & Commerce.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cambridge grad, founded London-listed oil and gas explorer Indus Gas, in which he has over two-thirds stake. Stock price jumped more than a third in past year, making him a billionaire for the first time. Company owns a hydrocarbon block in western Indian state of Rajasthan, together with its Indian operating arm Focus Energy, which he also chairs. Active member of the World Economic Forum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Hengan International Group, biggest maker of sanitary napkins in China. Sales up 25% to $822 million in the first half of last year, thanks to increase in consumer spending. Deputy chairman of All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce and also Political Consultative Conference in Quanzhou in Fujian Province, and also the deputy chairman of Fujian Province Industry and Trade Association and the chairman of Quanzhou City Trade Association. Hui's son Hui Ching Chi, who holds a University of London law degree, is a member of Hengan's board of directors. Co-founder Sze Man Bok also makes the billionaires' list this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Penny-pinching consumers and falling commodity prices supporting Little Caesar's bottom line throughout economic slowdown. Recession hampering other fortune: wife, Marian, owns Detroit's MotorCity Casino Hotel; gambling industry recently crushed as cost-conscious consumers avoid the tables and slots. She isn't deterred: she wants to invest in an Indian casino in the Hamptons. Owner of pro hockey's Detroit Red Wings, pro baseball's Detroit Tigers. Ilitch was front-runner to buy pro basketball's Detroit Pistons last fall, then walked away, but is said to be back in the hunt again. His hope is for a new downtown arena for both hockey and basketball.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former stockbroker is one of Singapore's shrewdest investors. Made a killing selling his stake in palm oil giant Wilmar, started by his former client Luok Khoon Hong . Bought Thomson Medical, a Singapore-listed healthcare firm for $410 million. Also has stakes in fashion retailer FJ Benjamin, investment firm Rowskey. Still sitting on cash pile and likely to make more deals. Made headlines with his failed $500 million bid for English football club Liverpool. Pledged $7 million to the Singapore Olympic Foundation to provide scholarships to budding athletes.

name: Billionaires
bio: GPS king's fortune is up $100 million as Garmin shares have risen slightly but it's been a bumpy year. Firm moved its place of incorporation from Cayman Islands to Switzerland this summer. Met partner Gary Burrell, who doesn't make the list this year, at AlliedSignal. Produced Global Positioning System navigation tools for pilots and sailors. Started marketing GPS units to directionally challenged drivers in 1998. Donated $17.5 million in 2005 to his alum UT Knoxville to fund an electrical and computer engineering building that has since been named after him.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Garmin Corporation', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction, media and Islamic banking tycoon. Kamel's plans to establish a much-touted global Islamic megabank might finally materialize this year. Al Baraka Banking Group wants to expand in France, home of Europe's largest Muslim population. Arab Radio & Television network declining in value as it loses viewers; film library is up for sale. Currently involved in major project to develop King Abdul Aziz Road in Mecca.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oxford-trained historian turned investor, now making one of the biggest personal bets on gold. His family office, Tigris Financial, largely invested in gold and silver assets. "The primal forces of economics, supply and demand, are arguing for an upward revaluation of gold," he says. Buying big stakes in mining development firms like NovaGold Resources and Gabriel Resources. Made much of his fortune in natural gas by buying leases in an East Texas field that turned out to contain 2.4 trillion cubic feet of gas. President of the board for Manhattan's 92nd Street Y and co-founded Panthera, an organization dedicated to ensuring the future of wild cats through global conservation action.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leal resigned from his post last May as cochair of Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon, to run as the Green Party candidate for vice president in the 2010 Brazilian presidential election. (He did not win.) Before getting into politics Leal helped Natura founder (and fellow Brazilian billionaire) Luiz Seabra build the cosmetics business into a multinational company, with consultants selling makeup and creams across Brazil and seven other Latin American countries. He personally promotes biodiversity and sustainable business practices and has worked with the World Wildlife Fund of Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manuel "Matty" Moroun controls Detroit's Ambassador Bridge, the busiest border crossing between the U.S. and Canada. But the bridge, his most valuable asset, looks to be in jeopardy. The Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, trucking and logistics magnate is being squeezed by mounting legal and political problems on both sides of the border. He wants to build a twin span adjacent to the Ambassador to protect his moneymaker, but a bi-national proposal for a publicly financed bridge two miles downriver is gaining traction among Michigan lawmakers and business leaders. Meanwhile, Canadian authorities have targeted Moroun with a new law that would subject him to hefty penalties if he were to build a new bridge without government approval. But don't count him out: Matty, who controls vast swaths of land on both sides of the border and has already spent $500 million in new infrastructure, usually finds a way to win. The bridge, which handles 8,000 trucks a day and $100 billion in trade,  accounts for bulk of his fortune. Other assets include trucking firms, logistics support, air freight and insurance.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York native is chief of Southern Union, with 15,000 miles of natural gas pipelines. Founded Vision Cable in 1972, sold 230,000-subscriber base to Newhouse brothers for $220 million a decade later. Formed cellphone company Metro Media with investments from billionaires Richard Rainwater and Bass brothers; sold to Bell Atlantic for $2.5 billion 1992. Family owns homes in NYC, Vail, Hamptons, West Palm, Napa, Kentucky.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former protégé of hedge fund legend Julian Robertson returned 14% in 2010. Assets: $16.5 billion. First job after business school: consulting at Mars & Co. Then worked at Goldman Sachs before joining Robertson's Tiger Management as a consumer analyst; became known as one of Robertson's "Tiger Cubs," group of star managers groomed by their well-known boss. In 1997, launched his own firm, Lone Pine, named after Dartmouth pine that survived 1887 lightning strike, according to college lore. Former Charter trustee of Dartmouth, Mandel was elected chairman of Dartmouth's board of trustees last year.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: The pet food billionaire is facing off against Internet calling company Skype with his own video communications firm, ooVoo. It has 16 million users, adding 1 million each month. Mathile's $130 million nonprofit Aileron teaches management skills to entrepreneurs. Former Campbell Soup accountant joined 5-person Iams as general manager 1970; bought firm 1982. Pushed premium pet food to high-end breeders, vets. Sold Iams to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999; gave employees $100 million out of personal cut. Wife MaryAnn runs Mathile Family Foundation, promoting education

name: Billionaires
bio: Telecom pioneer Craig McCaw stepped down in January as chairman on Clearwire, the nationwide high-speed wireless network he'd been trying to build. He founded its predecessor, which later merged with part of Sprint Nextel in 2008. In June 2010, Sprint launched first handset using 4G connection enabled by Clearwire.  But lately the company had been having funding problems, struggling to raise enough to build out and operate the network. McCaw has rebounded in the past and may do so again. Son of broadcasting magnate, McCaw sold cable services door-to-door for dad's company. Co-founded McCaw Cellular with his brothers; sold to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. McCaw then invested in satellite network Nextel; $5 billion lost from net worth during 2000 telecom crash, then had rebounded with Clearwire. His Craig and Susan McCaw Foundation focuses on education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though his first job was in China with Boston chemical maker Wellman, Nelson, the son of an orthodontist, has spent most of his life in his hometown of Providence, Rhode Island. He studied economics at Brown and later founded Providence Equity Partners in the city in 1989. His firm, which mostly buys and fixes up media and telecom outfits, now manages assets of $23 billion. Has earned $3 billion with stake in big German cable company, Kabel-Deustcheland, after taking it public last year with shares now up 70% since IPO. Sold Bresnan Communications to Cablevision this past fall. Other stakes in CDW, Altegrity, Hulu, Yankees Entertainment and Sports Network. Elected to board of Newport Festivals Foundation. Hobbies include big mountain skiing in rarely skied sites.
title: Chief executive officer
employment: {'name': 'Providence Equity Partners', 'title': 'Chief executive officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. Tony co-owns venture fund, New World Ventures, and private holding company, Pritzker Group, with brother J.B.

name: Billionaires
bio: In January, with partner Alexander Skorobogatko, sold stake in NMTP, the biggest port in Russia, to state-owned Transneft and its affiliate Summa Capital, earning $1 billion each. With money to spend, in March purchased a lavish holiday complex on Russia's southern black sea coast, nicknamed "Putin's Palace," for $350 million. Graduate of Simferopol State University and Russian State Academy of Management founded Russian General Bank with Skorobogatko, which served the Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port. After the 1998 crisis the partners began buying up shares in stevedoring companies that were working at the port and combined them to form one holding company. The firm, Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, went public in 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. In 2008 the partners sold 20% of their holding to Arkady Rotenberg, a powerful businessman who does judo with Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. Daniel is a songwriter and guitarist for a soul-rock fusion band, Sonia Dada. He made a silent film, Louis, about the life of Louis Armstrong; released to critical praise in 2010. A second jazz-infused film, Bolden, planned for release by 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. James, a retired Army lieutenant colonel, founded Pritzker Military Library in Chicago in 2003.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Gigi owns film production company Odd Lot Entertainment, which produces films in the $5 million to $60 million range, including hit The Wedding Planner. Split with long-time partner Deborah Del Prete after a major project, Frank Millers' The Spirit, bombed at box offices in 2008. Latest film: Rabbit Hole staring Nicole Kidman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. Karen, a homemaker married to investor Michael Vlock, founded My Hero Project charity in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Plan to pass control of empire to Jay's son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. Linda is a psychotherapist, Tibetan Buddhist and occasional donor to liberal political causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: The fertilizer tycoon bought 12 buildings in New York City in past year. Grew up poor in Ukraine, attended prestigious Soviet university. Ran high-end Hungarian resort in then U.S.S.R.; moved to New York to sell jewelry. His IBE Trade group of companies controls plants in Russia, Ukraine; clients include Yara, Transammonia, ConAgra, Koch Nitrogen. Enjoys tennis; holds a Ph.D. in international economics.

name: Billionaires
bio: The tech titan is on his way to making a full recovery after 2009 elephant attack during Tanzania safari nearly killed him; has undergone more than 15 surgeries since. Currently heads First Virtual Group; interests in commercial real estate, agribusiness, investment management. Founded C3, an energy and emissions-management company. Executive at Oracle before founding software firm Siebel Systems in 1990; sold to Oracle for $5.9 billion in 2005. Siebel foundation has donated $200 million to promoting education, alternative energy; fights methamphetamine abuse, homelessness.

name: Billionaires
bio: In January, with partner (and fellow billionaire) Alexander Ponomarenko, sold stake in NMTP, the biggest port in Russia, to state-owned Transneft and its affiliate Summa Capital, earning $1 billion each. Graduate of Slavyansk State Pedagogical Institute founded Russian General Bank with Ponomarenko, which served the Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port. After the 1998 crisis the partners began buying up shares in stevedoring companies that were working at the port and combined them to form one holding company. The firm, Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, went public in 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. In 2008 the partners sold 20% of their holding to Arkady Rotenberg, a powerful businessman who does judo with Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin. Since 2002 Skorobogatko has served as an elected deputy, barring him from participating in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diversified investor Clemmie Spangler Jr. is waiting for housing recovery to boost the fortunes of his building and construction products supplier, National Gypsum. Took over father's failing Bank of North Carolina, merged in 1982 with NCNB, and later Bank of America; his shares now  worth over $400 million.  Committed to education, served as chair of North Carolina's  board of education from 1982 to 1986; UNC president from 1986 to 1997.  President of Harvard University's Board of Overseers from 2003-2004;  the Spangler Center at Harvard 's Business School is named for his family.  Donates to Charlotte's Teach for America program through his C.D. Splangler Foundation.  Enjoys restoring antique grandfather clocks; says allure is working on something that someone else tinkered with 200 years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and one-time ship captain is helping to keep the ship steady at Evergreen Marine in Taiwan, one of the world's largest container shipping companies. Industry recovery helped the company's share price rise 37% from a year ago. Evergreen is also in the airport business through EVA Airways, which said in December that it would pay $50 million for a 16% stake in China Cargo Airlines, a mainland cargo joint venture between China Eastern Airlines and China Ocean Shipping Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire. Canada's auto parts king left his native Austria for Montreal in 1954, where he spent three years working menial jobs such as caddy, dishwasher, and machinist. Opened his own tool and die shop with his friend Tony Czapka in 1957; today Magna International is one of the world's biggest automotive parts suppliers. Disputes with shareholders led him to give up control of Magna last year in exchange for a payout worth upwards of $1 billion. He's also a successful horse breeder: his Adena Springs Farm won its seventh breeder Eclipse Award this year, raking in double the earnings of its closest competitor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of publicly-traded Hengan International Group, biggest maker of sanitary napkins in China. Sales up 25% to $822 million in the first half of last year, thanks to increase in consumer spending. Co-founder Hui Lin Chit also debuts on billionaires' list this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of pharmaceutical producer Salubris. Sales in 2010 rose 53% to $200 million. The company's Shenzhen-traded shares have gained 23% in the past year, boosting Ye's wealth. Business has benefited from strong Chinese spending on healthcare. Among its products are active ingredients for antibiotics. Ye, an alumni of Renmin University in Beijing, set up a $2.3 million foundation there for development of an international relations institute. A former deputy mayor of Shenzhen, Ye took the plunge as an entrepreneur in 1986. Son Kevin Sing Ye, the company's president, holds an MBA from Yale University and is an American citizen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich's much lower-profile right-hand man first worked with him at Runicom, an offshore holding. Was also main oil trader at Abramovich's Sibneft, which was sold in 2005 to Gazprom. Owns piece of Millhouse LLC, Abramovich's investment vehicle, with assets in metals, commercial real estate and cash. In 2010 he bought Abramovich's coal mines in Chukotka and sold them to Canadian company Kinross Gold. He also controls Prodo, the second biggest meat and meat products processing company in Russia and the biggest source of his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Executive director of property developer Guangzhou R&F Properties, chaired by fellow billionaire Li Sze Lim. R&F, which started its business in Guangzhou, has evolved from a regional leader to national heavyweight, with a market capitalization of $4.3 billion and projects in development in Beijing, Guangzhou, Tianjing, Xian, Chongqing, Huizhou, Hainan, Chengdu, Shanghai, Taiyuan and Shenyang. Holds minority stake in Chinese brokerage Haitong Securities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Outspoken chairman of 85-year-old Bajaj Group. Flagship Bajaj Auto, run by son Rajiv, stopped producing its iconic scooter, once much coveted by middle-class Indians. Group has retained marketing guru Jack Trout to advise on branding strategy. Joint venture with Renault-Nissan is developing a low-cost car, likely competitor to Tata's Nano. Insurance firm Bajaj Allianz, which younger son Sanjiv oversees, recently forged distribution tieup with Warren Buffet's Berkshire Hathaway. Has attended the World Economic Forum's Davos conference for past 33 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: A buyout titan in the 1990s (General Instrument, Gulfstream), Forstmann is now running sports management firm IMG, which his firm bought in 2004. Found himself at the center of scandal when a longtime business acquaintance accused him of betting on several IMG sports clients including Roger Federer, and against others, like Tiger Woods. Forstmann admits to having gambled in the past but denied the charges in the lawsuit. In 2010, announced a joint venture with Indian billionaire Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries to manage sports and entertainment in India; firm now has operations in 30 countries. Grew up wealthy in Greenwich, Conn., grandson of a German-born wool magnate. Played goalie on Yale's hockey team, attended Columbia Law School, and has squired a succession of beauties including Elizabeth Hurley, Princess Diana and current girlfriend celebrity foodie Padma Lakshmi. Has sided with Lakshmi in a custody fight against Adam Dell, father of her child and brother of billionaire Michael. Forstmann is the guardian of two South African boys, who he is raising.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder with husband Liu Ming Ching and brother Zhang Chengfei of Nine Dragons Paper, the largest packaging paperboard producer in Asia. Nine Dragon's Hong Kong-listed shares and family's wealth are off amid worries about how rising raw materials costs will affect future profit. She is a member of numerous associations such as the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and is vice chairman of Chamber of Commerce of Guangdong province. Son Lau Chun Shun is a member of the board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of an advertising executive grew up in New Jersey. Studied finance, economics at Alfred University. First job at Merrill Lynch doing mergers and acquisitions. Started investing money in 1985 for Alliance Capital Management. Held post at investment bank Allen & Co. before founding hedge fund Chilton Investment Co. in 1992. Art collector, mainly American furniture and paintings. Fund gained 8.3% in 2010. Assets under management: $7.5 billion. On board of Metropolitan Museum of Art.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'Chilton Investment Company, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Cork native sold programs at Dublin soccer stadium Tolka Park while a student. Took job at Citibank, then worked briefly as banking consultant for Pricewaterhouse Coopers in Kabul, Afghanistan. Founded NCB Stockbrokers in 1981; created Ireland's largest independent brokerage. Helped revitalize Ireland's economy in late 1980s with proposal for Dublin's International Financial Services Centre. Sold NCB in 1994 for $39 million, plowed proceeds into private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. Sold London City Airport 2006. Still owns international betting exchange Betdaq, online education outfit Intuition, mapping software company eSpatial. Also holds stake in Barbados' Sandy Lane Hotel. Known as The Kaiser for his distinctive gnarly mustache.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diversified investor owns My Bank in Moscow and investment firm My Decker Capital in Beijing, which is managing a fund that plans to invest in China's largest retail chain, New Cooperation Trade Chain (NCS). Studied economics at Moscow State University, where he got a doctorate. Headed several investment firms before joining Alfa Group in 1995. Worked in the firm's food-and-commodities-trading subsidiary, Alfa Eco, then led the group's takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia. Later became a lobbyist and member of the Federation Council, the upper house of parliament; stepped down last year. Maintains a large stake in Altimo, a company that inherited Alfa Eco's assets and now has major holdings in Russia's telecom industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlson Inc. has benefited from industry-wide recovery in main divisions: hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's), travel agencies. Focusing on global expansion to supplement slower growing U.S. assets and a goal of increasing its hotel portfolio 50% to 1,500 hotels by 2015. Father, Curt (d. 1999), began selling Gold Bond trading stamps 1930s; expanded into dining, hospitality. Barbara runs the family foundation, active with children's charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: His grandfather founded Gerling Konzern as a small insurance company in 1904; his father turned it into a significant player in the global insurance business. Despite his training as an economist, Rolf showed little interest in his legacy and eventually sold his 94% stake in the company in 2005 to Germany's Talanx Group for estimated $1.6 billion. Established the Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank set up to study the industrial world's impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive and cofounder of Infosys, he's rumored to be among front-runners to succeed N.R.Narayana Murthy as chairman. Got boost from 24% rise in stock price over past year. Company reportedly plans to invest $100 million in a new campus in China. He donates $2 million every year to several causes, including his alma mater IIT Madras and for research on Parkinson's disease. Technology and gadget freak.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of telecommunications distributor Shenzhen Aisidi debuts on this year's billionaires list after a successful IPO on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2010.  Aisidi has been a distributor of Apple IT products in China since 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: In February Gores closed a new $2 billion private equity fund. Last summer he teamed with billionaire brother Tom in acquiring Alliance Entertainment. Emigrated from Israel to Flint, Mich. in 1968; sold computers out of basement. Started buyout firm Gores Group in 1987; with new fund has $4.9 billion under management. His portfolio includes communication, fiber, security and technology companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard Business School grad has been friend of Warren Buffett since 1962; owns shares of Berkshire Hathaway and serves on its board. Founded investment advisor First Manhattan Co.; $11 billion assets under management.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'First Manhattan Co.', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former billionaire Michael Heisley passed away in late April 2014 at age 77. He founded Heico Companies, a Chicago holding company that specialized in buying underperforming or bankrupt companies to turn them around. He started in 1979 by buying Conco, a maker of sewer and drain equipment, with $150,000 in profit from selling his home and $10 million in bank loans. Heico expanded and bought several struggling Rust Belt manufacturers. He bought the Vancouver Grizzlies NBA basketball team and moved them to Memphis. He sold the team to a group led by technology billionaire Robert Pera in 2012. The Grizzlies made the playoffs in 2011.  Heisley was last on the Forbes Billionaires list in 2012. He fell off the list the following year.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of a growing number of female billionaires in China, chairs Beijing Orient Landscape, a provider of landscape architecture services. She debuts on the list thanks to her 54% stake in the Shenzhen-listed company, which listed in 2009; shares have more than doubled since then. Husband Tang Kai holds 11% and is vice chairman. A native of Zhejiang Province, He graduated from Beijing Forestry University, and has funded a scholarship at her alma mater. One of He's pleasures: walking in the rain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean immigrant moved to U.S. in 1955. Former law student started Amkor Electronics in 1968 as American sales/design partner to father H.S. Kim's Korean chipmaker, Anam Semiconductor. Went public in 1998. Stepped down as CEO in October 2009; remains executive chairman of Amkor board. Created Electronics Boutique mall kiosks with wife, Agnes, in 1977; bought out by GameStop in 2005 for $1.4 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Russia; now a German citizen. (Last name was formerly spelled Iorikh.) The former commercial director of Kuznetsk Coal in Russia became president of Swiss firm Conares Holding in 1995, overseeing export sales and financing. The public learned about him for the first time in October 2004, when Mechel, the largest producer of special steel and alloys, listed on the NYSE and Iorikh was named general director; he turned out to have the same size stake as better-known partner Igor Zyuzin, also a billionaire. Between 2005 and 2006 the two became divided over the direction of the company, and by January 2007 Iorikh had sold his shares to Zyuzin. Established an offshore fund to buy stakes in mining and machine firms in Turkey, Canada and Australia. Mining shares have risen dramatically over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Professor-turned-billionaire has seen his fortune rise by half a billion dollars this year thanks to Qualcomm's stock performance. He earned a doctorate at MIT and then taught electrical engineering for seven years. Moved to California in 1966, taught computer science at Univ. California at San Diego, where the engineering school is now named after him. Two years later, he founded Linkabit Corporation to develop satellite communication systems. Started wireless chip firm Qualcomm in 1985; son Paul took over as chief executive in 2006; Irwin remains chairman. Gave $6.5 million to Univ. California at San Francisco for cancer research after surviving a rare form of the disease. Also donates to the arts and education in San Diego.
title: Cofounder & Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Acron, the country's third-largest nitrogen fertilizer producer. Considering mergers with domestic rivals. Son of a Moscow department store director; graduated from the Moscow Aviation Institute and set up a computer trading firm in late 1980s. Later became friendly with the governor of Novgorod, Mikhail Prusak, and through privatization bought local fertilizer producer Azot. Renamed it Acron and made it the basis for his chemicals empire, now publicly traded. A passionate collector of paintings by Russian artists of Jewish origin, chairs Russian Jewish Congress. Spends most of his time at his mansion in Geneva.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Shinsegae Group and Korea's richest woman. She is the youngest daughter of late Samsung Group founder Lee Byung Chull and the younger sister of former Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun Hee. Shinsegae Group was owned by Samsung until the two separated in 1991; now the group is South Korea's second largest retailer after Lotte Group. Rapidly expanding in China with 23 E-Mart discount stores on mainland; planning another 88 within three years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Taiwan; got a degree in dental surgery from the University of Santa Amaro in Brazil in 1983.  Met his wife Yan Cheung in Hong Kong. Moved with her to the U.S. in 1990 where they set up a paper recycling business. Later returned to China and started paper manufacturer Nine Dragons with his wife and brother-in-law. Company went public March 2006. All three are once again billionaires thanks to stock surge in past year. Flags from China, the United States and Brazil hang outside their corporate headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago investor is cofounder and 30% owner of the fastest-growing company ever, Web phenom Groupon, which updates its online audience about deep discounts on products and services. Lefkofsky met Groupon founder Andrew Mason at InnerWorkings, a Chicago firm where Mason worked after college. Lefkofsky was a founder of the outfit, which farms out companies' printing jobs. Lefkofsky later gave Mason $1 million in angel capital for another startup idea he had. While Mason runs Groupon, Lefkofsky is busy looking for other investments.  Earlier this year, he cofounded a venture fund LightBank, which has stakes in nearly a dozen companies. He is also the author of Accelerated Disruption and an adjunct professor at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. Lefkofsky grew up in the Detroit suburbs.  Attended University of Michigan and then Michigan's law school.  Started a business in college selling carpet scraps to incoming freshmen on move-in day during the fall.  By his senior year, he had 10 universities under contract.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's largest cutter and polisher of diamonds is benefiting from diamond recovery; growing business in lucrative new markets like China and India. Trying to regain investor confidence in real estate holding company Africa Israel after negotiating a large debt settlement in 2009; injected a reported $400 million out of his own pocket, sold off assets. Still, stock price down 30% over the past year. Looking for uptick in Russia; sent his daughter to open high-end Moscow mall. Born in Uzbekistan, his Lubavitcher Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. Made his name undercutting De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola. President of the Federation of Jewish Communities in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three men -- Liao's late father, Lin Su-hon and Tseng Shin-yi  -- co-founded Chang Chun Group in Taipei in 1949 as a supplier of industrial materials at a time when Taiwan was recovering from World War II and civil war in China. The three families each own a third of what today has become a major plastics and petrochemicals manufacturer. Lin is chairman. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical. New billionaire this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three men -- Liao Long-shing's late father, Lin Suhon and Tseng Shin-yi -- cofounded Chang Chun Group in Taipei in 1949 as a supplier of industrial materials at a time when Taiwan was recovering from World War II and civil war in China. The three families each own a third of what today has become a major plastics and petrochemicals manufacturer. Lin is chairman. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Kangmei Pharmaceutical, a supplier of drugs including antibiotics, based in Guangdong Province. Business has been healthy: sales were up 32% in the first nine months of 2010 to $354 million; shares climbed 40%. Kangmei is headquartered in Puning, the city where Ma was born. He is an adjunct professor at the Guangzhou University of Traditional Chinese Medicine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former English teacher once offered tours to English-speaking tourists of Hangzhou's famed West Lake. Now runs one of China's Internet companies Alibaba.com, in which Yahoo! and Tokyo-listed Softbank hold shares. Suffered rare publicity setback this year Alibaba.com when president David Wei resigned after the company disclosed fraud among suppliers.  Alibaba Group in January unveiled plan to expand into logistics. He started the China Pages, one of the nation's first internet companies in 1995. Three years later, founded Alibaba with $60,000 in capital, mostly to offer a way for companies outside of China to find manufacturers and suppliers inside China. Took his business portal Alibaba.com in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: University of Chicago grad used $80,000 in savings to start Morningstar in 1984 out of his Chicago apartment. Investment research outfit gained fame rating mutual funds. Took it public in 2005; his fortune got a $300 million boost this year thanks to 20% stock rise. Bought Standard & Poor's fund data business in 2007; U.K. data, media and investor-relations Web site Hemscott in 2008. Magazine assets include Fast Company and Inc.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Morningstar Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Fastidious investor ran diversified investment portfolio himself until recently. "I celebrated 65 years and retired," Rahimkulov told Forbes; handed decision-making to asset management firm. In the mid-1990s became chief executive and 10% owner of joint venture between gas giant Gazprom and Hungary's oil & gas concern, MOL. To process payments from its local customers, Gazprom bought the Hungarian bank Altalanos ErtekForgalmi Bank (AEB); Rahimkulov headed this as well and later bought it from Gazprom. In 2007 he sold AEB and used the proceeds to buy shares in MOL and OTP, the largest bank in Hungary. Also owns shares of Gazprom and VTB.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire is Dutch businessman, founder of chemical company Melchemie Holland BV. Now  a major shareholder of HAL Trust, an international investment company based in the Netherlands Antilles. In 2005, his 37 year old daughter, Claudia, was kidnapped; ransom was 660 pounds of cocaine; released unharmed two days later. After the press insinuated he was involved in the drug trade, founded the Melchers Fund to provide financial aid to initiate lawsuits and legal aid to victims of slanderous media reports. Bridge fan: founder of the Onstein semi-professional bridge association. Tournaments are held at his castle estate in the Dutch city of Vorden; major sponsor of Dutch Bridge federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlson Inc. has benefited from industry-wide recovery in main divisions: hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's), travel agencies. Focusing on global expansion to supplement slower-growth U.S. assets and a goal of increasing its hotel portfolio 50% to 1,500 hotels by 2015. Father, Curt (d. 1999), began selling Gold Bond trading stamps 1930s; expanded into dining, hospitality. Marilyn stepped down as CEO in 2008.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Immortalized in the movie, The Social Network, which portrayed him being betrayed by his onetime best friend Mark Zuckerberg. After its release, published a piece about his reaction to the movie: "What I gleaned from viewing (the movie) was bigger and more important than whether the scenes and details included in the script were accurate." The buddies started Facebook together at Harvard, with Saverin apparently providing early seed money. For a brief time he had a one-third stake, which then fell to 30% when Zuckerberg's roommate, Dustin Moskovitz, joined. When the others dropped out of school to relocate to California, Saverin stayed behind.  A year later Facebook sued him for allegedly interfering with business and insisting on keeping a 30% stake; Saverin countersued. The parties settled, with Saverin apparently getting a 5% stake and a co-founder bio on Facebook's site. A source tells Forbes he's been selling shares and now holds a reported 2%. In January, made rare news when he led an $8 million round of financing of Qwiki, a hot Silicon Valley startup, along with other high-profile investors Jawed Karim, co-founder of YouTube, and Pradeep Sindhu, co-founder of Juniper Networks.  Last September, Qwiki won top prize at Internet startup conference TechCrunch Disrupt, putting it on the map for potential investors. Saverin had seen its demo at Disrupt over a livestream video in Singapore, where he currently resides, and reached out to Qwiki. Has public Facebook page, which he periodically updates. On it he says his activities are hurricane tracking and soccer; interests are digital media, the Internet revolution and happiness.

name: Billionaires
bio: In February his Matchzone Holdings consolidated 100% of shares in Rusagro, the agribusiness group that he founded; may consider Rusagro IPO again this year after tabling one last year. Started out selling apartments, vodka and oil in the early 1990s. Put the capital he scraped together in land, creating Rusagro, an agro-industrial holding company. Today it is one of the largest sugar producers in Russia. In 2005 bought a former cooperative farm not far from Moscow that had been established after the revolution to provide fresh milk to intelligence officers. Where cows once roamed, now he plans to build a massive residential and retail development. Also serves as Russian Federation Council Senator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley strategist and former Facebook president debuts as a billionaire based on the surging value the social networking site. His reported stake: just under 3%. At 19, the serial entrepreneur co-founded Napster in 1999, the peer-to-peer music sharing service that brought free music to the masses, but quickly collapsed under piracy allegations. Still, the disruptive technology helped trigger the record industry's precipitous decline. Parker joined Facebook in 2004. Recently made more famous after being played by Justin Timberlake in the Oscar-winning film "The Social Network." He's currently a managing partner at Founders Fund, a venture capital firm that invests in tech companies. Diving back into digital music with an investment in Spotify, the popular European music subscription service that hopes to launch in the U.S. sometime this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold a Cadillac; used $100 of proceeds to start Conair (formerly Continental Hair Products) with parents after family's Manhattan beauty parlor failed. Company manufactured hair rollers invented by father. Went public in 1972, then private again in 1985 through leveraged buyout. Expanded brand portfolio to include home appliance names Cuisinart, Waring and hair product lines Scunci, Babyliss and Rusk. Has CuisinArt resort in Anguilla, complete with hydroponic farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of China's most venerated investors, based in part on successful picks such as China Minsheng Banking and Hua Xia Bank. Giant Interactive, the Shi-led, Shanghai-based online game company that listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 2007, has had a rougher time amid tough competition and changing demographics in China. Giant in December said it had formed a joint venture with Huayi Brothers Media, a movie production company, to jointly develop a new online game, King of Kings III.  Shi has also invested in small-cap shares in China, such as Inner Mongolia Jinyu Group, whose businesses include vaccines and property. Holds a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Zhejiang University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kavitark "Ram" Shriram was one of the first people to write a check to Google co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page in 1998. Shriram would advise them one day a week in their Menlo Park garage. Today he is still a board member and large shareholder of the search giant. He is now running his own investment firm, Sherpalo Ventures, which has big stakes in online outsourcer 24/7 Customer and serendipitous website picker StumbleUpon, with 10 million members. It has also invested recently in Inkling, which makes interactive textbooks for the iPad. Firm cashed in on Mint Software, which was bought by Intuit for $171 million a year ago. Born in India, he joined Netscape in 1994. His next company, Junglee, was bought by Amazon in 1998. Elected Stanford U. trustee last December; one daughter attends, the other graduated.
title: Managing Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: As the best friend of Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, Shvidler has made his fortune alongside the richer Russian. His biggest holding: a 3.4% stake in Russia's largest steelmaker, Evraz. He also has investments in gold mining, Moscow real estate and cash from the sale of his Sibneft stake to Gazprom in 2005. His vineyard at his Château Thenac in France produces nine grape varieties; property also has two plum orchards. Has a 370-foot yacht, Le Grand Bleu, which was a gift from Abramovich. Also owns a house in Snowmass, Colorado.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former billionaires cover boy - he graced the cover of the 2002 billionaires issue - fell off the list in 2003. Returns this year, as shares of his cybersecurity firm Check Point Software Technologies jumped more than 40% in the past six months; group's sales and profits up 20%  last year. In spare time, avid photographer and passionate about cooking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brothers Hong-tu Tsai and T.Y. Tsai, one of three Tsai family members who inherited significant stakes of Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding when their father Tsai Wan-lin died in 2004. Hong-tu and Cheng-da purchased most of T.Y. Tsai's stake at the end of last year, industry executives say. Cathay Financial says it can't comment on any transfer of shares among the three brothers.

name: Billionaires
bio: US-educated son of a former billionaire who founded automotive group Astra but eventually lost control and much of his wealth. He began working to restore family's fortune, setting up investment firm Saratoga Investama Sedaya in 1998. Today, through his private equity firm Saratoga Capital, holds big chunk in coal miner Adaro Energy, where he's one of 5 cofounders. He took his firm's cell tower company Tower Bersama Infrastructure public in October.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brothers Cheng-da Tsai and T.Y. Tsai, one of three Tsai family members who inherited significant stakes of Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding when their father Tsai Wan-lin died in 2004. Hong-tu and Cheng-da purchased most of T.Y. Tsai's stake at the end of last year, industry executives said. Cathay Financial says it can't comment on any transfer of shares among the three brothers. Hong-tu remains chairman of Cathay Financial, which has been expanding in the mainland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jon Stryker has used his inheritance to fund two very different missions: advancing gay rights and protecting apes and chimpanzees. As a youth, he talked his mother into buying him a pet monkey, then realized that was inhumane and gave it to a zoo. Has since pumped millions into organizations like Save the Chimps in Ft. Pierce, Florida and the Ol Pejeta Wildlife Conservancy in Northern Kenya. Had a recently discovered species of monkey in Myanmar named after him: Rhinopithecus strykeri. Also one of the largest donors to gay and lesbian charities. Cash comes from medical device company Stryker Corp, founded in 1941 by his surgeon grandfather Homer Stryker (d.1980), the inventor of mobile hospital beds. Last September, Jon's former secretary was sentenced to two years in prison for improperly charging more than $1 million on his business credit card.

name: Billionaires
