bio: Owns more than 80% of $3.3 billion (sales) Hunter Douglas Group, a Netherlands company that makes and markets window coverings and architectural products. Father, Henry Sonnenberg, founded the group in 1919 as a machine-tool company, eventually developing new technology for the production of lightweight aluminum slats for Venetian blinds. Last year supplied window blinds and ceiling systems to the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa tower in Dubai. Has been chief executive since 1971. Sons Marko and David work alongside their dad.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Homer Stryker, the surgeon who invented mobile hospital beds and founded medical device company, Stryker Corp. in 1941. Pat is a large shareholder along with two siblings, Jon and Ronda. Firm sold $6.7 billion worth of hospital beds, artificial joints and other medical equipment last year. She has used her fortune to fund community non-profits through her Bohemian Foundation; backs Democratic candidates in Colorado politics. The press dubbed her as one of the "Gang of Four," a quartet of rich Democrats that financed a liberal agenda in Colorado. Wine enthusiast bought 32-acre vineyard in northern California in 1999; Stryker Sonoma produces about 7,000 cases a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: China-born, Singapore-based businessman has been a creative and successful force in the real estate market back in the motherland. Zhong-led Yanlord Land, whose shares trade in Singapore, was a pioneering national upscale brand as the country's real estate market opened in the 1990s. Zhong also broke ground by selling finished properties in a country where the interior is usually left to the individual buyer. Elected vice president of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in February. Active in the Singapore Federation of Chinese Clan Associations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three men -- Liao Long-shing's late father, Lin Su-hon and Tseng Shin-yi -- co-founded Chang Chun Group in Taipei in 1949 as a supplier of industrial materials at a time when Taiwan was recovering from World War II and civil war in China. The three families each own a third of what today has become a major plastics and petrochemicals manufacturer. Lin is chairman. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical. New billionaire this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: A great grandson of German auto pioneer Adam Opel. Business administration graduate from the University of Rhode Island, inherited over $150 million in 1989; carefully invested money via investment arm Hansa AG. In 2009 sold his share of the Swiss Jelmoli Holding to real estate company Swiss Prime Site for $230 million in cash and a 9% stake in the company. Also controls 96% of private investment firm Athris through which he has stakes in a Swiss hotel chain, a restaurant chain, a sports store and shopping centers in Russia and Algeria. A long-time Swiss resident, his Georg and Emily von Opel foundation funds care and education of underprivileged children and teens in developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: The South African makes the cut thanks to his stake in the continent's biggest retailer, low-price supermarket chain Shoprite. Known as "Christo", he also owns a stake in discount clothes, shoes and textiles chain Pepkor (slogan: "Making the desirable affordable.") Restored a South African farm estate and remodeled it into a five-star hotel, Lanzerac Manor & Winery. Replanted the vineyards around it, created a modern cellar and has restarted brewing wine. Also owns wine producer Lourensford Estate and a private game reserve in the Kalahari.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhou chairs Xiyang Group, one of China's largest suppliers of magnetite products, used in making steel. Sales last year totaled $3.7 billion, a 26% increase from the prior year. Xiyang also supplies steel and fertilizer, and is expanding its overseas investments. Zhou holds a master's degree from the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. His hobbies include basketball and mountain climbing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Long Island-born Abraham joined his uncle's medical supplies company after serving in the Army in World War II. He struck it rich with the Slim-Fast line of diet supplements, starting with shakes and expanding to snacks. He sold out to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000. Very involved in Middle East peacemaking efforts, he founded the S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace and wrote a book called Peace is Possible. He's a big donor to the Democrats and friend of the Clintons.
organization: S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: His trade fair operator and retailer, Crocus, last summer opened the first Vegas Mall in Moscow which features over 300 shops (including Starbucks) and an amusement park. In the fall, leased two Moscow locations to Prada which is entering the Russian market. Also building in Vladivostok ahead of the APEC summit in September 2012. Got his start trading computers, but saw that trade fairs had more business potential. In 1988 established Crocus, which became one of the country's largest trade-fair operators. Opened the Crocus Inter store, which grew into a retail company with malls offering housewares, and the luxurious Crocus City Mall, the "city of boutiques." Seen as the unofficial representative of the Azerbaijani diaspora in Russia. In 2006 his son, Emin, married the daughter of Azerbaijan's president, Ilkham Aliyev. Publishes Baku magazine, which is edited by daughter-in-law Leyla Aliyeva.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson in 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, in 1968. Bass Enterprises Production planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion in 2005. Ed studied architecture at Yale. Built hotel in the Himalayas; spent $200 million building Biosphere 2 project in Arizona 1990s. Invested in venture capital, ranches in Texas, Kansas, Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate investor Barrack founded Colony Capital in 1991. Bought up bad real estate loans from busted S&Ls. The firm now manages around $30 billion in assets; has holdings in 8 casinos in Atlantic City, the Gulf Coast and Europe. The firm has an eye for troubled assets: it refinanced celebrity photographer Annie Leibovitz's $24 million loan in March and bought the $23.5 million mortgage on Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch in 2008. It has its own woes: Station Casinos filed for bankruptcy in July 2009; in August it surrendered the stalled Meadowlands Xanadu project to lenders. Barrack served in the Reagan administration as Deputy Undersecretary of the Department of the Interior. Was a principal at the Robert Bass Group before starting Colony. Parents were Lebanese immigrants. Studied law at U of Southern California, where he was editor of the Law Review. Enjoys tennis, surfing and horseback riding; his ranch near Santa Barbara is home to polo grounds and Bordeaux-producing vineyards.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Italian industrial magnate owns more than 50% of conglomerate Caltagirone SpA, which has investments in construction, cement makers, banks, utilities and media assets. Scooped up shares of downtrodden companies during the credit crisis: insurer Generali, building-materials manufacturer Italcementi, and bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena. Last year, his personal financial holding company, ICAL, bought two buildings in Rome from a Goldman Sachs fund for a reported $225 million. Dubbed Franco the Taciturn by media for his quiet ways.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Baltimore Ravens worth $1.1 billion; have sold out every game since team moved to Baltimore from Cleveland in 1996. Father died of leukemia when he was young; raised by sports-crazed mother. Became obsessed with making enough money by age 35 so his wife and kids wouldn't have to work if his father's fate befell him. Early jobs: pumping gas, mowing lawns, babysitting. Founded staffing firm Aerotek in basement with $3,500 at age 23; now holds majority stake in staffing and recruiting company Allegis Group.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker became head of Banco Santander in 1986. Built it into Santander Central Hispano. The bank he chairs is now the fourth largest bank in the world by profits and eighth by stock market capitalization. Posted $10.9 billion in net profits in 2010. Over 14,000 branches worldwide; present in the U.S., through Sovereign Bank; in the UK is the third largest bank in the country by deposits. An early presence in Latin America, the region now contributes over 40% to profits. Daughter and heir apparent, Ana Botin, runs Banesto, bank's retail branch. Botin's great-grandfather discovered the famous Altamira caves in northern Spain in 1879. Emilio enjoys golf, hunting and fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of TPK Holdings, a supplier of touchscreens for Apple's iPhones and iPads. Listed on Taiwan exchange last year but mainly manufacturers its products in Xiamen on the mainland China. His first company, TVM, supplied video monitors. He majored in management at Fu Jen Catholic University in Taipei. Shares fortune with wife.

name: Billionaires
bio: Basel art fair regular owns multimillion-dollar art collection, including pieces by Pablo Picasso, Jasper Johns and Andy Warhol. First job: research analyst for a liquor company. Cofounded vitamin retailer Keystone Discount Stores. Merged with Philadelphia Pharmaceuticals in 1967, cashed out for $1 million a year later, moved to Florida. Bought Cadillac dealership in Tampa in 1972; today owns 16 car dealerships in Florida and Colorado. Business has been picking up: "Things are very optimistic." Lost lawsuit attempting to stop public funds from being used to build stadium for Florida Marlins. Charitable foundation and grandchildren¹s trust fell victim to Madoff¹s fraud.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $2.7 billion (sales) Hubert Burda Media Holding, which publishes well-known German magazines such as Focus and Bunte. In January 2011 transferred  40% of the company to his two children, Jacob (age 20) and Elisabeth (age 18); he retains 60%. Committed philanthropist: supports the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German literature; established the Felix Burda Foundation, committed to reducing the the number of deaths from colon cancer in Germany; formed the Burda Academy of the Third Millennium, an inter-disciplinary forum for researchers and thinkers. Holds the Leo Baeck Prize for his efforts to bring together Jewish and non-Jewish communities in Germany; also the Federal Cross of Merit. Married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwangler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst. Family's media empire today includes 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, Albany Times Union), magazines, TV and radio stations, stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, and A&E. Family owns the 90,000-square-foot Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif; state has paid the Hearsts $95 million to preserve the property.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a carpenter. Founded Sonae GSPS, maker of decorative laminates, in 1959. Later diversified into supermarkets, eventually becoming Portugal's biggest retailer through his Modelo Continente superstores and supermarket. Holds 53% stake in the now $8.4 billion (sales) Sonae, which today has interests in tourism, car parks, real estate, shopping centers, a radio station, a newspaper and a maker of wood panels. Chairman of company. Son Paulo is CEO; son Nuno and daughter Claudia also work at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and CEO of York Capital hedge fund sold a 30% stake to Credit Suisse in September for $425 million. Got his start working 100-hour weeks at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He lost his entire life savings on Black Monday in 1987. Since then, says he rarely uses debt. He founded York Capital in 1991 with $3.6 million from DLJ colleagues. Bet that put him on map: in 1993 he invested about $600,000, or about 5% of York's assets at the time, in Sears stock and doubled his money in six months. Today firm manages $14 billion; it posted returns of 7.5% in 2010. Dinan says he enjoys being a dad, sailing, skiing, exercising and DIY projects. He wears a hearing aid because he lost much of his hearing as an infant after being given the antibiotic streptomycin for a fever.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded 1&1 AG in 1988 with a borrowed desk and some $300.000 in seed capital to service software and telecommunication companies too small to reach clients on their own. In 1998 took company public on the now defunct Neuer Markt, Germany's exchange for high tech companies. Presently owns 36% of the company, renamed United Internet AG, which posted $2 billion in revenues in 2009; it's an international Internet service provider with 9 million customers. Avid sailor owns yacht; his company sponsored the German sailing team in the 2007 America's Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Italian financier is good buddies with embattled billionaire Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. Doris cofounded financial services group Mediolanum SpA and partnered with Berlusconi's Fininvest Group in 1982. Still runs the group, whose companies provide investment advice, banking services, life insurance and real estate loans. One of Italy's largest such groups by market capitalization. The shares are flat since February 2010 after making a strong recovery in 2009. Son Massimo, 42, is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive billionaire is Toyota's middleman in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Arkansas. Former Hollywood stunt pilot owns Tanzania Game Tracker Safaris; Friedkin Conservation Fund protects land and gives to rural communities. Son Dan runs Friedkin Cos.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former director of Chinese automaker Geely Automobile Holdings took control of Hong Kong-listed publishing company Jessica Publications in 2007, renamed and refocused the business, now called Honbridge Holdings, and has turned himself into a billionaire through it. The company's main focus is on mining projects in South America. He is a graduate of Anhui Finance and Trade College and worked in the Chinese Ministry of Commerce before becoming an entrepreneur. Still owns a small stake in Geely Automobile.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Paychex founder recently sold the NHL's Buffalo Sabres to fellow billionaire Terry Pegula for $189 million. The city praised Golisano's reign for saving Buffalo hockey. The longtime New Yorker moved to Florida for tax relief in May 2009. Made three failed runs at being governor of New York via his Independence Party. Formed Paychex with $3,000 and a credit card 1971; expanded payroll and HR services company via franchising and joint ventures.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman's Fujian Sunner Development is one of China's largest chicken breeders. Started supplying KFC in 1994 and signed an agreement to do the same in a joint venture  for McDonald's in December. Fu started his business in Fujian Province with a $3,000 loan. Sunner's revenues last year: $318 million, up 44% from a year earlier.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri, who left behind a fortune now shared by his five children. Ayman sits on the board of Saudi Oger, a construction, telecom and real estate conglomerate. Oversees group's construction division, which is behind mega projects such as  Princess Noura Bint Abdulrahman University for Women and King Abdullah Financial District. Sits on the board of 3C Telecommunications, a South African mobile operator which is majority-owned by Saudi Oger.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafiq Hariri inherited stake in his father's construction, telecom and real estate conglomerate Saudi Oger after his death in 2005. Serves on the board of family's Future TV, a satellite and terrestrial television network covering the Middle East. Lives in Paris.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Novosibirsk State University graduate started out in 1993 selling a variety of consumer goods to an eager public. Later founded the Profit House investment firm, traded shares on Russian stock exchanges, took part in some big deals as a representative of Roman Abramovich. In 2003 Profit House together with Abramovich bought five Russian generic-drug plants and a drugstore chain from ICN Pharmaceuticals, a U.S. company founded by former Yugoslav prime minister Milan Panic. These assets grew into Pharmstandard, now the largest domestic drugmaker in Russia. In 2007, it went public on the Moscow bourse and the London Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: America's richest practicing lawyer. Says he turns down hundreds of cases each year -- most recently, BP: "I'm too busy. I didn't want to deal with it."  Built business on personal injury cases. Penned autobiography Trials and Jubilations. Gave the University of Texas $15 million last year; gave Rice University, which will soon open the Lee & Joseph Jamail Academic Wing, $1 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of top 10 landowners in the U.S., buying up more ranch acreage in Texas. Farmer's son founded Commonwealth Brands in 1990, made fortune with discount cigarettes. Outperformed big brands by keeping prices low, skimping on advertising. Sold business for $1 billion in 2001. Reinvested in real estate: owns 1.7 million acres in New Mexico, Florida, Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the 1990s was good friends with Vladimir Putin when the future president was vice mayor of St. Petersburg. Their country houses were both in the Ozerki dacha cooperative, and when Putin became president, many of Ozerki's members saw their careers improve. Now the largest shareholder of Rossiya bank, which controls insurance company Sogas, one of the largest in Russia; its main client is gas behemoth Gazprom. Also has 40% of Gazprombank, the third-largest bank in the country in terms of capital; Gazprom is also its main client. Over the past year has added to media holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: After studying construction and finance in Moscow secondary schools, got a job at privately held BIN Bank; then Slavneft, an oil company then led by fellow billionaire Mikhail Gutseriev. Between 2001 and 2003, Khachaturov and his partners spent $60 million buying 75% of the insolvent insurance giant Rosgosstrakh from the government. Managed to transform the Soviet-era company into one of the highest-volume Russian insurers. In 2010 Khachaturov and his partners bought the government's remaining 25% stake in Rosgosstrakh; they now own the entire company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of teachers studied food process engineering at Kiev Food Industry Institute, began trading grain after Soviet Union's collapse. While renting grain silos, saw opportunity to sell to for domestic grain customers; decided to go into production using grain for poultry production. Began precursor to today's MHP with 10 employees in 1998. Got IMF funding in early 2000. Took his poultry producer MHP public in May 2008; briefly became a paper billionaire before markets crashed that fall. Sold 10% stake in December 2010 for approximately $165 million. Firm, which sells only to Eastern Europe right now, has plans to expand throughout Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Russian copper producer Urals Mining and Metals Company (UMMC) which  increased output 15% in 2010. The Urals and its metals industry are in his blood. Grew up in the town of Verkhnaya Pyshma in the Urals region and studied at a metallurgy institute. In 1979 went to work as a mechanic at Uralelectromed, now the main factory at the UMMC. Served as general director from 1995 to 2002. The company also manages agricultural, construction and telecom companies in the Ural region. Now fellow billionaire Iskander Makhmudov's closest partner, helping him build up holdings in Urals mining and metallurgy companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Bob" owns the New England Patriots, NFL's third most valuable team. Bought struggling franchise in 1994 for record $172 million; today squad worth $1.4 billion. Team has won three Super Bowls. Father was clothingmaker. Studied at Columbia, then Harvard M.B.A. Joined packing firm Rand-Whitney. Later bought company, diversified. Today Kraft Group controls real estate, paper companies, private equity, New England Revolution soccer team. Partnered with Massachusetts Lottery for $150 million Patriots game. Winners get cash, lifetime season tickets, autographed memorabilia.
title: Chairman & CEO
employment: {'name': 'The Kraft Group', 'title': 'Chairman & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Morocco native attended Clark University, then New York Law School. Clerked for bankruptcy judge in Southern District of New York. Later became co-director of bankruptcy department at Cowen & Co. With sister Sonia Gardner founded distressed-debt brokerage Amroc Investments in 1989. Launched hedge fund Avenue Capital in 1995. Sold 15% stake to Morgan Stanley for $275 million in 2006. Flagship fund fell 25% in 2008, but has since soared. Assets in December 2010: $18.3 billion.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch who cofounded Hero Group with three brothers in 1947 as a trader in bicycle parts, presided over family split last year. He and sons Pawan and Sunil got to keep biggest asset: family's 26% stake in flagship Hero Honda, India's leading motorcycle maker. After months of speculation, announced he was ending long-standing partnership with Honda Motors and buying out Honda's stake in the 27 year-old  joint venture at a 50% discount to market price. Will also drop Honda name from its motorcycles. Stock took a hit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin made the biggest part of his early fortune with a successful investment in Ping An Insurance, a big-three Chinese insurance company that is 16% owned by HSBC. Lin, who manages his businesses from Shenzhen just north of Hong Kong, has other successes in the making. Nanjing Liye Power Transformer, an unlisted power components company he purchased in 2003, is looking to apply for an IPO. Lin also owns a stake in Chinalion Securities, and has other investments in batteries, property, pharmaceuticals and mining.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief of mineral fertilizer company Uralchem. Running for Russian parliament in March elections. The Minsk native attended Minsk Suvorov Military School; in late 80s, served in Afghanistan as an interpreter. Graduated from Moscow State Institute of International Relations. Until mid-2000 worked as a manager with TNK and Sibur; deputy chairman of Russian Federal Property Fund. In 2004, founded his own company, which bought up stocks of chemical plants. Later, these assets were merged into Uralchem, which scrapped an IPO last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: The tycoon is trying to sell baseball's Houston Astros for $800 million. Paid $100 million for the club in 1992. Sold his distribution business to tennis partner Sam Walton for 10.4 million shares of Wal-Mart stock and $50 million in 1991. The deacon still teaches Sunday school. McLane Co. distribution empire is now owned by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway.

name: Billionaires
bio: The aging population keeps private hospital business Ramsay Health Care in clover and pushes its founder into the billionaire ranks. Now it's expanding into Europe with acquisitions in France and the U.K. Ramsay's stake in regional media outfit Prime Media Group falls for second straight year. Owns a Sydney soccer team and property in luxury beach town of Byron Bay.

name: Billionaires
bio: Miller co-founded Duty Free Shoppers, or DFS, with Chuck Feeney in Hong Kong in 1960.  Feeney and two other investors sold their shares to LVMH in 1996.  Miller has kept his minority stake. DFS today has more than 150 airport and downtown retail outlets worldwide. Miller today is the chairman of the Search Investment Group, a private investment concern. The company is a shareholder in Ortelius Capital Partners, an investment firm also backed by Miller's son-in-law Prince Pavlos of Greece. Miller holds a bachelor's degree in hotel administration from Cornell University, where he is a presidential councilor and trustee emeritus. He is also a trustee of the Asia Society.

name: Billionaires
bio: Commercial real estate baron. With property partner John Arrillaga, oversees just under 15 million square feet of land and office buildings in and around San Jose. Began buying California farmland and converting to office parks in the 1960s. Sold off half their portfolio beginning in 2005, including 5.3 million square feet of office and R&D space in 2006 for $1.1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began his career as a research assistant for Heine Securities in 1975; became sole owner by 1988. Considered an expert in value investing, he increased the value of his mutual funds to more than $17 billion before selling Heine Securities to Franklin Securities for $670 million in 1996. Money manager now runs MFP, whose top holdings include Citigroup and ConocoPhilips. Donated $18 million to University of Oklahoma to create the Price College of Business in 1997.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Named for the famous Italian war hero, the newly minted billionaire joins the list thanks to a 30% boost in the stock of his Adaro mining empire. He started out in coal mining in 1992 and later founded PT Wom Finance, now one of Indonesia's largest publicly listed finance groups. His Adaro Energy is the country's second largest thermal coal producer and operates the largest single coal mine, producing "envirocoal" with low carbon and sulfur content.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharma czar founded his $1.5 billion (sales) Dr Reddy's Laboratories 27 years ago, now run by son Satish and son-in-law G.V. Prasad. It bought an oral penicillin plant in the U.S. from GlaxoSmithKline, with which it has an alliance to sell generic drugs in emerging markets. Pfizer took it to court to block the sale of its generic version of Lipitor. He denies rumors that he plans to sell out to a multinational. Chairs company's charitable arm Dr Reddy's Foundation and the Naandi Foundation, a non-profit focusing on poverty eradication.

name: Billionaires
bio: Partner in Leon Black's private equity company Apollo Management. Studied at U. of Pennsylvania; stayed at Wharton for M.B.A. With Joshua Harris (also a billionaire) took job in M&A department of Drexel Burnham Lambert, joined Black to create Apollo 1990. Apollo is now moving toward its own initial public offering. Rowan sits on the boards of Harrah's Entertainment and Norwegian Cruise Lines, in which Apollo has big investments. Active with National Jewish Outreach Program, Youth Renewal Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of one of China's largest financial information companies became a billoinaire after his Shanghai Great Wisdom listed its shares on Shanghai exchange in January. Firm provides financial statistics and analysis to about 10 million users daily though PC terminals; another two million users get the stats via mobile phones, according to a report by brokerage SWS. In China, the company competes with domestic rivals such as Hexin, East Money Information, Qianlong Technology International Holdings, Beijing Compass Technology and Nasdaq-listed China Finance Online.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger brother of billionaire Sergei Sarkisov. Started his own company in 1990 after quitting his job at a Soviet company that exported commodities. Traded metals and imported construction equipment. Later joined his brother's successful insurance company, RESO-Garantiya, with oversight of the firm's largest clients. Now manages the RESO group's construction projects. French insurance company AXA owns a 36.7% stake in the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thiel cofounded PayPal in 1998, sold it to Ebay in 2002 for $1.5 billion, personally netting $60 million. Invested $500,000 in Facebook in 2004. This stake now makes up the bulk of his net worth. Opened hedge fund Clarium Capital in New York in 2005 but recently moved operations back to California reportedly because the firm was facing losses. The firm's assets, once as high as $6 billion in mid-2008, have fallen to just  $460 million (a quarter of that is Thiel's money). He's now seeking to lease his Bryant Park space. Interested in human rights, philosophy, technology. Sits on board of Palantir, a computer analysis firm for goverment agencies. Co-produced film Thank You for Smoking. Chess champion, ranked no. 7 in the U.S. under-13 bracket; was rated a master by the U.S. Chess Federation. Enjoys running, hiking, surfing.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start at the Soviet state insurance firm Ingosstrakh. Founded his own insurer, RESO-Garantiya, in 1991; today serves as chairman of the board. Sold a 37% stake to French insurance giant AXA in 2007 for $1.2 billion, a record sum for a Russian insurer. He and his brother Nikolai, also a billionaire, are still its largest investors. Fond of auto racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile daughter of Brazilian banker Amador Aguiar, the founder of Banco Bradesco, one of Brazil's largest banks. Amador's death in 1991 sparked more than a decade of court fights between his widow and daughters over inheritance. His widow, 40 years his junior, married him less than 4 months before he died. During ugly public court fights widow reportedly demanded her husband's body be exhumed for DNA test to prove paternity. Daughters prevailed in court.  Majority of Amador's fortune was left to the philanthropic Bradesco Foundation to benefit education in Brazil, founded by Amador in 1956.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped off last year's list, after shares in Gulf Bank plummeted due to nearly $1 billion loss from derivative trades in October 2008. Brother Kutayba first replaced him as chairman, then in 2009 Ali Al-Rashaid Al-Bader took over. Comes from Kuwait's sovereign fund, which picked up a 16% stake to shore up the bank. Aggressively bulked up on provisions against bad loans, and bank finally turned a profit in the first nine months of 2010.  Alghamin remains involved in family holding Alghanim Industries, with interests in manufacturing, advertising and shipping--among others.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister-in-law Joan Tisch, controls family fortune built by their late husbands, famed investors Preston and Laurence Tisch. Duo started with small New Jersey hotel 1946. Acquired Loews Theatres 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. holding company includes diverse assortment of investments: oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk), insurance (CNA). Stock up 17% over the past year. Joan's son, Jonathan, heads Loews Hotels. Wilma's son, James, is CEO of Loews. Other son, Andrew, is Co-Chairman of the Board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Succeeded his brother Bassam as chairman of Gulf Bank in 2008 in the wake of huge losses at Gulf Bank, but then ceded his position to non-family member Ali Al-Rashaid Al-Bader in 2009. Al-Bader comes from Kuwait's sovereign fund, which took a 16% stake to bail-out the bank. Shares are up, putting Kutayba back on the list. Son Omar now sits on the board. A Harvard MBA, he is also CEO of family conglomerate Alghanim Industries. Prior to that, worked in investment banking at Morgan Stanley in London on big pharma deals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Consumer goods tycoon controls $6 billion (market cap) Hypermarcas SA, which manufactures and sells largest portfolio of consumer brands in Brazil. Operates in areas of food, drugs, cleaning, beauty and personal hygiene products. Now also invested in media: In December bought 30% stake in Universo Online S.A., Brazil-based online media portal and Internet company, for BRL350 million ($208 million). Founded Arisco, a cleaning product business, with father in 1969 and was its director, president for more than 20 years. Arisco became the biggest in Brazil's food sector and was sold to Bestfoods for $760 million in 2000. In 2002 created Hypermarcas after buying steel wool companies throughout Brazil. Owns three boats, an extensive art collection by Brazilian artists and reportedly replaced old Citation X jet with brand new Falcon 2000 he bought for $33 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: An is a member of a growing flock of Chinese entrepreneurs succeeding  in the pharmaceutical industry. He chairs Hualan Biological Engineering, a producer of blood products and vaccines including the world's first vaccine for the H1N1 flu virus. The company was founded in 1992 and became the first Chinese blood product manufacturer to be granted GMP certification ("Good Manufacturing Process," a quality measure required by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration). Hualan's shares, traded on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, have risen 11% in the past year. An worked in government health offices before starting up his own company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began buying up tracts of California farmland and converting them into office parks in the 1960s. Now, with property partner Richard Peery, oversees just under 15 million square feet of land and office buildings in and around San Jose. The partners sold off half their portfolio beginning in 2005, including 5.3 million square feet of office and R&D space in 2006 for $1.1 billion. Stanford University alum; donated $100 million to the school in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of a group of homegrown Chinese entrepreneurs that are making a mark in the sportswear market. Chen chairs sports footwear and apparel supplier China Dongxiang (Group), whose goods are sold under the Kappa brand in China. The company took a step beyond China in 2008 when it bought Phenix Co., which owned the Kappa and Phenix brands in Japan. From 1991 to 2005 , Chen rose through the ranks at Chinese rival Li Ning to become CEO. He holds an executive MBA from Lincoln University in Pennsylvania.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and former chairman of Astroc Mediterraneo S.A. Made his debut as a billionaire in 2007 worth $7.7 billion. Lost $6.4 billion within a year amid rumors of inflated earnings and a cooling property market in Spain. Now holds under 3% of the company, renamed Quabit Inmobiliaria S.A.. Is reinventing himself in Latin America, notably Brazil. Held 30% of Agre Empreendimentos Imobiliarios S.A., a  Brazilian real estate group which merged last May with realtor PDG Realty, one of Brazil's largest builders. Now holds 6% of PDG and is the major individual investor in the company. Runs a private foundation that promotes Spain's cultural heritage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ron Baron runs Baron Capital, which manages $18.5 billion in private accounts and 9 mutual funds. Inside his office in the GM building, has Babe Ruth's Yankees contract, John F. Kennedy's rocking chair and letter from Albert Einstein. Hosts popular annual investors conference at the Metropolitan Opera House that have in the past featured performances by Elton John, Jerry Seinfeld and Jon Bon Jovi. Baron paid $103 million for 40-acre Hamptons estate in 2007. He also has a home in Vail and an extensive modern art collection. Baron's parents wanted him to become a doctor; he got his start as a biochemistry teaching fellow and then as a patent examiner in U.S. patent office, while attending George Washington law school. He became securities analyst in 1970 and started his own firm in 1982.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beekeeper's son from small North Island town now heads Legatum, an investment firm, venture fund and think tank. Made first fortune when he and brother Richard, also a billionaire, invested proceeds from selling parents' department store in Hong Kong real estate. Together founded investment firm Sovereign Global in Monaco, focusing on transitioning industries in Russia, Latin America and eastern Europe. Brothers amicably split to go solo in 2006. Based in Dubai, Legatum continues investment approach of predecessor with special emphasis on socially sustainable enterprises, such as microfinance; owns a majority stake in Share Microfinance, one of the largest microfinance lenders in India. At one point his investments in India were estimated to be worth $4 billion; In 2009 was reported to be dumping investments there. Founded Legatum Center for Development & Entrepreneurship at MIT, which sponsors students from developing countries who aspire to launch businesses back home.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of Israeli conglomerate Federmann Enterprises, started by late father and uncle. Chairs boards of its two biggest publicly traded holdings: defense elctronics maker Elbit Systems and luxury hotel operator Dan Hotels Corp. The hotel group has been enjoying growth thanks to booming tourism and business in the country. It began as a boarding house on the Tel Aviv seafront; now expanding into India. Also deputy chairman of the board of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem and a board member of Weizmann Institute of Science.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cook cofounded Intuit in 1983 and took it public a decade later. Quicken software idea grew from wife's complaints about balancing checkbook. Products now include QuickBooks, Quicken Health Expense Tracker and TurboTax. Stepped down as chief exec in 1994 but still a board member and holds 6% stake in the company. Intuit purchased web-based personal finance company Mint.com in 2009 for $170 million. Total sales are $3.5 billion. Intuit Tax Freedom Project has donated over 20 million returns to low income taxpayers since its 1998 inception. While studying math and economics at USC, he transformed university's bankrupt ski club into largest campus organization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive money man behind Nolan Ryan's winning bid for Texas Rangers in 2010 saw his team shock baseball by making it to the World Series last fall. Retired chief executive of publicly traded pipeline company Energy Transfer Partners. Teamed with Kelcy Warren to form gas pipeline company Cornerstone 1993. Bought small pipelines, consolidated holding into efficient network. Flipped to El Paso in 1999, duo then formed Energy Transfer. Stepped down as co-chief executive in 2007, sold $600 million worth of stock. Still owns nearly 19 million shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Eczacibasi Holding, prominent Turkish industrial group with investments in pharmaceuticals, consumer products, building materials and financial services; 2009 revenues hit $3.8 billion. Partners include world giants such as Baxter, Beiersdorf and Georgia-Pacific. Along with wife, Oya, Bulent was a major benefactor of Istanbul Museum of Modern Art. Chairs the board of trustees of the Istanbul Modern Art Foundation and the Istanbul Foundation for Culture and Arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Returns to billionaires' list after dropping off in 2009; back on due to increased value of his shares in hotel chain Sol Melia. Opened his first hotel, the Altair Hotel, over 50 years ago at the age of 21 in Palma de Majorca. His Sol Melia group now has $1.6 billion in sales and over 300 hotels and resorts in 30 countries. They are one of the world's largest hotel chains and the largest in Spain. Escarrer still runs the show with help from his two sons. Has received numerous awards in his career such as Tourism Personality of the Century and Corporate Hotelier of the World and is a major figure in the development of the Spanish hotel industry. Avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yahoo cofounder is highly regarded engineer. Has sold only a small percent of his Yahoo stock over the years. Recent stock sales said to be for charity. Michigan native moved to Louisiana as a child, B.S. degree in computer engineering from Tulane University and an M.S. degree in electrical engineering from Stanford University. Met Yahoo cofounder (and fellow billionaire) Jerry Yang as Stanford grad student.  Yahoo went public in 1996.  Filo donated $30 million to alma mater Tulane University. His Adidas sneakers are a company totem; he donated a signature pair at an eco-friendly Yahoo swap meet last year.
title: Chief Yahoo (director)

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald (d. 2009) and Doris founded Gap as a San Francisco jeans and music store in 1969. Has controlled company with brothers Robert and William since 2004. Now more than 3,000 locations; expanded empire includes Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986) and Old Navy (1994). Doris owns large contemporary art collection, featuring pieces by Andy Warhol, Chuck Close, Richard Serra and Alexander Calder. Owns minority stake in Oakland A's baseball team.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Sinovel Wind Group, a Chinese maker of wind turbines and the country's first wind power billionaire following an IPO on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in January. The listing also generated a second billionaire: investor Wei Wenyuan, who holds 10.4% of Sinovel. He is a former top executive at the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Sinovel signed a strategic alliance with the state-run China Development Bank last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas farmer's son bought his first bank for $1.2 million in 1975, later sold it for $80 million. Turned around California's struggling Golden State Bancorp and, with fellow billionaire Ron Perelman, sold it to Citigroup in 2002 for $6 billion in stock. Survived the Citigroup meltdown in 2008 by hedging his shares with options. Ford has homes in the Hamptons, Dallas, Manhattan and Beverly Hills, as well as a working ranch in New Mexico and thoroughbred farm in Kentucky.
title: Managing Member
employment: {'name': 'Ford Financial Fund', 'title': 'Managing Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs correspondence education and publishing company, Benesse, which also owns Berlitz language schools worldwide. Benefiting from enrollment spike in English conversation schools in Japan. Founder and chairman of electric-vehicle startup SIM-Drive; espouses efficiency of electric vehicles and benefit to future generations. Owns Benesse Art Site, an art world amusement park located on a group of islands off the coast in western Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Austrian national, a former skiing champ, has made his fortune in France. He worked in packaging before investing in French cosmetics firm L'Occitane in 1994. By 1996, he was the majority shareholder, having ousted a venture capital company. Since then, L'Occitane - known for its natural, Provence-made creams and perfumes - has grown from three shops to an international empire of 1,500 outlets. One of its shea butter products is sold somewhere in the world every 10 seconds.Today, Geiger spends much of his time in Asia, where L'Occitane now does about 50% of its sales. He took the company public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2010; its market cap now hovers around $4 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners, Israeli-American investor sold hedge fund GLG Partners to UK-based Man Group for $1.6 billion in October, creating one of the world's largest hedge funds, managing a combined $68 billion in assets. Gottesman's wealth comes from about $300 million in Man shares from the sale, taking GLG public in 2007 and an extensive art collection (frequent buyer of Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon and Lucian Freud). The Columbia grad and trustee cofounded GLG in 1995 with investment from Lehman Brothers. He remains CEO, charged with helping Man grow its U.S. market. Divorced, dates actress Lucy Liu.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'TOMS Capital', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest shareholder in SDS-holding, a coal mining, railway transportation and machine building concern. In 1980s worked as the head of Novokuznetsk railways division responsible for civil facilities; forged ties with head of Novokuznetsk railways division Aman Tuleev, who is now governor of Kemerovo region where SDS-holding is based. In 2007 Gridin was appointed State Duma deputy from Yedinaya Rossiya party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former hippie Hayne has made a fortune creating trendy brands for young urban customers. He opened his first store, apparently called The Free People, in 1970 near U. of Pennsylvania selling clothes to college kids and cash-poor urbanites. Today lords over 341 stores operating under three brands in addition to flagship Urban Outfitters: Anthropologie, Free People (run by second wife Margaret) and Terrain Garden Center. Also runs wholesale apparel line Leifsdottir. Sales up an average 19% annually over the past five years to $1.9 billion. Hayne has sold approximately $160 million of shares since Sept. 2008. Donated $10,000 to Meg Whitman's campaign for governor.
title: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Urban Outfitters Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'salary': 1.0, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: A star in London's hedge fund world, he saw his fortune soar last year. Trained as an engineer, he served in the Australian army and started his Convertible & Quantitative Strategies (CQS) hedge fund in London in 1999 after stints at Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston. Now a well-known philanthropist, he's given millions to the University of Sydney and is also one of the biggest donors to the U.K.'s Conservative party. Collects rural properties in Australia. Funds restoration of Michelangelo's frescoes at Vatican's Pauline Chapel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded J.B. Hunt Transport Services with late husband Johnnie in 1969; now one of the largest transport companies in U.S. with over 12,000 trucks, trailers. Sold a quarter of her stock for about $250 million last May. Latest projects: a real estate venture in Arkansas and a rock quarry in Honduras.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nine straight playoff appearances helped push the value of his Indianapolis Colts football team to $1 billion. Colts lost Super Bowl in 2010 to New Orleans Saints; won in 2007 against Chicago Bears. Music fan and collector owns guitars of Jerry Garcia, George Harrison and Elvis Presley; letters from George Washington and Abraham Lincoln. Paid $2.4 million for the original manuscript of Jack Kerouac's "On the Road" in 2001. "I think my destiny was to be that wizard behind the curtain more than anything. I think I have a pretty good idea of how to show people how to have a good time and let them experience things."
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of GoerTek, a supplier of acoustic and audio-related consumer electronics headquartered in Shandong Province's city of Weifang founded in 2001. Supplier to Microsoft and Apple, according to Chinese brokerage reports.  Sales of $406 million in 2010 more than doubled those of a year earlier. Jiang holds a MBA from Tsinghua University.  GoerTek went public in 2008, listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads real estate firm Tashir Group which owns 15 shopping centers, seven office centers and seven hotels. Managed to navigate the 2008 crisis with prudent investments, even managing to strike deals on several projects. Born in Armenia, moved to Kaluga, near Moscow, in the 90s and bought Kalugaglavsnab; sold consumer goods, construction materials, industry equipment, fuels and lubricants. This March, signed an agreement on long-term cooperation with Armenian capital city of Yerevan for large-scale investments in tourism, construction, creation of green zones.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire is big player in generator manufacturing, natural gas distribution, installation and operation of electricity plants and electricity distribution markets in Turkey. Their Aksa Enerji Uretim subsidiary sold shares to the public in May 2010. The group run by Ali Metin Kazanci and his son, Cemil. His eldest son Mehmet Kazanci broke off from the family enterprise in 2010 and with fellow Turkish billionaire Mehmet Emin Karamehmet formed MMEKA, which bid against Aksa in recent auctions of state-owned assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Sichuan Kelun Pharmaceutical, which went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last June. Shares are 93% above the offering price.  Founded in 1996, Kelun makes antibiotics as well as traditional Chinese medicine. Liu's hobbies include photography, literature and sports.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley venture capitalist Vinod Khosla had a very good 2010. SKS, the Indian microfinance lender he backed in 2006, went public last August; his personal stake was worth a recent $90 million. Four other portfolio companies were sold since May of last year. Another one, Calera, which converts CO2 emissions from coal/gas-fired plants into cement by-products and clean water, sold a stake to coal company Peabody Energy for $15 million last year. His firm raised $1.1 billion in the teeth of the recession (summer 2009), the most by a venture firm in 3 years. Indian-born engineer came to the U.S. to attend grad school at Carnegie Mellon; he made his early fortune as a cofounder of Sun Microsystems. He joined Sun investor John Doerr at venture firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers in 1996. He left in 2004 to start Khosla Ventures. His Three Dog Vineyards, named after his dogs, produces a thousand bottles of cabernet sauvignon a year. Avid skydiver, hang glider.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of LG Group, Korea's fourth largest conglomerate by assets, with more than 50 affiliates in electronics, home appliances, chemicals, telecom. In New Year's Day speech, he announced plans to spend $13 billion on research and development, improving existing production facilities and establishing new ones. Son died in an accident in 1990s. Adopted brother's son in 2004; he is expected to one day head LG Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lee founded private equity shop Thomas H. Lee 1974; paid $140 million for Snapple in 1992; 2 years later flipped to Quaker Oats for $2 billion. In 2006 started anew with Lee Equity Partners. Holds stakes in Dunkin Donuts, Warner Music. Collects Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon, Mark Rothko; sits on boards of Whitney Museum, Museum of Modern Art. His apartment is on the top three floors of an upper east side apartment building.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing is chairman of Hong Kong's biggest phone company. His Pacific Century Group paid $500 million for AIG's asset management business, Pinebridge, in March 2010; father's foundation later moved small sum to firm. Split with his girlfriend Isabella Leong, who starred in The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor. The pair have three sons, including twins born last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited hundreds of millions of dollars in stock from dad, Bob Magness (d. 1996), founder of cable television titan TCI, which merged with AT&T in 1999 in a $54 billion deal. Owns water rights in Colorado through ranch holdings; also invests in oil, gas, cattle. With wife, Sarah, produced critically acclaimed movie Precious. Next project: documentary based on young adult book series that follows indigenous Brazilian tribe. Leader of off-road truck racing team Mango Racing; travels to races, mostly in Mexico and Las Vegas. Prize money goes back to local villages in Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mitchell started acquiring west Texas and Colorado oil and gas properties in 1985. Partnered with Exxon, Chevron, BP. In 2006 sold controlling stake in Riata Energy to one-time billionaire Tom Ward, co-founder of Chesapeake Energy, for $500 million. Mitchell and Ward renamed the company SandRidge and in late 2006 bought billionaire Carl Icahn's National Energy Group for $1.5 billion. Mitchell sold the rest of his shares in 2007. Now he's looking to redeploy his cash horde overseas through pipsqueak publicly traded TransAtlantic Petroleum. Has bought up acreage in oil and gas spots like Turkey, Morocco and Romania, with hopes of using his team's eye for geology and new-fangled drilling skills to unlock vast reserves. Spent 150 days in Turkey in the past year. Risk: it ain't Texas. With wife, Amy, last year donated $57 million to alma mater Oklahoma State to fund entrepreneur program; school's second-biggest giver behind T. Boone Pickens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Colorful liquor and airline baron. His United Spirits is world's second largest liquor maker, by volume. Also owns Whyte & Mackay. Partnered Heineken to make and distribute beer in India. Hired new chief executive for his money-losing Kingfisher Airlines and is recasting its mountain of debt.  Force India, his Formula One team, gaining momentum. Son Sidhartha works in the spirits business and oversees cricket team Royal Challengers Bangalore.  He recently acquired three bottles of century-old Mackinlay whiskey from New Zealand, left there by a 1907 Antartic expedition,  and took them back to Scotland in his private jet. Bought beachfront mansion in Cape Town for $8 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his Mumbai developer Oberoi Realty public last October. It has built 5 million square feet in suburban Mumbai.  Showpiece is Oberoi Garden City, an 80-acre complex of offices, apartments, mall, school and a Westin Hotel.  Upcoming signature project is on a mid-town site where it will build two towers comprising residences, offices and a hotel. Has retained Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates architects of the Shanghai World Financial Center,  Recently learnt flying and bought a single-engine, 4-seater Cirrus airplane for $1 million. Also learnt to play the guitar to entertain his kids.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cogen Technologies founder sold nation's then-largest privately held power company to Enron for $1.5 billion in cash and stock at peak of tech bubble. Says he immediately sold shares; avoided energy giant's bankruptcy in 2001. Hometown hero brought pro football back to Houston in 2002 NFL expansion. His stake in Houston Texans is worth $630 million net of debt. Horse aficionado sold Kentucky's Stonerside Stables, home of the Kentucky Derby, to Dubai's Sheik Mohammed in 2008. With wife, Janice, actively supports Houston philanthropies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wealth held steady due to aggressive investments in distressed real estate and oil pipelines. Original source: record $1.35 billion settlement between him and device giant Medtronic in 2004 after years of litigation over spinal surgery patents. Windfall freed Michelson to leave the operating room and focus on animal welfare. Started Found Animals Foundation, focuses on dogs, cats and problem of overfilled shelters. Announced $25 million Michelson Prize, for the scientist who invents the first injectable pet sterilant. Has another charity in the works that would publish free digital textbooks for low-income college students. Last summer teamed up with actor Pierce Brosnan to successfully pressure the White House to renew a moratorium on whaling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former race car driver abandoned plan to buy car maker Saturn in fall 2009. Worked for aluminum company Alcoa, purchased Philadelphia Chevy dealership. Founded Penske Corp. in 1969; distributed Detroit Diesel for GM. Today Penske Auto Group operates more than 300 car dealerships. Owns Penske Racing; team has posted more than 310 wins, including 15 Indy 500 victories.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brewmaster of Turkey created one of country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. He and fellow billionaire Kamil Yazici together control 38-year-old Anadolu Group conglomerate. Also a car guy: makes Isuzus in Turkish plants and imports Lada and Kia cars made in Russia and Korea, which are then distributed in Ukraine and Central Asia countries. Built hospital affiliated with Johns Hopkins Medical School; it opened in 2005. Ex- basketball player never misses Efes Pilsen basketball club's games. Has a 3,000-piece pen collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family firm Yildiz Holding, which he owns with his brother Murat Ulker, also a billionaire, is one of Turkey's oldest food firms; group has 68 companies with over eight divisions. It bought Godiva in 2007. Also has stakes in a half dozen other businesses in the banking, logistics and information technology sectors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned fortune building up energy conglomerate Perez Companc, which he sold to Brazilian oil giant Petrobras for $1 billion in 2002. In December 2009 stepped down from active involvement in business, gifting his entire 75% stake in food giant Molinos Rio de la Plata, a diversified maker of pasta, flour and frozen vegetables, to his seven children. Spending $15 million to build a meat-processing plant. At wife Maria Carmen's urging, launched ice cream parlor chain Munchi's.  Established the Bioparque Temaiken, a nature and wildlife preserve outside of Buenos Aires. Collects old cars; reportedly paid over $9 million for a Ferrari.

name: Billionaires
bio: Only son of Ross Perot Sr. ran Perot Systems until 2009, when family sold company to Dell for $3.9 billion. Joined Dell board and pocketed approximately $400 million in cash. Still runs real estate development firm Hillwood, which he founded in 1988; he and his father each own 50%. Sold majority stake in Dallas Mavericks to Mark Cuban a decade ago; still has 5%, and took Cuban to court over perceived mismanagement of the team and its American Airlines Center arena. In February, an arbitrator ruled in favor of majority owner Cuban. There is still one lawsuit outstanding. Served in Air Force; at age 23, became first pilot to circumnavigate the globe in a helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Budapest in the middle of WWII. Peterffy spoke no English when he emigrated from Hungary to the U.S. in 1965. Started out as a draftsman, then taught himself computer programming. Bought his own seat on the American Stock Exchange in 1977 and started Interactive Brokers in 1993. Unclear how much his personal stake is, but even the most conservative estimate ranks him on the Forbes World's Billionaires list. Avid equestrian keeps horses at his Greenwich home.

name: Billionaires
bio: This winter his Alliance Boots signed on to supply cosmetics to Carrefour, Europe's largest retailer and the second largest in the world behind Wal-Mart. The pharmacy giant bought a majority stake in German drug whole seller Anzag for $200 million last October. The former nuclear engineer turned his family's ailing Naples drug wholesaler into Alliance UniChem Group, which merged with U.K. pharmacy chain Boots Group in 2006 to form Alliance Boots. It went private in $22 billion deal in 2007 with financing from private equity firm KKR. Today Alliance Boots has more than 115,000 employees in more than 20 countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Since 2008 the oilman has spent $70 million-plus promoting his  "Pickens' Plan," an energy strategy based on natural gas and wind, calling on the U.S. to stop buying oil from hostile regimes. Wants trucks to run on natural gas-a big boon to his investment in Clean Energy (natural gas stations). Graduated from Oklahoma State with degree in geology in 1951. Started Mesa Petroleum in 1956 with $2,500. Sold to Richard Rainwater; made name with attempted takeovers of Phillips, Unocal. Now invests via energy fund BP Capital; owns water rights in Texas panhandle. Has donated $500 million to Oklahoma State athletics, academics; $500 million to medicine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Middle son of Orascom founder and billionaire Onsi Sawiris. Samih runs real estate and hotel division which owns and operates hotels in eight countries, including Egypt, Jordan, Oman, UAE and Switzerland. Hotel properties in Egypt may take a hit, as tourists flee Egypt due to unrest. In 2010 partnered with French luxury goods company LVMH to develop two resorts in Oman and Egypt under Cheval Blanc brand. Also building luxury hotels and a golf course on a former Nazi supply route in Andermatt, Switzeland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Piramal Group with interests in pharma, life sciences, glass and real estate. Sold his domestic formulations business to U.S.-based Abbott Labs for a whopping $3.7 billion last year. In a separate deal, he also sold his diagnostics business to billionaire brothers Malvinder and Shivinder Singh for $ 129 million. Now focussing on real estate: reportedly plans to build luxury villas in Oman. His wife Swati, a qualified doctor, and daughter Nandini, a Stanford MBA., are directors. Onetime horse-riding champion, he draws inspiration from the Bhagavad Gita, the sacred Hindu text

name: Billionaires
bio: In November the "No. 1 King of All Fun" sold his pharmaceutical distributor, Kinray, to Cardinal Health for $1.3 billion; Stewie Rah Rah owned 100% of the company. Now he's focusing on giving back and has set up a $100 million charity fund. NYU grad worked for dad's pharmacy; built generic drug distributor after dropping out of law school. Jet-setter no stranger to gossip pages; lines wall of Queens office with hundreds of framed photos of him posing with celebrities. Make a Wish Foundation's largest donor; last year pledged $1,000 to the charity for each home run New York Mets hit out of Citi Field.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Zhejiang Semir Garment, one of the largest apparel retail chains in China, which listed in March 2011 after billionaire rankings were published. Qiu's stores compete directly against fellow billionaire Zhou Chengjian's Metersbonwe for young shoppers. Qiu is active in industry groups in his hometown of Wenzhou, including the Wenzhou Fashion Association and Wenzhou Entrepreneur Association.  According to the company's website, Qiu's success story has been compiled in the following books: "People Creating the World," "International Talented People Library -- China Volume," "Biography of China's Contemporary Talented People," "Flying (the) Flag of the Communist Party of China" and "Backbone of the Republic."

name: Billionaires
bio: The widow of conglomerate Dogus Holding founder Ayhan Sahenk, who died of a heart attack in 2001. Dogus Holding owns Garanti Bank, one of Turkey's largest banks, as well as Porsche, Audi and Volkswagen dealerships, retail and food stores, construction companies and tourism operations. Her children Ferit and Filiz Sahenk each have separate billion-dollar fortunes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leads Cathay Fortune Corp., headquartered in the prestigious Jin Mao Tower in Shanghai's Lujiazui financial district. The company is an investor in Hong Kong-listed China Molybdenum, whose Sandaozhuang Mine contains one of the largest reserves of molybdenum and the second-largest reserves of tungsten in the world. Cathay Fortune Corp. also has branches in Beijing and New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mall owner. With brother and business partner Melvin (d. 2009), covered country with shopping malls. Today Simon Property Group is the largest publicly traded real estate investment trust in the U.S.; firm owns or has interests in 264 million square feet of leasable space at 393 properties in North America, Europe, Asia. Company's takeover bid for rival mall operator, General Growth Properties, was rebuffed last year. Sole owner of loss-making Indiana Pacers basketball team. Father of seven; third wife is a former Miss Universe.
title: Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.
employment: {'name': 'Simon Property Group', 'uri': 'companies/simon-property-group', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Rode tech bubble onto The Forbes 400 in 1999 with $9.3 billion sale of Aspect Development software firm to i2 Technologies. All-stock deal left fortune depleted 4 years later. Used remaining millions to start or acquire 9 business software and IT companies; clawed fortune back to ten-figures. Best investment: bought market-research company Information Resources 2003; former moneyloser now generates operating profit margins of 10%. Attended Indian Institute of Technology in Mumbai. Moved to U.S. 1969, earned Ph.D. in electrical engineering at Carnegie Mellon. Founded Aspect 1991. Firm made software that allowed clients to track internal spending, inventory, buying behavior. Uses little leverage to buy companies: "Financial engineering is not our game."
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Symphony Technology Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Wynn achieved billionaire status after her second divorce from billionaire casino king Steve Wynn in January (yes, they were married to each other and divorced two times). Still a director at Wynn Resorts. Elaine received more than 11 million shares as part of the settlement; those shares have surged nearly 100% since last February. Basketball fan is on the board of the Basketball Hall of Fame.
title: Board Member
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Las Vegas, LLC', 'title': 'Board Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Emperor Watch and Jewelry, one of Hong Kong's largest watch retailers; LVMH's L Capital signed agreement last August to become a strategic investor in the retailer whose shares have doubled in the past year. Yeung opened his first watch store in 1964. The watch business is part of Yeung's larger Emperor Group, which also has interests in film, hotels, music, restaurants. Hong Kong-born Yeung traces his roots to Chaozhou in Guangdong Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Disciple of famed investor Benjamin Graham founded Brandes Investment Partners in 1974. Today the firm manages $47.8 billion, down from $120 billion in March 2007. Stickler for due diligence, Brandes believes in painstaking financial analysis to find high-intrinsic-value companies at low stock prices. Enjoys studying and understanding worldwide economic growth and lack thereof. Paid Elton John to perform at wedding to wife, Tanya, in 2006. Chairman of Salk Institute for Biological Studies. Plays soccer and tennis in spare time; rides horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime pharmacist sold family pharmaceutical business 1985; invested proceeds in several industries, from banking to textiles. Accumulated 10% stake of construction giant Sacyr Vallehermoso, of which he is a vice president. Often appears in tabloids alongside well-known politicians and members of Spanish artistic and cultural circles. Known for his valuable art collection which includes works by Edgar Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Salvador Dali and Van Gogh, among others. Enthusiastic hunter; enjoys bullfights, soccer

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Home Depot; stock up 18% since last year. Got his start with partner Bernie Marcus in 1978; handed out dollar bills in parking lot to lure first customers. Hardware giant went public 3 years later. Founded The Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation in 1995; has granted over $250 million to various charitable organizations. Retired in 2001; has been in talks with Jon Bon Jovi about selling the singer a minority stake his pro football team Altanta Falcons.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Huge conglomerate Al Futtaim Group operates Ikea, Toys "R" Us and Marks & Spencer franchises; sells Toyota, Jeep, Dodge and Lexus, and co-owns the Middle East's largest privately-funded urban community, Dubai Festival City. Turmoil in Egypt could delay plans to open residential/commercial complex Cairo Festival City early next year. Al Futtaim hired former head of Best Buy International Robert Willett this past June to run the sprawling group, but Willett abruptly resigned after only six months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of United Laboratories, a Hong Kong-based pharmaceutical manufacturer with factories in China. Thai-born Choy's family roots trace back to Jieyang in Guangdong Province. Founded United Laboratories Limited in Hong Kong in 1990.  United said in January that China's State Food and Drug Administration had approved three insulin products for sale in the country, bringing the total number of United products that can be sold in the mainland to five. Choy is active socially as a member of the Guangdong Political Consultative Conference, the All-China Federation of Returned Overseas Chinese, and the China Overseas Friendship Association. He is also the honorary president of the Shenyang Medical University and Wuhan Tongji Pharmaceutical University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile former banker derives chunk of his fortune from 2000 sale of Banco Bozano, Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano. In 2006 reportedly sold stakes in coffee plantation and Rio de Janeiro shopping center to new Brazilian investment fund. Owns a 10% stake in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer, the world's third-largest maker of airplanes. Bozano has invested in Azul, the new discount Brazilian airline launched by JetBlue founder and former chief executive David Neeleman. Devout thoroughbred horse owner reportedly has 300 mares at several farms around the world. Has a home in Greenwich, Conn.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Brown joined Stryker as chief executive after founder's son, Lee, died in plane crash in 1976.  Spent 32 years as president and chief executive, transforming it from a $17 million hospital bed maker into one of the world's leading medical technology companies with $6.7 billion in 2009 sales; company makes joint replacements, software, surgical cameras.  Retired as chairman in December 2009; is now chairman emeritus. Runs four miles a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Expanding his conglomerate, Calik Holding, in energy, mining and real estate. Acquired electricity distribution company; investments planned in wind, solar, hydro and thermal power plants in Turkey, Central Asia, Middle East and Balkans. Looking to bring in Russia's Rosneft and Transneft to construct Trans-Anatolia pipeline. Building property portfolio in Istanbul. Media assets,Sabah and ATV  lifted by strong advertising market; publishes Forbes Turkey, under license from Forbes Media LLC. Textile entrepreneur owns Gap Guneydogu Tekstil, one of the world's top 10 denim producers, which sells products to Diesel, Levi's, Gap and other Western brands. May take the group company public over next two years.

name: Billionaires
bio: AOL founder was appointed by President Barack Obama to lead Startup America Partnership with mission of inspiring innovation and entrepreneurship. Case made biggest bet in tech boom, merging with Time Warner in 2000; resigned as chairman 2003. Created Case Foundation with wife, Jean, in 1997 to invest in "citizen-centered" philanthropy and encourage civic engagement on community issues. Some pet ventures: social commerce outfit and Groupon rival, LivingSocial; car sharing service Zipcar and online wine marketplace Vinfolio. Case also chairs Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure (ABC2), a nonprofit he founded with his late brother, Dan, which has an entrepreneurial approach to funding brain cancer research. The entrepreneur's mantra, according to Case: "Change the world, empower consumers." Hawaii native attended prestigious Punahou, same high school as Obama.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate investor is facing a lawsuit filed in December over $22 million mezzanine loan on NYC office tower. Son of a sewing supplies salesman inherited $34 when father passed away; paid for Brooklyn Law School by singing in synagogues. Considered career as vocalist, chose entertainment law instead. Star client: Sammy Davis Jr. Built practice by figuring out way to maximize tax benefits for oil partnerships. Jimmy Carter adviser claims to have helped broker Camp David Accords between Egypt and Israel 1978. Bought first building--One Times Square--on the night Carter lost reelection to Reagan in 1980. Borrowed, reinvested rental income into 12 surrounding buildings. Owns 3 skyscrapers in Times Square, 1.5 million square feet of commercial space.

name: Billionaires
bio: Big U. of Maryland supporter owns millions of square feet of office space; 15,000 residential units in Washington, D.C. area. Heavy construction helps keeps fortune afloat; his Clark Enterprises builds museums, prisons, university buildings, stadiums. Built Camden Yards; FedEx Field, Verizon Center and Nationals Park (Washington, D.C.); Miller Park (Milwaukee); Petco Park (San Diego). Current construction projects include airports, hospitals and convention centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of power generator Inner Mongolia Junzheng Energy & Chemical Industry, which listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange this year. Sales last year totaled 2.8 billion yuan, or $431 million, an increase of 115% from 2009. Another Du-backed company, Beijing Bohui Innovation Technology, applied for an IPO in 2009 but was reportedly turned down.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first drugstore in 1969. Now the Jean Coutu Group is one of North America's largest pharmacy chains. Bought into the Eckerd brand in 2004 buying stores in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states for $2.4 billion.Two years later announced it was selling its U.S. operations, including the Eckerd and Brooks brands, to Rite Aid, in a deal worth $3.4 billion in stock and cash. Jean Coutu Group is Rite Aid's top shareholder. Coutu's son Michel is nonexecutive cochairman of the board at Rite Aid, while other son Francois is president and chief executive at the Coutu Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chairman of Italian shoemaker Tod's steps into billionaire status as the luxury fashion market continues its post recession comeback: shares up more than 65% since last February. Tod's shoes and bags are hand-made in Italy, but he gets his growth from Asia where sales surged 20% over the past year. Tod's Group also controls the Hogan and Fay fashion brands. Along with billionaire brother Andrea, he is the largest shareholder of Saks, with a 19% ownership stake in the posh U.S. department store. This January the proud Italian pledged $34 million to restore Rome's ancient Coliseum, and called for other entrepreneurs to join in. A huge fan of John F. Kennedy, he hangs a portrait of the 35th president in his office; owns The Marlin, the  52-foot yacht once owned by Joseph Kennedy and used by the president for important cabinet meetings.

name: Billionaires
bio: The multimedia mogul and his longtime rival John Malone parted ways this year, with the latter selling his firm Liberty's stake in InterActive Corp (IAC) after years of disagreements over how the company was being run. Diller stepped down as CEO as part of the deal, but his fortune got a boost despite the turmoil: IAC's stock gained 10% year on year. Big news for the brand: its Daily Beast blog merging with Newsweek magazine. Other IAC-owned entities include Match.com, Ask.com and Citysearch. This year also saw Diller bow out of his role as chair of Live Nation, the concert promoter that merged with his Ticketmaster in a $2.5 billion deal last year. He dumped most of his shares. Diller famously started out in the mailroom at the William Morris agency after dropping out of UCLA. Worked at ABC, Paramount and Fox between 1964 and 1992; oversaw the launches of hit TV shows including Cheers and The Simpsons during this time. Started IAC in 1995; bought the Home Shopping Network two years later. He is married to fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman emeritus of RPG Enterprises, a conglomerate with interests in power, tea, tyres, and software. Biggest holdings are power generation company CESC and power transmission unit KEC International. Group's Philips Carbon Black reportedly bidding for the carbon black unit of Germany's Evonok Industries. Patriarch has divided empire between his two sons Harsh and Sanjiv, but continues to run plantations company Harrisons Malayalam, which produces tea, rubber and pepper. Harsh is a collector of contemporary Indian art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded PeopleSoft, the company that would make him a billionaire, at age 47. His fourth venture, he mortgaged his house to fund it, but he says he wasn't nervous: "You kind of know when you're on to something." He sure was: PeopleSoft became the world's second-largest application software company. After 18-month takeover battle with nemesis Larry Ellison, sold out to Oracle for $10 billion in 2005. Once again fighting Oracle chief with his fifth start-up, enterprise software firm Workday. Sales were up 90% to an estimated $100 million last year. With wife, created Maddie's Fund, named for family's beloved schnauzer. Pet rescue foundation is endowed with $300 million to save shelter dogs and cats. Has paid for the adoptions of 600,000 pets since started in 1994. Duffield says he plans to leave his fortune to his animal charity, not any of his 11 children, when he dies.
title: Chairman and co-CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Chongqing Zhifei Biological Products, a supplier of vaccines that listed at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2010. The company's shares are about 10% below Zhifei's listing price, but high enough for Jiang to make this year's list. Sales revenue last year rose by 22% to $113 million. Jiang worked as a health official in Guangxi Province before becoming an entrepreneur.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares industrial and pharmaceuticals fortune with older brother and fellow billionaire Bulent. Worked in family business since 1980 except for a stint in U.S. at American Hospital Supply Co. Now vice chairman of Eczacibasi Holding. Founder and, since 1995, president of the Turkish Informatics Foundation. Also on board of Turkish Technology Development Foundation. Big on jazz music, plays bongo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beijing-based investor targets under-performing state-owned listed companies for restructuring. Fang took control of a third listed company, Fangda Jinhua Chemical Technology, in 2010 after he successfully reorganized Fangda Special Steel Technology, a Shanghai-listed supplier of steel to the auto industry. Fangda Group now has more than 30,000 employees across more than 10 provinces in China. Also invests in minerals.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Bharat Forge, among world's leading forgings makers, turned around after taking its lumps when the global auto industry skidded.  Expanded into non-auto forgings in the energy, transportation and capital goods sectors.  Has new venture to make a hybrid auto engine with KPIT Cummins. His BF Utilities is building an expressway in South India. Group recently listed its investments firms. Passionate about motorbikes.  Son Amit in charge of finance, strategy and the infrastructure business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Consumer lender Promise, which he founded, facing industry chill: regulations in June set interest rate ceiling at 20% and limited the amount individuals could borrow. Closed half its branches in 2010. Rival lender Takefuji filed for bankruptcy protection in September 2010. Promise profits plunged 34% for the nine months ending in December.
