Japanese bank Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group owns a 20% stake in the lender and has stated it will inject capital to support the company. Retired in 2001, Jinnai now grows mangoes and bananas in greenhouses on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido, known for its frigid winters.

name: Billionaires
bio: After marrying daughter of salsa maker David Pace, Goldsbury worked his way up from the production line and became president in 1977. With his wife, bought out the rest of the family then bought her half for $95 million after 1991 divorce. Sold the company in 1996 to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion. Now runs private equity firm Silver Ventures; has stakes in Desert Glory, MarketFare Foods, Shadewell Grove Foods. Sold artisan bread maker Ecce Panis to Campbell in 2009 for a reported $65 million. Also developed 22-acre Pearl Brewery complex in San Antonio, which includes restaurants, shopping, condos and a culinary school. Recently purchased about 5 acres of land nearby, reportedly to expand the village.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Silver Ventures', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Alexander Vagin, controls Raspadskaya coal mine; last May held accountable for mining accident which killed 66. Kozovoy's entire career is connected to the coal industry. Started working at Raspadskaya coal mine in 1978; in 1991 he was appointed acting chairman of supervisory board of Raspadskaya: it was turned into a joint-stock company by its staff, among the first in the country. Soon he became its CEO and later with Vagin consolidated shares. May buy Roman Abramovich and Alexander Abramov 40% stake in the coal miner if put on the block.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Beijing-based Century Golden Resources Group, which has interests in real estate, including six shopping malls and 16 five-star hotels. Huang also invests in minerals. Initial entry in the financial industry through a minority stake in Bank of Beijing was augmented last year by an 8% stake in China Securities that cost $199 million. Regularly appears near the top of philanthropy lists in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Berlin, Jarislowsky moved to Canada in 1949 after earning his M.B.A. at Harvard. Six years later founded Jarislowsky Fraser, investment company that today manages $44 billion for institutions and individuals. Convinced there's a housing bubble "waiting to burst" in Canada. In addition to eclectic art collection that includes jade, Chinese furniture and Eskimo artifacts, owns private island in British Columbia with 16 miles of shoreline. Holds degree in fine art from University of Chicago. Moonlights as professor of investment analysis at the likes of Queens University, McGill University and University of Victoria, B.C.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of Kazakhstan's President Nursultan Nazarbaev; mentioned in recently revealed diplomatic cables as main operator of Kazakh economy. Owns large stake in Halyk, Kazakhstan's second-largest lender by assets (wife Dinara Kulibaeva, has a separate billion dollar fortune and also owns shares). Deputy CEO of country's sovereign wealth fund, Samruk-Kazyna. Also chairs national oil and gas company KazMunaiGas, national railway company Kazakhstan TemirZholy. Will benefit if upcoming referendum allows Nazarbaev to remain in power another twenty years. Under investigation by Swiss authorities for alleged money laundering; denies the allegations, calling them politically motivated.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second daughter of Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbaev will benefit if upcoming referendum allows Nazarbaev to remain in power another twenty years. With husband Timur Kulibaev, shares stake in Kazakhstan's second largest lender by assets, Halyk Bank. Executive director of education foundation named after her father.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moscow-born banker emigrated to America with parents in 1976; became U.S. citizen. Studied at Carnegie Mellon, M.B.A. from Harvard. Returned to Russia in mid-1990s, headed Credit Suisse First Boston's Moscow operation. Became chief of Alfa Bank, Russia's largest private commercial bank. Now director of Pamplona Capital Management; British private equity firm helps Russian businesses invest overseas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of China Shineway Pharmaceutical Group, one of the country's largest manufacturers of China medicine. Sales at the Hong Kong-listed company in the first nine months of 2010 rose by 26% from a year earlier to $216 million. Increased business has helped to push up Hong Kong-trade Shineway's shares by 23% in the past year.  Li holds an EMBA degree from the Yangtze Commercial Institute. Company is based in Shijiazhuang of Hebei Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and founder of Jointown Pharmaceutical, a drug wholesaler and distributor. The company is one of more than a dozen controlled by members of this year's list to go public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in the past year. Jointown has benefitted from growth in spending on healthcare in China. Anticipating more business in the future, it is setting up distribution centers in Anhui, Guangxi, Heilongjiang, Tianjin, and Zhejiang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Qi's Hangzhou Binjiang Real Estate Group is one of the most successful property developers in what many consider to be one of China's most scenic cities. Hangzhou was a favorite of Marco Polo when he visited China centuries ago. Today, travelers flock to the city for views of its famous West Lake.  Binjiang's sales in 2010 rose 119% from a year earlier to $956 million. The company's share price has dropped 18% in the last year, pulling down Qi's wealth amid a Chinese government effort to put the brakes on real estate prices and inflation in the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment banker Langone made his mark taking Ross Perot's Electronic Data Systems public in 1968. Made millions raising capital to start Home Depot in1978; still has a large stake in the retailer, whose stock is up 15% in the last 12 months. Has been on its board for 30 years. Langone was chair of the New York Stock Exchange's compensation committee from 1999 to 2003; was thrust into limelight when he was forced to testify in lawsuit over $187 million pay package awarded to former NYSE chief Richard Grasso. Has been married to his wife for 54 years. Graduate of the MBA part-time program at NYU, a program which now bears his name.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former owner of Minnesota Vikings, Billy Joe "Red" McCombs dropped out of law school to sell cars. He owned his first dealership by age 25 and eventually established a string of car lots across Texas before cofounding radio empire Clear Channel Communications with Lowry Mays in 1972. Reaped big payday in 2008 when Clear Channel went private in $26 billion deal with private equity outfits Thomas H. Lee and Bain Capital. Received $36 per share in the deal; netted $200 million. Other holdings include oil, real estate, more car dealerships. Enjoys ranching, rooting for Longhorns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Reinhard Straumann, who founded alloy research institute in 1954. Reinhard invented metals for use in watch components. Thomas' father Fritz led push into dental implants. Opened offices in United States 1989. Public 1998. Thomas retired as chairman of Straumann Holding 2002; still sits on board. Also owns luxury hotels in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mechanical enegineer, started his career at carmaker Astra International in 1969. Now involved in Adaro Energy, Indonesia's largest coal producer, with cousin Edwin Soeryadjaya, also a billionaire.  Is Adaro's vice president commissioner and president commissioner at Adira Finance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited stake in family's Sainsbury's, one of the U.K.'s largest grocers; in recent years group has expanded into insurance, banking and travel businesses. Sales rose 5% year on year, and the chain's UK market share is now at just over 16%. Now looking to expand overseas, with a move to China reportedly being considered. Stepped down from management in 1998 to enter politics; spent 8 years as Minister for Science & Innovation but resigned in 2006. Has been a loyal Labour donor, giving over £12 million since 2000, but has broken with the party recent months: he supported David Miliband to take over as leader, but Miliband's brother Ed won the vote, prompting pundits to question whether he'll keep donating.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Shagang Group, whose sales climbed 22% to $27 billion last year even though China's steel industry had a tough year. Shagang, which employs 40,000, is reportedly looking to increase its competitiveness even further with plans to invest $4.6 billion in a steel logistics project. Shagang Group holds 75% of Shenzhen-listed Gaoxin Zhangtong after it injected its 64% stake of Huaigang Special Steel, worth about $323 million, into the company in December.  Helping to fund new investments, Shagang Group obtained a $3 billion credit line with Bank of China last November. Shen, a former steelworker, is vice chairman of the China Iron Ore and Steel Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine, a pharmaceuticals producer whose history traces back to the days of China's Cultural Revolution in 1970. It went public in 2000 on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, and has expanded into the U.S. through a wholly-owned subsidiary Hengrui USA in New Jersey. Sun graduated from China Pharmaceutical University with a bachelor's degree in chemistry in 1982. He calls Lianyungang in Jiangsu Province home.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Gennady Kozovoy, controls Raspadskaya coal mine; last May held accountable for mining accident which killed 66. Graduated from Kuzbass polytechnic institute and went to work at Raspadskaya. It was turned into a joint-stock company by its staff, among the first in the country; consolidated shares with Kozovoy, took public. Now responsible for corporate governance. May buy Roman Abramovich and Alexander Abramov 40% stake in the coal miner if put on the block.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Turkey's largest construction company, Enka.  In 1985 took reins from his father Sarik Tara, also a billionaire and the company co-founder. Using family foundation funds to start Enka Schools, one in Istanbul and the other in Adapazarý; 2,000 students are enrolled. Known for his modest character, his office has bare white walls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs privately held Summit Property Development of Shanghai. Entrepreneur entered the Shanghai real estate business in 1992; today is one of the city's most prominent developers with interests in residential, apartment, hotel, office and shopping mall properties. Partners include CapitaLand of Singapore, with which it is currently embarking on a second mall in Shanghai, Hongkou Plaza, in the city's Hongkou district. According to Hongkou Plaza's website, Summit has developed 800,000 square meters of commercial properties in downtown Shanghai. In addition, Summit has more than 6 million square meters of commercial properties in the pipeline, including more than 1.1 million in Shanghai and 5.4 million in Shenyang. The company employs 5,000 people.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulk of fortune comes from ownership stake in publicly traded BIM, a chain of discount supermarkets with operations in Turkey and Morocco. To keep prices low, BIM limits the number of items in its stores to around 600 and sells a large number of private label products. Topbas also has investments in the textile industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech tycoon Tsai has made his fortune as leader of Mediatek, one of the world's largest semiconductor design houses. Tsai's wealth is down from a year earlier after a business slump hit Mediatek's shares. The company said in January that sales dropped by 22% in the fourth quarter of 2010 from a year earlier. It blamed lower prices and the appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar. Works with Microsoft on smartphone technology. Tsai holds bachelor's and master's degrees in electric engineering from National Taiwan University and University of Cincinnati respectively.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger in 1985. Sold 80% of company to a British investor group for $800 million in 2002. Sold rest to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in July 2004 for estimated $360 million. Now retired.

name: Billionaires
bio: His former Dutch TV production company, Endemol, launched reality-show craze with the creation of programs like Big Brother and Fear Factor. Made fortune when  Endemol was sold to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. Then focused on theater, a passion he's had since childhood (at age 6 Van den Ende put on  puppet shows for neighborhood children in his hometown). Owner and founder of Stage Entertainment,  a musical theater company and Endemol spin off that produces blockbuster musicals like The Lion King and Mamma Mia. Its U.S. division has won 46 Tony Awards.  Stepped down in September 2008 as chairman, now president of the supervisory board.  Humble beginnings; started career as party-supply salesman. Was awarded the cross of Honor of the House of Orange in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mapped coal deposits as Queensland government geologist and then started his own company, QCoal. Made his fortune getting and then selling licenses at increasing prices, first to Australia's Macarthur Coal, then to a U.S. company, then to a Japanese consortium. That last deal raised $560 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and CEO of Hong Kong-listed Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding, one of China's fastest-growing beverage companies and a leader in Chinese-flavored instant noodles. Wei hails from Taiwan but has made his fortune in the mainland, where Tingyi's "Master Kong" brand is one of the best-known and easily recognizable by its chubby chef logo.  He is one of four brothers to derive most of his fortune from Tingyi, along with Ying-Chiao, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng. Ing-Chou is the oldest brother. Tingyi's roots go back to 1958, when the father started an industrial oil business. Sanyo Foods of Japan acquired one third of Tingyi in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the four Wei brothers to obtain most of his fortune from Hong Kong-listed Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding, one of China's fastest-growing beverage companies and a leader in Chinese-flavored instant noodles. Yin-Chun is the third eldest of the four, and is chairman of Wei-Chuan Foods, a Taiwan beverage company acquired by the family in 1998. Tingyi's roots go back to 1958, when the father started an industrial oil business.  Sanyo Foods of Japan acquired one third of Tingyi in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of HEC Group, a manufacturer of aluminum products such as foil, tools and measuring instruments. HEC is the largest shareholder in Shanghai-listed Guangdong Dongyangguang Aluminum. Benefitting from a rebound in the global electronics market in 2010, Dongyanguang says net profit soared by as much as 280% from 2009's $11 million. HEC also invests in pharmaceuticals, and now is one of the world's largest producers of macrolide antibiotics. Zhang was reportedly born in Dongyang in Zhejiang Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of  the four Wei brothers to obtain most of his fortune from Hong Kong-listed Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding, one of China's fastest-growing beverage companies and also a leader in Chinese-flavored instant noodles. The youngest of the four, Yin-Heng is leading the family's retail expansion in China. Investments by Ting Hsin International, the family's main holding company, include:  Family Mart of Japan's  Shanghai operation, Dicos, a fast-food chain with 1,000 stores in China that serves up chicken steak burgers and plenty of other greasy food, and a newer chain, "Master Kong Chef's table," which focuses on noodles. Tingyi's roots go back to 1958, when the father started an industrial oil business. Sanyo Foods of Japan acquired one third of Tingyi in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Executive director of Hong Kong-listed Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding, one of China's fastest-growing beverage companies and also a leader in Chinese-flavored instant noodles.  He is one of four brothers to obtain most of their fortune from Tingyi, along with Ing-Chou, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng.  Ying-Chiao is the second oldest brother, and oversees the family's growing interests in real estate. The family in 2009 became the largest-non-government investor in Taipei 101, one of the world's tallest structures, and has been successfully helping to bring mainland businesses looking to expand in Taiwan in as new tenants. Tingyi's roots go back to 1958, when the father started an industrial oil business. Wei and his brothers set up Ting Hsin International. Sanyo Foods of Japan in 1999 acquired one third of Tingyi, which has partnered with Asahi of Japan in China since 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former eBay chief  may have dug $144 million deep into her pocket book for her failed run at the California governor's seat in November, but her finances--and ranking--are up thanks to her remaining eBay stock's performance.  In addition to her personal coffers Whitman raised $30 million from supporters including ex-Yahoo CEO Jerry Yang in what was the costliest state-level campaign in U.S. history. Since losing to Democrat rival Jerry Brown by 13 points Whitman has jumped back into the private sector. Days after his swearing in, Whitman was named to the board of directors of HP and in February rejoined Procter & Gamble's board where she served from 2003 to 2008 before taking time off for her political foray. Still hoping to hold onto her fortune, Whitman turned down Warren Buffett's invitation last year to join the Giving Pledge, in which billionaires agree to donate half their money to charity in life or death.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: The Chief Yahoo is still on the board of the company, yet divides his time between several other boards. While Yahoo hasn't been wowing the technorati in Silicon Valley, stock is up 11% from a year ago and company still commands an impressive reach online. Yang hired Carol Bartz to run Yahoo in late 2008, and seems content to see fruition of her plans to make Yahoo a tech-driven content company (including farming most of the search business to Microsoft). Born in Taiwan, moved to the US at 10. Created his Web directory in 1994 with business partner (and now fellow billionaire) David Filo when both were Stanford grad students. Duo left Ph.D. program 1995 to form fast-growing Web portal. Yahoo went public a year later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-husband of billionaire heiress Esther Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Cortina, who married Esther's sister Alicia, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages fell apart in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. Sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004. Cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Alcocer reportedly enjoys hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Super low profile tycoon has two seaside residences by the Bosphorus, one in Kanlica and the other in Yenikoy. Also has an automobile collection of 80 cars including a McLaren F1, Superamerica, Enzo and a $4.5 million Ferrari FFX. Source of his wealth is Habas Company, well-known producer of industrial and medical gases, heavy machinery and LNG. Predecessor firms were founded by his father.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Suzhou Gold Mantis Construction Decoration, a provider of interior building materials such as curtain walls and stone material, and a supplier of interior design services. Signed a two-year agreement with Evergrande Real Estate in November in which the Guangzhou-based developer led by fellow billionaire Hui Ka Yan will provide 3 billion yuan, or $461 million, of indoor construction contract in the first year. In January, Zhu stepped down as chairman at Gold Mantis, which listed at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2006.  Active in industry groups as vice chairman of the Jiangsu Decoration Association and vice chairman of the China Building Decoration Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns E4 Group, one of the biggest private construction subcontractors in Russia's energy sector. In October, sold his entire 25% stake in Russian road and bridge construction company Mostotrest prior to company's IPO. Started out importing food from Bulgaria in early 1990s as a student of Moscow State University. Later built controlling stake in Novosibirskenergo, the biggest of the regional energy companies which remained independent of the state monopoly. After a stint at the government owned energy concern, RAO UES, resigned in 2005 and bought several engineering and construction companies, which he combined to form his E4 Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Flamboyant Egyptian businessman, father of Dodi Al Fayed who died in a car crash along with Princess Diana in Paris in August 1997. A natural born salesman, began flogging homemade lemonade to his classmates during recess; said to have sold Pepsi in market stalls, worked as a sewing machine salesman.  Became an associate of businessman and weapons dealer Adnan Khashoggi, whose sister he eventually married. Became a British resident in 1974. Acquired House of Fraser group in mid 1980s,  including the venerable Harrod's department store, which he revitalized and refurbished. Sold it to Qatar Holding for a reported $2.4 billion in May 2010; now honorary chairman.  Owner of the Hôtel Ritz in Paris, the  Fulham football club, and a castle in Scotland.   Anglophile has yet to be granted British citizenship.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hit hard by the credit crisis, Bucksbaum's General Growth Property filed the largest real estate bankruptcy in U.S. history. It has since restructured billions in debt but neither Matthew nor his son, John, are part of the business any longer. Matthew and his brother started GGP in 1954. By 2007, GGP was the nation's second-largest REIT, owning 200 million square feet across 194 malls and planned communities in 44 states. John Bucksbaum served as CEO from 1999 to Oct. 2008. He is no longer on the board, but family still owns a chunk of the mall giant.

name: Billionaires
bio: Estranged brother of billionaire Abdulla Al Futtaim. Runs glitzy Mall of the Emirates, known for its indoor skiing, but has a string of "City Centre" malls in the UAE, as well as in Egypt. New York Times reported in January that City Centre mall in Cairo was "ravaged," with looters ripping ATM machines, and smashing skylight. Had recently announced plans to build a Mall of Egypt with indoor ski slope for a reported $750 million. Also in the works: a huge mall outside Damascus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pioneer of China's online gaming industry chairs Shanda Interactive Entertainment, one of the industry's leaders. Tough competition and changing demographics in China have made for a difficult battle for Chen and Shanda. Although revenue during the first nine months of last year increased by 9%,  net income plunged 49% by $92 million. Shanda's U.S.-listed shares have lost value in the past year. Chen holds a bachelor's degree in economics from Fudan University. He co-founded Shanda with brother Danian in 1999. Wife Qianqian Luo and Danian sit in on the board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-husband of billionaire heiress Alicia Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Alcocer, who married Alicia's sister Esther, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages fell apart in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. Sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004.  Cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Said to like boating, collecting art and hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been a tough year for Russia's richest woman. Currently under suspicion for fraud after investigators claim to have found nearly $500 million in misappropriated funds in her personal bank account. Baturina currently residing abroad, daughters have moved to the UK; meanwhile her disgraced husband, former Moscow mayor Yuri Luzhkov still in Russia. Rumored to be considering selling her construction company Inteko. Baturina started out as a factory worker, then entered the Moscow Institute of Management. Met Luzhkov in 1987 when they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal commission. In 1991 started plastic-products company Inteko, which produced furniture and crockery but then expanded into construction and construction materials.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate titan investing millions of dollars in scientific and technology ventures, including publicly-traded electric vehicle battery company Valence Technology. "My philosophy on life is if you aren't raising money there's no purpose in telling anybody anything, or all you're doing is giving your competitors information." Former vending machine repairman worked night shifts to pay his way through U. of New Mexico. Bought real estate investment trust Mission West 1997. Portfolio includes 8 million square feet across 100 properties; counts Microsoft, Apple among Silicon Valley office tenants. Inducted into 2010 Developer Hall of Fame by National Association of Industrial and Office Properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: The only one of the Big Three that didn't ask for a government bailout, Ford Motor is on a roll, racking up $6.6 billion in net profit last year, its best performance in more than a decade. Ford stock nearly doubled in the past year, helping to rebuild Bill Ford Sr.'s wealth, but the shares have been lower in recent weeks. Ford, the grandson of legendary industrialist Henry Ford, retired from the carmaker's board in 2005. His son, Bill Jr., is now executive chairman. Bill Sr. is also the longtime owner of the Detroit Lions, bought for $5 million in 1964.

name: Billionaires
bio: Che Jianxin is the CEO of Red Star Macalline, one of China's largest furniture retailers. Started out as a carpenter in Changzhou, and established a furniture workshop in 1986 that he later into a furniture company. Opened first furniture shopping mall in Nanjing in 1997. Che's chain has since expanded into 72 stores in Beijing, Shanghai, Changzhou, Tianjin, Nanjing and 53 other cities in China to date. Partly owned by Fosun International Group of Shanghai, one of China's largest non-government businesses. Fosun Media is a licensing partner of Forbes Media.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marguerite Harbert, widow of John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995), died on March 17, 2015 at age 91. Harbert met her husband in grade school and they were married for 43 years. After college, Harbert worked at the Red Cross and headed it up its safety service division. Her husband turned $6,000 in craps winnings into construction titan Harbert Corporation, which includes water systems power plants, airports and a South American pipeline. He purchased coal reserves in eastern Kentucky, Tennessee in 1960s and sold it to Amoco in a stock deal during energy crisis in 1970s. Harbert was last listed among Forbes' Billionaires ranks in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Infosys cofounder, director since 1985, debuts on list. Currently heads quality, information systems and the communications design group and chairs the Australian subsidiary.  Is also president of the  Infosys Science Foundation, which awards an annual prize for scientific research.  His family's Ashraya Hastha Trust, a non-profit that wife Asha runs, focuses on education and health.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Tod's Group vice chairman makes his billionaire debut as luxury fashion market continues its post recession comeback: shares up more than 65% since last February. Company's shoes and bags are hand-made in Italy, but it gets its growth from Asia where sales surged 20% over the past year. Brother Diego, also a new billionaire, is the group's chairman. Brothers also own 19% stake in posh U.S. department store Saks, making them the biggest shareholder ahead of the world's richest man, Carlos Slim.

name: Billionaires
bio: At urging of younger daughter, Gerry, and wife, Sandra, created Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in 1996 in homage to 1969 Woodstock festival. The $100 million outdoor performing arts center and museum in Bethel, N.Y. developed to improve economy of Sullivan County. Dropped out of high school, served in Marines in WWII. GI Bill provided training in television repair. Started cable company in Liberty, N.Y. with $1,500 in 1956. Developed into 5-channel system; sold to Time Warner in 1996, netting $900 million.

name: Billionaires
bio:
*Correction: Harris and Marc Rowan have equal stakes in Apollo Global Management and should have both been listed with net worths of $1.5 billion apiece. Harris' $1.2 billion net worth at the time of the Forbes 400 list of richest Americans was inadvertently not updated for the Billionaires' list. Forbes regrets the error. 

Harris did a stint in M&A at now defunct junk bond purveyor Drexel Burnham Lambert. Created private equity group, Apollo, with Leon Black and Marc Rowan in 1990. Apollo, which is now getting ready for its own initial public offering, has recently feasted on distressed debt. Serves on Corporate Affairs Committee at Council of Foreign Relations, director at Mount Sinai Hospital plus others.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire is chairman of Hattat Holding, with investments in the automotive, energy, tourism and construction sectors.  Produces Valtra tractors, a brand owned by US firm Agco, and sells them in Turkey. Has leased a coal field and is planning to build a power plant in Amasra, which is on Turkey's Black Sea coast, that will utilize the coal it produces. Owns a sofa and vases that once belonged to Napoleon Bonaparte.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief executive of Banamex reaped an estimated $2 billion windfall when Citigroup bought the Mexican bank in 2001. Martinez remained on the Citigroup board until 2009. Has created two foundations intended to preserve the environment and Mayan cultural heritage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hsu-led Far Eastern Group's roots go back to the mainland in 1937.  Founder T.Z. Hsu's son Douglas has turned Far Eastern, today headquartered in Taipei, to a globally minded conglomerate, with more than 180 affiliated companies with interests in transportation, mobile phones, retail and textiles, among other industries.  Hsu last Sept. was cleared by a Taiwan court of all wrongdoing in connection with a department store takeover there. He had been indicted in Taipei in 2006 for forgery and breach of trust in the case.  Far Eastern has been actively expanding in the mainland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Greater China International Investment Group, a pioneering property developer in Shenzhen just across the mainland border from Hong Kong. Best-known spots include the International Finance Center and Hilton Hotel. Huang serves as executive vice president of the United World Chinese Association and the executive vice-president of the Shenzhen Chinese Entrepreneur Association. Daughter Huang Wenxi is a graduate of the University of Wisconsin-Madison with a business degree. Family controls Hong Kong-listed Waytung Global Group, a real estate concern. Reportedly brother of fellow billionaire Huang Maoru.

name: Billionaires
bio: The self-made billionaire chairs Tibet Cheezheng Tibetan Medicine, a supplier of ointments, plasters and powders. Sales in 2010 were $80 million, up 11.6% from a year earlier. Lei's profit margins are a healthy 20%-plus. The company's shares trade at a price-earnings ratio above 50, however, and its share price is down 2% from a year earlier.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former attorney Bruce Karsh cofounded Oaktree Capital Management with Howard Marks, now also a billionaire, in 1995. With Marks, raised $1 billion when they sold 16% of their money management firm on a private Goldman Sachs exchange in May 2007. The firm was recently valued at $5.7 billion. In August, Oaktree and Marc Lasry's Avenue Capital acquired the assets of the troubled Sea Island resort.  Before Oaktree, Duke alum served as assistant to SunAmerica chairman Eli Broad until 1987. With wife donated $20 million to Duke in 2008 to support international students.
title: President
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: India's Warren Buffet, trades on his own account through investment firm Rare Enterprises. Top holdings include watchmaker Titan Industries and fellow billionaire Desh Bandhu Gupta's drugmaker Lupin. Remains bullish.  His $4 million investment in 2006 in engineering services firm A2Z Maintenance, soared more than 20-fold after company's recent IPO.  Last July, he took 250 close pals on a chartered flight to Mauritius for a week-long vacation, to celebrate his 50th birthday. His uncle Amitabh is Anil Ambani's close aide.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Sun Paper, a paper and pulp producer based in Yanzhou in Shandong Province. Listed at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2006.  Sun employs 10,000 people and exports its products to Southeast Asia and the United States. Customers include McDonald's, KFC and LG. Sun last year signed a letter of intent to set up a joint venture company with New York-listed International Paper.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Tiens Group, a direct seller of healthcare products. Founded in Tianjin in 1995, Tiens today has more than 8,000 employees in industries including bio-tech, education, retail and tourism in more than 190 countries. Tiens net profit in 2009 totaled $438 million, according to a report by the All-China Federation of Industry & Commerce. Li, a native of Cangzhou in Hebei Province, is an active philanthropist. Among his charitable donations: founded the Tiens Meijing International Charitable Foundation with approximately $100 million. Li also provided $100 million to set up Tianshi College in China, a private school in Tianjin which currently enrolls more than 3,400 students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Rahmi Koc and chairman of the board of industrial group Koc Holding since 2003. On the billionaires list for the first time. He received a B.A. in business administration from George Washington University in 1984. Into wildlife photography, which he took during an African safari. Exhibition his photos in June 2010. Brothers Mehmet Omer and Yildirim Ali Koc, aunts Suna Kirac and Semahat Arsel and his father Mustafa Rahmi Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fertilizer tycoon forced to refinance debt on the $1.4 billion license he won at auction against rival Dmitry Rybolovev to develop one of the world's largest potassium deposits. The graduate of the Magnitogorsk Iron and Metals Institute, worked for 35 years at the Silvinit fertilizer factory and in 1990 became head of the company. He organized the privatization of the company and became one of its largest shareholders. Today the factory, located in the city of Solikamsk in Russia's Perm region (in the Urals), is the second-largest producer of potassium fertilizer in the country. In summer of 2010 he sold his stake to businessman Anatoly Skurov and State Duma deputy Zelimkhan Mutsoev; remains on Silvinit board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of $7 billion (revenues) Mahindra Group, returns to list after four year gap. Group's businesses include automobiles, information technology, real estate, aerospace and financial services. Flagship Mahindra & Mahindra, run by nephew Anand, is world's largest maker of tractors by volume, India's biggest seller of SUVs. It bought ailing South Korean automaker Ssangyong Motor for $465 million and electric car maker Reva. Company's US  distributor recently withdrew lawsuit that had delayed launch of  its pickup trucks in that market. Last June, he was convicted and awarded two years' imprisonment by a Bhopal court because he was non-executive chairman of Union Carbide India in 1984 when the Bhopal gas leak tragedy occurred. He got bail and has appealed against the order.

name: Billionaires
bio: As board chairman of Alfa's Altimo telecom-holding company has oversight of cell network operator Vimpelcom's $6 billion bid for Wind Telecom, the telecom assets of Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris; March meeting of shareholders will decide deal fate. Born in then Soviet Republic of Estonia and graduated from the Moscow Power Engineering Institute; served as commercial director at a small firm founded with the institute's help. In 1992 hired by Alfa Group to oversee establishment of a privatization-investment fund; months later became chief executive of Alfa Capital, the group's fund-management company. After expanding Alfa Capital became responsible for all of the bank's investment units.

name: Billionaires
bio: In January filed suit against against potash miner Silvinit and Computershare's Russian subsidiary, Computershare Registrator, for lose of shares in Silvinit. Has long-standing ties to the company. During the Soviet period, worked in an organization that exported Russian raw goods and materials. In 1992 started the International Potassium Company (MMK), persuading three of the largest post-Soviet producers of fertilizer including Silvinit to unite. But several years later the alliance broke up over reserve sharing. In 2005 MMK began exporting only fellow billionaire Pyotr Kondrashev's Silvinit's production; exports three-fourths of Silvinit's fertilizer abroad. Now Silvinit and Uralkali are merging.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad got start in investments with First National Citibank (which later became Citicorp) in 1969, joined TCW in 1985. Marks hired Bruce Karsh in 1987; the pair founded Oaktree Capital Management 8 years later. With Karsh, raised $1 billion when they sold 16% of their money management firm on a private Goldman Sachs exchange in 2007. Oaktree was one of 9 investor groups tapped by the U.S. government in March 2009 to soak up toxic debt from troubled banks under the Public-Private Investment Plan. Last August, the firm and fellow billionaire Marc Lasry's Avenue Capital acquired the assets of the troubled Sea Island resort in the state of Georgia.
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The patriarch of his family's supermarket chain Morrisons faces a probe by the UK's financial services watchdog following allegations that he substantially reduced his holdings in the firm without disclosing share sales. Stepped down as chairman of the U.K. food retailer in 2008 after 55 years at the company; had been chairman since 1956, when took over from his father, who founded Morrisons in 1899. During his tenure transformed it from small market stall into a $8 billion (market cap) company. Suffered criticism from some shareholders for his management style.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of steel mini-mill developer Maxi Group was detained in Moscow in February on charges of abuse of power; posted bail of $1.8 million. Case drags on. Maximov sold a controlling stake in Maxi Group to NLMK (owned by billionaire, Vladimir Lisin) in 2007; NLMK paid a first tranche of $300 million in January 2008, but the second tranche became locked in a dispute. NLMK accused Maxi Group's former top managers of stripping funds from the group, while Maximov demanded additional payment for his shares. Bankruptcy case against Maxi Group scheduled for August. The Yekaterinburg native, graduated from a mining institute; went on to found family timber and furniture business in 1991. Three years later began trading scrap iron, investing income into buying shares of small metallurgy works in Ural. Founded Metallurgy Holding in 2004, later renamed to Maxi-group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chesapeake chief selling off some shale assets to help deleverage his natural gas giant. Wall Street is rewarding his effort: shares are up more than 25% over the last year. Last January he sold  25% of company's Texas shale assets to France's Total for $2.25 billion; now attracting investments from Asia. An October 2008 margin squeeze forced him to sell chunk of his shares; now rebuilding stake. Cofounded company with $50,000 in 1989; today second largest US natural gas producer, most active driller. Market cap near $13 billion. Duke grad invests in oil and gas, venture capital and real estate. Wine collector owns 20% stake in the NBA's Oklahoma City Thunder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Limak Holding, active in the construction, energy, tourism and cement sectors. Shares ownership of the group with fellow billionaire and friend from university Sezai Bacaksiz.  In May 2010 Limak announced that it planned on gathering its port, energy and airport businesses in a company called Limak Investment and taking it public. The group's cement and tourism assets will be offered to the public separately at a later date. Is awaiting trial on charges of corruption dealing with tenders for state-owned Turkish Pipeline Corporation in 2007; Ozdemir says he is innocent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Through private equity firm, Metropoulos & Co., paid $250 million in June for Pabst Brewing Co., North America's largest privately held brewer. Greek immigrant invests in and turns around faded food brands. In 1996 he and partners formed International Home Foods, revamped likes of Chef Boyardee pasta products, PAM cooking spray and Bumble Bee seafood. In 2000 sold IHF to ConAgra for $2.9 billion. Four years later bought Aurora Foods out of bankruptcy and merged it with Pinnacle Foods (Aunt Jemima, Duncan Hines, Log Cabin). He and fellow investors sold it to Blackstone Group for $2.2 billion 2007. Immigrated to Watertown, Mass. with family at age 10. Moved to Geneva at age 25 to become financial director for GTE International's (now Verizon) European, Middle Eastern and African operations; returned to U.S. as company's youngest controller. Owns Castle on the Hudson, converted to a luxury boutique hotel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of Russian food discount chain Pyatyorochka (now X5 Retail Group) which merged in 2006 with Perekriostok, a majority-owned subsidiary of Russia's Alfa Group. Also co-founded grocery hypermarket chain Carousel which merged with X5 in 2009. Resigned from X5 board three years ago to be able to sell stock freely. His real estate assets not faring well; heavy debts and lawsuits are stunting Macromir, his St. Petersburg based development company and entities in his LEK Group are facing bankruptcy. Born in Tula, near Moscow; graduated from the Institute of Hydrometeorology in St. Petersburg. In early 1990s worked on the production of ecological-control instruments, participated in the creation of an electronic bourse and traded in imported food products before launching business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Honeywell executive, Morgridge became chief of networking firm Cisco in 1988 at 55. Took Cisco public in 1990, stepped down in 1995, and became a billionaire the next year as stock continued to climb. Chairman emeritus now teaches at Stanford University's Graduate School of Business. Avid hiker chairs the Nature Conservancy, which uses private funds to buy and protect land from development. With wife Tashia, donates to alma mater University of Wisconsin; gifted $175 million to set up a fund for college bound students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Japan's largest furniture and home furnishings chain, Nitori; stock is up 8% over the past year on strong sales. When he was 27, traveled to California to see how Americans shopped; changed the way he ran his business; every year flies about 800 employees to the U.S. to visit Wal-Mart, Target and other stores to continue learning.  Keeps average age of stores at 24; average age of employees from 30-34.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nephew of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Dynastic carve-up, which included 2007 sale of  Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Hyatt's 2009 initial public offering, due to wrap up this year. Labor unrest across cities have been rocking its crown jewel, Hyatt Hotels, in the past few months. Nick, head of Hyatt's new-hotel development efforts for many years, retired in 2009 and now spends much of his time in California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former founder of insurer, Aon Corp; shares up 25% over the past 12 months. Launched brokerage firm last year; invested a reported $275 million in Ryan Specialty Group. Retired from Aon Corp. in 2008 to focus on Chicago's failed 2016 Olympics bid; appointed chairman of World Sport Chicago, named to panel to improve U.S. Olympic Committee. Attended Northwestern on football scholarship; jumped to insurance, sold policies for 5 years after graduating. Founded own firm, auto credit insurer Pat Ryan & Associates 1964 at age 26. Merged with Combined International 1982, renamed Aon Corp. 5 years later. Grew through acquisitions into world's largest reinsurance broker. Owns stake in pro football's Chicago Bears.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ryan Specialty Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chief of Sega Sammy, pachinko machine and gaming software firm, returns to the billionaires list after four years; company stock price rocketed 73% over the past year with rising sales across divisions and improved profitability in mainstay game arcade operations. In fiscal 2009 Satomi was the third-highest-paid CEO in Japan with 435 million yen ($4.9 million) in executive compensation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shareholder of publicly traded Sabanci Holding, founded by deceased father Haci Omer Sabanci, and Turkish bank Akbank. Sevket founded smaller Turkish conglomerate Esas Holding in 2000. Spends as much time in London as he does in Istanbul. Graduated from Manchester University as a textile engineer. Had library named for him at Yildiz Technical University in Turkey. Past charitable projects include an archeological site in Turkey first excavated in the 1960s and a refurbished park in Bodrum, Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice-chairman of Limak Holding, which has businesses in the construction, energy, tourism and cement sectors. New to the list this year. Bacaksiz, a mechanical engineer by training, owns half of Limak; fellow billionaire Nihat Ozdemir owns the other half. Entered airport management business in 2008 with winning bid to manage Istanbul's second largest airport. Won tender to manage Kosovo airport in July 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Socialite and philanthropist splits her time between London and New York and has homes in Geneva and Monaco. Counts among her friends the U.K.'s Prince Charles and his wife Camilla. Inherited her fortune from late husband Edmond Safra, a billionaire banker who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment in 1999. Reportedly bought Alberto Giacometti sculpture, "Walking Man I," for $103 million in Sotheby's auction after 8 minute bidding battle this February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sagi founded gaming site Playtech, which he took public in London Stock Exchange in 2006 and now owns a chunk of its stock. Also owns several e-commerce services, an e-payment company, instant messenger service Messenger Plus and commercial real estate and hotels in Europe. Reportedly bought the most expensive home in Israel in December for about $35 million. According to tabloid reports dated Israeli model Bar Refaeli.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold his Chevy Chase Bank, which he set up in a trailer in 1969, to Capital One for $476 million in 2009; kept Chevy Chase Trust, which services high net worth individuals and has $2.4 billion in assets under management. The long-time Washington, D.C. businessman also owns real estate investment trusts; his publicly traded Saul Centers operates a real estate portfolio of 8.2 million square feet in the DC and Baltimore areas. Also owns and manages 18 hotels.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Saul Centers Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Often described as reclusive, Richard Scaife is the heir to the Mellon fortune; industrialist Andrew was his great-uncle. The value of his trusts became public after 2007 court documents were leaked online during his second, messy divorce. Owns Pittsburgh Tribune-Review newspaper, Newsmax and other right-leaning media outlets. Far-right Republican who has supported controversial causes including a program encouraging drug addicts to be sterilized.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brooklyn-born son of a bricklayer was a small-time builder; risked everything on one Manhattan high-rise in 1972. A familiar face in court: last October settled a suit over $111 million owed to Fisher East River Associates, former partner in $4 billion plan to redevelop 9.2 acres of land once owned by Con Ed along Manhattan's East River. Also being sued by Citibank, which claims he owes payment on a credit line of $503 million. In March 2010 judge ordered that Solow pay $67 million plus interest to Citi. Iconic Manhattan tower, 9 West 57th Street, apparently still having trouble finding tenants to pay steep rents. Reportedly owns paintings by Balthus, Matisse, Bacon, and Kline; sculptures by Giacometti and Moore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a trucking company owner, got into steel, supplying premium steel to the auto industry. Clients include Tata Motors, Maruti Suzuki and Mahindra & Mahindra. Took big leap investing $3 billion in a new steel mill in the eastern state of Orissa, with long-time partner Sumitomo Metals. Owns valuable mining concessions for iron ore and thermal coal.Younger son Neeraj runs operations. Estranged older son, Sanjay, runs own unlisted steel and power outfit. Practices yoga

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of the Nanshan Group headquartered in China's Shandong Province. Song hails from the village of Longjiang where, according to Nanshan's website, young men were too poor to attract local brides. He doesn't have that problem these days: Song's Nanshan Group today has almost 60 businesses, including two listed companies, whose scope extends across aluminum, textiles, real estate, finance and tourism. Son Song Jianbo chairs the aluminum products producer, Shandong Nanshan Aluminum, whose shares trade at the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Korea's largest cosmetics firm, Amorepacific, which had sales of $ 2.3 billion in 2010. Sales and profit rose by 16% and 13% compared to 2009. He had fallen off the billionaires' list but returns this year due to strength of Amorepacific shares. Chairs Korea Cosmetics Association. Avid art collector. Donates to charity that helps children in North Korea. For past decade company has supported the nation's Pink Ribbon Love Marathon to benefit women with breast cancer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swieca recently launched new investment firm Talpion after a long, prosperous partnership with grade-school chum Glenn Dubin came to an end in 2009. Swieca left Highbridge, the hedge fund and private equity outfit the pair had founded in 1992. The two grew up in Washington Heights, NY; they sold 55% stake in Highbridge in 2004 to JPMorgan Chase for $1.3 billion, and continued to manage its investments. He is on the executive committee of pro-Israel lobby American Israel Public Affairs Committee.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made entrepreneur runs conglomerate Berjaya which means 'success' in Malay. Owns social networking website Friendster.com and bought shares of Facebook through his Internet company, MOL.com. Operates Wendy's, Starbucks, Papa Johns Pizza, Kenny Rogers Roasters, Krispy Kreme and Borders bookstores in Malaysia. Listed retail arm in Hong Kong. Failed to get a sports betting license from the government. Hates golf but loves scuba diving and working out at the gym.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four board members from equipment manufacturer Sany Group to make this year's billionaires list, along with Liang Wengen, Mao Zhongwu and Xiang Wenbo. Tang is the CEO of parent company, Sany Group. Along with Liang, Mao and Yuan Jinhua, he was one of the group's founders when the business was formed in 1989 as a small welding materials factory. Tang graduated from Central South University, the same school as Liang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tapped rubber in his teenage years to support his family before building his fortune from timber concessions and palm oil plantations in Malaysia, Papua New Guinea and New Zealand. Referred to as Asia's Rupert Murdoch, he owns Media Chinese International which publishes more than 30 magazines and newspapers in North America, Southeast Asia and China. Sale of his stake in EON Capital, one of Malaysia's smaller banks, to fellow billionaire Quek Leng Chan's (No.219) Hong Leong Bank is pending a court case filed by a dissenting shareholder.

name: Billionaires
bio: 2010 was a year for horse-racing enthusiast: His Super Saver won the Kentucky Derby and his Drosselmeyer nabbed the Belmont Stakes; owns Winstar Farm in Versailles, Ky. Bartender's son studied at Southern Illinois University; paid tuition with money earned selling life insurance. Pounced on booming telecom market; founded long-distance provider Excel Communications 1988. Public 1996. Merged two years later with Teleglobe in what ended up as a $3.5 billion deal. Reinvested in stocks, bonds, horses. Sold minority stake of Gold's Gym back to Robert Rowling last year. Spends time sponsoring two sons' nationally competitive youth basketball teams.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the last dot-com billionaires to still command a 10-figure fortune. With partner Mark Cuban, sold live sports and concert Web site Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in stock 1999. Instantly made 300 employees millionaires, Wagner and Cuban billionaires. Yahoo toyed with site for nearly a decade before finally fizzling out domain address. Co-owns 2929 Entertainment, Magnolia Pictures, Landmark Theatres, HDNet. Founded charitable foundation in 2000 to help better the lives of underprivileged children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Campbell Soup heiress is a director of the $7.6 billion (sales) Campbell Soup Company. Her grandfather John T. Dorrance developed method of canning condensed soup in 1897. Today Campbell's is the world's leading soup maker; also owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth). Weber owns Live Oak Stud, a 4,500-acre thoroughbred farm and commercial cattle operation in Ocala, Fla.. Recipient of the 2005 Penny Chenery Most Distinguished Woman in Racing Award. Art patron, studied art and design at  l'Ecole du Louvre in Paris; honorary trustee of Metropolitan Museum of Art, funds the museum's  Charlotte C. Weber Galleries for the Arts of Ancient China.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Yangtze River Pharmaceutical Group, one of China's largest pharmaceutical manufacturers. Company roots go back to 1971 during China's Cultural Revolution. Today, Yangtze River has more than 7,000 employees. Sales last year rose by 38% to $3.8 billion. Signed an agreement last year with TNO-SU Biomedicine of the Netherlands to build up Chinese medicine sales in Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile daughter of Brazilian banker Amador Aguiar, the founder of Banco Bradesco, one of Brazil's largest banks. Amador's death in 1991 sparked more than a decade of court fights between widow and daughters over inheritance. His widow, 40 years his junior, married him less than 4 months before he died. During ugly public court fights widow reportedly demanded her husband's body be exhumed for DNA test to prove paternity. Daughters prevailed in court. Majority of Amador's fortune was left to the philanthropic Bradesco Foundation to benefit education in Brazil, founded by Amador in 1956. Lia started her own foundation, Fundacao Lia Maria Aguiar, to benefit the city of Campos de Jordao.

name: Billionaires
bio: In December sold a 19.61% stake in diary and juice-maker Wimm-Bill-Dann to Pepsico, which is set to acquire all the company's shares and delist the entity. Back when the company listed in 2002, the prospectus served up a juicy morsel: that Yushvaev had served nine years in a Soviet prison camp: In 1980 he had been found guilty of a "violent crime." Investors weren't scared off. Yushvayev was released in 1989 and started doing business. He was one of the founders of Trinity car dealership, of Cherry casino, one of the first in Russia, of Metelitsa dance club, popular in the beginning of 90s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jiangsu Province businessman's largest source of wealth is a minority stake in Shenzhen-listed Jiangsu Yanghe Brewery, a supplier of Chinese wine.  Also holds stake in Nantong Jinghua Pharmaceutical, a pharmaceuticals supplier.  Zan's main holding company, Zhongyi Group, is headquartered in Nantong, northwest of Shanghai above the Yangtze River.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oklahoma-born oilman used energy profits to fund pigskin empire. Helped found AFL in 1959; brought pro-football to Houston with $25,000 purchase of Oilers. Moved team to Tennessee in 1997; today Titans are worth $994 million. "Bud" is one of four current NFL owners with 350 wins. Made headlines with his decision to let controversial quarterback Vince Young go. Fined $250,000 fall 2009 for making "obscene gestures" at opposing fans. U. of Kansas grad served as an aviation engineering officer in the Navy during WWII. Founded ADA Oil Co. in 1946. Later renamed Adams Resources & Energy; public 1974. Owns cattle ranches in Texas, melon, rice, tomato, walnut farms in California. Enjoys collecting Western art, Native American artifacts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Suning Universal, one of the largest real estate owners in the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing. Fortune fell from a year ago amid government moves to cool the country's real estate market, which led Chinese investors to push Suning's share price down by a quarter.  Zhang is a graduate of Nanjing's Dongnan University with a major in architecture. Brother of fellow billionaire Zhang Jindong. Son Zhang Kangli owns part of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made king of Australia's West Coast house building industry keeps building. His firm constructs homes, almost entirely from bricks, wall panels and windows supplied by Buckeridge factories. Commercial, contracting units focus on mining, which is boosting business. One complaint: being held up by government land-release policies that he says are slow and expensive, forcing up housing prices and dulling demand for materials.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive investment banker hosts very visible retreat in Sun Valley for media big shots. Helped take Google public 2004. Uncle Charles (d. 1994) started investment bank Allen & Co. 1922. Father Herb Sr. (d. 1997) joined 5 years later. Herb Jr. started at boutique bank in 1962. Rumored to be forwarding fortune to children; annually disputes net worth estimate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited fortune from late husband, Hunan entrepreneur Wei Dong, who died in 2008. Chen holds stakes in several listed companies in China -- Beijing Originwater Technology (sewerage treatment), Sinolink Securities (brokerage), Zhuzhou Qianjin Pharmaceutical (drug maker), Jiuzhitang (Chinese medicine maker), and Zhejiang Dahua Technology (security equipment manufacturer).

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and co-founder of Hong Kong-listed pharmaceutical producer Sihuan Pharmaceutical Holding Company had 7.4% of the cardio-cerebral vascular drug market in China in 2009. Sells to nearly 10,000 hospitals in China. Che worked for more than eight years as a neurologist, before moving to the business side of the pharmaceutical industry.  According to a company biography, Che holds bachelor of medicine (aviation) and master of medicine (neurology) degrees from the Fourth Military Medical University in Xi'an. He has also obtained an EMBA degree from the China Europe International Business School. Sihuan went public in Hong Kong last year, after moving its listing from Singapore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and largest shareholder of RMK, Russia's third-largest copper producer. In the fall of 2009, with Iskander Makhmudov's UGMK, bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Zinc Factory, the largest zinc producer in Russia. Started out in the early 1990s trading scrap metals. In 1997 established Uralelectromed-Vtortsvetmet, which became the main supplier of scrap and copper to Makhmudov's UGMK. In the end of the last year he disclosed his stake in the company: it is more than 75%. Bought madonna's former house.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sidney, ran shoemaking business, invested in Florida real estate. Ed bought Miami TV station for $3.4 million in 1962; later added 3 more in Boston. Son Andrew runs family's real estate operation. Owns real estate around Miami and Indianapolis. Boston broadcasting tycoon offended fans of hometown hero Jay Leno when he had announced his local NBC station would air a 10 p.m. newscast rather than the former Tonight Show host's variety show; changed mind when NBC threatened to yank affiliation.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: After months of petitioning and politicking, Shlomo Eliahu's wish came true in January when the Israeli government sold a 5% chunk of Bank Leumi, making him the Israeli bank's largest shareholder. The Iraqi immigrant came to Israel with his family in 1950 and went from living in a transit camp to founding an underwriting agency. He built his fortune hawking insurance in Israel after building the country's first insurance company. Eliahu served as a member of Israel's Parliament from 1978-81 and chairman of its Finance Committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Continues to grow his agricultural food company, Agrofert Holding, via acquisition in the Czech Republic, looking to expand in Central Europe. Chided European Union for too stringent regulations on new members, calling Czech Republic a second class member of the entourage. Son of diplomat was born in what is now Slovak Republic; began as trader for Petrimex, precursor to Agrofert. Grew Agrofert with investors; today sole owner.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Chicago native started insurance giant Admiral in Cardiff in 1993; today, it is the highest valued public company in Wales. Trained as a journalist, but couldn't find a job so worked as a futures broker. After an MBA at INSEAD, was headhunted to start a car insurance firm targeting young urbanites with affordable policies. Launched well-known insurance quote aggregator Confused.com in 2002. Floated Admiral on the London Stock Exchange in 2004; second ever Welsh firm to land on the FTSE 100.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Admiral Group plc', 'uri': 'companies/admiral-group', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: His Funai Electric, which manufactures and sells low cost television sets and DVD players sold under brand names such as Emerson and Sylvania, is struggling because of weak consumer demand and slow pick up in LCD TV sales, especially in its core US market. Revised TV sales target for latest fiscal year to 5.8 million units vs its prior 7.5 million unit target; inventory risk persists. Company stock plummeted 28% over the past year. New venture into CloudTV which will stream content versus download content to TV.

name: Billionaires
bio: Strong performance by the Ultimate Fighting Championship throws the Ferittas back into billionaire ring. The mixed martial arts league is actively expanding overseas. Along with his brother Lorenzo, he'll get back into casino game when their family's Station Casino emerges from bankruptcy later in 2011; Fertittas will remain controlling owners. Brothers bought mixed martial arts outfit Ultimate Fighting Championship for $2 million 2001; plowed in cash to improve operations. Today UFC is their most valuable asset. Father Frank Jr. started as Las Vegas dealer; built casino geared to locals. Station went public 1993, private 2007. The appreciation of Frank's extensive art and jewelry collection adds to his growing fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and fellow billionaires Konstantin Nikolaev and Nikita Mishin co-owns railway and port operator, N-Trans group. Born in Ukraine, graduated from physical culture and sports Academy in Belarus as a chess teacher and coach. Worked in expedition companies in Murmansk's port before partnering with Nikolaev and Mishin in 1996 to found Severstaltrans; Alexei Mordashov also investor. In 2007 the partners bought Mordashov's stake; in 2008 the group was renamed N-Trans. Financed memorial in Paris to famous chess master and the first Russian world champion, Alexander Alehin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Hong Kong property company, Hip Shing Hong. Fong and his father Fong Shu Cheun arrived in Hong Kong from the mainland in 1927, starting out in business with a sesame factory. By 1948, after the devastation of World War II, they had started an import-export operation. In 1951, Hip Shing Hong was the largest cinnamon exporter in Hong Kong. The company entered the real estate business in 1953 with the purchase of a plot of land at Wong Chuk Hang Road. Today, that real estate empire includes serviced apartments, commercial, industrial and residential projects. Hip Shing Hong is expanding into hotels, with plans to open an 88-room inn in Hong Kong's Jordan district at the end of this year or early 2012. Fong senior was also cited by Forbes Asia as a Hero of Philanthropy last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Weak consumer spending made life difficult for the cofounder and main shareholder of electrical goods and furniture chain Harvey Norman. Shares fell as heavy discounting hit margins. Added a shopping center to his property portfolio in October. With partner Ian Norman, he started retailer Norman Ross. When that business was taken over, both men quit, later opening Harvey Norman in 1982. Remains chairman of the now publicly traded group. Has a passion for horses: owns part of Magic Millions Thoroughbred auction house and personally owns some 900 horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wealth of retailer Renrenle Commercial Group's chairman has slid from a year ago amid weak profits.  He founded the company in 1996 in Shenzhen just north of Hong Kong. Sales in 2010 last year totaled $1.5 billion, up 14.5% from a year earlier. Yet net profit rose only 4% to $37 million, and earnings per share tanked by 21%. Wealth estimate doesn't include wife Song Qi's shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of RiseSun Enterprise, a real estate developer headquartered in Langfang in Hebei Province. Geng holds an EMBA from Nanyang Technological University and is studying for a Ph.D. in economics at Wuhan University of Technology. Shares in RiseSun have had a double-digit gain in the past year despite a government effort to brake real estate prices that has hurt other developers' shares. Investors took heart after Geng added to his own stake, boosting his stock price.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Palmali Navigation owns roughly 220 ships that transport oil and petroleum products. Also owns a small media company with two Istanbul radio stations, real estate holdings and a new hotel in Istanbul. Originally from Azerbaijan. Was sent to military school as a teenager, later worked in Soviet internal intelligence. For a year and a half also worked as a cook on various ships. The first ship he bought was an old Soviet vessel  that no one wanted. Likes animals; built asylums in Russia and Azerbaijan for homeless animals.  Sleeps at most 4 hours a day. Owns several Falcon jets and flies at least 120 hours a month.Sleeps at most 4 hours a day. Flies at least 120 hours a month.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gustavson debuts on the Forbes World's Billionaires list as her father, Public Storage founder B. Wayne Hughes, has started shedding his assets to her and her children. She owns just over 11% of the storage giant as well as being majority shareholder of Public Storage Canada. Gustavson also owns a commercial real estate company,  American Commercial Equities Management LLC, with property in Hawaii and California. Gives to Republican candidates and causes and donates money to the HollyRod Foundation for autism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder, chairman emeritus of Kyocera, maker of ceramic electronic components, solar panels, cell phones; company stock up 9% over the past year. In February, Sprint Nextel Corp., the third- largest U.S. wireless carrier, added a Kyocera smartphone to its lineup. Trying to turn around bankrupt regional carrier Japan Airlines; assumed chairman's post early last year. A trained Buddhist priest, he heads Inamori Foundation, which awards Kyoto Prize.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs drugmaker Cipla. He and brother inherited company from their late father who founded it in 1935 after being inspired by Mahatma Gandhi. Cipla champions low cost generics and derives more than half of its $1.2 billion in annual revenue from overseas. New mission: making affordable cancer drugs. Company recently denied report that he and family are in negotiations with Merck to sell their stake in Cipla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deputy Chairman of the Board of Koc Holding, one of Turkey's largest conglomerates. Attended Georgetown University and Columbia University; has a bachelor's and an MBA from the latter school. One of Turkey's most noted art collectors.  Has an orientalist painting, drawing, book and etching collection as well as a large contemporary painting collection. Expects to exhibit his collections in a private museum he is planning. His brothers Mustafa and Ali Koc, his aunts Suna Kirac and Semahat Arsel and his father Mustafa Rahmi Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Member of the family that owns industrial conglomerate Koc Group debuts on billionaires list this year thanks to 58% increase in the share price of Koc Holding and rising values of the family's privately owned companies. He serves as chief executive of the information technology arm of the group. Received his B.A. in 1989 from Rice University in Houston, Texas, followed by an MBA from Harvard University in 1997. Then worked in various companies in the US and within the Koc Group. Also the vice president of Fenerbahçe, one of Turkey's largest soccer clubs.  His brothers Omer and Mustafa Koc, aunts Suna Kirac and Semahat Arsel and his father Rahmi Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her five children, Gunter, Joachim, Michael, Wolfgang, and Daniela, inherited a fortune from her late husband, coffee magnate Max Herz. Personally held 15% of Maxingvest AG last year; now  holds 10% after an internal reorganization of the family holding. Originally called Tchibo Holding, the consumer good group was run by her late husband, then by her son Gunter but nasty family feud led Gunter and Daniela to cash out in 2003. Sons Michael  and Wolfgang now control the holding.  Son Joachim  died in May 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake. Joachim, who was childless, left his share of the fortune to a charitable foundation in his name.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner God Nisanov, owns the Ukraine Hotel, European Shopping Center and Radisson SAS Slavyanskaya Hotel. Born in Azerbaijan, moved to Moscow and began selling alcohol before partering with Nisanov and creating shopping markets near metro stations. Turned these into shopping complexes. Now growing pipeline of hotel projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forty years after founding his Jones Group apparel chain, Kimmel stepped down as chairman in January. His second career as a film producer via his Sidney Kimmel Entertainment shows no signs of slowing: his Matthew McConaughey caper 'The Lincoln Lawyer' is out this March, and he's in pre-production on the Amanda Seyfreid-starring thriller 'Gone'. Joined the Gates and Buffett Giving Pledge in 2010; in his accompanying letter, he wrote: "My thinking is rather simple: I learned as a young boy that sharing with others is the right thing to do". Kimmel founded women's outfitter Jones Apparel with a partner while working at W.R.Grace chemical company in 1970; became chairman five years later. Stepped down as CEO in 2002. The Philadelphia-born retailer's group started snapping up other brands in the 1980s and 90s; now owns Nine West, Gloria Vanderbilt and Evan-Picone. Owns 5% of the Miami Heat basketball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Lukoil Overseas Holding; parent company, Lukoil, expects to invest over $3 billion in projects outside Russia. Economics graduate founded Perm commodity exchange in the early 1990s; grew into Perm Financial and Industrial Group (PFIG). The group's main asset was a stake in Lukoil-Perm company, which Kuzyaev sold to Lukoil in 2003. Today PFIG owns telecom company ER-Telecom Holding, a regional cable TV and broadband Internet access provider. Last November, Kuzyaev sold a 10% stake in ER-Telecom Holding to Baring Vostok Capital Partners for $80 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner, Valery Kogan, owns Domodedovo airport which was hurt by unforeseen events over the past few months: the ice rain last December which paralyzed the airport, and the terrorist act in January when 30 people died. The Moscow State University philosophy student started his business in 1992 by chartering Il-76 plane which flew goods from China to Moscow. Business grew; Kamenshchik built a cargo terminal in Moscow's Domodedovo airport and later took over control of the whole airport. After reconstruction in 1999-2000 Domodedovo became popular among airlines and became the biggest airport in Russia: in 2010 it was used by more than 22m passengers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of the Heesung Group, which sells display components to LG. (LG is run by his billionaire younger brother Koo Bon-Moo.) Heesung acquired majority stake of paper and hygiene products maker Daehan Pulp in early 2009. A big fan of LG Twins, the baseball team owned by LG Group. Published a photo book on Korean baseball history in 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Still a largely private person, Michael Krasny left the spotlight after selling his Computer Discount Warehouse to private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in 2007. Auto dealer's son started selling used computers after a $3, 3-line ad in Chicago Tribune for his old IBM met with high demand; founded firm in 1984, took it public nearly 10 years later; retired from leadership in 2001. Donated more than $350 million in shares to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liang is the vice chairman and co-founder of Fosun International, one of China's largest privately-owned conglomerates in China with interests in pharmaceuticals, property, steel, mining, retail, services and strategic investments. The company has become active as a partner for foreign companies looking to expand in China. Fosun International bought a 7% stake in Club Mediterranee SA last year and is helping to grow its business in the mainland. In January, it signed a tentative agreement with U.S. insurer Prudential to jointly invest up to $600 million. Holds stake in U.S.-listed Focus Media, the largest outdoor media in China. Liang holds a bachelor's degree in genetic engineering from Fudan University and a master's degree in business administration from Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business. Fosun Media is a licensing partner of Forbes Media in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Fimalac, parent of Fitch Ratings, which operates in 50 countries. Vilified  for his rating agency's role in subprime real estate debacle. Founded the company in 1991 after a varied career. Started a teen magazine in 1961 at age 21. Sold it off a few years later. Attended elite Ecole Nationale d' Administration, then moved into banking and finance. Eventually landed at L'Oreal, where he spent 15 years, rising up to group executive vice president of finance. Now a board member at L'Oreal and Renault. A theater buff, he has helped fund renovations for the Theatre du Rond Point in Paris. Is also on the board of the American Friends of the Louvre. In August, 2009,  was named good will ambassador by UNESCO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Hua Nan Financial Holdings, one of the largest financial services companies, also has large Taiwan land holdings built up over generations after his family arrived in Taiwan from the mainland in 1778. Lin-led Ta Yung Hsing Yeh real estate company dedicated land for the burial of Taiwan presidents Chiang Kai Shek and Chiang Ching-kuo. Hua Nan was penalized last year for selling investments offered by discredited U.S. firm PEMGroup, whose founder Danny Pang committed suicide in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born into one of Hong Kong's most prominent textile families, Law has successfully put his efforts of late into hotels.  His Park Hotel chain, which has locations in China, Japan and other Asian countries, is aiming to list a REIT in Asia in the next year or two. Law's Knightsbridge Department Store, run by daughter Wendy, opened its first store in Wuxi last March and is hoping that relatively young mainlander shoppers will take to a British-flavored shopping experience. Law's father founded the family empire as one of Hong Kong's most successful textile companies. They moved downstream into retail through Law's Garment& Knitting Factory and Bossini International, a retailer with more than 1,000 stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former ballroom dance teacher from Guangzhou rose from humble beginnings to become the managing director of her husband Stanley Ho's casino empire, Sociedade de Jogos de Macau (SJM). The fourth "wife"--although never properly married--and purported favorite of Ho, makes her debut after Ho, who had been sick, recently transferred shares in SJM to her. Ho's family, which includes 17 children and the four wives, are now locked in a bitter feud over control of his wealth. Leong is a second-term lawmaker in Macau, where she plans to build a $1.3 billion family-oriented theme park. Her wealth includes a stake in SJM and properties in Hong Kong.

name: Billionaires
bio: About 90% of his net worth is held in Progressive, the auto insurer his father founded. He stepped down as CEO in 2000 but still chairs; stock up just over 10% in the past year. Lewis is a well-known proponent of marijuana legalization: gave $200,000 to November's Prop 19 legalization bill in California and $900,000 to reform group Marijuana Policy Project in 2010.
