Was once arrested for cannabis possession in New Zealand; his lawyer told the court he uses the drug to combat pain from a partial leg amputation

name: Billionaires
bio: Australia's best-known rag trader took the reins of his father's small business when he was 18 and built it into a clothing, footwear and toy empire. Sold stake in country's second-biggest retailer Coles for $950 million in 2007. More typical: repeatedly buys stakes in related businesses, resulting in a network of companies that are often supplied by his other outfits. Among them entity that owns French Connection and Nine West shoe stores in Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Attempting to take his Culture Convenience Club private: in February 2011 announced tender offer for the company which includes leading movie, music and game-rental chain Tsutaya. If accepted by shareholders, plans to delist and refocus firm on older customers. Has a 3.4% stake in online shopping mall operator Rakuten, owned by fellow billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs and runs Spice Global Group from Singapore. It has interests in mobile devices, retail, financial services, entertainment and infrastructure. Made killing when he sold his Spice Communications in 2008 for $590 million to billionaire Kumar Birla.  Privately held Spice Televentures was recently merged with listed Spice Mobility. Spice Retail, which has 772 stores in 172 cities, plans to expand to 5,000 stores by 2015. Son Dilip was questioned by agency that is investigating telecom scam. He's written books on universal harmony and managerial excellence. His long-standing project is to make a film on Buddha.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton M.B.A. started at Oppenheimer & Co.; learned investing from firm's cofounder Leon Levy. Took over company that became First Reserve 1983; launched buyout fund 9 years later. Big score: earned $240 million profit over 6 years selling stake in drilling equipment producer National Oilwell. Last year finished raising $9 billion fund, creating the world's largest energy investment firm. Total assets: $19 billion. Fishing for deep-sea oil in Gulf of Mexico, Gulf of Guinea via publicly traded portfolio company Cobalt International. Enjoys bird-watching.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lawyer turned politician, plunged into real estate in 1980. His Lodha Group has 38 upcoming projects covering 29 million square feet, mostly in Mumbai. Group's signature development will be the 117-story World One, billed as the world's tallest residential tower. Due to be completed by 2014, its apartments cost upto $11 million each. Backers include Deutsche Bank and J.P.Morgan. Listing of his flagship long delayed. Sons Abhisheck and Abhinandan handle daily operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four board members from equipment manufacturer Sany Group to make this year's billionaires list, along with Liang Wengen, Tang Xiugo and Xiang Wenbo. Granted the honorary title of "Pioneering Star" by a research body of China's Cabinet, Mao was a co-founder of Sany with Liang, Tang and Yuan Jinhua when it was founded as a welding materials supplier in 1989. All are still active at Sany Group. Once a union leader, Mao has studied management at the National University of Singapore in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and fellow billionaires Andrei Filatov and Konstantin Nikolaev co-owns railway and port operator, N-Trans group. Studied philosophy at Moscow State University. Partnered with Filatov and Nikolaev in 1996 to found Severstaltrans; Alexei Mordashov also investor. In 2007 the partners bought Mordashov's stake; in 2008 the group was renamed N-Trans.

name: Billionaires
bio: The wildcatter made perhaps the biggest find of his life last January with offshore gas field "Davy Jones," holding up to 6 trillion cubic feet of gas. Production expected to begin in third quarter of 2011. Fan and benefactor of U. of Texas and Texas Christian football getting own statue at the UT field this fall. First taste of energy business at age 10 with father W.A. "Monty" Moncrief Sr.; Tex witnessed dad's discovery of 6-billion-barrel East Texas oilfield. Wanted to quit school to become a pro golfer 1939, dad talked him out of it. Studied petroleum engineering at U. of Texas; Navy in WWII; later worked for father's Moncrief Oil. Not slowing down: "As long as your mind's in good shape you can work until you die," he says. "My dad died right here in the office working on a deal at age 91."

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 24.5% stake in Eurasia Drilling Company which recently agreed to buy drilling assets of oil company Slavneft and provide service to the company. Former mechanic started his career as a fitter in oil fields. Later he headed production facility Ukrayneftegaz, now a part of Lukoil. From 1993 to 1998 he was president of state-owned oil provider Rosneft; then became official representative of British Petroleum in oil company Sidanko. Eurasia Drilling founded in 2007; he spearheaded concern's strategic planning.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and fellow billionaires Andrei Filatov and Nikita Mishin co-owns railway and port operator, N-Trans group. Born in Ukraine, studied philosophy at Moscow State University. Worked in expedition companies in Murmansk's port before partnering with Filatov and Mishin in 1996 to found Severstaltrans; Alexei Mordashov also investor. In 2007 the partners bought Mordashov's stake; in 2008 the group was renamed N-Trans. He is one of the co-founders of the Moscow school of management, Skolkovo, the first business school in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Zarakh Iliev, owns the Ukraine Hotel, European Shopping Center and Radisson SAS Slavyanskaya Hotel. Born in Azerbaijan, moved to Moscow. With Iliev, created shopping markets near metro stations. Turned these into shopping complexes. Now growing pipeline of hotel projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Port operator joins billionaire ranks for first time this year. Shares of his Manila-listed International Container Terminal Services, which he has headed since 1995, almost doubled in past year thanks to uptick in global trade. It has operations in 14 countries, including the US; it took over operations of its first port in that country in February. He sold his stake in power unit National Grid to son of fellow billionaire Henry Sy (No.173)  last year, pocketing handsome profit. Avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with fellow Chinese billionaires Huang Yi and Li Guoqiang, Pang is one of the world's richest auto distributors. Worked early in his career at a government machinery factory. Pang's Power Diversity Automobile Trade distributes 77 brands of cars, including Subarus and Chryslers, in 21 Chinese provinces and in Mongolia. Pang holds an EMBA from Fudan University in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Raised in gold-mining town in central Australia. Quit school at 14 to sell hand-carved handkerchief boxes. Dabbled in plumbing, construction, a small airline and ice-skating ventures. His best cash business came as a going-away gift in 1962 when he stepped down from his job as a manager for
an earthmoving outfit. The company chairman gave Perron Toyota franchise rights, allowing Perron to set up dealerships in western Australia. Perron says he tried to give it away, but "nobody wanted it." Still selling Toyota vehicles decades later; a bit of rough ride last year when his Prestige Toyota lost 4-wheel-drive sales when the Japanese car company was slow to supply more airbags to meet mining industry (a key customer) safety standards. But he still returns to the ranks of billionaires and expects record car sales this year. His property business is about to start on a new shopping center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ren is the founder and CEO of Huawei, China's biggest telecommunications equipment company. Ren established the privately-held company in 1988 in Shenzhen, a few years after serving a decade in the People's Liberation Army. Huawei says it has no connections with the PLA. Ren has led Huawei into the ranks of the world's largest telecommunications hardware companies. According to its website it provides hardware to 36 of the world's top 50 telecommunications operators in more than 100 countries, and has 17 research and development centers around the world such as in the Silicon Valley, Dallas, Stockholm, Moscow and Bangalore. Whereas China is famous worldwide for intellectual property theft, Huawei says it filed 6,770 new patents in 2009, ranking second in patents applications under the WIPO Patent Cooperation Treaty (PCT). Its partners include Siemens and Motorola, among many others.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Central Cipta Murdaya, more than 25 year-old group, with interests in IT, real estate, timber, plantations, consumer goods and engineering.Mostly private, its only listed entity is property developer Metropolitan Kentjana, which went public in 2009. Group recently got licence to provide WiMax services in 24 cities; targeting 3 million customers. Wife Siti Hartati Murdaya, helps manage business. A vegetarian, he enjoys playing golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul returns to the ranks as share of his real estate investment trust Vornado Realty rose about 40% in past year. REIT owns 40 million square feet of office space in New York and Washington, D.C. Has had a busy 2010 and start to this year. Purchased ground lease under Borgata Hotels Casino & Spa in Atlantic City for $80 million; invested in loan servicer LNR, lifting stake and giving it potential special access to distressed real estate deals. Roth even bought (for himself) ponzi master crook Bernie Madoff's Long Island home, for $9 million. Since start of 2011, he's resigned from the board of Toys "R" Us and been elected to that of JC Penney. Native New Yorker founded Interstate Partners more than four decades ago. Wife Dylan is a Broadway and off-Broadway producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, one of China's largest shipyards. Ren has been with the company since the 1970s when it was known as Jiangyin Shipbuilding Factory. He moved to become head of the ship body workshop. By the mid-1980s, when Jiangyin Shipbuilding Factory was changed to Jiangsu Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Factory, he had become a factory supervisor. From 1997, Ren has been chairman of the company, whose shares now trade in Singapore and, following a 2010 offering, in Taiwan. He received an economics degree from Jiangsu Television Broadcasting University in 1986. Ren enjoys swimming and table tennis. He has applied for Hong Kong abode.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Beijing Dabeinong, a supplier of animal feed and seed that listed at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last April. Shao, born in China's entrepreneurial mecca of Zhejiang, began his career as an educator. He worked as a teacher at a Beijing college for two years after receiving a Ph.D. from China Agricultural University.  He left in 1994 to start Dabeinong.  A Buddhist, Shao enjoys tea and reading in his spare time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Childhood friend and judo compatriot of prime-minister Vladimir Putin owns Stroygazmontazh Corporation, one of the biggest construction subcontractors of Russian gas giant Gazprom; also a pipes supplier for Gazprom. He owns 26% stake in Mostotrest (big road construction corporation), Bank Severny Morskoy Put  (together with his younger brother Boris), and a concession company for a toll road from Moscow to Saint-Petersburg which is under construction.

name: Billionaires
bio: Infosys co-founder and chief operating officer since 2007, debuts on list. Used to head worldwide sales and customer delivery, based in Boston from where he built the US business.  He's tipped to be the next CEO. Avid movie watcher and gadget freak, is hooked to his IPad and Galaxy Tab. His family's  The Advaith Foundation, a non-profit that his wife Kumari spearheads, supports education and research. Daughter Shruti, who's studying at Columbia Business School in New York, owns two restaurants in Bangalore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Keeping low profile since retiring from the small kimono shop he built into nearly 1,600-store discount retailer Shimamura, whose shops sell everything from home decor to baby clothes to shoes. Slow uptick in consumer spending has hurt company's sales; stock down 4% over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Became chairman of Akbank, a unit of the family-owned Sabanci group, in 2008 after her father Erol Sabanci stepped down. Began working at the bank in the 1980s. Has degrees in business from Richmond College in England and Boston University. Husband Haluk Dincer is chairman of Sabanci Holding's retail group. The couple have two children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secunda knew Michael Bloomberg from a stint as a researcher at Salomon Brothers. After working as a trader at Morgan Stanley, Secunda joined his former colleague in setting up data analytics firm Innovative Market Systems in 1982 -- renamed Bloomberg LP in 1987. Secuda has 4% stake in the company, which sold its 300,000th terminal this year. He oversees financial products and global staff.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swedish badminton prodigy attended college outside Stockholm. Stint in Paris covering European stocks for Atlantic Finance then MBA at Columbia. Joined legendary investment banker Ace Greenberg at Bear Stearns 1988. Memorable assignment: worked on billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's bid for Chrysler. Launched hedge fund Sandell Asset Management 1998. Funds returned between 5.5% and 9% in 2010; focus on capital preservation. Firm now manages $1 billion, down from $7.5 billion 2 years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Strauss Group, Israel's second-largest food and beverage company, which produces and exports hummus, dairy products, coffee and water purifiers. Group was started in northern Israel by parents, who immigrated to Israel from Germany in 1936. Michael helped turn the family company into international conglomerate but keeps parents' home in Nahariya as a showcase and reminder of Strauss' beginnings. Daughter, Ofra, now leads the company. Michael is  strong supporter of city of Akko, which he is personally vested in making an economic, social and tourist stronghold for the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: University of Maryland dropout became a millionaire with marketing outfit Snyder Communications; outsourced marketing for companies lacking own sales force. Bought pro football's Washington Redskins for record $750 million in 1999, became a billionaire as the team surged in value. Team's net-of-debt value: $1.6 billion. Snyder's Red Zone Capital owns chunks of Johnny Rockets restaurant chain, Red Zebra Broadcasting and Dick Clark Productions. Recently sued local alternative weekly newspaper over an article he claims was libelous and anti-Semitic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil and minerals investor debuts on the billionaires list this year thanks to stakes in three public companies: African Minerals, African Petroleum Corp. and International Petroleum, which extracts oil and gas in eastern Kazakhstan; the latter two companies are listed on Australia's National Stock Exchange. Was born in Romania, began working in mining industry in Western Australia at age 16. Now based in London. Has had a controversial past; while heading up UK-listed Regal Petroleum in 2009, company was fined nearly $1 million by UK authorities for issuing misleading statements about its oil reserves. Owns two Bombardier Challenger 604 airplanes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Campbell Soup heiress, whose son Archibold led Campbell's sales force until October 2009. He is now a director of the firm. Her chemical engineer grandfather John T. Dorrance  developed method of canning  condensed soup in 1897  that used half as much water, cutting costs by a third. Today Campbell's, which has sales of $7.6 billion, is the world's leading soup maker; also owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth).

name: Billionaires
bio: Swimmer at University of the Pacific worked in his parents' bakery. Started catering company 1951 with $800 loan; plowed profits into real estate. A.G. Spanos Cos. has built 120,000 apartments in 19 states in 6 decades. Bought controlling stake in pro football's San Diego Chargers 1984. Big donor to Republican candidates, causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apollo is the country's largest private university, but its shares have hit the skids over last 12 months, falling 30% (along with similar drops in share prices of Apollo's competitors in the for-profit education world). The Department of Education closed its review of how the University of Phoenix, Apollo's largest unit, handled financial aid funds after questions rose following high dropout and default rates. DOE said it made no adverse findings. Both Apollo's founder, John Sperling, and his son, Peter Sperling, have been dumping shares over the past year. Stock drop hit John Sperling harder than son because the elder Sperling owns nearly double the number of shares as son Peter. John left humanities professorship at San Jose State University in 1976 to start the University of Phoenix; son Peter joined in 1983. Apollo went public in 1994. Today 400,000 students take classes for associate, bachelor's master's and doctoral degrees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apollo is the country's largest private university, but its shares have hit the skids over last 12 months, falling 30% (along with similar drops in share prices of Apollo's competitors in the for-profit education world). The Department of Education closed its review of how the University of Phoenix, Apollo's largest unit, handled financial aid funds after questions rose following high dropout and default rates. DOE said it made no adverse findings. Both Apollo's founder, John Sperling, and his son, Peter Sperling, have been dumping shares over the past year. Stock drop hit John Sperling harder than son because the elder Sperling owns nearly double the number of shares as son Peter. John left humanities professorship at San Jose State University in 1976 to start the University of Phoenix; son Peter joined in 1983. Apollo went public in 1994. Today 400,000 students take classes for associate, bachelor's master's and doctoral degrees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained dentist got start selling study guides while in school. Has since made a fortune selling to Indonesia's new middle class. His conglomerate Para Group has interests in banks, TV stations, theme parks, retail. Owns franchise rights to Baskin-Robbins; high-end brands Armani, Jimmy Choo, Valentino. Bought 40% in retailer Carrefour Indonesia for $300 million last year. Plans to build Southeast Asia's largest theme park in Jakarta.  Wears same all-black uniform as staff.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Yuyue Medical Equipment, a producer of diagnostic equipment including anti-bedsore mattresses, wheelchair bound vehicles, stethoscopes. Yuyue listed at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2008. Yuyue was listed on the 2011 Forbes China Up-and-Comers List. Wu, who is studying for EMBA at the China Europe International Business School, enjoys wine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Zhejiang Sunflower Light Energy debuts on the latest billionaires list after a successful IPO at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last August. Shares in the supplier of solar cells have nearly tripled since. Sunflower is located in Shaoxing in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, yet Wu is a resident of Hong Kong. Wu holds an EMBA from Zhongnan University of Economics and Law.

name: Billionaires
bio: Came up with idea for mobile phone company Turkcell, funded by billionaire Mehmet Emin Karamehmet. Sat on Turkcell's board from 1993 until 2005; still owns a big stake in the NYSE-listed outfit. His MV Holding operates in telecom, enegy and tourism sectors. Also owns stake in KVK, the  biggest mobile phone retail network in Turkey.  His Dost Enerji entered the renewable energy market in 2007; now has 10% market share of Turkey's wind power market. Rents out his 120-foot yacht, Jasmin, docked at Antibes, France, for $70,000 per week in low season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took agribusiness conglomerate Kernel Holding public on Warsaw stock exchange in 2007. Stock price has doubled over the past year. On acquisition hunt. Parliamentary deputy adroitly switched parties from Yulia Tymoshenko's bloc to new president Victor Yanukovich's bloc when the political winds shifted.

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiu's China Xiuzheng Pharmaceutical Group was spawned from a small pharmaceutical factory owned by the Tonghua Institute of Pharmaceutical Industry. Under Xiu's leadership, the company has grown into one of China's largest pharmaceutical manufacturers with more than 60,000 employees. It supplies medicine to combat ulcers and digestive problems, among other ailments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Sound Environmental Resources, a supplier of water and sewage treatment facilities. Holds a bachelor's degree in environmental engineering from the Lanzhou Railway College, currently known as Lanzhou Jiaotong University, in July 1986, and a master's in environmental engineering from Tsinghua University in 1989.  Wen is a part-time professor in Tongji University and Lanzhou Jiaotong University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and co-founder of VTech, one of the world's most successful manufacturers of electronic toys and educational learning devices.  Got interested in electronic toys as a player of "pong" games in the 1970s, and went on to set up VTech as a maker of game consoles in 1976. Today, the Hong Kong-based company has operations in 11 countries and 27,000 employees. "I tell my staff, 'We're not a toy company, we're a technology company,'" Wong explained to Forbes Asia recently.  Besides a leader in learning devices, VTech is one of the world's largest makers of cordless phones and a contract manufacturer. Wong holds a graduate degree in electrical and computer engineering from the University of Wisconsin at Madison.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Shenzhen Grandland Decoration Group debuts on the 2011 billionaires list following a successful IPO at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last September. Grandland is one of the country's largest interior decoration and building services companies. Business partners include Hui Ka Yan's Evergrande Real Estate. Ye is the chairman of the Shenzhen Promotion Association for Small and Medium Enterprises, and vice chairman of the China Building Decoration Association.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yung's family has lived through some of the largest ups and downs of any clan in China in the past century. The family was among the richest in the country before the Communist Revolution; many members left for Hong Kong and elsewhere after. Yung's father Rong Yiren, stayed during Communist rule, and was called on by Deng Xiaoping to help rebuild; Yung himself subsequently went to Hong Kong and founded CITIC Pacific, a conglomerate with government ownership that help fund growth in China. Yung left as chairman in tumult in 2009 after losses on foreign currency bets. Yung has been embroiled in controversy over an investment in Hainan real estate. Yet Yung may be rebounding. In February, Yung-owned Paragon Asset Holdings, apply to buy a stake in Hong Kong-listed Imagi International Holdings, which in turn plans to purchase red-hot animation company Toon Express Group for cash and shares. Toon's properties include: "Pleasant Goat and Big Big Wolf," a popular cartoon series seen as one of China's successful homegrown efforts to date.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder with sister Cheung Yan and brother-in-law Liu Ming Ching of Nine Dragons Paper, the largest packaging paperboard producer in Asia. Nine Dragon's Hong Kong-listed shares and family's wealth are off amid worries about how rising raw materials costs will affect future profit. Nephew Lau Chun Shun is a member of the board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four board members from equipment maker Sany Group to make this year's billionaires list, along with Liang Wengen, Tang Xiuguo and Mao Zhongwu. Xiang joined Sany Group in 1991 and today is CEO of its main China-listed business, Sany Heavy Industrial. Xiang is frequently the public voice of Sany, expressing views about government policy. Xiang has been a member of China's National People's Congress and is a director of China Construction Machinery Association. Xiang is a graduate of the Dalian University of Technology, and holds a master's degree in molding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang leads Beijing Jianlong Heavy Industry Group, one of China's largest non-government-controlled steelmakers. According to a disclosure at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in November, Jianlong plans to take a stake in Shenzhen-listed electrical equipment manufacturer Acheng Relay. Jianlong would obtain the stake by exchanging shares it currently holds in Jiamusi Electric Machine, a subsidiary of Acheng's parent company Harbin Electric, for an undisclosed number of shares in Acheng.  Zhang started Jianlong by leasing a faltering iron and steel plant from the government a decade ago. He bought 100% of it a year later and renamed it Jianlong Iron & Steel.  Jianlong's nets assets as of Sept. 30 last year totaled $1.4 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Joincare Pharmaceutical Group Industry, a maker of pharmaceuticals and healthcare products with sales of $688 million in 2010, up 21.5%. Zhu moved from Henan to Shenzhen in the early 1990s and set up Shenzhen Taitai Healthcare Food, which expanded its product offerings and later became Joincare. Joincare today has 9,000 employees, and in addition to health supplements also produces pharmaceutical intermediates and over-the-counter drugs.  The Shanghai-listed company announced a $46 million stock buyback plan this January. Zhu's hobby: Golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sits on board of family's engineering firm Thermax. Worked in company from 1985; took charge when her husband died in 1996. Was chairman until 2004 when she stepped down , making way for daughter Meher, a UK-trained chemical engineer, who now chairs. She devotes time to social causes, primarily education. She cofounded Teach for India in 2008, a non-profit that recruits young people to teach for 2 years in schools for low-income kids. Also supports and sits on board of Akanksha Foundation, an education charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and head of egg producer Avangardco Investments Public joins the billionaires list after floating a 20% stake in the company in June. Stock price up 35% since going public. Sister, Nataliya, is CEO. Bakhmatyuk previously worked in state oil and gas company Naftogaz Ukraine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recruited by Richard Elman 2 decades ago to help run his commodities firm Noble. Longtime executive of firm, sold $250 million worth of shares, his first ever sale, in March 2010, ahead of his retirement from day-to-day operations in June of last year. Vice chairman emeritus still sits on firm's board. Harry has several homes in Hong Kong, where he has lived for quarter of a century; India, where he was born; and New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bank of Moscow president in tussle with state-owned VTB bank. In February, VTB approved a gradual acquisition of 100% of shares in Bank of Moscow; began with purchase of a 46.48% stake held by the Moscow government, added 17.3% owned by Stolichnaya Insurance Group. VTB's move to acquire Goldman Sachs 3.88% stake being fought by Borodin in London courts; appeal set for mid-March. The Moscow Institute of Finance graduate was appointed adviser to Moscow mayor Yuri Luzhkov at 27.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former violin player Amar Bose started repairing radios in high school, after WWII depressed father's import business. Fulbright scholar earned Ph.D. in electrical engineering from MIT. Began research on hi-fi sound. Started Bose Corp. 1964. First contracts with NASA, U.S. military improving audio communications. Built brand on groundbreaking loudspeaker design. Today Bose iPod docks, surround-sound home entertainment speaker systems and noise-canceling headphones dominate market; its loudspeakers are used in Sistine Chapel, several Olympic stadiums.  Launched VideoWave TV last year, incorporating state-of-the-art speaker technology into 46" flat screen LCD. Sales believed to exceed $2 billion, today has 126 stores in North America. National Inventors Hall of Fame inductee enjoys badminton, wears nametag around the office like all other employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michigan State grad left Wall Street in 1969 for a fresher perspective on markets; moved to Denver, founded mutual fund giant Janus. Enjoyed exceptional returns during bull markets of 1980s, 1990s; became fourth-largest mutual fund company in the country. Losses mounted in 2000; resigned chief exec post 2002. Stepped down as chairman 2 years later. Now breeds horses at his Iron Rose Ranch in Carbondale, Colo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Structural engineer, chairs Unitech, India's second largest listed property company, run by sons Ajay and Sanjay. Focussed on affordable homes and on reducing debt after being hit by downturn. Spun off infrastructure and telecom business into Unitech Infrastructure. Telecom unit Uninor, a joint venture with Norway's Telenor, under scanner as part of investigations into a corruption scandal over sale of telecom licences in 2008. Company denies any wrongdoing saying it complied with government guidelines. Stock has fallen lately. Unitech Chandra Foundation, family's charitable arm, works in the areas of education and health.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Benson is one of 20 NFL team owners among America's billionaires. His New Orleans Saints won their first Super Bowl in 2010 and led the league in NFL-licensed merchandise sales for that season. Team only got a wild-card berth this past season and lost in the first round of the playoffs.  His granddaughter, Rita Benson LeBlanc, is EVP of the Saints. Benson and others paid $70 million for the team in 1985; he bought out his partners in 1993 in a deal that valued the team at $120 million; it is now worth $955 million. Benson also owns car dealerships and the city's Fox affiliate. With his family, he has been helping restore New Orleans in the wake of Katrina, buying and fixing up former Dominion Tower, now the Benson Tower, and New Orleans Centre.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former government bureaucrat turned billionaire. Based in Guangdong Province, Hopson Development is involved across the spectrum of the real estate business: residential, commercial, hotel properties as well as tourist and vacation businesses. Stock has dropped by a fifth amid government efforts to curb real estate prices. Hopson holds shares in Hong Kong-listed BBMG, another real estate company.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the leading innovators of integrated avionics, Burell founded Garmin in 1989 with Min Kao to make navigation devices for aviation and boating. Name 'Garmin' comes from the two founders' names - Gary and Min. Original office: 2 folding chairs and a card table. U.S. Army servicemen loved GPS units during Gulf and Iraq wars but Garmin never had a military contract. Took the newfangled Global Positioning System, used till then for satellites and developing military navigation, to directionally-challenged drivers on US highways in 1998. Fortunes soared, spouses stop bickering. Burrell retired as co-chairman 2004, now chairman emeritus.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Armed with a degree in radio electronics, in the 1990s had first stores in Moscow with bar code readers. Diversified company later traded food and electronics, imported bananas, managed banks and an airline; group eventually collapsed. Now focuses on gambling business; bought chain of perfume and cosmetics shops, Douglas Rivoli. Also invests in real estate. Injured in an accident at a friend's home; appears frequently in a wheelchair. Heads the Russian Committee for the Development of the Paralympics Movement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns electric power plants, copper aluminum and soda ash mines, hotels and a media company in Turkey. Got his start selling auto parts; in the mid 1980s began importing Mercedes vehicles to Turkey. Started publishing a newspaper 2009. In December 2010, his Park Holding was the highest bidder for Akdeniz Electricity Distribution, with 1.5 million subscribers. New investment: shipping. Has ordered 8 cargo ships being built in Korea.  Owns apple farms on the outskirts of Istanbul. Has personally funded building multiple schools throughout Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Major shareholder and chairman of publicly traded IDB Group, Israel's largest diversified business group with assets of more than $30 billion, including interests in in insurance, biotech and finance. Dankner founded the Ganden Group, which holds the controlling interest of IDB. Has served as director and vice chairman of Bank Hapoalim, one of Israel's largest banks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Springland International, an operator of supermarkets and department stores that went public in Hong Kong in October. Our estimate of Chen's wealth is based on public reports filed with the Hong Kong Stock Exchange that show his holding as well as his disposal of approximately 29 million shares in connection with over-allotment option. An attorney for Chen objected to Chen's inclusion on the list but did not refute the information and iinstead explained that Chen strongly disagrees with the HKSE's requirement to disclose holdings.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice president of China's sporting goods maker Anta Sports of Fujian Province, one of a flock of China's home-grown sportswear brands that is looking to go global. Sales last year increased by 26.1% to $1.1 billion, yet its shares have declined recently amid worries about future profit growth. The company went public in Hong Kong in 2007. Anta has marketing contracts with Luis Scola of the Houston Rockets and tennis star Jelena Jankovic. Brother Ding Shizhong is also a member of this year's list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Chinese sporting goods maker Anta Sports of Fujian Province, one of a flock of home-grown sportswear brands that is looking to go global. Sales last year increased by 26.1% to $1.1 billion, yet its shares have declined recently amid worries about future profit growth. The company went public in Hong Kong in 2007. Anta has marketing contracts with Luis Scola of the Houston Rockets and tennis star Jelena Jankovic. Brother Ding Shijia is also a member of this year's list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice-chairman of $1.4 billion (sales) Asian Paints, among world's top ten paint companies which aspires to be in the top 5. It has 23 factories in 17 countries. Stock price jumped by more than a third, propelling him into billionaire ranks for first time.  His father co-founded company in 1942 with three others and he joined in 1968.  Son Jalaj looks after international operations. Wife Ina sits on board. He practices yoga and collects art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Darwin Deason agreed to sell his outsourcing firm Affiliated Computer Services (ACS) to Xerox in September 2009 but only after it agreed to pay him a hefty premium for his Class B shares. Shareholders sued, but claims were resolved in November and deal closed in February. He pocketed $800 million at the time, mostly in stock. Deason who founded ACS in 1988 as a bank data processor, credits much of his success to having instituted a "hustle" culture in which people come in earlier, stay later and do more for the customer than the next guy. Favorite saying: "I know I can't cheat death, but I can cheat old age, and I've lived my life that way." Known for his lavish lifestyle; he has a 205-foot yacht named Apogee, a 9,300-square-foot oceanfront home in  La Jolla, Calif. and a Dallas penthouse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of the first Russian food discount chain Pyatyorochka (now X5 Retail Group) which merged in 2006 with Perekriostok, a majority-owned subsidiary of Russia's Alfa Group. Also co-founded grocery hypermarket chain Carousel which merged with X5 in 2009. Produced two Russian movies The Strawberries Time and Do Not Think of White Monkeys. Currently resides in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turkish government levied a $2.9 billion (4.6 billion Turkish Lira) tax penalty against the country's largest media group, Dogan, in 2009. The Dogan Group filed an appeal for the cancellation of these tax penalties. Some of the cases have been resolved in favor of Dogan while some are still in the appeals process. Dogan Group of Companies Holding, owned in majority by the Dogan family, sold its 54% shares in Turkey's largest oil company Petrol Ofisi to its Austrian partner OMV A.G. for $1.4 billion (1 billion Euros) in October 2010. Family announced they were selling all their media assets and appointed Goldman Sachs as consulting company in September 2010. Aydin Dogan retired from Doðan Holding in January 2010, handing over the post to his daughter Arzuhan Doðan Yalçýndað.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of consumer electronics manufacturer Shenzhen MTC debuts on this year's list after MTC's successful IPO last June. With sales of about $500 million, MTC is smaller than the likes of Apple or contract manufacturing giants such as Hon Hai (run by billionaire Terry Gou). Gu's MTC stays competitive by coming up with its own features and focusing on niche customers, such as private labels sold by department store chains.

name: Billionaires
bio: Was enrolled in the University of Washington but left to join the Army during the Korean War. Upon his return, started building sailboats in his garage; founded Bayliner Marine Corp in 1955, focusing on affordable plywood motor boats. Bought out by the Brunswick Corporation for $425 million in 1986. Donated $5.4 million to an Arizona State University entrepreneurship program in 2005; longtime supporter of Seattle's Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center. Spends time on his 164-ft yacht Evviva (Italian for "long live").

name: Billionaires
bio: Dad, Joyce C. Hall (d. 1982), founded postcardmaker Hallmark 1910. Donald took over in 1966, expanded into crayons (Crayola), and real estate (Crown Center shopping complex). Son Donald Jr. runs Hallmark, son David heads wholesale operations. Family's greeting card company Hallmark is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year amid sales downturn; for latest fiscal year, sales fell 7% to $4 billion. Restructured debt owed by Crown Media Holdings, parent of Hallmark Channel; Hallmark now effectively controls 90% of the cable channel's shares. Its Crayola brand makes 3 billion crayons every year, including 1 billion made using solar power. Martha Stewart set to appear regularly on Hallmark channel which had been struggling for viewers. Hall Family Foundation gives to Kansas City area: education, arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Zhejiang Hailiang, a copper processing company based in Zhuji in China's Zhejiang Province, one of the country's meccas for entrepreneurism.  Feng is in the process of acquiring control of Shanghai-listed Sichuan Golden Summit Group, another mining company. His Hailiang Education Group has more than 10,000 students and faculty at two schools, and he owns the Chongqing Haiyu International Hot Spring Hotel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Strong performance by the Ultimate Fighting Championship throws the Ferittas back into billionaire ring. The mixed martial arts league is actively expanding overseas. Along with his brother Frank, he'll get back into casino game when their family's Station Casino emerges from bankruptcy later in 2011; Fertittas will remain controlling owners. Brothers bought mixed martial arts outfit Ultimate Fighting Championship for $2 million 2001; plowed in cash to improve operations. Today UFC is their most valuable asset. Father Frank Jr. started as Las Vegas dealer; built casino geared to locals. Station went public 1993, private 2007. The appreciation of Lorenzo's extensive art and jewelry collection adds to his growing fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Viscount Rothermere, as he is known, assumed leadership of the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) newspaper conglomerate--which includes brands like The Evening Standard, Metro and Euromoney from his late father in 1998, when he was just 30 years old. A decade later he's proved adept at guiding DMGT in a shrinking U.K. newspaper market. Under his leadership the group launched the free daily Metro newspaper now copied around the world and has been growing its insurance and property arms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known as "El Chapo," Guzman is a criminal and the leader of the illiegal drug smuggling outfit the Sinaloa cartel, responsible for an estimated 25% of the illegal drugs trafficked from Mexico into the U.S. Guzman is believed by drug experts to be spending more money to defend the cartel than in previous years due to stepped up enforcement efforts by the Mexican government, and is expanding cartel operations to Central America, particularly Guatemala.
title: Drug Trafficker

name: Billionaires
bio:
The majority of his wealth comes from Yakin Dogu which is one of the largest universities in Northern Cyprus and from the hospital, bank, hotel, gas station, molding, plastics and cable production companies he owns. Suat Gunsel is also the owner of one of the largest land portfolios in Northern Cyprus.
After studying physics at ODTU (Middle Eastern Technical University) in Turkey, he returned to Cyprus and worked for a short time in the public sector and finally he entered the education sector in 1978 by founding the Basari Dershanesi (Tutorial College). This college which helps students prepare for university also helped prepare Gunsel to establish a university himself. In 1989 Suat Gunsel officially founded the Yakin Dogu (Near East) University. He likes to spend his spare time jogging, riding horses and playing tennis. Also collects stamps and antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Star River, a Guangzhou-based real estate developer, started out in the wooden furniture business. Last year, Star River ranked as China's no. 20 developer with contacted sales of 13.5 billion yuan, or $2 billion.  Pushed ahead with new projects in 2010 amid government efforts to slow market: Shanghai Star River, a high-end residential development and Star River Haiyi Peninsula in Guangzhou, another residential project. The company also announced its first project last year outside of the mainland in Macau, a residential joint venture with Victory Real Estate Development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy global futures trader John Henry once again a billionaire thanks to October acquisition of Liverpool soccer club. Built his fortune with hedge fund J.W. Henry and Associates; now worth just $5 million. Illinois native purchased baseball's Florida Marlins from Wayne Huizenga (see) 1999; sold three years later in deal with Expos' Jeffrey Loria. With partners Tom Werner and Larry Lucchino, bought Red Sox for $700 million 2002. Two years later led team to first championship in 86 years. Today his New England Ventures owns Sox, Fenway Park, 80% share of lucrative New England Sports Network. Auto racing buff owns 50% of NASCAR's Rousch Fenway Racing, co-founded online racecar site iRacing in 2004. This past summer, the Red Sox sold out over 600 consecutive home games, the longest sellout streak in Major League Baseball history.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulk of fortune comes from 2001 sale of Mexican bank Banamex to Citigroup; Harp was former head and significant shareholder. Currently chairs  publicly traded Grupo Marti, which owns a chain of sporting goods retailers. Harp Helu is the principal shareholder.

name: Billionaires
bio: A graduate of the Moscow Institute of Chemical Engineering, had a brief flirtation with the world of entertainment as manager of Moscow's Satiricon Theater in the last years of communism. Then quit and began trading cars, metal products and steel pipes. In the mid-1990s, in hometown of Chelyabinsk, teamed up with the manager of the town's pipe-manufacturing plant, who invited him to jointly privatize the enterprise. Now the main shareholder of the ChPTZ group, which includes Chelyabinsk Pipe Rolling, First Urals New Pipe and the Chelyabinsk Zinc Factory. The group controls 20% of the country's steel-pipe market. In February, scrapped IPO on London market because of unfavorable market conditions. The Harley-Davidson motorcycle fan, represents his home region in the parliament's upper house.

name: Billionaires
bio: Piloted a B-17 bomber in WWII. Founded Mercury General Corp. in 1962; had been working as door-to-door insurance salesman before realizing auto companies were not adequately screening customers. Firm was the main supporter of Prop. 17, a California auto insurance ballot that was defeated in June 2010. Opponents said it would punish those without continuous coverage, like disabled or ill drivers. Accused of nepotism last year, employing his nephew as company's chief actuary; responded that he was within SEC rules.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Dmitry Troitsky took Russian retailer O'KEY Group public on London Stock Exchange this fall; current market cap: $3 billion. Collaboration began as students; started out in car sales founding Mega-auto company in 1993, now one of the biggest dealers in Saint-Petersburg. In 1995 founded juice producing plant Multon, and after 10 years sold it to Coca-Cola for $500 million. In 2001, co-founded O-Key chain of supermarkets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief of mid-market retailer of Kohl's. Department store finding recovery as store sales show signs of strength; stock is flat over the last year. The former Kohl's employee teamed up with partners John Herman and Jay Baker for management buyout of its 39 department stores in Wisconsin. Now Kohls has more than 1,060 stores in 49 states. Took public 1992; stepped down as chief exec 2001. Also owns shares in auto dealer CarMax.
title: Director and Member of Executive Committee
employment: {'name': "Kohl's", 'uri': 'companies/kohls', 'title': 'Director and Member of Executive Committee', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: South African water and diving enthusiast made fortune as an original investor in Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. He has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998; now focuses on venture capital and philanthropy in Israel. Founded Zalul, nonprofit organization dedicated to cleaning up water in Israel. Donates personal time and money for promote cataract surgeries in Ethiopia. Also owns camps dedicated for sick children who need a safe place to recuperate and therapeutic horseback riding center for the disabled. Cofounder of Coral World International, a string of aquariums in locations such as the Bahamas and Australia; still owns a 50% stake. Son, Benjamin, is a marine biologist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Became chief executive of LG Electronics after the company's poor performance in 2009, which was due primarily to its slow response to the smartphone market boom.  His track record within the LG Group includes LG Electronics, LG Chemicals, LG-Phillips LCD. Has proved himself to be a talented manager. In October 1999 he was the first CEO to take on LG-Phillips and led the company to be the largest producer of large scale LCDs (liquid crystal displays) in terms of market share. Received his MBA from the University of Chicago in early 1980s; after graduation worked at AT&T in the U.S. In early 1990s sorked in the Japan offices of LG Group unit DPS LG. Said to be fluent in both Japanese and English; oversees formal meetings in the foreign languages.  Younger brother of billionaire Koo Bon-Moo, who chairs LG Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: His online gaming company NCSoft saw its stock price double in 2010, boosting Kim to billionaire status. As a student at Seoul National University, he developed software to help practice typing in the Korean language. He launched NCSoft soon after graduation. Last year's hit game "Ion" was a success beyond Korea, selling big in the Chinese market. An avid fan of golf and other sports, he recently attracted much publicity after announcing plans to create a professional baseball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made fortune creating credit card giant MBNA. Barely billionaire: family's fortune fluctuating on Bank of America stock; shares dropped 15% in past 12 months. Al Lerner, born in Brooklyn to Russian immigrants, sold furniture, invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991, eventually sold to BofA. Returned pro football to Cleveland in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iranian-born academic and former art dealer has one of the world's largest private collections of Islamic art with over 20,000 items spanning 1,400 years.  Collection is his passion and the basis of his wealth.  Artifacts include ceramics, metalwork, glass, rare Koranic manuscripts, paintings and textiles. Bought his first piece, a 19th century Qajar lacquer pen box, as a teenager.  Also collects Japanese Art from the Meiji period, Indian and Swedish textiles, Spanish metal works.  Nicknamed the secret sultan, left Iran before the 1979 revolution, now lives in London as a dual U.S.-British citizen. Also owns commercial and retail properties in and around London, including tony Mayfair.  Building an innovative energy efficient office block named "The Wave". Co-founder and chairman of the Maimonides Foundation, a charity which promotes interfaith peace and understanding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made fortune creating credit card giant MBNA. Barely billionaire: family's fortune fluctuating on Bank of America stock; shares dropped 15% in past 12 months.  Al Lerner, born in Brooklyn to Russian immigrants, sold furniture, invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991, eventually sold to BofA. Returned pro football to Cleveland in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made fortune creating credit card giant MBNA. Barely billionaire: family's fortune fluctuating on Bank of America stock; shares dropped 15% in past 12 months. Al Lerner, born in Brooklyn to Russian immigrants, sold furniture, invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991, eventually sold to BofA. Returned pro football to Cleveland in 1999. "Randy" took control of Cleveland Browns, bought British soccer team Aston Villa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Guangdong Galanz Group, one of the world's largest manufacturers of microwave ovens. Galanz's domestic market share is about 65% in the mainland and 46% overseas, according to company figures. Liang's corporate wisdom includes: "We can't make customers more affluent, but we can make the results of customers' hard work more valuable." The company, headquartered in Shunde, has 52 sales offices across China, branches in Hong Kong, Seoul and North America, and employs more than 50,000 people. Liang's son Zhaoxian is vice chairman and heir apparent. Galanz also manufactures air conditioners, washing machines and refrigerators.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with fellow Chinese billionaires Pang Qinghua and Huang Yi, Li is one of the world's richest auto distributors. Li's Zhongsheng Group, which he co-founded with Huang, focuses on luxury and mid-to-high end automobile brands including Mercedes-Benz, Lexus, Audi, Toyota, and Honda. Li has served as deputy chairman of the China Automobile Dealers Association since December 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Beijing Shiji Information Technology, a supplier of software systems to hotels. Its clients are like a Who's Who in the hotel business, and include: Accor Hotels, Starwood Hotels and Grand Hyatt Hotels.  Li holds an undergraduate degree in space physics and a master's degree in optoelectronic technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Philip Smith (d. 1961) built family fortune with investments and movie theater operator General Cinema. Earned Ph.D. from Brandeis University; taught social policy at Boston University. Left for silver screen, founding Chestnut Hill Productions 1985; films included Foxfire, one of Angelina Jolie's first movies. Paid a then record $195 million to buy Eagles from Norman Braman in 1994. Team worth over $1.1 billion today. Back in movies: with wife, produced Academy-Award winning documentary "Inside Job," about the 2008 global financial crisis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Veteran developer, got into real estate in 1969 in Mumbai after working with uncle.  Bagged lucrative construction contracts in the Middle East during the 1970s oil boom where he built, among much else, the palace of the ruler of Sharjah. Today, his Kalpataru Group has expanded into property management, power transmission, logistics and telecom infrastructure. Plans to list his privately held property firm.  His Munot Foundation, group's charitable arm, organizes health camps and mobile crèches for workers on their construction sites. He has a passion for Urdu poetry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded online retailer of apparel and accessories Zozotown, which caters to young fashionistas. Website is structured like actual mall where stores are set up; sells on consignment. Sales have grown on average 50% annually over the past five years. Company announced 300-for-1 stock split in December. Maezawa, an avid customer, owns 59% of the firm. Plans to branch out to older customers in an alliance with Yahoo Japan. Also looking to sell overseas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hit some turbulence in the last year that would make a lesser entrepreneur reach for a parachute. Microjet company Eclipse, which he funded with $200 million, is in bankruptcy. Insulin-inhaler biotech Mannkind, a quixotic attempt to reinvent how diabetics manage their disease, has had its powdered insulin inhaler rejected twice by the FDA, and had to lay off almost half its workers. Over the years his companies have dominated the markets for pacemakers (Pacesetter), insulin pumps (Minimed) and cochlear implants (Advanced Bionics). Recently changed his official residence from his Mulholland Drive mansion to sunny, less taxing Las Vegas. So far built three Alfred Mann Institutes, at the University of Southern California, Purdue and the Technion in Israel. They help develop scientific research into commercial medical products. Brother Robert Mann is one of the most accomplished violinists of their generation.

name: Billionaires
bio: The savvy internet investor hit the list thanks to the growing value of his social media holdings. He divided his Digital Sky Technologies into two parts last year, taking email portal Mail.Ru public. His DST Global remains a private fund investing in global internet companies like Facebook, Zynga and Groupon. In 2009, DST paid $200 million for a stake in Facebook; this initial investment has grown an estimated five-fold since then. Next, he plans to invest in every startup that comes out of Silicon Valley-based incubator Y Combinator without reading the business plan. Former particle physicist plays chess for fun. Wife Julia is contemporary artist.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam vet partnered with Outdoor Systems founder William Levine in 1984; sold to Infinity for $8.7 billion in stock in 1999. Bought baseball's Angels from Disney in 2003; team has made the playoffs 5 times since. Once a small market team, Angels now seventh most valuable team in Major League baseball with a 2010 worth of $520 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Berkshire Hathaway lieutenant gave shares he co-owned with his wife, Nancy, to his 8 children after she passed away last February: "I don't need them where I'm going." Last summer Berkshire acquired the remaining 20% of Wesco Financial, the holding company Munger ran, to make it a wholly owned subsidiary. Omaha native dropped out of University of Michigan to serve as meteorologist in U.S. Army Air Corps; later attended Harvard Law. Pragmatic investor met friend, business partner Warren Buffett at a dinner party 1959.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2007, the Wharton and Harvard Business School grad founded social media gaming company Zynga, named after his beloved late bulldog. Company is now worth billions of dollars. Zynga's staggering success is tied to Facebook's; its popular interactive games including FarmVille, FrontierVille and Mafia Wars, are played via the social network. Pincus serves as chief executive and owns an estimated 20% of the company. Its latest game, CityVille, attracts 20 million players per day.
title: Chief Product Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Zynga', 'title': 'Chief Product Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: A member of one of Turkey's leading business families debuts on billionaires list on back of 15% rise in Sabanci Holding share price over past year. Sister of billionaire Suzan Sabanci Dincer and granddaughter of Sabanci Group founder Haci Omer Sabanci. Her husband Faruk Bilen joined the Sabanci Group in 1996 and has been chief financial officer of Sabanci Holding since 1977. He is also a board member of various Sabanci Group companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: This winter the activist investor launched a failed bid to take over Family Dollar. In 2010 he dumped what was once a $1.8 billion stake in Kraft. His Trian Fund Management also cut positions in Heinz and Tiffany, though he is still a large shareholder in both and sits on the board of Heinz. Trian's biggest holding is its more than 20% stake in Wendy's/Arby's.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Board member and shareholder of large conglomerate Sabanci Holding and member of the board of directors of the Sabanci Foundation. Returns to billionaires list this year after falling off 2009. Her father Ozdemir Sabanci was gunned down in 1996 in his Sabanci Towers office in Istanbul along with the general manager of Sabanci group company ToyotaSA and a secretary, by assassins hired by the leftist armed group DHKP-C. She is a niece of fellow billionaire Sevket Sabanci and a cousin of billionaire Suzan Sabanci Dincer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of cybersecurity firm Check Point Software, programmed the original code and fetched the soda. Media-shy Nacht still serves on the executive board. Back on the list for the first time since 2002 as shares of Check Point jumped more than 40% in the past six months; sales and profits up 20% last year. Trained by Talpiot, an elite division of Israeli army. Now lives in Tel Aviv with wife and child.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Blackstone chief received $1.85 billion in pre-tax cash after exiting the firm in 2008. Pledged more than $1 billion to his Peter Peterson Foundation; funds to be transferred incrementally over the years. Was Commerce Secretary under Nixon, became chairman of Lehman Brothers in 1973. Headed the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from 2000 to 2004. Is concerned about the state of the economy--his foundation is creating initiatives to fight the growing national  deficit. Joined the Buffett / Gates Giving Pledge. In his letter he says "On our current path, I fear we are imperiling their future by passing on massive, hidden debts and unthinkable taxes." Is an author of many books, including his autobiography. Married to Joan Ganz Cooney, creator of Sesame Street.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime entrepreneur founded Genel Energy in 2001 to extract oil in Iraqi Kurdistan. His partner in the company: fellow Turkish billionaire Mehmet Karamehmet. Genel Energy now has 6 fields in Northern Iraq. An earlier venture, Epik Construction, did infrastructure work in Kosovo and Afghanistan.  Lives in Ankara and Istanbul; often travels to London. Goes to Northern Iraq once a month. Worked in the U.S. for five years in the 1980s.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Harry Potter series has earned $6.4 billion at the global box office and the last film hits theaters this summer. Between the films, books, merchandise and amusement park at Universal Studios in Orlando, Fla., Rowling is worth $1 billion. If she never comes up with another good idea, she will be able to collect Harry Potter money for the rest of her life. Rowling wrote the first Potter books while a single mother living on welfare. She wrote the last book in the upscale Balmoral Hotel in Edinburgh, Scotland.
title: Author

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Kazakhstan's largest bank Kazkommertsbank continues bank turnaround. Government's Samruk-Kazyna National Welfare Fund remains Kazkommertsbank  shareholder after infusing cash during 2008 financial crisis to prop up bank. Analysts concerned with bank's low liquidity, free float of less than 10%, as well as exposure to volatile real estate market. Via his stake in Central Asian Investment Company, has interests in oil and gas, energy, telecommunications, transportation and media companies in Kazakhstan. Attended Moscow State University with fellow Kazakh billionaire Timur Kulibaev.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of 5 major shareholders of Indonesian coal miner Adaro Energy. Former vice chairman of carmaker Astra International; former president director, United Tractor. Also ran palm oil company under Astra. Admires Warren Buffett. Once said in interview important to "never stop learning." Likes to play golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Dmitry Korzhev took Russian retailer O'KEY Group public on London Stock Exchange this fall; current market cap: $3 billion. Collaboration began as students; started out in car sales founding Mega-auto company in 1993, now one of the biggest dealers in Saint-Petersburg. In 1995 founded juice producing plant Multon, and after 10 years sold it to Coca-Cola for $500 million. In 2001, co-founded O-Key chain of supermarkets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Schwartz is known as Canada's Henry Kravis, with over 260 deals under his belt at his private equity firm Onex Corp. The Harvard MBA founded Onex in 1984 after stints at Bear Stearns and CanWest. Schwartz also owns a large stake in electronics manufacturer Celestica.  He donates money to Jewish causes as well as education -- the business school at Nova Scotia's St. Frances Xavier University is named after him. He owns homes in Toronto, Malibu, Nantucket, and Palm Beach--where he keeps his 19-foot dinghy "Know Heather" , named after wife Heather Reisman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former executive at  Shanghai Stock Exchange has become a billionaire investor himself this year.  Owns 10% of  Sinovel Wind Group, a Chinese maker of wind turbines that IPOed at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in January.   Sinovel's chairman Han Junliang also debuts on the Forbes Billionaires list this year. Sinovel signed a strategic alliance with the state-run China Development Bank last year. Wei is chairman of Orica Capital of China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Hidili Industry International Development, a coke and raw coal mining company. Xian graduated from the People's Police School of Sichuan in 1994, studied law at Southwest University of Political Science and Law from 1994 to 1997, and worked in the police force and customs bureau of Panzhihua in Sichuan Province prior to setting up Hidili in 2000, according to an official biography. He was awarded a "Grade Three Achievement" by the Ministry of Public Security for his service. Hidili, whose shares were listed at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2007, raised $400 million in a debt at the end of last year to upgrade its mines and repay other debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Netted $200 million when drug distributor Protek raised $400 million in an April public offering; still holds majority stake. In 1990 founded Protek Center of Implementation. Imported computers, wrote software; also did some tourist business in particular in Hungary. While there, he met representatives from Gedeon Richter and decided to start a drugs import business. In time Protek managed to become the biggest importer of drugs in Russia. Later Yakunin founded the Rigla chain of drug stores, built a pharmaceutical factory and logistics center near Moscow.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former amateur boxer, founded discount retailer Don Quijote in 1980; stock price is up 38% this year on strong sales and profits due to higher margin on its own branded products and lower store operating costs. Has 150 outlets, including four stores in Hawaii. Claims to have spent much of his time at Keio University playing mah-jongg.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Ufida, a big Chinese homegrown supplier of business software that competes for small- and medium-sized companies with Oracle and SAP in the country's booming economy. In a country with few mergers among private-sector companies, Wang has been willing to acquire other software houses during his career, and bought Shanghai-based automobile software developer Infoservice for $76 million in 2010. Wang was born in a poor, isolated village in Jiangxi Province before entering college at age 14. He founded Ufida in 1988. The Beijing-headquartered company went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of New Oriental Education and Technology Group is one of the world's richest educators. The group traces its origins back to Beijing's New Orient School established by Yu in 1993, offering TOEFL test preparation courses to Chinese college students. Today the Group is the largest provider of educational services in China offering a wide range of programs and products. New Oriental now has approximately over 9 million cumulative student enrollments in 41 schools and 400 learning centers across 39 cities. The group's Nasdaq-listed stock is up 21% in price last year.  Yu was called on by Anthony W. Miller, U.S. Deputy Secretary of Education, during a trip to Beijing in December. Yu is a vice chairman of Beijing Young Entrepreneurs Association. He holds a bachelor's degree in English from Peking University, where he also taught as an English instructor before setting up New Oriental.
